entries.name: (10+) Spellcaster's Spirit
entries: You are aware of its Comet Shards and Nightmare Pattern actions.

entries.name: (15+) Unstable Intellect
entries: You recognize the monster's strongest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Arcane Wraiths take advantage of their Incorporeal Movement, gliding through walls and small openings, before blasting targets with Comet Shards from above. They use Nightmare Pattern to control foes and focus attacks on those unaffected by the illusion. Occasionally, they collaborate with other undead, such as Haze Husks and Haze Wights, commanding them like apprentices or minions.

entries: Arcane Wraiths often have {@dice 1d3} uncommon potions or spell scrolls collected nearby and may occasionally have a spellbook with {@dice 2d6} wizard spells of 3rd level and lower scribbled inside.

items.name: Ascendant Vladimir von Drakken

entries: Covered in the gore exploded from his regal form, Vladimir von Drakken has become a hulking monstrosity. Now twelve feet tall, his upper frame is hunched over, and his arms support him like a gorilla. Spiked bones and frilled f ins emerge from his arms and his clawed hands are large enough to crush skulls. Bladed scythes and spikes sprout from great batlike wings. The remains of his armor and cloak hang over his swelling new form. Bony protrusions jut from his head like a demonic crown. His once-imperial countenance is gone, replaced by a beastly face, a cross between wolf, bat, and dragon. Trickling blood and sweat, he breathes heavily between grunts, growls, and roars, barely uttering a sentence without howling.
In his Ascendant form, Vladimir von Drakken is truly a monster. Once he ascends to this form, he savagely attacks anyone he sees, including his own underlings.

monsterFluff.name: Beetle Knight

entries: Two insectoid legs hold up the beetle-like creature, rhythmically clacking as it skitters about. Two clawed arms scrabble beneath blade-like limbs as gnashing mandibles chitter under its beady eyes. A massive pincer-like horn protrudes from its helmet-shaped head and a tough blueish-silver shell protects delicate wings hidden beneath.

Beetle Knights represent the mutations found within even the smallest creatures in the aftermath of the meteor's strike. Insects that once crawled up from the soil, out of wall cracks, or from between floor boards have been transformed by contact with delerium and exposure to the Haze. Many have grown monstrously, to humanoid size or even larger.

Beetle Knight shells are thick enough to protect them from most attacks. Their name comes from the way their shells have mutated to resemble plate armor, while scything hands and a massive horn look like a pair of blades and an ornate helm. At a glance, these creatures resemble an armored knight ready for battle.

Beetle Knights commonly hide within the ruins and sewers of Drakkenheim, feeding on Deep Dregs and other smaller creatures. Occasionally, at night, or after heavy rains, Beetle Knights emerge in large numbers, to surprise and overwhelm the unprepared.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to study a Beetle Knight, revealing the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Alien and Unflinching
entries: You identify its condition {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Watch Out for that Horn!
entries: You recognize its Fling {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, and Pincer Horn action.

entries.name: (15+) Slow and Unintelligent
entries: You know its strongest and weakest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Beetle Knight is surprisingly agile, rarely standing still in battle. They charge during the first round, flinging enemies aside or attempting to grapple. If possible, they back up to charge again but will otherwise defend with their arm blades. They attempt to flee losing battles where their {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} fall below half their maximum.

monsterFluff.name: Belfray

entries: A shrill screech pierces the air as a large, misshapen bat swoops overhead. Its outstretched wings resemble elongated human arms, with flesh pulled taut to its deformed body. Rows of hooked fangs fill its maw below bulging, red eyes and a sniveling snout.

Once a common sight, bats in Drakkenheim have swelled in both number and form. Many are now as large as dogs with wingspans stretching almost six feet. Insects no longer satisfy their thirst for blood and they crave the taste of flesh.
Belfrays are nocturnal and seldom encountered during the day. Even within the Haze, they prefer the nightly octarine glow to the strange hazy days.

When night falls, Belfrays gather atop old towers and flutter through the streets. They can be found hanging from old lamp posts and in the rafters of ruined houses, waiting to swoop down upon passing creatures. They are most often found in the city's highest locations such as {@i Castle Drakken}, the Clock Tower, the Inscrutable Tower, and some of the city's larger buildings.

Belfrays mostly feast on {@creature Ratlings}, but many victims have been surprised by these creatures swarming from the darkness. One should always be wary of damp and dark spaces where a handful of Belfrays could lurk. Disturbing them might be your last mistake.

entries.name: (5+) Accustomed to the Dark
entries: You understand the Belfray's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Flying Blood-Drinker
entries: You recognize its Flyby and Keen Hearing features, and Enfeebling Bite attack.

entries.name: (15+) Weak Mind
entries: You know the Belfray's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Belfray attempts to strike with a Sonic Blast from the shadows before engaging. Once a target is weakened, it swoops in with its claws. When damaged, Belfrays Bite, feeding on the blood of their victims to regain strength. It uses movement to stay away from threats, diving to attack before flying to a safe distance. If reduced below half of its maximum Hit Points, it attempts to fly away.

monsterFluff.name: Big Linda

entries: The ground shudders beneath the approach of a monstrosity: a pale, green-white, bipedal reptile. A huge mouth dominates its skull-like face, as acidic saliva drips between rows of razor-sharp teeth. Spines run down its back and tail, and its great body is supported by two trunk-like legs, though its feeble forearms appear nearly useless. It roars a sound like rent metal as it charges forward to devour you.

Hidden beneath the ruins of Drakkenheim, the enigmatic {@b Queen of Thieves} has a vast arena where the ambitious battle for a chance to win her favor. Those who climb its ranks must ultimately face the Queen's favorite pet: a monstrous reptilian creature affectionately nicknamed "Big Linda." Should any survive a minute in the pit—or manage to slay the beast—the Queen of Thieves promises anything within her power to grant. Of course, no one has yet claimed this prize.

Pit fighters are often puzzled by the Queen's calm smirk when they believe they can gain her favor. Few realize that each victory brings them ever closer to a tragic end in Big Linda's jaws while a crowd of thieves cheers on their gruesome deaths.

Big Linda was first spotted in the ruins near King's Gate hunting trolls. No creature like her has been seen, and it remains unclear how the Queen captured the beast. It's thought that she herself played a role, since no one hired for the mission is still alive. Even the crew she paid to deliver the caged beast met their deaths at the hands of a Hooded Lanterns patrol shortly thereafter.

It remains a mystery what creature transformed to become Big Linda, perhaps a mutated bird, or an overgrown gecko. The only creature remotely resembling it is the old dinosaur skeleton in the Drakkenheim museum, but even then, the many differences bring up a slew of questions as to its origin.

Although the Queen keeps Big Linda well-fed and securely contained, she is aware the monstrosity is barely under her control. Maintaining the beast's feeding schedule of fresh "challengers" is difficult and few handlers last more than a week before being gobbled up. The position is seen as a death sentence rather than any position of prestige amongst the Queen's Men.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (15+) Acidic Mucus!
entries: You're aware of her Acid Spew attack.

entries.name: (20+) Big, Clumsy, and Dumb
entries: You recognize Big Linda's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Big Linda sends Acid Spew against groups of opponents. She then tries to optimize her Bite and Tail attacks by placing herself within her enemies. She is hesitant to leave the Deep Haze but is also not smart enough to resist chasing those who antagonizing her. She rarely flees unless severely wounded, wherein she will seek the safety of the Deep Haze to recover.

monsterFluff.name: Bigger Linda

entries: Thundering through the streets of Drakkenheim with a crash, the infamous pet of the Queen of Thieves has mutated and enlarged to unfathomable proportions. The Haze swirls around it, and octarine energy pulses in its sunken eye sockets. The broken hafts of weapons and old arrows are embedded into its scales, stuck deeply between its regenerated flesh. Its spined back is illuminated by webs of glowing octarine veins; its wide snout is filled with jagged teeth. As it opens its maw wide, the building contaminated energy at the back of its throat begins to glow.

If {@creature Big Linda|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ever escapes the confines of the {@creature Queen of Thieves|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, the beast will no doubt return to the ruins of Drakkenheim and immediately seek out new hunting grounds. However, Big Linda's containment has stunted her true growth potential. Once freed, the longer Big Linda spends directly exposed to the energies the Haze, the more she grows. As she grows, new mutations begin to form, further amplifying her ferocity, predatory senses, and resilience. If left unchecked, Big Linda might become the apex predator of Drakkenheim—Bigger Linda.

items.name: Blackjack Mel

entries: A short and scrawny man in his late thirties stands before you with a funny-looking but clean-shaven mug and greasy slickedback hair. He wears a black padded jacket and buckled slacks that appear distinguished at first glance but are actually quite shabby and worn.

Blackjack Mel is the Queen of Thieves most trusted advisor. That is to say that she doesn't trust him at all, but knows that he is afraid of her, and will do her bidding as long as she pays him more than others. She pays in protection and a good position. No one is more manipulated by the Queen of Thieves' than Blackjack Mel, who handles much of her communications and business deals with the local gangs.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I can always make a deal with the right angle, I just gotta pitch it the right way. I don't give up when the mark doesn't take the bait, just try something new!

entries.name: Ideal
entries: We're all in this for ourselves. You scratch my back, I'll scratch yours.

entries.name: Bond
entries: Listen, I got some close connections with some powerful people. You wanna meet the Queen of Thieves? Stick with me. We'll go places together. Just uh, watch out you don't piss anyone off, okay?

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I'm a compulsive liar, so what? Yeah, sometimes even
I get confused by my own lies, but the truth can always do with a little exaggeration, it makes life more interesting

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Blackjack Mel is a coward, a swindler, and a thief. He is often surrounded by Thugs and Assassins who protect him; Mel rarely draws a blade. His overconfidence relies on his company, and he will often only take a stab at someone if they are held down.

Mel's first line of defense is his mouth. He will double-cross, backstab, swindle, and con even his allies to ensure his own survival. He knows a lot of information about a lot of things and will use his well of secrets to bargain for his safety. He is also clever and will usually only divulge half of a fact to save his life, ensuring the other half will be granted once his safety is ensured. He knows very well that information is what keeps him alive, and he isn't about to use up that usefulness.
Mel flees without question at any opportunity if he feels threatened, and often keeps a {@item Potion of Invisibility|XDMG} on his person for just such instances.
All bets are off when you're dealing with this thug. He's got info on anything for a price or a threat.

monsterFluff.name: Bloated Dreg

entries: A gurgling moan emerges from the dark as the slopping footsteps of a bloated form emerges. Its rippling, sagging flesh is wet and dripping. Its rotund face and soggy skin are covered in boils, blisters, and leaking sores. Wet, acidic saliva dribbles down its chin, leaving trails of burned flesh. The Dreg's one arm is a mass of writhing slick tentacles. As its mouth opens, a low gurgling sound slowly builds.

People who are submerged in contaminated water often become Bloated Dregs. These half-drowned unfortunates are found near bodies of water throughout the city, such as the sewers or near the Drann River. They have absorbed so much contaminated water into themselves that it festers and mixes with their stomach acids, producing a corrosive bile that they hurl towards their foes. Often a Bloated Dreg will only leave the water for a few hours before finding another puddle of sludge or a contaminated pool to rest in.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Bloated Dreg shuffles aimlessly through Drakkenheim, stopping to rest in places where contaminated water has built up, or in pools of delerium sludge. It produces large amounts of acidic bile in its guts that it expels when threatened. A Bloated Dreg will retreat to its watery home when threatened, trying to hide amongst the contaminated liquids.

monsterFluff.name: Bloated Hive

entries: Dripping with sweet smelling pus and mucus, the creature shuffles about on spindly limbs like a gangly ape. It has long gnarled fingers and an emaciated whip-cord thin frame. Where there should be a head there is instead a mass of pulsing flesh covered in gaping pores that extend down its neck and across its shoulders. Its body writhes with thousands of bugs crawling beneath its skin and swarming around its head. They burrow in and out of open wounds and sores and buzz in and out of its pores. It smells faintly of honey and sweat, and gurgles painfully amidst the chorus of buzzing and clicking of insects, as if the thing is painfully aware of its wretched state.

The Bloated Hive is a product of contamination that seems to have turned people into walking hives of insects. Some suspect the honey farms on the outskirts may have been the main source of these strange mutations, causing the apiarists and their hives to warp together, fusing into a grotesque and tortured creature. Their upper torso and head are now a writhing mass of open pores like a beehive, with bugs swarming in and out. They lumber around the ruins looking for nesting places where their hive can thrive. Many Bloated Hives operate alone, but sometimes a much more horrifying event occurs, where a single colony begins to occupy multiple Bloated Hives, forming a horrifying network.

The Bloated Hive tends to hide itself in the dark corners of ruins, often seeking the most damp and warm locations in the city. Many hives have been found along the Drann River within the Inner City, a large group of them living under Champion's Bridge, and even more in the sewers, Queen's Park Garden, and a sparse few in the woods to the north of Drakkenheim. Whenever traversing into dark and damp areas in the city, be on the lookout for an increase in insect activity and the sound of buzzing.

A Bloated Hive cannot speak, and acts on the whims of its occupants more so than its own free thought. Its mind is now a broken thing, connected inherently to the hive mind of a swarm of insects, but within that is a tortured human struggling for sentience. Some Bloated Hives have been known to respond to kind words, trinkets of their former selves, or music they recognize. Though these moments of subtle sentience are fleeting, as the hive reacts quickly to the feeling of an unwanted psyche struggling for dominance within the hive mind and could trigger a frenzied tantrum if not handled delicately.

entries.name: (5+) Sightless Awareness
entries: You know the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} and senses.

entries.name: (10+) Endless Insects!
entries: You are aware of the creature's Spawn Swarm action and Disrupt the Hive trait.

entries.name: (15+) Frail
entries: You recognize the Bloated Hive's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Bloated Hive is usually a solitary creature that spends its time cowering in dark corners living out its cursed life as nothing more than a conduit for its colony. In combat, they focus entirely on keeping their distance from threats and spawning swarms of insects to defend themselves. If cornered, the Bloated Hive uses its Claws and Distracting Swarm before moving back into the shadows and attempting to escape and find a new nest.

Larger packs of Bloated Hives are much braver and more violent, and actively hunt and pursue targets until their numbers are less than their prey. Places where large colonies gather are dangerous. The Bloated Hives work in unison to protect their nests. Only if they become outnumbered do they flee.

items.name: Blood Leech
entries: Although the practice of draining a patient's blood to draw out illness and disease is long discredited, many apothecaries understand the value of transfusing blood during surgical procedures. However, storing the blood long term can be a problem. Apothecaries have solved by modifying normal leeches with occult science, transforming the creatures into living blood bags. While these bloodletting techniques are of dubious therapeutic value to patients, they make an effective method for collecting samples from lessthan-willing subjects.

Though often benign in nature, these bloated leeches can be turned to violent purpose by an apothecary willing to use the creatures in such a manner. During combat, an apothecary may dispatch the leeches against their foes, then call the creatures back to themselves to heal using their foe's blood.

entries.name: Blood Leeches

entries: The black, plump wriggling form of the leech squirms and crawls. Its oily, slick skin is wet and slippery. It lets out a high-pitched screech as it lunges towards its prey.

Leeches are a common creature kept in large quantities in apothecaries' laboratories. Aside from their standard practical uses of bloodletting and transfusions, they have also been the subjects of early apothecary experimentation. Different forms of leeches have been designed to better suit apothecaries' needs. Some Alienists have designed leeches that attach directly to the brain stem, allowing the leech to eat the intellect and thoughts of other creatures. Mutagenists have designed leeches that can harness the arcane energies found in mageborn blood.

items: {@b Leech Variants:} Ambitious apothecaries have used leeches in different ways. There are two mutant variations of the Blood Leech.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Leeches attempt to get close to a target to Bite and Attach to them. They do not retreat, as they are driven by their basic need to feed on the blood of others and nothing else.

monsterFluff.name: Body Snatcher

entries: This patchwork monster of stitched-together corpses oozes black ichor from its seams. The figure is a hulking form, about 7 feet tall with broad shoulders and a hunched back. Its head seems small compared to its body, with pale white eyes highlighting sunken dark sockets. A lipless mouth forces the creature into a constant menacing grimace. Draped in a thick black trench coat and wide brimmed hat while smelling of sulfur and brimstone, the unsettling humming and mumbling of the creature echoes in the ears of those it is about to grab. The most unsettling feature is the creature's four arms, which end in massive, oversized hands, each with eight long, spindly fingers. The creature shifts from shadow to shadow effortlessly, in a haunting ghost-like fashion unusual for its size.

Stitched together from the remains of numerous corpses and animated through forbidden alchemical processes, the Body Snatcher roams the darkness. Created by a deranged doctor to abduct subjects for gruesome experiments, it lingers in shadows, waiting for unwary travelers to seize and vanish into the night.

Empowered by the night, the Body Snatcher uses shadow to drain the vitality and energy of those it grabs, weakening them as they attempt to resist and escape. Shadows wrap around it, helping it hold its victims in place while it absconds with them into the darkest corners of the night

entries: You recognize the Body Snatcher's Sunlight Weakness trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Body Snatcher sticks to dimly lit areas or places of complete darkness. It teleports up to a creature and attempts to grapple it, teleporting away as soon as it has one or two targets in its hands. Often the Body Snatcher will emerge from tunnels or secret entrances to its lair. They do not travel far from the labs they were created in and often have easy points of escape to disappear once they have a victim in hand.

monsterFluff.name: Bojack

entries: This creature, which appears to be a dead horse flopped on its back, convulses and its stomach suddenly splits open, exposing its intestines and organs. Long, spindly, arachnid-like legs violently sprout from its torso as its stomach opens into a maw filled with sharp jagged teeth formed from the splayed rib cage of the beast. The horse legs limply hang in the air, as the creature skitters towards you with intense speed, intestines flapping around its maw like a sickly tongue. The head of the horse dangles lifelessly, but its mouth still gnashes and salivates acidic bile.

Many valiant warriors have ridden into Drakkenheim mounted on a loyal steed, not realizing that the rubble and wreckage filling the streets makes the ruins an unsuitable environment for a horse. Often, these poor animals must be abandoned not long after entering the ruins, injured from the unstable terrain. Prime targets for other predators, the horses are often tragically slaughtered. However, when their corpses are left behind, a parasite-like mutation festers within them, causing their skin to erupt with spider-like limbs, pincers, and maws.

Disguising themselves as mere corpses strewn across the dark and misty streets of the ruined city, one can hardly differentiate a Bojack from a dead horse. With their spider limbs they can scurry along walls and ceilings with ease, and barely make a sound. They move with lightning-fast speed, able to scuttle across a city street in mere seconds. This terrifying speed, ease of traversing the terrain, and ability to disguise itself have made them a deadly threat to adventurers in the city.

One of the most horrifying recorded encounters with Bojacks in Drakkenheim came from an early report from Hooded Lantern scouts investigating old stables south of Champion's Gate near the city outskirts. They reported finding "piles of dead horses buzzing with large, mutated flies feasting on the meat." The report goes on to speak of several of the horse corpses suddenly "bursting open" with "insectoid legs and a horrible maw formed from the splayed rib cage of the dead beasts." The report describes the speed and ferocity displayed in the immediate strike, with nearly an entire squad of eight Hooded Lantern scouts ripped to shreds in only a matter of seconds while the remaining Lanterns fled back out of the city.

One of the surviving Hooded Lanterns, Sten Livingston Sr., was brave enough to volunteer to lead the following expedition into the ruins. On the road into the city a dead and bloated horse corpse lay on the side of the road. Livingston stopped his troops and approached the beast with weapons drawn, kicking the corpse to check if it would spring to life. The corpse remained motionless. It has since become a tradition spread through the Lanterns, and even into new adventuring parties, to kick the horse on the way into Drakkenheim. Many have chalked this up to a sign of good luck, not realizing the harrowing story and the lives lost that caused this strange tradition.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Bojack is an ambush skirmisher. It waits for the opportune moment to strike, attempting to surprise as many targets as possible. After it surprises its prey, it attacks with its Impaling Limbs or Corrosive Mucus and uses its Predatory Cunning to move out of melee range.

The Bojack can climb walls and will try and skitter up buildings or behind walls, springing back out to attack before escaping again. If brought below 20 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the Bojack attempts to {@action Dash|XPHB} away and {@action Hide|XPHB}.

monsterFluff.name: Cacophonous Chimera

entries: The Cacophonous Chimera's three heads include a chittering rat, a screeching harpy, and a howling garmyr, which together perform a madness-inducing chorus as they slaughter their prey. Its forelimbs are clawed rat-like paws, its rear legs are avian talons, and the beast's colossal furry body is borne upon massive wings of blood-red feathers with a slithering lamprey eel for a tail.

The Cacophonous Chimera emerged from a catastrophic convergence of several creatures — a Garmyr, Deep Dreg, Manticore, Ratling, and a Harpy — amidst a fierce battle. Caught in a terrible arcane anomaly, these creatures were unwillingly combined into this single, horrific form. Each head retains the memories and instincts of its original form, driving the chimera in a constant battle for dominance and survival. This relentless conflict within itself fuels its madness and aggression towards anything it encounters in the ruins.

The Cacophonous Chimera lives in a constant state of internal discord as its three heads, each with its own predatory instincts, vie for control over its body. The constant bickering and screaming among the heads produce a sound that reverberates painfully within the skulls of all who hear it, inducing terror, confusion, and madness. Depending on which head momentarily gains dominance, the tone and effect of their combined shrieking varies, leaving their prey disoriented and defenseless.

This terror hunts throughout the Outer City, making lairs within the crumbling ruins of the Spokes Merchant's Exchange. The main tower was one of the tallest buildings outside Drakkenheim's walls and functioned as a hub for traders and local craftspeople to conduct business without needing to travel to the bustling market square of the Inner City. The structure has become a ramshackle ruin, the crooked spire compromised by the constant shrieking of the chimera. Still, this strategic perch not only provides an ideal vantage point for the monstrosity. The structural damage also dissuades other monsters and adventurers from intruding on the chimera's personal domain.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The following traits can be used to inspire roleplaying the Cacophonous Chimera:

items: {@b Personality Trait:} "Just ONCE can we chat with someone a little before we eat them? RARGH! STOP TALKING! RIP AND TEAR! NO! NO! NO! Our stomach is FOUR TIMES bigger than it used to be! I'm STARVING!"
{@b Bond:} "We're fused together. Although each of us wants to be separated, in truth we're afraid of what would happen if we were ever torn apart."
{@b Ideal:} "I make such wonderful music! Each howl, shriek, and chitter resonates to form a deadly orchestra. I can't stand silence!"
{@b Flaw:} "We're constantly arguing. Our internal strife often distracts us from opportunities or leads us into traps, as we can't agree even on the simplest decisions."

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} a Cacophonous Chimera, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (15+) Freakish Fusion
entries: You're aware of the chimera's Epic Resistance Epic Action.

entries.name: (20+) Fighting for Control
entries: You recognize the chimera's Cacophony Epic Action, noting that if the creature could be silenced, it would be far less formidable.

entries.name: (25+) Powerful but Distracted
entries: You understand its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Desperate to eat and consume, the Cacophonous Chimera viciously attacks prey on sight despite the desires of its harpy head to engage in a little conversation first. The Cacophonous Chimera is not a very subtle hunter. Its prey can hear it coming by the sound of its droning cacophony from at least a city block away, which may give them opportunity to prepare, hide, or flee.

The range of its Cacophony can affect creatures before they can see the chimera itself. By the time the chimera arrives, its prey may be shaken and immobilized by the sound. Depending on how ravenous and furious it is, the chimera closes with its prey and tears them apart using its Claws, Bite, and Tail.

Against a target that shows resilience to its cacophony or who retaliates with formidable attacks of their own, the chimera keeps a middle distance, trying to keep out of melee range while leaving its foes in its Cacophonous Chorus aura. However, its ravenous Garmyr head and Ratling head can often get in the way of the better judgment here, prompting the chimera to engage in melee even when it would not be advantageous.

Furthermore, the three creatures are generally too busy arguing or overconfident to think twice about the actual danger and stakes they might be facing, and so may need to be grievously wounded before fleeing is an option.

items.name: Lieutenant Petra & Captain Ansom Lang

entries: Petra Lang is a fit and nimble teenager with long black hair, a narrow, pointed chin, and bold features. She wears the Lanterns' hooded green cloak and light {@item studded leather armor|XPHB} with a lieutenant's insignia on her shoulder pauldron.

Ansom Lang is an athletic teenager with long black hair and a short neat beard, angular jaw, and rugged features. He is garbed in a hooded green cloak and {@item studded leather armor|XPHB} of the Hooded Lanterns that prominently displays a captain's insignia on his shoulder

Petra, the youngest of the two, has spent most of her life training under the Hooded Lanterns. She prides herself on her marksmanship and scavenging, and knows she is looked up to by many of the soldiers. She is a proud and friendly commander who the troops are happy to follow.
Ansom plans to become the Lord Commander once Elias retires. He is a stern commander who leads by example, displaying incredible discipline and unwavering loyalty to his adopted father

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I have been in Drakkenheim long enough to know not to trust anyone. I am extremely wary of adventurers, and anyone who might cause problems for the Lanterns.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I believe that if my sister and I work hard enough, with the right people, that maybe we can change things.

entries.name: Bond
entries: Myself and Petra have had each other's backs since we were children. That will never change.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I find reasons to not like people, and find reasons to doubt the commitment of the people around me.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Petra is a skilled archer and skirmisher. She prefers to keep her foes at range to gain a vantage point over them in combat. She is a cunning scout who is more likely to set up an ambush than attack directly. When pinned down, she tries to move out of melee into a more advantageous position. If she is low on options, she attempts to escape.

Ansom is a skilled swordsman who prefers to engage his foes in melee combat. He typically starts combat from a good vantage point by attacking with his bow and then moving closer to unleash a flurry of sword attacks. He is a confident and aggressive, and has pushed the Hooded Lanterns through many decisive victories over the horrors of Drakkenheim.
Ansom has enough sense to know when a combat encounter is threatening to cost the lives of his unit, and will fall back or retreat if his instincts tell him it is the better move.
Nothing like family to keep you honest. That and a sword that makes you tell the truth.

Given the strange features of this massive, muscled, eight-foot-tall figure, it is difficult to say if it was once human or a troll. Its bruised skin stretches and rips over barely contained muscles. It is pin-headed, with an emotionless face, glassy-eyes, and a slack-jawed maw.

Most disturbingly, its ribcage is splayed open, revealing guts and viscera along with a smaller, vestigial creature with wrinkled flesh and a mewling mouth. It holds its sticklike arms and curled fingers close, and its neck can barley hold its massive head. Thin translucent skin covers its huge brain, the blood vessels within softly glowing. Raising its tiny hands to its temples, its eyes bulge and its face contorts into a twisted expression.

The Cerebrograft is a horrific attempt to combine two creatures into a singular form, a nightmarish combination of brains and brawn. Through surgical implantation and flesh-melding, an apothecary creates a forced symbiosis, fusing their nervous systems and unlocking potent psionic abilities.

entries.name: Improved Lackeys
entries: A Cerebrograft is often the "reward" granted to a pair of loyal lab assistants, a means of "removing deficiencies" by combining their bodies and minds, frequently named a portmanteau of its constituent beings.

entries.name: Dominant Personality
entries: Although intended to be a symbiosis of two minds, typically, the implanted creature subsumes the psyche of its host, fully controling the new form. However, sometimes, the two beings form a constituent mind combining elements of the originals, or even a bicameral mind where the original two debate internally over what action to take.

entries.name: Delicate Work
entries: Thanks to their psionic abilities, Cerebrografts are well suited to controlling other test subjects. Apothecaries find their precise telekinetic powers especially useful in surgical procedures and laboratory experiments.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study a Cerebrograft, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Occult Fleshmending
entries: You uncover the Cerebrograft's Dual Minds trait.

entries.name: (15+) Powerful Psionics
entries: You recognize its Telekinetic Grip and Psychic Crush.

entries.name: (20+) Powerful, Clumsy, and Slow

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Despite its physical and psionic might, Cerebrografts prefers fighting alongside allies of its apothecary master. When confronted with multiple foes, it tries to overwhelm their minds using Psychic Crush to escape and find reinforcements.

A Cerebrograft uses its Telekinetic Grip to hold its enemies, unruly test subjects, and wild experiments at bay. It typically focuses on one target, allowing allies to pummel the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} foe. If it can, it uses the environment to its advantage, moving foes to restrain them such as into mancles, cages, or surgery tables.

Word of advice, if the doctor you go to looks like this guy, maybe find a new doctor.

The figure is garbed in large safety goggles, an acid-burned thick lab apron, white chemical-stained lab coat, and rubber gloves. The skin on their face is the only visible flesh on them, scarred by bubbling chemical burns.

Chemists indulge in the science of the alchemical, often harnessing the raw potential of elemental formulae while creating unique compounds and reagents. They have been known to dabble in the science behind the creation of elementals and oozes, and perfecting explosives and acids.

entries.name: Chemist Minions
entries: Although Chemists often do not dabble in creating creatures, any apothecary can make use of minions. Simple elementals and oozes can be found in a Chemist's lab. {@creature Tanker|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Tankers} work as a good lab assistant for administering large amounts of chemical formulae for the scientist, while {@creature Living Biohazard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Living Biohazards} are often the failed early experiments many Chemists. A {@creature Chemystral|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is the ultimate pride and joy of many chemists.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} I revel in the chaos and destruction that my concoctions cause, watching the flames and corrosion with maniacal laughter and a crazed gleam in my eyes.
{@b Bond:} Creativity is born from chaos; the most groundbreaking discoveries require pushing boundaries, no matter the dangers involved.
{@b Ideal:} I am obsessed with avenging my mentor, who was persecuted by those who feared our knowledge and power.

{@b Flaw:} My obsession with perfecting destructive formulae often leads me to take careless risks, sabotaging my own work and safety. I've burned down my own workshop more times than I can remember, and I'll do it again.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Chemists opt to start things off with a bang, unleashing their Explosive Concoction on the first round, especially against a grouped together party. They use Acid Rain to create a dangerous zone between them and their enemies and default to unleashing their Chemical Spray on enemies stuck in the difficult area. If a creature closes the distance on the Chemist, they use their Caustic Grip. If they find themselves surrounded or outnumbered in close quarters, they attempt to escape.
The only chemists I admire are the ones who make Caspian cinnamon rolls. This is not one of them.

This massive, undulating chemical ooze shimmers in hues of blue, green, pink, and purple. Its large amorphous form throbs and wobbles as it alters its composition constantly to adapt to its surrounding environments. Everything the blob touches dissolves quickly within its form. The distinct smell of bile and stomach acid surround it.

One of a {@creature Chemist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}'s ultimate creations, the Chemystral is a perfectly balanced sentient compound capable of altering its physiology to adapt to surrounding threats. The horrific ooze has the ability to stick to any surface and even propel itself into the air and fly. It is impervious to nearly all forms of elemental attack. Much like a chameleon changing its color to blend into its surroundings, the Chemystral changes itself at a cellular level to adapt to environmental changes and elemental threats, gaining properties to better combat predators. Even with its inherent resilience, the Chemystral is unable to adapt to the cold, or deal with intense sound.

monsterFluff.name: Chitinous Dreg

entries: The body and face of this mutated wretch is covered in thick, knobby bone plates that have torn violently through their flesh. The exposed ribs of their chest have fused together into a single plate, forming an armor-like appearance. Past their elbow, the muscle and sinew of their forelimbs hangs limply from their protruding exposed bones, which have been reshaped into long, serrated bone-blades caked with gore.

These Dregs have heavy mutations to their bone structure which covers them in a plated exoskeleton. Able to shrug off most attacks, Chitinous Dregs charge into battle, using their jagged forearm bone blades in a frenzy of ferocious strikes upon their prey.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Chitinous Dregs often charge into the front lines of combat. It positions itself between other Dregs and their foes almost as if it was defending its allies. Chitinous Dregs attempt to draw the combat towards itself at all times, using its Bone Blades to keep the focus on it, and its Sentinel Strike Reaction and No Escape trait to ensure creatures facing it cannot get away. The Chitinous Dreg is a warrior and rarely retreats: it is too enraged with a protective bloodlust when thrust into battle to worry about its own wellbeing.

monsterFluff.name: Chitter

entries: Scampering up the wall is a creature the size of a hound. It resembles a mostly hairless squirrel save for its bushy tail and patchy tufts of mottled fur. Its eyes are glassy and milk white, and its mouth seems almost human, sporting huge, pearly white teeth that grin maniacally. It frantically clambers upward, while chittering a maddening chorus with its clacking teeth.

The Queen's Park Gardens are one of the most heavily contaminated areas in the city. Its massive gardens and trails were once a place of lush beauty, thick with trees, floral arrangements, topiary masterpieces, tranquil groves, and an abundance of wildlife. Drakkenheim's contamination warped all things, monstrously changing the creatures within. Now even the squirrels, which occupied the gardens in large numbers, are feral and mutated. Those wandering forested areas should be wary of chittering sounds echoing through the trees. These monsters attack in numbers, their clacking teeth maddening those nearby. The once friendly squirrels that locals would stop to feed now feed whether you want them to or not.

Chitters are also encountered along the heavily wooded northern outskirts of Drakkenheim and much of the farmlands surrounding the city. These places are not free from contamination; Chitters have been seen roaming like packs of feral dogs through the fields or lurking near woods. Chitters now occasionally roam the streets in the center of the city, climbing towers and buildings before leaping down onto their prey. No longer confined to the gardens, the city is their hunting ground and its ruins make wonderful homes for packs of Chitters.

entries.name: (15+) Simple Minded
entries: You recognize its mental ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Chitters often attack in a small group. Usually two to three that form a family will stick together. The mutated squirrels have been known to be quite territorial and hostile, even to other Chitter families who try to infringe on their territory.

Chitters are excellent climbers, capable of falling a great distance without fear of hurting themselves. It is not uncommon for Chitters to be found in tall buildings, or up on the top floor of ruined houses, or hard-to-reach rooftops or attics. Chitters charge their enemies and leap at them, attempting to disable them with their chittering, and relying on their Claws and Bite. Chitters protect their homes with determined ferocity, but if reduced to less than a third of their Hit Points, they leap and clamber away.

items.name: Congregation

entries: A crowd of pilgrims brandish clubs, torches, and pitchforks. They begin to muster up courage, spouting out passages from the writings of the Falling Fire, calling out the blasphemous to be brought low by the fires to cleanse them of their sins.

The Followers of the Falling Fire gather in great throngs filled with fiery passion, lighting their torches and lanterns and taking up whatever they can find as a weapon. When the zealous masses flood the streets, the crowd becomes more than a match for the mightiest warriors.
Three's a crowd and coincidentally the number of prongs you get stabbed with. People get too excited in groups.

monsterFluff.name: Crater Wurm

entries: The earth trembles, vibrating pebbles and dust. A deep rumble wells from below. Suddenly, stone cracks, extruding a titanic wurm. It rears its massive head, opening a petal-like mouth filled with long jagged crystalline teeth all pointed into its throat. Its body is covered in muddy purple plates with octarine spines jutting from between. Its hot breath sends octarine slime flying as it dives toward you.

Those who dared venture into the Crater Basin returned with harrowing tales of the tremendous Crater Wurms. They describe the earth shaking moments before a gargantuan wurm breaches the surface, swallowing creatures in its path. Curiously, the wurms are only seen in the desolate crater. Few understand how such gigantic creatures, let alone multiple wurms, can survive here, or why they do not leave to hunt elsewhere.

In truth, Crater Wurms mainly subsist on inorganic minerals found in the dirt, mud, and rock they burrow through, requiring little organic matter. The wurm's gullet functions like a contaminated crucible: minerals, rock, and living matter are broken down and crystallized, with delerium expelled as waste. Crater Wurms spend most of their lives underground, creating miles of twisting tunnels filled with glittering delerium, only surfacing in the Crater Basin to reproduce. Though none have yet seen the event, the wurm's massive form splits, releasing young from the carcass.

Perhaps no creature in Drakkenheim is more responsible for the deeply rooted contamination than Crater Wurms. The continued existence of these monsters could see the world transform into a contaminated wasteland. Tunneling below the surface, they have spread contamination deep into the bowels of the earth. Indeed, all the crystals scattered across the surface, the rich veins of delerium near the Scar, and the great deposits around the Crater itself pale in comparison to the mass of delerium left buried far underground by the Crater Wurms.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Crater Wurms disregard other creatures, viewing them as only morsels to consume. All are as the dust of the earth to it—simply food. These wurms understand that creatures they devour often try to flee. Their favored tactic is to remain buried until their {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} detects movement. They then surface with its Breach action, making Bite attacks, swallowing nearby {@condition Prone|XPHB} creatures. They dive beneath the ground once at least one creature is swallowed, or if reduced to half its Hit Point maximum.

monsterFluff.name: Crimson Countess
entries: The Crimson Countess is a powerful queen of harpies. Her red-feathered wings and deep crimson hair set her apart from the many harpy followers she commands. She is clad is black and gold armor and carries with her a spear that crackles with magical energies. Her hands and feet are black talons with sharp claws. The Crimson Countess is a cunning hunter and territorial to the Clock Tower. She has staked her claim over the center of the city, and hunts the various monsters and misguided faction agents who come close.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Countess only leaves her clock tower to join in on hunts with her valkyries, but otherwise she prefers the defendable position at the towers highest floor. From here any adventurer who makes it past her soldiers and into her lair can easily be grabbed and thrown off the open balconies, falling to their death.

She is overconfident and will do anything to protect her advantageous position in the city. She only flees if all her minions are dead and she is below 25 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. If she flees, she will attempt to gather more soldiers and return to reclaim the clock tower at a later date.

monsterFluff.name: Crimson Knight

entries: Clad in blackened steel armor accented in red, this knight wears the marks of their vampiric master emblazoned upon their tower shield. They carry an axe that crackles with red energy; their blood red eyes peer out from their helmet, fangs visible and hungry.

The Crimson Knights are formidable vampire spawn, meticulously trained as elite house soldiers and personal bodyguards for their vampiric masters. These fierce warriors are inextricably bound to serve their lords with unwavering loyalty, showing little interest in advancing beyond their designated roles. Instead, they derive immense satisfaction from the carnage they unleash in honor of their household and liege.

Proud of their exceptional combat skills, the Crimson Knights devote their eternal lives almost exclusively to honing their martial prowess. Their existence is characterized by relentless training and preparation, making them adept in various forms of battle. This rigorous focus on combat not only sharpens their abilities but also fuels their insatiable thirst for the chaos of warfare.

In the heat of battle, the Crimson Knights are at their most formidable. They hunger for the bloodshed that accompanies fierce engagements, and they sustain themselves by feeding on the blood of those they defeat. To fight is to feed for these knights, and their hunger is perpetual, driving them to seek out conflict where they can showcase their deadly skills and quench their relentless thirst.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Crimson Knights form units with other minions and thralls of their vampire masters. Several Crimson Knights may form an elite guard, or one might be attached to lead a contingent of vampire thralls.

In battle, Crimson Knights seek out the most formidable melee combatants to meet head on, disarming them with Crackling Smite. They make use of Unholy Smite to prevent their target from healing, and terrorize them using Wrathful Smite.

A Crimson Knight will give their undead existence to defend their master and hold fast even as they are cut down. If they encounter a foe capable of dealing Radiant damage, they make them the target of their attacks to ensure they can continue to regenerate.

items.name: Crypt-Starved Vladimir von Drakken

entries: Before you stands an emaciated undead man. He looks downward, with sallow red-glowing eyes hidden behind a mass of long, matted black hair. His nose is rotted and gone, his flesh cracked and decayed, and his bent pose a far cry from the imperial majesty he possessed and lost so long ago. He is swathed only in an ancient burial shroud and wrappings worn like a robe. Across his neck, a prominent and wretched scar marks how his head was sewn back upon his shoulders. He drags an ancient obsidian greatsword behind him, holding the weapon by its blade as a thin trickle of blood seeps from his fingers. From his back emerge the broken stumps of clipped wings, now little more than useless limbs of tattered gore. Yet, there is a quiet, primal power thrumming within his form.

When returned to unlife via the Sanguine Rite, Vladimir von Drakken first manifests in this form. He remains in this form until he has fed on enough individuals of sufficient power, upon which he assumes his Reborn form.

Although he cannot be permanently destroyed in this form, Vladimir von Drakken is greatly {@condition weakened|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} in this state and desires nothing more than returning to his full power.

monsterFluff.name: Crystalline Dreg

entries: The creature's jagged features make them appear to be made from shattered glass. Their flesh is a fractal arrangement of polygonal angles of shimmering crystal. Throughout their body, sharp jutting shards extend and retract as they move towards you, their body pulling in and refracting light at odd angles and with an increased intensity.

Much in the manner that some buildings closer to the meteor site had their fundamental elements changed in bizarre ways, such as stone and wood being transformed into flesh or glass, these Dregs have had their flesh warped into hard crystal. They have an innate ability to pull in light and the elements, briefly storing them in their form before expelling them in a manner that uses their body as a focusing lens, increasing the potency of these forces.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Crystalline Dreg is quite literally a glass cannon. It prefers to stay behind other Dregs, blasting its foes with its beam attacks and absorbing any elemental damage to alter its attacks. If an enemy who can deal Bludgeoning damage is present, the Crystalline Dreg will flee from that creature and attempt to kill them from a distance, knowing it is their biggest threat. The Dreg tends to focus on enemies approaching with melee weapons over anyone using elemental damage. If the front line of Dregs that the Crystalline Dreg often uses as shield is gone, or if the Crystalline Dregs are outnumbered and threatened with melee combat, they attempt to flee.

monsterFluff.name: Cyclopean Hulk

entries: Tall and lithe, this Haze Hulk's body is uniquely marked by taut muscles and pronounced blood vessels beneath its semi-translucent skin, which shows occasional fissures from the intense eldritch power contained within. Its elongated face is dominated by a single, malevolent cyclopean eye that glows like a lantern in the dark of the ruins.

Cyclopean Hulks have developed a singular eye as a focal point for the contaminated energy stored in their body, which they unleash as a destructive beam. They also have the unique ability to close their eye and wink out of their plane of existence temporarily, somehow triggering an arcane temporal rift using their focused magic

monsterFluff.name: Dark Confessor

entries: Dressed in robes of black and red that stand as a mockery to the garb often worn by members of the Sacred Flame, and clutching an ornate golden staff with a crimson orb in one hand, and a shimmering spectral maul in the other, these Dark Confessors call forth unholy curses and spirits from the abyss to bend to their will. Their pale skin, sunken black eyes, and sharp fangs stand as a grim reminder that even the holy can succumb to the whims of vampiric lords.

When the Court of the Night seeks to infiltrate a community, their first priority is to corrupt its leaders, especially their most bitter rivals in the Faith of the Sacred Flame. Thus, the flamekeepers or local priests are often targeted in particular to be transformed into vampire spawn. When these devout worshipers become vampire spawn, they are known as Dark Confessors. Their divine powers twist and warp into dark, corrupted magic under the influence of vampiric forces. In undeath, they channel that same potent energy, now converted into terrifying vampiric sorcery, which they wield to serve their masters. As Dark Confessors, they lead sinister rites and unholy rituals, gathering more followers to the cause of their vampiric overlords.

With their natural authority and sway over commonfolk, Dark Confessors manipulate communities to fall under the influence of vampire lords. They often foster cult-like followings, leading the people into pledging allegiance to their dark masters. These cults believe that by proving their loyalty, they might escape the curse of undeath and servitude. Entire towns and villages have succumbed to the charismatic influence of a Dark Confessor, their inhabitants abandoning former beliefs and swearing unwavering fealty to their vampire lords, hoping this grim devotion will save them from a far worse fate.

monsterFluff.name: Dark Growth

entries: The remains of a corpse is splayed across a ruined wall. A chaotic mass of jet-black brambles and vines pours from its torso, clinging to the nearby stonework. Branches have burst from its form, and its neck erupts into another mass of plant matter. The skull is severed from the body with its jaw unhinged and hanging in a horrible expression, stuck in place by the writhing vines. Throughout this Dark Growth, flowers bloom in iridescent neon hues and the smell of sweet pollen and decaying flesh fills the air. You hear gentle whispers from a distant voice, distinctly familiar and beckoning.

{@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} causes most plants to wither and die, but some thrive on it, absorbing water and delerium from the soil to mutate into deadly flora. In Drakkenheim's urban wasteland, suitable plots of fertile soil are scarce outside {@link Queen's Park Garden}, necessitating a creative adaptation to proliferate. These Dark Growths take root in the bodies of creatures through their infectious, delerium-infused spores.

Emitted from their blooming flowers, these spores drift silently throughout the air until they enter another creature's body through the ears, mouth, or nose. Once inside, these spores can lay dormant for some time, slowly contaminating their host with internal mutation which slowly decay their flesh and bone from within, transforming it into an ideal place for the Dark Growth to germinate. When the creature succumbs to contamination, or dies with the spores within it, the plant awakens. Consuming the internal organs of the dying infected, it suddenly and violently sprouts. Often, this transformation occurs so suddenly that the creature remains walking around, the Dark Growth using the corpse as a mobile shell so it may plant in an ideal location to spread future spores.

One apothecary reports a case where a knight returning from a mission into the Inner City had survived the journey relatively unscathed save for an excursion into the gardens where a puff of what they thought was pollen from strange iridescent flowers got in their eyes. The knight thought little of it, suffering no immediate effects. After returning to Emberwood, the knight complained of stomach cramps, nausea, and headaches, eventually passing out from the pain. The apothecary performed an emergency surgery, cutting the patient open only to have their intestines burst out like a barrage of meaty, thorn-covered brambles that attempted to strangle the apothecary. Their intestines had been completely replaced with plant matter that had fused into their guts.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Dark Growth is a simple-minded plant. It uses Mimicry to lure passing creatures towards it, often mimicking the sounds of children or people in need. It entangles and infests any target near it, infecting it with its spores. The creature is a stationary plant and does not flee.

monsterFluff.name: Dark Growth Shambler

entries: Staggering from the shadows is a gaunt humanoid with pale flesh and a hunched form. Vines and branches protrude from its gaping mouth and push through its flesh throughout its body. Flowers emerge from these growths, blooming in iridescent neon hues. A smell of sweet sugar and decaying flesh fills the air, and whispers begin to issue from it even though the creature's mouth doesn't move.

Sometimes, when the body of one infected with {@creature Dark Growth|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Dark Growths} bursts open in the moment of their death, the body does not immediately collapse and decay. Instead, the creature shambles around, its body still intact, but with vines and thorny black branches bursting from its eye sockets, mouth, and flesh, its body now a protective shell for the plant within.

monsterFluff.name: Deep Dreg Warrior

entries: Emerging from the contaminated waters is a humanoid figure with disturbing piscine mutations. Their body is covered in glittering scales of sea green, midnight purple, and deep blue. Their monstrous face has two large, bulbous eyes and a gaping, fishlike mouth filled with oddly-shaped teeth—a mixture of humanoid, shark, and other aquatic animals. Spindly, fleshy whiskers surround their fish lips. They have webbed feet and hands, and thin fins jut from their arms, legs, and face. They wear little more than ragged clothing and scraps of leather armor, and carry a brace of javelins, a spear, and a fishing net.

Dwelling in the contaminated sewers and waterways of Drakkenheim, a Deep Dreg Warrior is left with only dim memories of their former lives, their identities are fully subsumed by eldritch contamination and thralldom to the Duchess. Nevertheless, many describe their state as preferable to the lives they lived before, describing unfortunate humans as cursed landwalkers who must be "freed.".

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Deep Dreg Warriors attack from the water, throwing their spears and diving back under the surface as added protection against ranged retaliation. When they engage in melee, the warriors use their Net to restrain their foes, and make melee attacks (with the bonus damage from Catch of the Day) to knock them {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}.

Deep Dregs Warriors flee whenever they are outnumbered or if they are reduced below half their maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. They swim to safety rather than die fighting, and prefer to fall back and retaliate after gathering reinforcements.

monsterFluff.name: Deep Knight

entries: Towering over the other Deep Dregs is a muscle-bound warrior with a head shaped like a hammerhead shark. They carry a colossal shield made from the opalescent shell of some mollusk, and their gnarled hide is covered in algae and barnacles. A thick chain is wrapped around their wrists, attached to the massive, spiked harpoon they carry.

Champions of the Duchess, Deep Knights tower over others of their kind. They lead groups of Deep Dreg Warriors on excursions and important missions. The Duchess keeps a contingent of Deep Knights as her personal honor guard to protect her lair.

The Deep Knight will defend the other Deep Dregs to the death. If it is the last one standing it will attempt to flee, but as long as there are allies to protect, it will stay and fight.

monsterFluff.name: Deep Siren

entries: This a wretched, mutated crone has sea-green hair and blue-gray flesh, and is garbed in a gown of algae and kelp. They carry pouches filled with occult reagents, and vials filled with a strange octarine goo. Despite their appearance, as they speak their words are no less honeyed and sweet.

Spellcasters transformed by the Duchess's influence become Deep Sirens, retaining a measure of their magical abilities. These sirens will act as forward generals or confidants for the Duchess, and often a well-regarded siren will act as her personal court mage.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Deep Sirens are the generals and confidants to the Duchess and often serve as the eyes and ears of their mistress. They use their Illusory Appearance to walk among humanoids and observe them, planning and plotting the attacks of the Deep Dregs. Once it has gathered information, a Deep Siren returns to the Duchess, and is often sent with the Deep Dregs to storm beaches, infiltrate sewers, or take over cities on stormy nights.
The siren doesn't like being in close combat, and always attempts to use {@spell Misty Step|XPHB} to move to a more beneficial position, then unleash Storm Lash or spellcasting upon their foes.
They flee if surrounded, if outnumbered, or if they feel the battle is not going in their favor.

A wyrmling usually does not yet fully understand their transtemporal senses, and experiences memories of their adulthood and future in dreams and visions.

entries.name: Delerium Dragons

entries: This unearthly dragon is a crystalline horror, its body formed from angular gem-like scales pulsing with octarine light. Its form is raw delerium. Each scale is a gleaming crystal refracting light into eerie hues of purple, yellow, and green, with an unnatural sharpness that feels both fragile and impossibly durable.

The dragon's wings are translucent and webbed with glowing crystal veins that shimmer, casting kaleidoscopic patterns as it moves. Each beat causes the air to hum, vibrating with a chaotic energy that overwhelms and distorts the senses. Each step the dragon takes leaves delicate motes of crystal growing into jagged formations, tainting the landscape. Its eyes are like multifaceted gems, swirling with chaotic magic pooling within their depths. The beast's crystalline horns and talons are razor-sharp, gleaming like polished jewels, yet crackling with eldritch energy.

Inscrutable beings of the Space Between Worlds, Delerium Dragons are order from chaos incarnate. How such creatures came to be is unknown, and few know of their existence. Some propose that they emerged spontaneously, hatching from crystalline eggs with octarine shells.

A Delerium Dragon is not simply contaminated, but a unique type of gemstone dragon with an otherworldly physiology. These dragons are literally made of the crystals: their claws, bones, and scales are refracting {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shard}. Their flesh and organs are incomprehensible organic matter, and their blood is delerium sludge. When unleashings its breath weapon, it exhales a storm of glittering shards that explode, causing madness, mutation, and wild magic to erupt in the area.

Delerium Dragons are amongst the most powerful beings born within the Space Between Worlds. Capable of perceiving dimensions imperceptible to mortals, these dragons often seem flighty or {@condition distracted|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, but this is because they experience layers of reality which humans cannot. They are thus strange intermediaries, able to interact with creatures on a transdimensional level. Indeed, Delerium Dragons are unstuck in time, unrestrained by the linear progression of past, present, and future. Some experience their entire lives simultaneously, whereas others live their lives non-sequentially. Most understand that even their own existences is beyond comprehension, and many contemplate the fundamental nature of existence, chaos, and the cosmos. any are nihilistic solipsists who believe that nothing actually exists except themselves, and even then many doubt their own existence, believing they are merely half-remembered dreams caught betwixt a fleeting thought. Others instead revel in their chaotic existence, seeking new forms of art and untamed creation. Powerful mages and talented bards have sought their wisdom and knowledge.

Most Delerium Dragons find the Mortal World, and mortals, rather limited and boring. Throughout history, only one emerged in the Mortal World, the mighty Amaranthyst, archmage of the Amethyst Academy—the dragon's true nature known only to the other members of the Academy Directorate.

Delerium Dragons exert their force of will over the Space Between Worlds and make their lairs realms unto themselves. hese lairs may open into a Thin Place, the yawning cavern of a normal dragon's lair instead leading to the madness of the Delerium Dragon's home. These dragons fill their lairs with treasures and secrets of mysterious significance and anachronistic origin, hoarding items which may have been valuable in the distant past, or of critical importance to the distant future. Like themselves, some of their greatest possessions may exist in a state mortals can't perceive or which are fundamentally hazardous, such as multidimensional art objects, miniature primordial black holes, degenerate matter taken from a neutron star, or magical vessels containing another universe or pocket dimension.

entries.name: (20+) Octarine Breath

entries.name: (25+) Few Weaknesses
entries: You learn its highest and lowest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Delerium Dragon views combat less as a violent encounter and more as a chance to change foes into a new form. It darts about using flight and teleportation, seldom remaining in the same place for more than a turn. Their movement makes it easy for the dragon to find the perfect place to catch many enemies with its breath weapon. Delerium Dragons love to spread {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and cause {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly}, and delight causing monstrous transformations with their contaminated attacks.

Delerium Dragons use their Bite, Contaminated Rend, and Tail attacks to tear opponents apart in between uses of their breath weapon. When they are unable to close the distance, they mentally assault their targets with Mindfire.

monsterFluff.name: Delerium Dreg

entries: This wretched figure has been twisted and warped by eldritch contamination. Beneath their shredded and torn clothing, you can see all manner of sores, lesions, and bulging blood vessels upon their purple-gray flesh, and their limbs and joints bend at unnatural angles. Their facial features are unnaturally warped into a permanent expression of confused agony, and an octarine glow fills their sunken eyes. Small aberrant mutations appear across their bodies: crystalline bony protrusions and small tendrils bursting forth through their skin, a yellow eyeball blinking open upon their neck, and a disturbingly elongated tongue. As they catch sight of you, they moan painfully and lunge forward.
The typical Delerium Dreg is a disheveled and piteous creature who wanders the ruins in a quasi-addled state. Most have benign mutations that confer no special traits or unique abilities.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Delerium Dregs are desperate and confused combatants, incapable of any complex tactics beyond lunging towards their foes to attack by the most direct means. If they see a creature who is not contaminated, they will attack on sight. However, they will band together to form small herds, shuffling through ruins, or wandering the streets together. A wounded Delerium Dreg typically responds with fury and rage, attacking whatever damaged it last without regard to its personal wellbeing. In very rare cases, a wounded Dreg may attempt to flee, especially from a much more formidable combatant.

monsterFluff.name: Digipede

entries: Scuttling atop dozens of spindly legs, this grotesque creature resembles a mutated centipede grown to horrific proportions. A segmented body nearly thirty feet long undulates atop unnaturally bending limbs resembling emaciated human fingers. Elongated yellow fingernails crackle and scrape the ground menacingly as it moves. Dominating its fat, round head is a single, massive human-like eye that swivels frenetically with a disturbing, unyielding intensity. Its antenna sprouts above like an eyebrow, while tightly closed mandibles resemble bags under the eye. Its foremost finger-legs end in pincer-like talons thrumming with electricity.

Adventurers exploring the {@link Inner City} learn to heed the sound of scraping nails—a harbinger of the Digipede's approach. Nicknamed "house" centipedes for their prodigious size, Digipedes are nightmarish creatures with a disposition toward violence. Rather than consuming their prey, they leave the bodies of their lifeless victims abandoned in the desolate city streets.

How Digipedes came to be is unknown. Perhaps they originated from ordinary centipedes mutated by pools of contaminated sludge, manifesting humanlike features during their grotesque transformations. Alternatively, they may be the result of an ongoing metamorphosis, their forms continuing to twist and warp, fueled by the relentless magical forces of the Haze. A few attribute their creation to a powerful wizard hiding in the ruins known as the {@creature Pale Man}, claiming he commands them as spies and assassins. Finally, it's possible the beasts are not the product of contamination but a horrific experiment created within the Inscrutable Tower long before Drakkenheim fell.

Nevertheless, a Digipede is solitary, preferring to avoid others of its kind. A few ingenious adventurers have taken advantage of this curious trait, mimicking the creature's rhythmic scraping and generating bursts of static electricity to drive them off, or even guide them toward other threats. This secret is well known to vanguards of the Hooded Lanterns, who use Digipedes as a bizarre form of pest control against other threats haunting the ruins.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Despite its size, a Digipede will try to hide along rooftops, dark corners, narrow alleys, and any crevice which can accommodate it. It launches its Eye Beam from hiding to hinder its prey's escape, then rips into them with its Talons and Bite. The electric shocks from its attacks disrupt the ability of its prey to effectively fight back.

This revolting creature resembles a large floating brain still attached to its nervous system. The abomination hovers slowly within a field of psychic energy. The loose spindly threads that dangle down from it form into arm-like appendages. A high-pitched thrumming emanates from it as it crackles and sparks with latent psychic powers.

An {@creature Alienist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} looking to permanently control the mind of their victim may opt to remove the brain altogether, killing the patient and resurrecting the mind as its own sentient entity. Somewhere within this process the brain loses its sense of self and any connection it had to the former body it held, becoming an organism made up entirely of electrical synapses and controlled thoughts. The Disembodied Psyche is then subject to several arduous experiments to heighten its fortitude and mental capabilities, giving the creature forms of telepathy and telekinesis.

The now-undead form of this controlled consciousness can be unleashed upon the foes of the alienist and even take over the bodies of other victims, putting them in a controlled and obedient state for the alienist to perform even more mental experiments on, or use as a puppet against their enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Displacer Dreg

entries: This mutated Dreg shudders violently as it appears to strobe through reality. An indistinct blur envelops their form as they move with a stunted, unnatural, and fragmented gait, as if moments of their reality are missing, causing them to appear to skip fractions of time within their unnaturally rhythmic movements.

Displacer Dregs are often the result of contamination leaking from Thin Places within the ruins. These places are shifting gateways between realms that cause those who enter them to traverse alien planes and unknown landscapes. When the contamination leaking from these wounds in reality affects a creature, it can cause them to split into a fragmented form — both existing and not existing, both present and on some distant plane of existence. The Displacer Dreg is, at all times, not fully present. The Dreg uses this broken reality to its benefit when threatened.
