What appears to be a sliver in the air is likely something from the weird.

Dr. Everett Freed regards you with a stern frown. He is longfaced, bald-headed, and wears thick, circular glasses that magnify his focused gaze. Beneath his bleached-white surgical apron, he is dressed in a tailored dark jacket. The coat is deceptively normal: thick and heavy, it conceals numerous pockets stuffed with vials and unusual instruments. His hands, sheathed in slightly stained rubber gloves, tightly grip a black leather doctor's bag at his side. A faint scent of formaldehyde and burnt metal clings to him.
I think we can all agree you're better off without vocal chords

Perhaps no apothecary is a more prolific creator of monsters than the Reanimator, and amongst them, Dr. Everett Freed is perhaps the most infamous. A gifted professor of anatomy and medicine at Altbruke University, Dr. Everett Freed served as a field medic and surgeon during the Westemr Civil War, where the brutality and chaos of war allowed him to clandestinely begin his experiments with the fallen or grievously wounded soldiers thrust into his care. The sights of the war caused him to see the frailty of the human form—the cries of pain and agony of the wounded collected in the fields disgusted him with their feeble, broken bodies. Deep within himself welled the desire to create a perfect soldier, a warrior who would not bend or break in battle.

During the war, one of Dr. Freed's duties included triaging casualties to determine who could be saved or recover. Unbeknownst to his commanders, Dr. Freed used his position to manipulate the diagnosis, choosing ideal specimens for his experiments, individuals who would then be listed amongst the slain and missing.

entries.name: Reanimator Minions
entries: It's possible Dr. Freed was the first to create many creatures. He is most well known as the first to create Reautomata. In the process of making his magnum opus, Freed built creatures such as the {@creature Body Snatcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Cerebrograft|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, the {@creature Ripper|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and the {@creature Stitcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Freed's experiments did not stop there, and in many ways his practice ascended the body alone thanks to his collaborations with the Alienist Dr. Sina Rienks, eventually transforming himself into a {@creature Think Tank|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Mind Over Body
entries: One of Freed's infamous gambits was to remove his brain from his own body, placing it into a body double. Eventually, Freed became a Think Tank, able to remotely control brainless bodies from his hidden sanctum.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} I am always calm and composed, especially when explaining the 'necessary' cruelty of my experiments
{@b Ideal:} Progress demands sacrifice; the advancement of knowledge justifies all actions, no matter how gruesome.
{@b Bond:} I still possess the first successful reanimation I ever created: the preserved head of a beloved family member. It's both my proudest achievement and my darkest secret.

{@b Flaw:} I am obsessed with the perfection and infallibility of my creations, often dismissing any evidence of their defects, uncontrollable behavior, and horrific appearances. I never accept any failure as my fault.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study} the Reanimator, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Protected by the Reanimated
entries: You know of his {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, and Bodyguard {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

entries.name: (15+) Deadly Toxins
entries: You are aware of his Touch of Death.

entries.name: (20+) Electrical Reinvigoration
entries: You learn of his Reanimate action.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Prior to combat, Freed casts {@spell False Life|XPHB} and {@spell Death Ward|XPHB} on himself, and perhaps any allies joining him in battle. He does not engage in combat without creations by his side. If Freed is caught alone, he doesn't fight; he flees. However, when supported by his loyal creations, he can be overconfident and brash, secure that his bodyguards will keep him safe from harm. Freed always remains within 10 feet of one or more creations so he can use his Bodyguard {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} reliably.

On his turn, Freed uses Electric Jolt and Necrotic Blast to hammer his foes, while directing a favored creation with Creator's Command. Should one of his minions be brought down, he uses Reanimate and immediately sends it back into the action with Creator's Command.

Freed uses Touch of Death against a particularly loathsome foe, one who harries him with dangerous abilities, or who he especially wishes to slay. All the while, he threatens his enemies by telling them his plans for their body parts once he's killed them.
The mastermind behind some of the worst things to ever find in a basement. Watch out because even your fallen allies can be enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Drakkenheim Sewer Gator

entries: Surfacing from the rancid sewer waters is a terrible alligator nearly fifty feet long. A jagged ridge of delerium runs along its back, ending in a fell crown atop its head as pallid skin frames its octarine glowing eyes. A thick, purple tentacle-like tongue undulates out of its tooth-filled maw. Strong and sturdy legs support its scarred body, attesting to countless battles in the ruins.

Some creatures seem less affected by contamination, or perhaps are just lucky to only grow in size and ferocity. Reptiles are speculated to be more resistant to uncontrollable mutations than other creatures. The occasional gator making its way up the {@link Drann River} was always a problem, but now, stories of vicious lizards are becoming more bizarre and horrifying.

Rumors speak of a massive gator living in the sewers, with sightings in the Drann River or echoes of its growls heard from sewer grates. None who came close enough to verify its existence have yet survived. Some report half-submerged forms passing through sewer entrances, sometimes mistaking them for large turtles. Others tell of a large beast rumbling through the pipes under their feet. In the taverns of Emberwood, the creature has earned the nickname "the Gray Queen" due to her pale skin and delerium crown. Others have called it by other names: the Devil of the Drann or the Greater Gator. Some have suggested that multiple giant gators live in the dirty waters.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to study a Drakkenheim Sewer Gator, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Fearless Aquatic Predator!
entries: You learn the Drakkenheim Sewer Gator's condition {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} and Swim speed.

entries.name: (10+) Watch out for its bite!
entries: You are aware of the creature's Crushing Bite and Death Roll actions.

entries.name: (15+) Get it out of the water!
entries: You know of the creature's Contaminated Regeneration trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Drakkenheim Sewer Gator is primarily aquatic, haunting the sewer system or the Drann River. These monstrosities lunge from the waters to grab prey, dragging it beneath the surface. Once a target is in its jaws, the gator Death Rolls until its victim stops moving. It is a cunning hunter, knowing how to disappear below murky waters, but it can be provoked to chase its prey. Out of the water it is vulnerable and flees if reduced below half its Hit Points.

monsterFluff.name: Druid of the Sanguine Rite

entries: This ancient druid is adorned in skulls and bones hanging off its thick gray cloak. They carry a staff of bone drenched in animal blood, with dried blood painted on their face and clothes. Their features are skeletal in nature, their skin stretched tightly over them. They appear ancient, their eyes sunken and black, their teeth yellowed with age and neglect. The druid whispers in forgotten tongues as they perform blood sacrif ices and draw on primal magics.

These druids are older than even the vampire families. The few that remain are not descendants of any vampiric bloodline; they are the ancient blood druids who performed the rituals that created Vladimir von Drakken. Few of these druids still remain and those who do are reclusive and hidden. Their ancient blood rituals instilled in them a cursed eternal life, and those still roaming the world have transformed into something half alive. Not the same as a vampire, and not shackled by the vampires' weaknesses, these druids are bound to darkness to replenish them and use blood to fuel their rituals and magic. Their powers are a tightly guarded secret that few have witnessed.

Some of these dark druids saw Vladimir as a prophet, a destiny fulfilled. The Druids of the Sanguine Rite saw Vladimir as a vessel for their dark magic, a powerful being that would usher in an age where they could practice their rituals openly and grow their power. Others live eternally in deep regret of transforming Vladimir, feeling that in doing so they cursed themselves to an eternity of hiding in the darkness.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The druid of the blood rites uses dark magic to twist the lifeforce of other creatures. The druid uses its bloodthorn whip to inflict a series of open wounds upon its foes, and then feeds on their lifeforce by pulling it through their wounds using plasma absorption.
When not directly engaged in combat, the druids attempt to charm a group of foes and convince them to partake in their blood rituals, using their life force as sacrifice to empower one of their own.
If the druids are directly confronted with greater numbers, or their health is below half, they attempt to flee.

monsterFluff.name: Effulgent Cnidarian

entries: A translucent bulbous mass floats through the air gently, throbbing neon colors radiating across its skin like a cosmic nebula or an eldritch borealis. A mass of thin strands dangle down from the creature, pulsating with bioluminescent light. The tendrils move and glide about, gently groping and grabbing at objects as it passes by. The whole creature glows, illuminating the darkened city streets around it. A distant chorus of ethereal hums and tones fill the air.

Drakkenheim glows at night. The bizarre alien color palette of the cosmic borealis caused by the Haze and the {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} is a sight to behold. Yet, within the drab nighttime landscape, one can also spot orbs of strange hypnotic light bobbing and swaying between the tall towers and ruined buildings. Upon closer inspection, these wispy lights appear to be a sort of aerial jellyfish, whose semi-translucent skin shifts in kaleidoscopic colors.

These strange jellyfish creatures light up the Inner City of Drakkenheim at night, like bizarre night lights that float through the city. Their nature and what exactly created them remains a mystery. Jellyfish were not a common creature found in the Drann River, and so Academy researchers have speculated that these creatures emerged from rifts between the Mortal World and the Space Between Worlds, or that they are the core of arcane energies coalescing into a sentient wisp before transforming into a body made of delerium that illuminates the city in the twilight of dusk. They gently hum in dissonant notes, giving an eerie presence to the ruins at night.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} an Effulgent Cnidarian, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Aberrant Resistance
entries: You recognize the monster's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} and {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (10+) Hypnotic Color Change
entries: You learn of the monster's Hallucinogenic Bioluminescence trait.

entries.name: (15+) Weak but Aware
entries: You are aware of the monster's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Effulgent Cnidarians are not predatorial—they only want to bask in the glow of {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}, feeding slowly on the arcane energies they emit. They are, however, protective of their food sources. If creatures venture into an area of heavy delerium crystallization, they are sure to find a few Cnidarians bobbing about. The Cnidarian prefers to use its Hallucinogenic Bioluminescence to dissuade threats from engaging, instead hoping to cause its enemies to kill one another. The Cnidarians feed on creatures under its hypnosis, absorbing their essence through its tendrils. If attacked, it uses its Reflexive Flash and attempts to move away from its threats, often floating straight up as quickly as it can and out of the reach of danger.
Cnidarians do not stay around to fight. If all targets have avoided its charm and are actively attacking it, it abandons its food source to seek other safer areas.

items.name: Eldrick Runeweaver

entries: Eldrick Runeweaver is a towering and broad-shouldered black man in his mid-sixties. His amber eyes glow softly behind his circular glasses, and a square-cut graying black beard. Eldrick wears nine rings of silver, gold, and electrum: one on each finger except his left thumb. He wears flowing purple garb with golden embroidery and carries an obsidian staff tipped with a {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystal}.

One of the finest professors in the Amethyst Academy, Eldrick Runeweaver has personally instructed a generation of talented arcane spellcasters. He is the foremost living expert on abjuration magic but is also highly regarded within the Academy as a dedicated administrator and calculating leader. If Eldrick Runeweaver successfully retakes the Inscrutable Tower, he will likely take up the vacant spot in the Academy Directorate and assume the mantle of Archmage of Drakkenheim.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I carefully calculate my every action, and I speak using a few well-chosen words. I'm a teacher at heart, so I often phrase my responses in the form of a pointed question.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I will seek out more information whenever I encounter an unknown situation or problem. Through reason and logic, the facts always bear out the truth of the matter.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I hold a position of responsibility and authority within the Amethyst Academy, and it is my duty to protect the Academy's interests, carry out its agenda, and keep its many secrets.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I care deeply for my students but tend to overlook their faults and failures. I've had several wayward apprentices over the years, and I've often had to cover up their mistakes.

Eldrick Runeweaver has a {@creature Cat|XMM} familiar, travels with an {@creature Iron Golem|XMM} bodyguard, and a {@creature Homunculus|XMM} servant. He most often communicates via {@spell Sending}, {@spell Rary's Telepathic Bond|XPHB|Telepathic Bond}, and {@spell Project Image} spells, or by sending his simulacrum instead. Eldrick has a clone kept in a distant stronghold with extra equipment should the unthinkable occcur.

monsterFluff.name: Eldritch Cataclysm

entries: A swirling vortex of dark clouds, debris, and icy shards moves in like an eldritch storm. Crackling octarine lightning fills the air, the ground rumbles and shakes with the might of the unnatural weather phenomenon, but this is no ordinary storm. Within the dark clouds appears a snarling face, its eyes and mouth like pools of octarine light. The creature is the weather itself, warped and infused by the Haze of Drakkenheim into an arcane and twisted form of life, filled with the uncaring and unbridled anger of a storm.

Drakkenheim was always known for its lousy weather; miserable rainy days were commonplace even before the city was ravaged by the falling stars. Now, the city is frequently wracked by violent and otherworldly weather conditions. The ever-present mists of the Haze occasionally give way to contaminated acid rain, flashing bolts of arcane lightning, and piercing hailstones filled with {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shards}. Most adventurers know it's best to avoid venturing into the ruins altogether on such days, but in the erratic conditions of the ruins, the weather can shift dramatically at a moment's notice.

During the fiercest octarine thunderstorms, the powerful energies converge into a maelstrom of lesser elemental forces, fusing into a sentient storm known as an Eldritch Cataclysm. Its manifestation is marked by a swirling vortex of dark clouds, debris, and icy shards, all illuminated by the ominous glow of octarine lightning. These raging elementals are driven by pure destructive impulse, and their presence calls forth a host of other Contaminated Elementals to join them in a cacophony of annihilation. {@creature Entropic Flame|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Entropic Flames} and {@creature Living Deep Haze|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Living Deep Hazes} are readily drawn to Eldritch Cataclysms, but their presence compels even normally docile Contaminated Elementals such as {@creature Walking Delerium Geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@creature Animated Delerium Sludge|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} to rise up and destroy.

Fascinated by the destructive power of these elemental creatures, mages of the Amethyst Academy have studied these phenomena surrounding the emergence of an Eldritch Cataclysm. Corroborating reports from Hooded Lantern scouts indicate that the locus for these storms appears to be the swirling vortex of raw magical energies which overhang the Crater itself.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} an Eldritch Cataclysm, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (15+) Amalgamation of Energies
entries: You learn the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, as well as its Air Form trait.

entries.name: (20+) An Octarine Storm
entries: You recognize its Chain Lightning, Meteor Strike, Quake, and Icy Bolt actions.

entries.name: (25+) Exceedingly Resilient
entries: You are aware of its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Eldritch Cataclysms rule the skies, and never willingly descend to the ground. Instead, it rains down lightning, meteors, and icy blasts from above. The temperamental nature of these elementals means they delight in attacking with a variety of elements, and seldom use the same action two rounds in a row. They enjoy using their Meteor Strike on targets they've {@condition Frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} with Icy Bolt, and delight in using their Cyclonic Storm to blow away weapons and equipment dropped by targets of their Chain Lightning.

These enraged creatures revel in destruction but have little conception that anything could actually pose a threat to them. When confronted with a foe able to withstand their onslaught, they treat it as a personal affront, and furiously focus their subsequent attacks upon them occasionally to the exclusion of all else. Despite this single-minded strategy, an Eldritch Cataclysm can recognize when a creature is resistant or immune to its elemental attacks and tries to use only the most effective powers against its chosen target.

monsterFluff.name: Eldritch Crawler

entries: Amidst a web of fractured realities and glimpsed timelines sits an arachnid creature with twisted features. Its elongated form writhes and shivers as it clambers across its broken glass mosaic of possibilities. Its fanged maw gnashes and chomps. Within its movements one can make out faint resounding reverberations of possible movements and reactions that did not occur, as if with every step the creature takes, an infinite ghost of possible movements it may have taken glimmer and fade.

These strange arachnid-like creatures seem to weave together partial realities, parallel dimensions, and alternate timelines like a spider spinning its web. They have features that resemble that of a large spider, but their twisted forms, elongated torsos, fanged maws, and spiny hides give them an otherworldly guise that makes them hard to distinguish as anything from this plane of existence.

Those who have faced one have commented on the broken sense of reality that occurs when attempting to attack an Eldritch Crawler. In response Eldritch Crawlers shift realities, and whether the attack hits or misses, a glimpse through time and space shows all possible outcomes of the attack at once. Even when an Eldritch Crawlers is defeated, it's debatable if they are truly dead, or if it was simply observed in a single timeline in which it was killed—the monster may still exist in every other possible reality. This could mean Eldritch Crawlers transcend human concepts of time and space and can't actually be killed, only removed from one instance of time and space amongst an infinite sea of them.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Eldritch Crawlers weave together fractured timelines, and slip in and out of the Space Between Worlds with ease. They create their own Thin Places and travel through them back and forth as needed. When under attack, Eldritch Crawlers bend and alter the realities they exist in to shift to one where they are more likely to survive. They teleport around the battlefield and vanish into the Space Between Worlds as they need to, using Void Walker and their Fractured Reality Reaction, only to reemerge and attack their prey with Contaminated Venom.

monsterFluff.name: Eldritch Dreg

entries: The scrawny, twig-thin creature shuffles out of the shadows, seeming unstable on its feet, and disproportionately weighted by its massive, throbbing cranium that pulses with octarine energy. Suddenly, the creature lifts off the ground and a shimmering field surrounds it. Its hollow eyes begin to glow with contaminated energy as it whips its head towards you, a pulsing psychic energy emanating from its gaze.

Eldritch Dregs have a warped and twisted psyche. Contaminated energy collects in their brain, causing it to swell to a massive size while granting the Dreg arcane powers which it can barely comprehend—or control. Through this strange mutation, the Eldritch Dreg has lost most of its muscle tissue. They struggle to hold themselves upright when shuffling on their feet but can Levitate into the air when needed. Spellcasters who succumb to eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} are particularly likely to become Eldritch Dregs, especially those who have dabbled with contaminated spells.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: An Eldritch Dreg curses its chosen target with Hazewarp Hex, and then hammers it with its Psychic Blast. It uses {@spell Levitate|XPHB} to keep itself out of melee by hovering above the battlefield and it will unleash its Synaptic Shock if its enemies are close to one another. If brought to less than half its Hit Points, it attempts to flee.

items.name: Eldritch Trickster

entries: Draped in black robes and carrying an obsidian wand, the Eldritch Trickster has a hood pulled up tight around its head as arcane power focuses into its hand, forming a blade of raw energy.

The Queen's Men have attracted a handful of renegade mages, undiscovered sorcerous talents, and wicked warlocks. Many are malfeasants who used their magic to commit crimes such as robbery, conspiracy, impersonation, or murder. Now seeking to avoid the clutches of the Amethyst Academy and Silver Order alike, these mages offer their magical talents to the Queen of Thieves in exchange for her protection. Ironically, this often sees them using magic for many more misdeeds.

monsterFluff.name: Eldritch Troll

entries: The mottled faded purple skin of this massive creature is accented by erupting {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} along its spine, shoulders, and forearms. Its large, frog-like octarine eyes glare at you. Its skin writhes and crawls as new appendages burst forth from it, in a constant state of mutation.

When a troll's innate ability to regenerate combines with the devastating mutating properties of delerium, it causes an Eldritch Troll to form. These creatures are near impossible to kill, regenerating from almost any attack thrown at them. They also seem to have some control over their mutations, which they can change at any moment to help them hunt their prey. Eldritch Trolls have been known to grow wings and fly, or grow extra arms to attack or to cover their body in crystalized delerium.

Unlike most other trolls, Eldritch Trolls do not travel in packs or form tight-knit family groups. They are corrupted abominations and lose much of their sentience in the process. They are more likely to be encountered alone, wandering the ruins of Drakkenheim, or the corrupted Thin Places of the continent.

Eldritch Trolls tend to wander the areas they became corrupted in, never straying too far away from the delerium that they crave. Their grotesque transformation gives them a hunger for more {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and to contaminate anything else that comes near. When they sense danger, a threat, or even just wandering prey, Eldritch Trolls attack aggressively, and without remorse.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study} an Eldritch Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Hard to Kill
entries: You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

entries.name: (15+) Special Weakness
entries: You have insight into the troll's {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Eldritch Trolls stalk the streets of the Inner City of Drakkenheim attempting to contaminate any creature they come across. They use Corrupting Blast to contaminate their foes, mutating to whatever best suits them in the battle, and then use their Claws and Bite.
If an Eldritch Troll takes Psychic damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

monsterFluff.name: Entropic Flame

entries: An elemental alight with purple-green flames illuminates the desolate streets ahead. Composed of cascading octarine fire, the elemental moves like wildfire spreading uncontrollably. Within the dancing flames is a scornful expression of rage. It crackles and blazes, the heat from its body distorting the air around it. The pungent smell of burning ozone and sulfur saturates the area, and flecks of cinder and ash whirl about, shedding from the creature as it glides menacingly toward you.

The fires from the day Drakkenheim was destroyed never truly died. Many became Entropic Flames—Contaminated Fire Elementals that travel the ruins like living embers. Countless can be found wandering the areas around the Crater and southern Drakkenheim. The Followers of the Falling Fire view Entropic Flames almost like fallen angels, symbols of the vortex itself.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: An Entropic Flame is a haughty combatant driven by a burning desire to set the world on fire. It teleports from place to place using its Flickerjump, setting alight creatures and objects using its Dancing Flames. If possible, it tries to remain close to {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} targets to keep them on fire within its Enduring Flame aura.

Within the smoking ruins of Drakkenheim, Entropic Flames love to set buildings, furniture, and other objects on fire. They quickly turn the battlefield into a roiling inferno, one which cannot be extinguished easily thanks to their presence.

monsterFluff.name: Entropic Watcher

entries: This floating mass of wet flabby flesh drifts through the air, its many long spindly tendrils dangling down like an incomprehensible jellyfish. Appearing in strange hues of pale pinks, purples, and whites, its large single eye in the middle of its fleshy mass glows with octarine hues, weakening body and mind. The soft sound of thrumming and suckling follows it as it assaults minds with insane chattering in unknown languages.

Many of the creatures inhabiting the Space Between Worlds are aberrant and primordial in nature. The Entropic Watcher is one such incomprehensible creature. To look upon it is like looking at an abstract painting, the forms and shapes of it body painful to observe by the mortal mind. It silently drifts through the Space Between Worlds, drawn to Thin Places where it observes the places beyond, as if analyzing or calculating some unknown concepts as it stares through like a cat at a window. For this reason, Entropic Watchers are one of the more common occurrences in the Mortal World, as they tend to congregate around Thin Places, and often slip through.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine an Entropic Watcher, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (10+) Guarded Existence
entries: You learn the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Imperiling Stare
entries: You recognize the creature's Withering Gaze feature.

entries.name: (20+) Physically Resilient
entries: You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Entropic Watcher is a keen hunter who, by its very gaze, can cause a creature to grow weak and leave it open for annihilation. The Entropic Watcher focuses its gaze upon its prey and unleashes its eye beams towards it, knowing that if it can hold its gaze, the creature will succumb to the watcher's blasts much easier. It will use its Force Barrier and Shadow Crash to force its victims into an optimal position for it to strike, and grab them with its tendrils, holding them readily in its Withering Gaze.
If the Entropic Watcher is reduced to less than 50 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it attempts to flee.

monsterFluff.name: Executioner

entries: The massive construct looms menacingly within the center of Slaughterstone Square. Pacing back and forth, it drags its guillotine blade behind it, with the grinding of steel on stone echoing off the old buildings. Its form is a mass of steel plates and gears resembling a huge suit of armor. From within its frame, the glow of octarine light illuminates it with an eerie glow of corruption. The poor souls of its victims cling to it, reaching out in terror as if clawing to escape their last moments when the Executioner took their heads.

The Executioner is a hulking clockwork knight that originally carried out public death sentences in the Slaughterstone Square of Drakkenheim. This ancient machine was engineered by the dwarves of Glitter Peak during the height of their brilliance in distant antiquity. It was left buried deep beneath the avalanches which destroyed the magnificent dwarven capital, and subsequently unearthed by an expeditionary team several decades ago. The king commissioned the Amethyst Academy to bring the construct back into good repair; they altered its arcane programming to obey the commands of the monarch of Westemr.

Laws and customs surrounding capital punishment in Drakkenheim have been a controversial matter ever since the tyrannical reign of Albrecht von Drakken, who issued a draconian decree that demanded family members of the convicted be the ones to carry out their execution sentence. After his reign ended, few were ever willing to serve the role of royal headsman, viewing the act of carrying out the killing as yet another act of murder. Although various devices and contraptions were used to create distance between the death and the administer of the punishment, these hesitations and public resistance to capital punishment remained. In the Executioner, the monarchy had the perfect solution to its judicial problem: the impartial construct is no mortal, and therefore none are culpable for carrying out the death sentence. That the machine makes an impressively terrifying show of the deed was certainly not an insignificant factor either.

Unfortunately, the erratic magic of delerium has scrambled the machine's control protocols. Now contaminated by the Haze, the construct is an engine of destruction and terror which can call upon spectral chains and the spirits of its victims to aid its duty. It attacks anyone who enters the square. However, it never wanders outside the bounds of Slaughterstone Square. The large octagonal plaza features the Executioner's platform, and the surrounding buildings have narrow balconies and tall, dour-looking windows overlooking the square. Mountains of corpses are piled in the square—the grim toll of the Executioner's vocation. Nevertheless, scavengers and adventurers still occasionally risk trying to slip past the Executioner to loot the corpses for valuable equipment and magic items. For many, this mistake is their last, and rather than escape with new treasures, they join the pile of the Executioner's trove.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@item artisan's tools|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the Executioner, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Unstoppable Machine
entries: You know of the Executioner's

entries.name: Immutable Form, Dimensional Anchor, and Rejuvenation
entries: traits, as well as its damage {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Strange Abilities
entries: You recognize its Destroyer, Summon Grasping Shadow, and Guillotine Blade actions.

entries.name: (15+) Powerfully Tough
entries: You are aware of the Executioner's strongest and weakest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Executioner is not a foe to be defeated, but rather an obstacle to be avoided or a danger to escape. It is a reminder of the callous and uncontrollable dangers present in Drakkenheim. The Executioner's combat tactics vary based on whether it detects low-level characters trespassing in Slaughterstone Square or high-level characters trying to defeat the machine itself. The Executioner pursues its targets within Slaughterstone Square, but never leaves the plaza.

When the Executioner detects creatures trespassing on Slaughterstone Square, it responds first by using Summon Grasping Shadows, followed up by Death Grip to try to prevent their escape. Meanwhile, it uses Lumber Forward to gain ground. You should embrace clever solutions that characters invent to escape or bypass the Executioner. As long as your players aren't trying to destroy it, the Executioner will only use Guillotine Blade against a {@condition Restrained|XPHB} target within its melee range, and does not make ranged attacks nor activate its Necrotic Vents aura.

However, should your players engage the Executioner directly in combat, do not pull any punches. They have made an incredibly foolish mistake by confronting a well-telegraphed deathtrap and should be served their just desserts. It activates its Necrotic Vents, and then relentlessly attacks with its Guillotine Blade. The Executioner throws the massive weapon to hit targets trying to avoid it in melee, or those that try to harm it with ranged weapons or spells. If it encounters any impediment in its way (such as a {@spell Wall of Force|XPHB}), it crushes it with Destroyer.

How do you dead what is dead? I see no end to this riddle.
Listen, I don't care if you call yourself a scientist or a doctor, if you put a demon in you, I'm going to kill you.

The figure wears a wide-brim hat that casts shadows on their face. A long, black trench coat covers their form. The dour figure carries a simple doctor's bag in one hand and a holy symbol of the Sacred Flame in the other. Ethereal energies flit and flick around the doctor as they mumble incoherent ancient words, summoning spirits, or perhaps something worse.

An Exorcist comes prepared to deal with evil entities, sinister spirits, and fearsome fiends. Equipped with their holy symbol, a book of prayers, and a bag of ritualistic baubles, Exorcists stand ready to face the most unnatural and otherworldly entities of the realms. Some Exorcists, however, are so familiar with the ways of the undead, they can summon spirits into hosts. In some rare cases, Exorcists allow demons to inhabit the living.

entries.name: Exorcists Minions
entries: Exorcists deal with all manner of entities. They can call forth Specters, Ghosts, Demons, Wraiths, and other extraplanar entities. The most horrifying creation of the Exorcist is the Soulbound Host, which occurs when an Exorcist allows themself to be a vessel for demonic, extraplanar, or fairy entities, attempting to harness the power of such beings. Most are driven mad during the process.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} I speak to the dead often, sometimes when I am not even sure if they are there..
{@b Bond:} The understanding of life and death grants us power over the planes that few have dared to grasp.
{@b Ideal:} It is in control of demons and ghosts that we will transcend to our true potential.
{@b Flaw:} I am sure I have the strength within me to host a demon or spirit without succumbing to its will.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study} an Exorcist, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Demons and Undead
entries: You recognize the Exorcist's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} as well as their Expel Evil action.

entries.name: (10+) Master of Possession
entries: You are aware of the Exorcist's Grasping Ghost action.

entries.name: (15+) Weak of Character and Body
entries: You learn the Exorcist's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Exorcist relies on its divine weapons and direct combat skills. They often reside in locations that have natural hazards where they can use their Grasping Ghosts to force enemies into danger. Hazards could include {@condition burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} braziers, spiked pits, or a pool of blessed acid. If any foe has a summoned creature, the Exorcist dispatches it using Expel Evil, and destroy any undead foes with Last Rites.
If the Exorcist is in a losing situation, they attempt to use Spiritual Healing on themself before fleeing.
I admire their divine focus but it's the controlling you with ghosts thing where they lose me.

The grim-faced doctor's jaw tightens as they lower their browand sigh. Suddenly, their face contorts into a wicked, impossiblegrimace, a smile stretched too wide for the muscles on their face.Fiendish light glimmers in their eyes as hornlike bulges rip throughthe flesh of their forehead. Profane runes suddenly blaze upontheir flesh, releasing the smell of burning meat and sulfur. Thebody rises into the air, the muscle spasms barely containing the evilspirit bound within this mortal host. A spiral of flame encircles theapothecary's body as they unleash a horrific scream, speaking in avoice which is not their own. "Now, you will die, mortal."

A Soulbound Host is the physical body of an apothecary who has willingly allowed an extraplanar creature to possess them, trapping the powerful outsider in a mortal form. Powerful yet vulnerable, Soulbound Hosts loathe their creators. They wander the world for the means to reverse the curse of mortality placed upon them and return to their otherworldly domains.

Exorcist and Alienist apothecaries do not primarily study the body, and rarely practice the type of magic and science which leads to mutant horrors and flesh-stitched abominations. They are instead concerned with the supernatural forces of the mind and soul. Many research and contact powerful extraplanar entities, eager to possess mortals as a means of entering the material world. These apothecaries learn how to create Soulbound Hosts as a powerful means to contain and fight back against these dangerous otherworldly foes.

entries.name: Desperate Gambit
entries: A Soulbound Host is usually created under truly desperate circumstances, such as when a heroic apothecary faces a dangerous otherworldly being such as a demon, fey, spirit, or inscrutable entity from the Space Between Worlds. Not only are these planar invaders pernicious foes, many are effectively immortal—often these creatures simply reform when killed outside their native planes. Thus, an apothecary who lacks the ability to defeat the demon on their own, or who wishes to defeat a powerful outsider in a more permanent fashion, may instead decide upon a heroic act of self-sacrifice by turning themselves into a Soulbound Host.

entries.name: Preparing the Trap
entries: Using an array of implanted metals, ingested tinctures, mental preparations, and occult incantations, a skilled apothecary may willingly prepare their body for possession. During the process, the apothecary can weave a unique spiritual trap. It then falls to the apothecary to convince the otherworldly creature to possess them, an act that many outsiders are eager to do. Thus, the canny apothecary preys on the ego of the monster itself.

entries.name: Mortal Curse
entries: When the outsider inhabits the body, the apothecary's soul departs, leaving the extraplanar creature to take their place spiritually. If this mortal form is killed or destroyed, the bound creature does not simply return to their plane of origin. Instead, the spirit departs to the afterworlds like any other mortal soul, losing their accumulated otherworldly power forever. Thus, the Soulbound Host becomes both a prison and a death sentence for the other wielding being tricked into the apothecary's body.

entries.name: Rogue Hosts
entries: Unfortunately, this act of self-sacrifice is not without its imperfections. The apothecary's body is filled with otherworldly essence, and while the creature's power is greatly diminished, they often remain extremely dangerous—allies of the departed apothecary may still find it challenging to slay the Soulbound Host. Many escape, wandering the world with stolen lives and even assuming the identity of their host while they search for the means to escape their now mortal form. All bound outsiders are painfully aware of their new mortality, frustrated that returning to their planes of origin is not a simple matter of destroying their flesh-cage or switching their essence into a different host, one which lacks the binding wards placed by the apothecary.

entries.name: Price of Freedom
entries: Trapped outsiders can win their freedom by calling back the soul of the apothecary who trapped them, and resurrecting them into their body. This is a thing many outsiders are loathe to do out of fiendish ego, since it puts the original soul in a bargaining position. In this way, the apothecary can force the spirit to accept a bargain which requires them to remain in their own worlds for at least the duration of the apothecary's lifetime.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB}, {@skill Medicine|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study a Soulbound Host, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Possessed Body
entries: You know the Soulbound Host's type and damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (15+) Extraplanar Magic
entries: Depending on the type of spirit, you learn either the Hellfire Chain, Illusory Assault, or Psychic Barrage actions, as well as the Spellcasting trait of the host.

entries.name: (20+) Cursed Fate
entries: You recognize its desperation caused by its spirit-bound mortality and its Reactions.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Soulbound Host is a careful combatant. Though powerful, the last thing they want is to be killed in their mortal form. If they are seriously injured, they often attempt to bargain, offering power and knowledge to assailants who spare them.

entries.name: Far Dweller

entries: This tall, gangly creature hovers ominously, levitating inches above the ground. Its arms hang loosely at its sides and thin legs dangle below its body. Shifting motes of otherworldly energy dance between its long, gnarled fingers. Its purple-gray skin stretches tightly over its emaciated frame. Instead of a head, a mass of thick, writhing tentacles sprouts from its neck, reaching out into the air. The atmosphere around it vibrates with chittering whispers, slurping and the hoarse mumbles of maddening truths and incomprehensible realities.

Known as Far Dwellers, these enigmatic beings are among the most persistent and terrifying entities encountered in the Space Between Worlds. They traverse dimensions and Thin Places, abducting victims to perform alien experiments on them. However, their motives and purposes remain utterly obscure, and their objectives beyond human understanding. Nevertheless, Far Dwellers demonstrate uncanny understanding of the psychic forces and wild magic of the Space Between Worlds, and perhaps have an interest in spreading the influence and {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} of that dimension. None possess greater mastery over delerium and contaminated magic than these creatures. They weave their spells to create eldritch machines with unknown purposes, dominate their victims, evade harm, and complete their esoteric research.

It is evident from the limited interactions Far Dwellers have had with mortals that they pose a grave threat and harbor malicious intentions towards humanoids. Far Dwellers perceive humanoids much as a person might view an insect or perhaps a stray animal—sometimes with indifferent disregard, other times with evident disgust or disdain. They rarely communicate with mortals and seem unwilling or disinterested in explaining themselves or their goals. Far Dwellers show scant concern for their captives' desperate pleas for help or cries for mercy as they secure them to stone slabs and invade their minds with countless probing tendrils.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Far Dweller, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (10+) Psychic Fortress
entries: You learn the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Mental Control
entries: You are aware of the creature's Pluck the Puppet Strings {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: (20+) Otherworldly Intellect
entries: They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Far Dweller often disregards creatures it deems lesser than itself until it is outwardly threatened, often outright ignoring nearby mortals like one might ignore a passing insect or rodent. However, when provoked they are intelligent, efficient, and ruthless. Thanks to its great intellect, a Far Dweller rapidly assesses the capabilities of its attackers and responds to methodically dismantle them accordingly.

Far Dwellers begin combat by casting {@spell Maze}, {@spell Hypnotic Pattern}, or {@spell Slow} to incapacitate as many foes as possible. On subsequent turns, it uses Contaminate and Mind Scramble to launch a contaminated psychic assault, preferring to target spellcasters and physically weak targets, while choosing physically strong but easily manipulated targets for Pluck the Puppet Strings.

When attacked, a Far Dweller disappears temporarily using Vanish to the Space Between Worlds. Note that this ability functions normally on the Space Between Worlds itself, as the Far Dweller momentarily travels to a different spatial dimension on that plane.

A Far Dweller is always willing to abandon a fight and its projects if it is sufficiently threatened, and will flee to the Space Between Worlds using {@spell Plane Shift} if it is {@status Bloodied|XPHB}.

monsterFluff.name: Far Dweller Abductor

entries: The being appears humanoid in shape, but much taller and more slender than would seem natural, with long spindly arms and elongated fingers. Their heads are large for their lank bodies, coming to a point where their chin would be, and round and bulbous at the top. They have no features upon their face but as their head tilts and shutters, there is a seemingly vast perception. The creature moves without making a sound and seems engulfed in blinding light from an unknown source.

Some folk have told tales of wandering travelers alone at night who saw strange lights in the sky, or through the trees of thick woods, or incomprehensible beings that wandered into their camps through rifts between worlds. The most horrifying are those who speak of the creatures effortlessly entering their homes and taking them somewhere else, only to awake with a hazy memory and no signs that anyone was ever there.

Their motives are completely unknown, but they arrive from the Space Between Worlds to observe, and experiment upon mortals. When one encounters a Far Dweller Abductor, they are left with no memory of ever having experienced the creature in the first place. The abducted are left with strange and bizarre dreams, confused visions, and blurred concepts of what may have occurred. This has led to doubt and discourse over the very existence of these creatures. For those who share stories are often met with disbelief, as witnesses and victim share conflicting tales of their experience.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Far Dweller Abductor, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (10+) Psychic Fortress
entries: You learn the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Confounding Existence
entries: You are aware of the creature's Unfathomable Presence trait.

entries.name: (20+) Malign Brilliance
entries: They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Far Dweller Abductors are not fighters, and simply wish to gather specimens and study them. When Abductors appear, they usually do so when a creature is resting or asleep. They rely on their Unfathomable Presence to confuse and dismantle their target. They use use Mind Warp or Devour Thoughts to weaken the mind of their target before attempting to Abduct them.

The Far Dweller Abductors do not wish to be observed or remembered, and do not want even their dead left behind to be discovered and known to the creatures they are researching. A Far Dweller Abductor will teleport away and use {@spell Plane Shift} if it has lost the upper hand, is outnumbered, or feels in any way threatened. If a Far Dweller Abductor dies, any Far Dwellers still engaged in battle attempt to take their bodies and vanish as quickly as possible, attempting to leave no trace of their presence.

items.name: Far Dweller Mastermind

entries: Draped in ancient robes and carrying a {@item staff|XPHB} made of otherworldly material, the creature observes you with cold disregard. It holds out a hand, bending the very fabric of time and space around it. It hovers above the ground, its head a mass of writhing tentacles, and its gangly pale body pulsing with octarine energy.
Especially ancient and terrible, these powerful Far Dwellers have wandered existence for untold eons.
Sometimes you have to improvise. for example, when a sword doesn't work, try throwing a javelin. if that doesnt work I am out of ideas.

entries.name: Price of Freedom
entries: Trapped outsiders can win their freedom by calling back the soul of the apothecary who trapped them, and resurrecting them into their body. This is a thing many outsiders are loathe to do out of fiendish ego, since it puts the original soul in a bargaining position. In this way, the apothecary can force the spirit to accept a bargain which requires them to remain in their own worlds for at least the duration of the apothecary's lifetime.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB}, {@skill Medicine|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study a Soulbound Host, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Possessed Body

entries.name: (15+) Extraplanar Magic
entries: Depending on the type of spirit, you learn either the Hellfire Chain, Illusory Assault, or Psychic Barrage actions, as well as the Spellcasting trait of the host.

entries.name: (20+) Cursed Fate
entries: You recognize its desperation caused by its spirit-bound mortality and its Reactions.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Soulbound Host is a careful combatant. Though powerful, the last thing they want is to be killed in their mortal form. If they are seriously injured, they often attempt to bargain, offering power and knowledge to assailants who spare them.

items.name: Flamekeeper

entries: Dressed in white and gold robes adorned with the holy symbols of the Sacred Flame, the Flamekeeper recites prayers and holds a burning candle. Warding off evil and healing its allies, it stands as a protective beacon to the Knights of the Silver Order.

Every monastery, chapel, cathedral, and shrine to the Sacred Flame is watched over by a Flamekeeper. These white-robed women guided by their faith are known throughout the nations to aid the downtrodden, protect the innocent, and perform religious ceremonies of many types. Occasionally, Flamekeepers will join Silver Order knights on holy expeditions, or as envoys for the Sacred Flame, joining battlefields and wars as protectors, healers, and symbols of the faith.
I'll show you who should be keeping the flame! It's me, with my awesome sword.

entries.name: Followers of the Falling Fire
entries: The Followers of the Falling Fire are a religious sect who believe the meteor signaled a celestial prophecy. These fanatics consider delerium a holy sacrament. Called to pilgrimage by the prescient testament of their leader, {@creature Lucretia Mathias|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, zealous masses of devout commonfolk now journey to the Crater's Edge to take their place in a divine plan.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.
There comes a time in every man's life where he wants more. Delerium in your chest is the wrong way.

monsterFluff.name: Fractal Lepidoptera

entries: Fluttering in midair is a cavalcade of color, of rushing energy and indecipherable movement, a tessellating fractal impossible to follow with your eyes. With a rush, it brushes past you, tossing you as a leaf on the wind. As you crash to the ground, your confused mind grapples with the creature's unfathomable form. A perpetually unfolding butterfly of vibrant color is the best your mind can interpret from the nonsensical imagery you see.
I keep waking from a dream thinking I am a butterfly that dreams they are Pluto. {@spell Polymorph} screws with your head, man.

To look upon a lepidoptera confounds the mind, as its essence extends into multiple dimensions and the patterns of its form tessellate and refract. Once mesmerized by the spiral of its wings, one is lost in the unformed realms of infinity of the Space Between Worlds. The lepidoptera is simultaneously present in both the known world and the world beyond, bridging the borders between, confounding all on both sides of the divide.

Fractal lepidoptera emerge in Thin Places, or in areas where the northern and southern lights flutter across the sky. These places are a chrysalis to the lepidoptera in which it waits until its pattern infiltrates a realm so it can take flight. Slowly it extends the range of its pattern until all around it exists within the lines of its fractal. And yet it is not truly malevolent. The lepidoptera merely is, living and growing in more dimensions than humans can comprehend. In the dance of its motif and the flutter of a butterfly's wing, mortal lives are set in motion on a path outside of their own will.

The presence of a lepidoptera is recognizable when creatures start behaving repetitively and against their nature. A conspiracy of ravens sings together in syncopated rhythm; streams flow in unnatural direct paths up and down hills; children speak in haikus; hunting animals perpetually circle their prey that has long since died of hunger.

entries.name: Lair effect
entries: Fractal Lepidoptera transform reality around them, manifesting the following effect:

entries.name: Quantum Entanglement
entries: Creatures taking a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} within 1 mile of the lepidoptera must succeed on a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw or gain a pattern effect. Creatures can repeat the saving throw at the end of each {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} once they are outside the range of Quantum Entanglement. Casting {@spell Lesser Restoration} or similar spells of higher level on an affected creature can remove the pattern effect.

entries.caption: Fractal Lepidoptera Patterns
rows: Something unseen hampers you. You gain the {@condition Staggered|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition.
On each of your turns, you can only walk in straight lines in the direction of either north, south, east, or west.
Your hands start to flutter uncontrollably. You gain the {@condition Clumsy|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition.
You can only speak in haikus, rhyming couplets, or iambic pentameter.
You float an inch above the ground. Your walking {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is unchanged and {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} does not affect you.
You gain the ability to see polarized light and the ultraviolet spectrum. You see {@condition invisible} objects and creatures, and you can see into the Ethereal Plane.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a lepidoptera, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (5+) Mothlike Features
entries: You recognize its Phototaxis trait.

entries.name: (10+) Chaotic Patterns
entries: You learn the lepidoptera's Quantum Entanglement and Tessellation features.

entries.name: (15+) Multidimensional
entries: You know of the creature's Multidimensional Presence and Incomprehensible Vision features.

entries.name: (20+) Creature of Energy
entries: You are aware of its {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities} and Energy Form trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The lepidoptera flies through creatures while making Fractal Wing attacks, scattering foes with its Energy Form trait. If at least one enemy is {@condition Staggered|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, it targets them with Tessellation. The lepidoptera uses Criss Cross to protect itself from attacks on the border Ethereal Plane.

entries.name: Getting lost in the Border Ethereal Plane
entries: When encountering a Fractal Lepidoptera, characters can get stranded in the Border Ethereal Plane. This has the potential to derail a campaign. Here are a few suggestions on how to run this scenario instead:

items: When the lepidoptera dies, the fabric of reality temporarily weakens and everyone can safely return to the Prime Material Plane.

Immediately after the lepidoptera dies, the party needs to succeed in a skill challenge to traverse the veil between the planes. Each character can contribute to the skill challenge by suggesting actions that they take to help find the veil, withstand the pull of the Ethereal Plane, and open a gate.
The group succeeds if they make 4 successful DC 15 skill checks before 3 failures.
The characters must harvest the animus of the lepidoptera and craft a {@item fractal key|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries: A wise me once thought to myself, the longer you can go without getting hit, the better. that's free advice for you.

monsterFluff.name: Frenzied Dreg

entries: This muscular Dreg bounds on all fours towards you, its hands and feet are stretched out with almost talon-like claws, its hanging open mouth foams and drips, its eyes mad with a frenzied bloodlust.

The Frenzied Dreg is a faster, more muscular cousin to its shambling brethren. It hunts the streets of Drakkenheim, actively seeking out prey. It lurks in dark ruins, even occasionally taking to the sewers, or clambering up the sides of buildings. When a group of Frenzied Dregs find other lesser Dregs, they herd them into the streets and use them as a trap, luring adventurers to engage with them and waiting to strike

entries.name: (15+) Dangerous Hunter

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Leaping into the midst of combat, Frenzied Dregs chase down their foes and unleash a flurry of claws. Frenzied Dregs howl in fury as they bound upon their targets. So loud are their screams and screeches that it often attracts other Dregs and monsters to the area. Frenzied Dregs rarely flee; they pursue their enemies through Drakkenheim up to the edges of the Haze.

monsterFluff.name: Fungal Trolling

entries: Resembling a large purple and white mushroom, Fungal Trollings throb and ooze with overcharged energy. They appear ready to burst as their grim little expressions whine and wail.

Fungal Trollings are grown from the strange concoctions of Troll Hags. A {@creature Troll Hag|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} can grow hundreds of these creatures in their gardens within a very short amount of time. However, the trollings are prone to bursting if they get too excited. Only a small few ever grow to adulthood, becoming {@creature HUmongous Fungus Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Humongous Fungus Trolls}.

monsterFluff.name: Garmyr Berserker

entries: Mutated to massive size, Garmyr Berserkers become so violent and murderous they no longer see friend or foe, only meat for the slaughter. Kept {@condition restrained} by their packs, berserkers are unleashed during the hunt as living engines of destruction. Once the berserker starts swinging its axes, they become incredibly difficult to stop.
Although no less bloodthirsty, experienced Garmyr often become more patient and methodical hunters. They take up ranged weapons and prowl the streets, often leading small packs of their own.

Once engaged, the berserker is a mindless killer, and will attack the closest target to itself—whether an enemy or ally. Due to its madness, a berserker never flees.

monsterFluff.name: Garmyr Bloodhound

entries: Lurking behind the pack is a Garmyr wearing a tattered cloak and hood, leaving only its snarling snout exposed and its red eyes glowing from the dark shroud. Its aloof patience belies its predatory fury. It carries a wicked longbow strung with sinew, and its quiver bristles with thick, barbed arrows.
Although no less bloodthirsty, experienced Garmyr often become more patient and methodical hunters. They take up ranged weapons and prowl the streets, often leading small packs of their own.

The bloodhound chooses a quarry and focuses its attention on that target. Often, they are accompanied by other Garmyr who handle the ground assault, while the bloodhound focuses on slowing targets and using its allies to gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}. If its target flees, the Bloodhound marks it as its quarry and leads the hunt after it.
If the Garmyr Bloodhound sees its allies losing, it flees before its enemies can reach its vantage point.

monsterFluff.name: Garmyr Thaumaturge

entries: Practically a runt compared to the other Garmyr, this creature is draped in filthy white robes stained with blood and adorned with a crown of bones. It clutches in its gnarled and ancient clawed hand a staff of bone with bits of rotting flesh dangling from it and a human skull adorning the top. Its wide and toothy maw drips gore as its octarine eyes swirl with a mystical energy.

A few among the Garmyr develop magical abilities, though it is not clear whether these powers are the result of inborn sorcery or a magical connection to some otherworldly entity. Regardless of the true origins of their powers, Garmyr spellcasters become influential leaders within the pack. Indeed, adventurers have observed Garmyr Thaumaturges building bone-shrines and conducting blood rituals, and speculation suggests that these Garmyr heed the whispers of the Old God Kromac. Others would rather assume that somehow the eldest of the Garmyr have tapped into blood and carnage, twisted by the inherent magics of Drakkenheim, and infusing themselves with unknown blood rituals, chants, and incantations that harness these energies to fuel their rage and malice.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The thaumaturge wades into battle surrounded by its allies. It attempts to position itself in a central location so its Aura of the Blood Moon trait affects as many targets as possible. It will use its Blood Call to target creatures from range; only when it has more than one ally on a target does the Thaumaturge consider running in and attacking in melee.
The thaumaturge will attempt to escape any situation where it is cornered or forced into melee, and if its soldiers numbers are dwindling, it will flee to recuperate.

monsterFluff.name: Garmyr War Dog

entries: These large hunting dogs stalk forth in a gaunt and hunched manner. Their muscular, canine bodies are hairless and covered in scars from many battles. Walking on all fours, they are closer to their canine origins than that of their fellow Garmyr. Beady, red eyes peer out from sunken sockets, while a mouth of oversized, jagged teeth gnash and snarl.

Many of the local hunters had dogs as companions when the city was at its prime. Dogs were common house pets, hunters, and friends to many of the people inhabiting the city. When the meteor fell and everything changed, many believe the most proficient of the hunting dogs became the war dogs of the Garmyr. Holding closer to their canine origins, these hounds still roam the streets on the hunt for prey and support Garmyr warriors in battle.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Using Pack Tactics, the war dogs attack in numbers, ganging up on a single target, knocking it {@condition prone}, and ravaging it.

The war dogs are brutal fighters, and feel no fear, but if their numbers dwindle, they retreat to regroup. They prefer to attack as a pack, and with intention; if the battle becomes too chaotic and more than half their numbers are gone, they flee into the streets.

monsterFluff.name: Garmyr Warrior

entries: Blood dripping from its snarling fangs, its beady red eyes peering hungrily upon you, the canine warrior stands on its clawed feet clutching a spear, crudely made from scrap metal and wood, in it's hands. It is draped in trophies of its former kills, and its mottled fur is caked in blood from battle.

Garmyr warriors make up the brunt of the garmyr forces. They rely on each other in combat, knowing that hunting as a pack will give them the edge. They often look for means to ambush their prey, and overrun them. They are ferocious and relentless hunters who will track their prey for miles, but will never stray from the twisting streets of Drakkenheim. Several packs claim their hunting grounds and compete with one another over who can hold the most trophies of their kills, hoping to curry favor with The {@creature Lord of the Feast|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Garmyr warriors fight as a pack, following their leader on the hunt. They choose the juiciest, most delicious-looking target as their prey, favoring unarmored or feeble-looking creatures. Garmyr group up and focus their attacks until they bring down their target, unless a more dangerous threat prompts them to respond.

Garmyr crave blood and close-quarters battle, closing the distance to attack with their bites even when it may be more advantageous for them to keep their distance using their spears. Garmyr don't stop attacking a foe once they've downed them—they start feasting instead. Garmyr make Bite attacks against downed foes in the midst of battle, making {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} and dying characters especially vulnerable to the Garmyr's appetites.

Garymr are mostly heedless in battle unless their numbers are significantly cut down. Although they prefer to start battles when they outnumber their enemies, they flee as the fight turns against them. However, Garmyr might also attempt to flee once they've secured a meal—a group of Garmyr who manage to down one character in a group might decide to scoop up the victim and enjoy their meal elsewhere rather than continuing to fight.

items.name: Ghoul Lord

entries: This ghoul wears ancient, blackened armor and carries a rusted shield emblazoned with the symbol of House von Drakken. It wields a large mace crackling with green undead energy.
Some ghouls thirst for combat as much as human flesh and rise above the others as warriors and leaders. These undead creatures are generals of lesser ghouls, leading the charge in vampire armies.

items.name: Ghoul Priest

entries: Clad in a torn smock and a rusted chain shirt, this muttering ghoul clutches a twisted, bone-carved symbol of Kromac, a representation of the blasphemous god of slaughter.
The ghoul priest is a magically gifted, harnessing necrotic energies to pull ghouls back from the brink of death.

entries.name: Ghouls

entries: The emaciated figure has ash-white skin and is completely hairless. The monster's eyes are two pools of abyssal blackness. Its fingers end in long points, and its teeth are jagged. It lurches away from a fresh corpse it was feasting upon, blood and gore dripping from its maw as it sniffs the air. Smelling something alive, it knows another meal is close by. Its gaze turns in your direction.

Those who fail as vampiric thralls, disobey their masters, or simply outlast their usefulness are transformed into horrible ghouls. Through dark magic and blood rituals, the vampires rob these mortals of their mortality and humanity, issuing them a fate far worse than death. A ghoul is a cursed creature, bound to the will of a vampire and cursed with undead life. These ravenous minions make great foot soldiers in the undead armies of vampires who bide their time until they can rise from their castles with an undead army to conquer the realm of the living. Ghouls are more mindless and chaotic than a thrall and are less useful for the vampire's complex plots. But a vampire hates losing its minions, and so will keep upwards of a hundred ghouls locked in their crypts, ready to unleash upon the living world.

Some ghouls end up with a more coherent mind than others, able to command and organize lesser ghouls. Some have even developed magical capabilities, twisting necromancy to keep their fellow ghouls alive. When a vampire finds a ghoul rising above the others, and showcasing these unique talents, they often become generals and leaders in their undead army.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks when taking the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Ghoul, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (15+) Agile Attacker
entries: You are aware of its highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Ghouls are mindless and vicious. They charge towards enemies with an insatiable hunger for human flesh, and rarely flee from a fight. They can be easily {@condition distracted|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} by a fresh corpse to eat, and follow the whims of their masters. The hungrier the ghoul is, the less mindful it is, and the more aggressive it becomes.

Some vampires are known to starve their ghouls for months before unleashing them into battle. Although these ravenous ghouls are less coherent, their complete frenzied hunger makes them a much more dangerous threat.

Ghoul priests and Ghoul Lords often accompany larger arrangements of ghouls to help focus them towards their vampire master's enemies. The priests keep them fighting through mortal wounds while Ghoul Lords lead the charge into combat.

monsterFluff.name: Giant Ratling

entries: Towering over the furry horde around it, this ratling is nearly the size of an ogre. Its coarse and matted fur hangs in ragged patches, exposing sinewy muscles that ripple beneath its greasy skin. Oversized, jagged incisors protrude from its gnarled muzzle, and it brandishes its long, hooked claws slick with the dark sheen of old blood. Despite its bulk, the creature moves with an unsettling swiftness, its thick, scaly tail swaying menacingly to counterbalance the heavy thud of its gnarled paws.

Occasionally, a ratling just doesn't stop growing. Unfortunately, their brains seldom keep up with their growing bodies, as a result, most of the lumbering brutes are rather dim. These dumb hulks lumber forward into combat with total disregard for themselves or other ratlings, at times scooping up other warriors and throwing them towards their enemies. Some ratlings love this, and excitedly run alongside a Giant Ratling hoping to be hurled—sadly most don't survive the impact.

Giant Ratlings are the exception to the ratlings' rule of letting the biggest and strongest lead. Although these ratlings are often the largest of the pack, their inherent inability to lead, or form any strategic thought besides to smash and eat, makes them a great destructive force for a smarter ratling to use against its enemies. Often a ratling warlock or alchemist will command one or two Giant Ratlings and use them as living siege weapons, digging tools, or personal bodyguards against scheming ratlings looking to put a dagger in a superior's back.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (5+) Furry Monstrosities
entries: You understand these creatures have an excellent sense of smell, {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, and are capable climbers and swimmers. They are Immune to {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, but have no other special {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (10+) Grab and Bash
entries: You recognize the Giant Ratlings Hurl Ratling and Enrage actions.

entries.name: (15+) Powerful but Dimwitted
entries: You learn the creature's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Giant Ratling will charge any enemy it sees that threatens its burrow or gets in its way. The ratling will Enrage and start hurling other ratlings at its enemy as it charges forward, bearing down on the creature with claws and teeth. These brutes are relentless in their attacks, and generally much braver—or dumber—than other ratlings. They are unlikely to flee from harm.
If the rest of the ratlings begin to flee, the Giant Ratling will follow, but it will usually be the last to turn tail as it enjoys pummeling and gnawing on flesh a bit too much.

monsterFluff.name: Graffiti

entries: Walking through the rubble-strewn city streets, scraps of parchment and bits of faded street art still advertise the events, political intrigues, and foreign affairs of that fateful eve. Broadsheets from the day the meteor struck feature the headline "Queen Lenore's Latest Outfit: Blue or Gold?" while scandals of Elyrian nobility and an interview with the latest champion of the Rex Colosseum dominate below the fold. The nearby debris coalesces into a crowd of figures that press against you, seemingly straining to read the page's changing headline that now reads, "Adventurers Assaulted on the Streets of Drakkenheim!"

On September 16, in the year 1,111, at 9:02am, strange graffiti appeared on the front door of the Drakkenheim Gazette. This defacement would prove to be a harbinger of doom, for when the meteor struck that woeful eve, a wave of arcane energy fused the heraldic street art with the spirits of the Gazette's couriers, creating a bizarre creature called the Graffiti.

The graffiti delights in using illusions to change road signs, disguise landmarks, and otherwise confuse travelers. Given its predilection for drama, some suggest that bold travelers with enticing words might win the support of the Graffiti, though none alive have claimed to have succeeded.
They say on rare mornings an {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} can strike within sight of a Graffiti, conjuring another Graffiti to seek the latest events within Drakkenheim.

entries.name: (5+) Reforming Words

entries.name: (10+) Manifesting Visions

entries.name: (15+) Magical Erasure
entries: You are aware of the creature's Solvent Susceptibility and Antimagic Susceptibility traits.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: When a creature draws a Graffiti's attention, it uses illusions to confuse its targets. It then uses Summon Public Opinion and watches the drama unfold. To keep things interesting, the Graffiti uses its Transposition ability to see how creatures respond to situations when they're forced to approach them from new perspectives.

When the graffiti is in the heart of the action, it targets the most influential creature with Satire. Should the graffiti decide its target is sufficiently entertaining, or dangerous, it will flee the situation. If the graffiti is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it plays dead and then escapes at the first opportunity.
