monsterFluff.name: Gravekeeper

entries: Before you is a hovering mass of writhing appendages. Amongst its horrid and grotesque form you can make out the many faces of the long-lost gravekeepers of Castle Drakken, but their expressions are twisted in the horror of their last moments, and their eyes are hollow with a dim octarine light emanating from within. Covering the floating mass are hundreds of arms, several of them holding softly glowing lanterns. The lanterns glow with octarine flames that cast flickering shadows across the crypt. The Gravekeeper wanders amongst the dead, awakening them into grasping souls, clawing their way out of the many graves amongst the lordly tombs of the castle.

The Royal Crypts below Castle Drakken housed the bodies of kings and queens, dukes and nobles of generations gone. They were tended by the many gravekeepers who worked diligently to light the lanterns below so the dead could have safe passage to the light. I shudder to think what has become of those crypts, and their keepers, in these dark times.
entries.from: —Overheard from a party of nobles in the Red Lion Hotel

entries: The seeping contamination within the castle formed a deadly octarine sludge that came to rest in the deepest parts of the catacombs below. The unfortunate fate of the royal dead of Drakkenheim was to be lost in the contaminated sludge that now rests as a thick pool in the crypts. The former gravekeepers used to tend to the crypts with illuminated lanterns that lit the way for the dead. They would tend to the crypts and keep them clean. They were sworn to protect the royal dead from graverobbers or any intruders. When the cataclysm of Drakkenheim sent waves of contaminated destruction through the city, the gravekeepers mutated into a mass of limbs and screaming faces, merged with several of the dead that were housed in the crypts, while still clutching their many lanterns.

The mind of the Gravekeeper was warped by contamination and now it acts as a hivemind for the dead in the crypts. The dead now reach from their graves causing the walls and pillars of the Drakkenheim crypts to appear as a mass of undead arms, grasping and groaning. The thick sludge below bubbles and ripples and at times gouts of contaminated goo spray upwards, seemingly on the command of the keeper of the crypt.

Now the creature known as the Gravekeeper drifts silently through the crypts, its control over its domain flowing through every corpse. The creature is still bound to uphold the tasks it held in life; protect the dead from any intruders and tend to the crypts.

monsterFluff.name: Grim Custodian

entries: Dressed in fine noble's clothes, the vampiric creature licks its lips, revealing its protruding fangs, as it holds quill and parchment in its hands, scribbling notes. The creature keeps its keen eye on those in the room before it.

The Grim Custodian is the right hand to many vampire masters. They have secured themselves a position as an invaluable member of the vampire's inner circle. They do their master's bidding in exchange for access to the finer aspects of vampirism. Grim Custodians work as bookkeepers, keepers of secrets, informants, and caretakers of the many undead who inhabit the castles and manors of vampires.

The Grim Custodian is capable of plucking the strings of death to some degree; the custodians are able to raise corpses up to serve the bidding of its master. It has been said that many vampiric soldiers who fall on the battlefield rise up once more when a Grim Custodian is nearby. Many of the skeleton and zombie minions work under the command of these custodians.

The Grim Custodian also serves the critical purpose of maintaining the illusion of mortal life around their vampire masters. Vampires thrive when the humans surrounding them believe they are nothing more than ordinary monarchs or nobles. The Grim Custodian maintains this guise, keeping any illusions in place and foiling attempts to see through them.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Grim Custodian does everything in their power to avoid combat, liberally using {@spell Suggestion} and {@spell Detect Thoughts}. When directly confronted and with no one to protect them, they cast {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} on themselves and flee. They focus on hiding their undead nature. Grim Custodians can use {@spell Nystul's Magic Aura|XPHB|Arcanist's Magic Aura} and {@spell nontection} to foil divinations which would otherwise detect them, and {@spell Major Image} and Seeming to further disguise the truth.

monsterFluff.name: Grotesque Gargantuan

entries: A monumental behemoth casts a shadow across the broken ground ahead. It is a giant standing over fifty feet tall, but its form is a horrifying spectacle of mutation, with limbs grotesquely elongated and thickened, pulsing with a disturbing energy. Across its hulking body, sharp, glowing fragments of delerium are embedded deep within the flesh. The creature's small, sharp-featured face is set with piercing eyes that burn with a relentless, haunting glow, while its massive legs carry its enormous frame with a heavy, resonant tread that echoes ominously through the desolate landscape. Enormous, jagged claws protrude from its fingertips, dragging furrows into the earth as it moves, leaving a trail of shattered stone and upturned soil in its wake.

These mutated human monstrosities have grown to tremendous size. {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium shards} are merged into their disfigured bodies, and their muscles pulse with arcane energies as they lumber forward. Furiously territorial, these creatures are occasionally sighted hauling massive {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} from the crater and placing them like obelisks in the ruins.

No one knows why these peculiar Gargantuans place {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} in odd patterns, carving lines in the dirt to connect them. It's unclear whether these are random acts or convey some eldritch message. The prevailing theory suggests that these formations are linked to numerous Thin Places reported throughout the city. It remains a mystery whether these Thin Places already existed and are merely being marked by the Gargantuans, or if the Gargantuans are strategically placing delerium to open planar gates.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (15+) Crystal Missiles

entries.name: (20+) Nearly Indestructible
entries: You learn of its Regeneration trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Grotesque Gargantuans are violently territorial creatures. Unlike the randomly mutated creatures found throughout the Haze, these hideous entities are more in tune with the arcane elements of Drakkenheim. Their form appears more intentional, as does their purpose, though the truth behind this intention remains a mystery

Gargantuans often drag chunks of delerium along with them, and their massive arms can swing or throw them with ease. They place the stones in odd formations around the city and, if witnessed by another creature who isn't a Dreg or a Haze Hulk, they will violently lash out and chase the observerer down. The Gargantuan hurls huge boulders of delerium at them. Whatever their intention is, they will not abandon their territory, or their work, and rarely flee from the site they are working in.

monsterFluff.name: Gutbuster Hulk

entries: The massive creature slumps forward on two stocky legs with bloated and bleeding feet. Its huge gut drags along the ground with several open sores weeping with puss and ichor. Its face is buried in multiple chins as acidic drool drips down them, running down its belly. It opens its mouth as it lets out a gurgling moan, and it reaches into one of its open sores, pulling out a pile of pus-covered contaminated meat. It rears back to hurl the fetid flesh at you.

The Gutbuster Hulk is a grotesque creation of eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Its body has swollen to a massive size, and it continuously mutates to produce more and more rotting flesh that seems to ooze out of the creature. It tears at itself and pulls its guts apart, only to have them replaced with more growths inside. This creates a grim display as the Gutbuster throws its contaminated flesh at its enemies and vomits bile upon them.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Gutbuster is a massive, bloated hulk that constantly grows fleshy masses within its ever expanding belly. If left unchecked, a Gutbuster Hulk can grow to proportions so large that it crushes itself under its own weight. Ratlings love when this happens—it supplies them with food for weeks.

The Gutbuster maintains its form by ripping chunks of flesh from its body, hurling them at enemies. This contaminated flesh erupts in a shower of gore and necrotic fluids. A Gutbuster usually opens with this attack to ward off foes, and then waits for more flesh to grow to hurl it again. If its enemies close in around it, it uses its Bile Blast to coat the creatures in acid, or will Slam them with its massive fists.
The Gutbuster is slower moving than other Haze Hulks and rarely runs from a fight.

monsterFluff.name: Gutwretch Dreg

entries: The abdomen of this Dreg is split wide open, its guts spilling and hanging out of it. Within its internal organs are several mutations, including a strange growth connected to its intestines that looks like a bulbous mass in the shape of a mutated and distorted face. The Dreg holds its intestines in its hand like a flail, preparing to launch them towards you.
The Gutwretch Dreg uses its mutated internal organs as a weapon. It is a violent Delerium Dreg that launches its gut flail towards anyone who tries to get close to it.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Gutwretch Dreg keeps its distance from other combatants, watching all creatures who dare approach while swinging its flail over its head. It often protects other Dregs, standing watch over them while they eat or tend to other matters.

The Dreg uses its Reactive trait, as well as its Flailing Guts {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to knock creatures out of its way the moment they come near. It will always try to move away from direct combat, preferring to keep its enemies at arm's length so it can continue to pummel them with its Gut Flail.
The Gutwretch Dreg will fight to protect its fellow Dregs and is often the last one to flee from combat.

monsterFluff.name: Haze Hulk

entries: This hulking mutant stands over ten feet tall, its swollen body grown beyond normal human proportions. Its rippling muscles and engorged veins pulse beneath its thin discolored skin. The hulk's flesh has split open in places over its body, barely able to contain the bulging and expanding sinew of its tree-trunklike limbs and wide torso. Its head, however, is strangely small given the size of its body, though it wears a furious expression upon its broad, flat face. Plodding toward you on thumping, gigantic feet, it curls its massive hands into a cannonball-like fist. Letting out a fierce roar, it reveals its jagged rows of teeth and elongated tongue.

Contamination often causes creatures to vastly increase in size and muscle mass, becoming more like lumbering ogres or giants. Delerium Dregs who grow beyond the proportions of normal humans are typically called "Haze Hulks." These lumbering forms, like their Dreg cousins, can take on many variations of mutations and growths as part of their contaminated existence. Haze Hulks are much more deadly, and much more ferocious, than a normal Dreg.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Haze Hulks are often found amongst other Dregs; they have the same general disposition and similar qualities as a common Delerium Dreg. However, when agitated or threatened, a Haze Hulk's ferocity outshines the Dreg's by a long shot. It will attack any creature it sees as a threat to itself or its fellow Dregs. The Haze Hulk will barrel in head first towards its foes, attempting to Trample them, slamming them with its massive fists. It is a relentless attacker and rarely flees from combat.

monsterFluff.name: Haze Husk

entries: The walking dead wander Drakkenheim draped in the ragged clothes from their final day. Their wounds billow with eldritch energy and their putrid flesh slides over their bones. Hollow black eyes stare, and their gaping mouths groan in pain. Each face wears the agony of their last moments while shards of delerium protrude from their skin.

The Haze reanimates those who died in Drakkenheim to mindlessly wander as zombies. Most Haze Husks are those who perished when the meteor struck, while others died exploring the ruins, remaining near where they fell.

While dead bodies do not decay in the ruins, over time even undead flesh is warped by contamination. Their skeletons slowly crystallizing into delerium, eventually bursting through their skin. When damaged, a Haze Husk's unstable crystals often break, releasing contaminated energy and splintered shards.

Haze Husks ignore most contaminated monsters but attack all others. They do not eat their victims, preferring to lie in wait until the dead rise to join them. Left on their own, they rarely travel far from where they died, but if commanded, they will follow more powerful undead, such as Haze Wights and Arcane Wraiths, who recruit them into a sort of militia or retinue.

entries.name: Reanimated by the Haze
entries: Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 5th level (or Challenge Rating 5) or lower has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Husk.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Haze Husk, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Unintelligent Undead
entries: You know these creatures are clumsy, relatively weak, and nearly mindless.

entries.name: (15+) Volatile Corpse
entries: You are aware of the Haze Husk's Death Burst.

entries.name: (20+) Made With Delerium
entries: You understand that it's possible to create these husks with delerium and the appropriate necromancy magic.

entries.name: (25+) Blind to Contamination
entries: Haze Husks seem to ignore contaminated monsters; a partially mutated person might avoid a Haze Husk's attention.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: In combat, Haze Husks lunge at the closest target without tactics or concern for self-preservation, battering down doors and clambering over obstacles in pursuit. When commanded by other undead or a spellcaster who created them, they are more capable, and can be ordered to remain at heel.

A character with one or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels and at least one mutation may be able to pass themselves off as a contaminated monster to a Haze Husk. Doing so successfully requires a DC 15 Charisma (Performance or Deception) check, which Charms the Haze Husk for 1 minute.

items.name: Haze Regent Lenore von Kessel
entries: Curing Lenore's contamination is a vexing problem. Due to her madness, she manipulates any who try to help, twisting them to further her contaminated power. As Lenore's mutations evolve, she may become an even greater threat than before.

monsterFluff.name: Haze Wight

entries: The stretched skin of this undead warrior is purple and bruised. Clad in broken armor, a deep gash in its breastplate marks the lethal blow that ended its life. Eldritch magic wells within the wound. As it catches sight of you, its face twists into a hateful scowl. Its dead eyes burn with spectral energy and contaminated magic seeps from blackened claws. In a cracked voice, it howls a delusional challenge: "To arms, comrades! Drakkenheim will be free of these monsters!"

Madness awaits those who too often venture into the ruins. Not even the dead are spared, as those who fall here may rise again as Haze Wights. These undead retain a semblance of their former intellect and personality but twisted by delusion, despair, and malice. Imbued with contaminated power, they often raise Haze Husks to fight alongside them.

Many Haze Wights believe they are great heroes rallying the common folk against invaders, but in their madness, they see all humanoids as monsters. Like their Haze Husk minions, Haze Wights generally ignore contaminated monsters and treat them like "fair citizens" of the city. Groups of Haze Wights may act as if they are still a party of explorers, monster hunters, or part of a military expedition. In battle, they launch contaminated energy as if making skillful sword swipes, deft crossbow fire, or streaking magical blasts.

Haze Wights are often encountered in groups including a small retinue of Haze Husks and sometimes even an Arcane Wraith. In their madness, they believe their ability to reanimate Haze Husks is an inspiring battle command, a prayer of healing, or a call for reinforcements.

entries.name: Reanimated by the Haze
entries: Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 6th level (or Challenge Rating 6) or higher has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Wight.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Haze Wight, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Delusional Undead
entries: You recognize that these creatures think they are still alive, and that we are the monsters!

entries.name: (15+) Contaminated Eldritch Power
entries: You are aware of the Haze Wight's Contaminated Blast.

entries.name: (20+) Awaken Minions
entries: You know of the creature's Animate Haze Husk Bonus Action.

entries.name: (25+) Made With Delerium
entries: You understand that it's possible to create these zombies with delerium and the {@spell Animate Dead|XPHB} spell (see the Creating Haze Husks sidebar).

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Haze Wights are intelligent warriors who can engage in melee or ranged combat. However, they mistakenly believe their foes are mindless monsters not requiring careful tactics, seeing most targets as beasts to be put down. When a foe demonstrates unexpected magic or strategy, some fight more carefully, commanding minions to surround and corner their opponents.

Groups of these wights sometimes believe they are still-living, acting as if they still possess their former abilities, using teamwork and "healing" each other by reanimating the fallen as Haze Husks. Nevertheless, their delusions render them incapable of imagining defeat; they do not flee when wounded, nor when allies fall. Instead, they believe they fight in a heroic last stand, desperately rallying against the inevitable doom they already suffered.

monsterFluff.name: Hazeblood Vampire

entries: The undead creature has pale skin and sharp fangs. Its eyes glow with delerium light, and its extended limbs end in over-sized clawed hands and feet. Its veins glow through its skin with a purple hue and you see the abnormalities protruding from its flesh. Tentacles, extra eyes, and mouths emerge across its body.

Vampires have an innate ability to both gain and purge delerium {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} from themselves by drinking blood. When a vampire drinks the blood of a contaminated creature, they take that {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} into themselves, but when a contaminated vampire drinks the blood of an uncontaminated creature, they can cleanse themselves in turn. However, this only works to a point: once a vampire has gained enough {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} to prompt a Monstrous ransformation, they become a disheveled vampiric Delerium Dreg: a Hazeblood Vampire.

This curious interaction has prompted some vampires to experiment with contaminated magic, perhaps as a shortcut to gaining the power of an ascendant vampire. Countess Constance Kleinkessel has fostered the research of her apothecary Deidrick Mors, hoping his work might yield potential. She has collected countless test subjects for Mors by transforming villagers in Kesselholm into vampire spawn, and then chaining them in coffins below her castle. There, Mors exposes them to delerium or forces them to drink the blood of contaminated creatures. Thus far, the experiments have yet to create a vampire monstrosity that is stronger, faster, and more terrifying than any other, but perhaps Mors is closing in on a breakthrough...

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: These vampires are riddled with contamination and simply attack any creature they are pointed towards. Their Contaminated Bites can spread contamination as they tear into their foes. They do not have the mind to retreat from a battle.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewind Harpy Crone

entries: The crone perches atop a stoop, its elegant wings unfurl, revealing a massive, 12-foot wingspan that vividly shimmers green, blue, violet, and gold. Unlike most harpies, it lacks arms. Its taloned feet clutch its perch, while matted, white hair falls upon wrinkled, sagging flesh. Sitting atop a long neck, its face seems distorted, bearing a hooked nose and pointed chin—its grin too wide, its teeth too sharp, and its eyes too large and white. Adorned with feathered necklaces, earrings, and a crown of golden ivy, it sings a chorus of unsettling notes, seemingly glowing with radiant light.

Hazewind Harpy Crones are the elders of their communities. Their songs tell of the generations of battles, triumphs, and sorrows of their broods. Harpies see them as oracles and sages, with their songs shared through the ages, but to those who threaten harpies, the crones stand as beacons of power. Their voices fill mortals with dread and foreboding of a coming doom. Few who hear these songs have lived to tell about them.

In Drakkenheim's streets, it's often easy to recognize when one is in harpy territory. Areas of the city left with belfries, towers, and places for harpies to roost often echo with distant melodies—a chorus of heavenly voices, twisted in discordant dissonance. The sound seems sweet, but is laced with uncomfortable notes. Many areas of Drakkenheim are filled with these songs. If you hear them, you know you are in hazewind territory.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a crone, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Dangerous Melodies

entries.name: (15+) Entrancing but Weak

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Hazewind Harpy Crone avoids direct combat. Her songs have a great range, allowing her to perch atop hard-to-reach places, while her songs help her more combat-focused sisters in battle. These songs empower ally attacks, while the Breakneck Hymns increase the falling damage of plummeting enemies. If creatures come too close, she may use her Mesmerizing Melody and move elsewhere.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewind Harpy Hunter

entries: This mutated creature resembles a human crossed with a red-feathered bird of prey. The harpy has great wings which end in claw-like hands in place of arms, their avian legs end in talons, and they have a feathered plume and tail feathers. They grasp their weapons in their taloned feet as they bear themselves aloft, adroitly aiming an elegant longbow.

The typical Hazewind Harpy Hunter is a skilled airborne killer, able to fly at high speeds while aiming their bow with deadly accuracy. They spend their days soaring over the city streets, taking their pick of prey in the streets below. Although they are perfectly happy to survive on ratlings, they are drawn to the weapons, treasure, and trinkets carried by explorers and faction agents, and eagerly attack for an opportunity at a meal with a prize.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Harpies hunt in small flocks, and always attack from the sky or an overhead vantage point using their longbows. They engage in melee only to make the killing blow on a wounded target. When confronted with a foe able to make effective ranged attacks, harpies become much more cautious. Accurate shots from the ground or an exploding airborne {@spell Fireball|XPHB} may be enough alone to shake their resolve, causing them to fly off in search of easier prey.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie

entries: Adorned in glimmering half-plate, carrying shields and javelins, these elite warriors stare unblinking with blood-red eyes beneath plumed helmets. Their lower halves are free to allow their talons to grasp and pull at their enemies.

Valkyries are the best warriors among the hazewinds. They have faced battles before, survived, and honed their fighting skills. They have practiced their maneuverability, quick strikes, and ability to cover distance. Relying on keeping to the air, pinpointing weak targets, and plucking them off their feet to toss them, valkyries keep to the tops of buildings and towers. Those who cannot fly always face the dire reality of falling to their death.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie are the chosen warriors of the Crimson Countess, and they are skilled with both their weapons and their talons. They wield barbed javelins and a shield in their hands, and leave their taloned feet open to pluck people off the ground and toss them. They often attempt to lure foes into elevated positions, such as rooftops, cliffs, or balconies, and then pluck them up and toss them to their death.
If they find themselves grounded, or outnumbered they will attempt to escape and fly to the highest location nearby to guard themselves and better defend against attackers.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewing Moth Adult

entries: This large moth has brilliantly patterned wings that glimmer purple and green. The delicate membranes feature hypnotic shapes that resemble screaming human faces. The creature has a grotesque bat-like face with a curved antenna sprouting from its forehead ending in a bioluminescent lantern that gives off splashes of prismatic light. Its eyes are a mosaic-like fractal, and delerium dust drifts around it as it flaps about.

Adult Hazewing Moths no longer consume {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}. Instead, they seek out mates and psychic forces to sustain themselves. The moths hypnotize their victims and drink their personalities and memories, gaining nourishment from the psychic forces of their prey. The memories and nightmares of the slain appear on the wings and chrysalis of the next generation of moths.

entries.name: (15+) Intellect Eater

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Adult Hazewing Moths are protective of the eggs, caterpillars, and cocoons of others of their kind, and use their abilities to defend the clutch. The moths use their Hypnotic Flutter and Delerium Dust to send their targets into a near catatonic state before they flutter down to drink the target's psychic energy using their Proboscis.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewing Moth Caterpillar

entries: The undulating body of this monstrous caterpillar bristles with sharp, luminescent spines. The creature's skin is a disturbing tapestry of purples and greens, throbbing with an eerie, bioluminescent glow.

The larval form of the Hazewing Moth is a disgusting, hairy, purring caterpillar. Using their strange mandibles, Hazewing Moth Caterpillars are able to slowly feed on and consume {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} by secreting a specially adapted saliva which turns crystalized delerium into sludge, that the caterpillars drink. The caterpillars metabolize this into a dust which coats their wings as adults.

entries: The caterpillar hungers for {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}, which may divert its attention.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Hazewing Moth Caterpillar is always seeking its next meal and attacks without discretion, wriggling towards the closest target to Bite them. The caterpillars continue to eat and Bite a downed character even in combat if they aren't being actively attacked. While it's happy to consume living flesh, a Hazewing Caterpillar is eager to feed on delerium. Characters may be able to draw its attention or even render it docile by offering it a shard or two and making a successful DC 15 Animal Handling check.

monsterFluff.name: Hazewing Moth Chrysalis

entries: Thick silvery strands fasten this bulbous glowing cocoon against a nearby wall. Within its crystalline shell, something pulses with unnerving, face-like patterns. These spectral visages seem to gasp and moan in silence. A thin mist rises off the surface of the chrysalis.

Once a Hazewing Moth Caterpillar has eaten its fill of delerium, it finds a secure place to wrap itself in a protective cocoon and begin the process of transforming into an adult. Filled with digested crystals, these cocoons magnify the presence of the Haze nearby, creating a potent natural defense for the otherwise immobile and vulnerable creatures.

monsterFluff.name: He Who Laughs Last

entries: The bloated demon lord descends, his wings unfurling like a curtain falling at the end of a tragedy. Holding a skull in one clawed hand, he is garbed in black-and-white checkered patterns, featuring a great belt of skulls and a frilled doublet made from finger bones. The skin upon his leering face has peeled away, revealing a mask-like goat skull beneath which frowns on one side and grins on the other. His appearance is almost like that of a great, macabre clown. His bellowing laughter resounds in your ears, stirs the blood, shakes the bones, and chills the soul.

He Who Laughs Last is a primordial demon of death and decay. Profoundly nihilistic yet strangely mirthful, this archfiend revels in the drama and theatrics of mortal existence, seeing life itself as a cosmic joke. To him, each moment is merely a meaningless scene in the grand tragicomedy of the universe. His spiteful laugh echoes through the corridors of time and space. Legend tells it will be the final sound at the end of all things — when the curtain falls on existence itself. He Who Laughs Last believes this to be his perverse destiny, and this purported knowledge fuels his interactions with mortals, who he regards as powerless pawns in the great play of life and death.

any undead creatures are believed to be his designs, mocking curses the demon lord has lain upon humanity for his own sick entertainment. Given his mastery over such dark magic, He Who Laughs Last is often sought by necromancers, warlocks, and other arcane practitioners alike as an instructor or patron. Furthermore, He Who Laughs Last often makes eldritch pacts offering power, knowledge, and the promise of escape from mortality. In particular, the demon lord is believed to know the blasphemous rituals required to transform a mortal spellcaster into an abhorrent lich. Rather than bargain for the souls of his petitioners, however, He Who Laughs Last demands they collect the souls of others instead. He cares not for the method, only that the quota is fulfilled. The demon lord hungers for mortal souls not for the power they contain — although that is certainly a factor — but because he enjoys keeping soul-puppets to entertain himself by replaying the tragedies of their lives.

he Theatre of the Danse Macabre is the domain of He Who Laughs Last. Located in the dark pits of the abyss, this fiendish citadel resembles a great theatre-in-the-round made from bone and blood. There, the collected souls of He Who Laughs Last are bound eternally among the shadowy players and audience members, where they must continually perform tragic stories and watch the dark circus play out.

Although the demon lord's followers are a common target for Knights of the Silver Order, the fiend himself has a particular enmity amongst worshippers of the Old God Morrigan, the goddess of death and magic. He Who Laughs Last often appears to desperate penitents and heretical priests of the Old God, occasionally even impersonating the deity to trick and deceive her devoted followers into creating undead creatures and participating in his schemes.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Adventurers who interact with He Who Laughs Last must endure his mocking laughter and jeering comments, as he remarks on the futility of their actions, the dramatic irony of their mistakes, and the meaninglessness of their quests. In doing so, He Who Laughs Last carefully offers an escape or solution—if the adventurers will offer him service in exchange, one that is almost certain to have unforeseen consequences.

entries.name: Personality Traits
entries: In conversation, I cannot contain my dark mirth, which manifests from a low chuckle to a belly-bursting guffaw. Most of all, I love the moment when mortals realize the cost of their terrible mistakes and poor decisions.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Mortals fear death. I play upon that fear, and with it I can catch the conscience of any soul.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I harvest of souls at life's curtain call, binding them to my cast of players in my Theatre of the Danse Macabre.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I oft direct the play too long, delighting in extending the final act. My patience is as deep as the grave, allowing me to savor each move in the mortal game, though sometimes to the detriment of a timely demise.

He Who Laughs Last loves nothing more than when mortal heroes attempt to outmaneuver him. As befitting his name, there is almost always some unfortunate upset or surprise twist the demon has in store. Even when he is seemingly defeated, he is always sure to remind his foes who will have the last laugh.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (20+) Powerful Demonlord.
entries: You are aware of his {@sense Truesight|XPHB} and telepathy, his {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, and his Epic

entries.name: Resistance.
entries: You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed.

entries.name: (25+) Killing Aura.
entries: You know of his Mortal Coil aura, and his spellcasting Epic Actions.

entries.name: (30+) Powerful Presence.
entries: You know his highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: He Who Laughs Last approaches battle lazily, as his mere presence causes mortals to die in short order from his Mortal Coil aura. Nevertheless, he casually ends lives using Sleep No More, Dusty Death, and Out Brief Candle, trapping another foe in a Cage of Sorrows so they must bear witness to the death around them before they expire to his Mortal Coil.

He Who Laughs Last does not fear his own destruction, confident that he will reappear if his corporeal form is destroyed. He is certain of his fate to watch the end of the universe, and even when slain his echoing laughter remains as a grim reminder of his power.

monsterFluff.name: Helpful Hand

entries: Skittering out from the shadows is a grotesque parody of a hand, desiccated and skeletal, its bony fingers clicking against the floor. The creature moves with an unsettling agility, crawling up walls and across ceilings with ease. As you watch, its sharp, talon-like digits flex and twitch, ready to jab or latch onto its next victim.

Every apothecary could use an extra set of hands. Overstretched apothecaries use Helping Hands in a variety of ways: fetching tools and ingredients, taking notes, sending messages, holding open ribcages, and assigning them to suturing or administering concoctions to a patient.

entries.name: Player Character Familiars
entries: Subject to GM approval, an apothecary with the Laboratory Assistant esoteric theory can create a Helpful Hand or Speaking Skull to serve them using the {@spell Find Familiar|XPHB} spell. A familiar created in this manner always acts in combat immediately after its creator's turn. It can use its special attacks in its stat block only if the apothecary uses a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on their turn to command the familiar to take one of those actions.

items.name: High Flamekeeper Ophelia Reed

entries: A stout woman in her late forties with rich brown skin stands invitingly before you. Her warm smile is framed by rounded features and braided hair. She wears the flowing gold and white robes of a Flamekeeper of the Sacred Flame. She carries a silvered staff and a censer with a {@spell Continual Flame|XPHB} spell cast upon it.

Ophelia Reed is one of the most renowned Flamekeepers in the Silver Order. She has been granted charge overseeing the efforts in Drakkenheim to ensure the Sacred Flame is represented, and the goals of the church and Divine Matriarch are kept during such trying times.

entries.name: Personality Traits
entries: I attentively listen to others and respond from a place of warmth and kindness.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I will always seek the right remedy for any ailment or problem, offering my patient guidance to those who ask for it.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I have taken a vow of poverty and devoted my life to the service of the Sacred Flame.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: Darkness is all-consuming once it has taken root. For some, death is the only salvation.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Ophelia is a powerful divine figure and is often accompanied by many Silver Order paladins and cavaliers. In combat she often defaults to buffing her allies more so than attacking directly, but will use her spiritual weapon liberally against foes who threaten her. If she can end an encounter using {@spell Banishment|XPHB} or {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB}, she will opt for that. Otherwise she relies on {@spell Bless|XPHB}, {@spell Guidance|XPHB}, and {@spell Healing Word|XPHB} to keep her allies in the fight.
She will flee if her paladin knights demand her to, or if most of them have been slain or she is left alone in a threatening situation.

items.name: Hooded Lantern Apothecary

entries: Hooded Lantern Apothecaries are the Lanterns' field medics. Called Apothecaries, they are distinct from other Hooded Lanterns, often wearing a white tunic with a simple green Hooded Lanterns insignia. They have a leather hood and typically carry a large doctor bag and a bandelier of vials for various ailments or poisons. They carry several medical instruments on their belt.

Apothecaries are trained field medics who support the Hooded Lanterns in battle with helping their wounded stay in the fight, and saving severely injured soldiers, pulling them to safety or administering emergency procedures in the midst of battle. Although an apothecary will rarely move beyond the Support Regiments, they are some of the most renowned and respected Hooded Lanterns. Every field medic has the stories of many Lanterns who would have been dead if it wasn't for their bravery in the face of the horrors of Drakkenheim.
Having an apothecary around can help if you've had a bad day. Of course, a good sword can prevent a bad day from ever happening.

items.name: Hooded Lantern Scout

entries: This lightly-armored urban scout is armed with a grapple gun, flare gun, shortsword, and longbow. They wear tight and simple garb to help them with mobility, with patches of boiled leather to protect critical areas. A simple green cloak and hood signify their allegiance to the Lanterns.

The forward patrols of the Watch Regiment, scouts are members of the Hooded Lanterns who are not yet ready for the intense field work of the Vanguard, but have proven themselves capable of navigating the ruins and remaining hidden in the streets. They operate as the eyes and ears of the Hooded Lanterns, keeping reports on the monster groups moving through the city. Not only will scouts be on constant patrols within a few blocks of secured Hooded Lantern bases, but also often move ahead of Vanguard Regiments to report any problems ahead of important missions. Scouts use their flare guns to signal issues ahead, calling in the more heavily armed Vanguard to deal with the issue.
Very reliable are the scouts of the Hooded Lanterns however with great eyes come weak abdomens.

items.name: Hooded Lantern Trapper

entries: This Hooded Lantern field agent wears a green tunic emblazoned with the symbol of the Hooded Lanterns, and a belt heavy with hanging tools, satchels of powders, and vials of liquids. Their large backpack is loaded with rope, animal traps, containers, small wooden kegs and boxes, and all sorts of gear for building and setting traps in the field. The Trapper wears thick leather boots and gloves, heavy worker goggles, and a dirt smeared face with wild hair.

The Hooded Lantern Trapper is one of the field operatives of the Support Regiment. Their job is twofold: they are both a hunter who keeps the Lanterns fed with fresh meats, berries, and foraged goods from the woods outside of Drakkenheim, as well as lays traps and ambushes for special operations inside the city walls. Trappers are well equipped with various tools and alchemical ingredients for building advanced traps for dismantling groups of monsters and helping give the Vanguard Regiments the advantage.
The Hooded Lanterns traps can be as deadly to monsters as I am, but I require less preparation.

items.name: Hooded Lantern Veteran

entries: These Hooded Lanterns are garbed in dark and rustic armor whose colors match and blend with the city ruins of Drakkenheim. They wear cloaks of deep green and carry well-made precision longbows. They wear masks that cover their nose and mouths to limit the sound of their breathing, and are equipped with grapple guns to scale walls quickly.

Rooftop snipers are members of the Vanguard Regiment and are exceptionally skilled at pinpoint accuracy with bows. They tend to stick to high vantage points and are a key part of any Hooded Lantern ambush. Rooftop snipers often travel in a group and will locate their enemies, find multiple vantage points to surround them, and wait for the opportune moment to strike. Often accompanied by scouts and other ground forces, one may suspect they know the number of Hooded Lanterns they are facing, and rarely account for the unseen snipers above them.
I've never had a bad day in Drakkenheim, except the first day, and maybe one more.

entries.name: Hooded Lanterns
entries: The Hooded Lanterns are an irregular military force drawn from remnants of the old Drakkenheim City

Watch and veterans of the Westemr Civil War, led by the grim Lord Commander Elias Drexel. They wish to drive out the monsters and outlaws who infest their nation's capital, find an heir to the throne, and restore the realm of Westemr.

The Hooded Lanterns are divided into three regiments which occupy the city and the areas surrounding it. New recruits joining the Lanterns are often first put into the Support Regiment. They make up the chefs, apothecaries, scribes, and maintenance workers at every Hooded Lantern fortification. Many of those positions are held by folk who will never move beyond the Support Regiment, and their job is valuable to the foundations of the Hooded Lanterns.

The Watch Regiment defend the walls and gates of any Lantern-controlled location. Oftentimes, if the Vanguards manage to gain a new foothold in the city, a group of Hooded Lanterns Watch are sent to hold the new position and ensure it remains in the Hooded Lanterns' hands. They also often operate as scouts in the field. Not specifically aiming for tactical engagement or large-scale battles, but they are the eyes and ears of the Lanterns throughout the city and occasionally clean up wandering monsters from the streets near their bases.

The Vanguard Regiment are the front line of the Hooded Lanterns. They are skilled combatants, who know their way around the ruins of the city and can find vantage points, plan ambushes, secure positions, and dispose of monster dens and other enemies. Vanguards are often soldiers who have proven themselves as reliable and talented Watch or Support Regiment and aim to prove themselves further in the city.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Hooded Lanterns rarely go into a fight without a plan. They set up ambushes, tailoring an encounter to put them at an advantage. They know their territory and can navigate the ruins of the city with relative ease compared to most adventurers who journey into Drakkenheim. They travel in well-equipped groups, and often carry tools to alert other nearby scouting parties if they need help.

The Hooded Lanterns are skilled archers. They often occupy rooftops and ruined towers. If they expect combat to occur, they position soldiers with bows in any nearby vantage points with a clear view of their allies down on the streets. They place scouts in ruined buildings to keep eyes on the streets and run for aid if a combat breaks out. The Lanterns lay traps and ambushes before their enemies have entered the area. Hooded Lanterns are often incredibly prepared and use the ruins as camouflage for their attack.

monsterFluff.name: Humongous Fungus Troll

entries: Fungus Trolls are most prominently found in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia but are also known to inhabit prominent wetlands and swamps within the continent. They are one of the most problematic troll groups known in the world. Their ability to produce new trolls en masse is staggering. Not only do the hags who tend to fungal gardens create hundreds of them at a time, but the Fungus Trolls can grow to such massive sizes, that their lumbering presence shakes the very trees of the swamps they inhabit. These massive fungal monstrosities rain down spores that grow into {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trollings}. These networks of Fungus Trolls travel together. When you see one Humongous Fungus Troll barreling towards you, be warned that there are likely more following.

{@b {@i Swampland Protectors.}} Humongous Fungus Trolls stand as the guardians of their swamps. They do not cater to trespassers of any kind. Loyal to their Troll Hag mothers, they defend their fungal farms and wander the swamps spreading their spores as they go.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Humongous Fungus Trolls remain motionless and observe trespassers to see if they are a threat. If combat is initiated, the Humongous Fungus Troll uses its Grasping Tendrils to pull victims towards it, then use its Entangling Mycelia to entangle as many creatures as possible within its Rotting Aura.

monsterFluff.name: Hunter Hulk

entries: A hunched and bloated form lurches out of the shadows. It has two massive tentacle arms that end in large talon-like hooks. The creature's head has two large octarine eyes, yet where a mouth should be there is only a fleshy surface. Instead, the creature has a massive snarling maw in its gut with jagged bone teeth and a large purple tongue. It squeals hungrily as its arms flail towards you, ready to pull you into its open mouth. But suddenly, it vanishes before your eyes, yet you can still hear its hungry squeals.

Hunter Hulks lurk the streets in a constant state of hunger. Unlike other dregs, these seek out prey to eat, yet their appetites never seem to falter. Even more horrifying is the way a Hunter Hulk has adapted to the hunt: they can turn Invisible using a natural camouflage that has mutated their skin. These stealthy Haze Hulks wait in the shadows for their prey to draw closer, only to pounce out and scoop them up for a snack.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (10+) Stealthy Assassin
entries: You know of its Invisibility trait.

entries.name: (15+) Hooked Arms
entries: You learn of the Hulk's Lashing Tendrils attack and Reel {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: (20+) Strong and Tough
entries: You are aware of the Hulk's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Hunter Hulks hide in the ruins of Drakkenheim, often Invisible, attempting to get the drop on their prey. Once the Hulk's target is in a prime position, it lunges out and whips its arms around them, pulling in the unfortunate target. The Hunter Hulk then devours them with its Belly Maw. If the creature breaks free, or if the Hunter Hulk is being too heavily damaged, it turns Invisible again and slinks back into the shadows. However, the Hunter Hulk will not so easily give up on its prey, and it may stalk the target and their party for a time, looking for a better moment to strike again. Sometimes it launches another ambush almost immediately, other times it will stalk them for several hours.

monsterFluff.name: Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom

entries: The multi-colored petals of this large lotus-like flower gently open. Light dances across its leaves and shimmering blossom in strange hypnotic rhythm. The colors seem to shift as it moves, at times creating unimaginable colors. As you gaze at it, maddening patterns fill your mind, and a wave of confusion sweeps over you, making it impossible to tell if your glance was for but a moment or a lifetime.

Queen's Park Garden was one of the most visited locations in the city prior to the meteor. Although the park existed since the city's founding, it was Helena von Kessel II, the mother of the late Ulrich IV, who ordered its redesign into the brilliance it grew to be. This redesign added tiered gardens, topiary masterpieces, cobblestone walkways, tranquil streams, and quaint waterfalls. The Queen's Park Gardens included an astounding assortment of flowers, many of which were exotic to Westemr. Even the wooded groves bustled with wildlife and an unrivaled selection of trees and bushes. With the contamination of Drakkenheim, the beauty of the gardens have become horrific feasting grounds for carnivorous plants, sentient trees, and strangling vines, and its flowers are now a constant threat to any who enter.

Hypnotic Eldritch Blossoms are one of many plants warped by mutation. They emit a hallucination-inducing pollen and overflow with contaminated nectar. They are often fatally mistaken for eldritch lilies, a magical plant sought for its contamination resistive properties. These flowers mimick lilies to lure prey close enough to be hypnotized. They often grow in hazardous environments such as near delerium encrusted growths, contaminated water, or delerium sludge. Once entranced by the pollen's influence, creatures move closer to be contaminated until transformed into a monsters.

Apothecaries who have studied the strange blossoms suspect they may be part of a network that "speaks" to delerium in a manner we could never understand. The flowers may be seeking to corrupt the living, changing them into more suitable creatures that can further the spread of contamination.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (5+) Slow Moving Plant.
entries: You're aware of the plants movement, {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Enchanted Blossoms.
entries: You learn of its Hypnotic Pollen action and Spell Reflection Reaction.

entries.name: (15+) Tough and Unthinking.
entries: You recognize the blossom's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: These plants typically grow in places protected from easy access, such as a pool of contaminated water, and they weaponize their environment against threats. The blossom attempts to contaminate victims with its nectar and uses the surroundings to amplify the danger of contamination. The flower is not agile enough to escape attacks, and relies on its Hypnotic Pollen to keep itself alive. Hypnotized victims view the flower as an impossibly beautiful object and are lured into any nearby hazards.

monsterFluff.name: Injector

entries: This lithe, 8-foot-tall creature has an array of tanks and hoses connected to four mechanical limbs that end in massive syringes, filled with all manner of toxins, contagions, and afflictions. Beady white eyes glare at you from its bald head. No mouth is visible, instead, it wears hose-connected mask and several magnifying lenses that can slotted over its eyes for surgical precision.

The first creations many apothecaries attempt to construct are lab assistants, and the Injector is one of these primary creations. Equipped with massive syringes and a tank with multiple canisters of toxins and tinctures, the Injector can mix and combine these chemicals to produce a multitude of medicines or toxins. Individual apothecaries outfit their Injectors with different chemicals for their experimentation. Although primarily a medical assistant, the Injector also doubles as a sentry or guard for the apothecary's occult research and hidden labs.

{@b {@i Different Injectors for Different Practices}}. Injectors are a common creation for Reanimators, often constructed from stitched-together body parts and medical instruments welded into the flesh, but both {@creature Chemist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Chemists} and {@creature Pathogenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Pathogenists} also create Injectors. Reanimators use Injectors as assistants to administer paralysis, mind dampening, and even adrenaline into their creations, hoping to keep subjects alive during intense procedures. Pathogenists use Injectors to deliver deadly viruses, poisons, and diseases. Chemists have been known to use Injectors for mixing alchemical formulae in case problems arise and cause unforeseen accidents—it's better you blow up an assistant than yourself.

entries.name: (15+) Be careful, it's volatile!.

entries.name: (20+) Hardy Creature
entries: You are aware of the Injector's AC, {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, and weakest ability score and saving throw.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: If the Injector has allies nearby, it uses Booster Dose to bolster them before combat. Otherwise, it ruthlessly attacks with its Syringe Arms. It feels no pain and does not waver or retreat.

monsterFluff.name: Innocent Harvester

entries: These small mannequins are cobbled together from wood, clay, and scrap metal. Visible tubes pump blood through their lithe forms. Garbed in scavenged clothing and wigs, many resemble human children, while some appear like deformed stuffed animals or dolls. Some especially macabre specimens are built with flesh, including painted masks as faces. Each has a single hand replaced with an array of scissors and scalpels, while the other holds an extractor or syringe. Several are equipped with small satchels or bloodied bags that they drag behind them. Some carry ragged stuffed animals filled with pockets. All bags are filled with dismembered body parts, bits of bone, flesh, organs, eyes, and other parts they bring back to their masters.

Apothecaries create Innocent Harvesters to be loyal, discrete minions that go out and harvest materials for their experiments. These constructs prove far more reliable than unscrupulous thugs and hirelings, who are likely to expose the apothecary to authorities if apprehended or bribed.

The Innocent Harvesters are mindless minions, built to resemble a young street urchin to those who catch a fleeting glimpse of them. Upon closer inspection, they are clearly not human, made from clay, wood, and sometimes metal scrap. A series of valves and gears pump real blood in their chests, infusing the construct with unlife. Many are simply dressed in ragged cloth, worn clothes, or old potato sacks, and fitted with dirty wigs and a painted doll-like face upon a porcelain mask. Some of the more grotesque versions have the surgically removed human faces stretched across their featureless heads.

The more bizarre harvesters are not made to look human but strange stuffed animals or contraptions. These unusual forms are rare, as most Apothecaries seek to create an illusion that the constructs are inconspicuous children roaming the streets.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study an Innocent Harvester, learning the following based on the result:

entries: You understand the Innocent Harvester's creature type as well as its damage and condition {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (12+) Clamber and Leap
entries: You are aware of the Innocent Harvester's Leap.

entries.name: (15+) Simple Construct
entries: You know the Innocent Harvester's mental saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Though small and innocent in appearance, Innocent Harvesters are not defenseless. They are fast and agile, equipped with surgical tools in place of one hand and a syringe in the other. Made to subdue trespassers, or remove body parts from corpses, these unflinching minions will not hesitate to leap atop targets. However, they are more comfortable hiding and fleeing than fighting. Their job is to collect body parts. If threatened, they leap onto a target and begin using their surgical tools on them. Harvesters attempt to sedate wounded targets and flee.

A creature of nearly impossible proportions and colors steps through a tear in the fabric of reality. It has spindly limbs that end in three sharp digits, attaching to a tubular stalk of a body. Opening within its form is a long, toothy maw lined with tiny undulating tentacles. A faint gurgling sound emanates from the creature. You feel hunger, but strangely, you realize it is not your own hunger, but that of the creature clattering towards you.

Within the Space Between Worlds, creatures exist that feed on arcane power, craving magic of all sorts, but particularly power that extraplanar patrons grant to mortals. One such creature identified by the Amethyst Academy has been classified simply as an Interloper.

entries.name: Drawn to Magic
entries: Interlopers crave magic, especially delighting in extracting the arcane power wielded by warlocks.
They latch onto the connection between a warlock and their patron, attempting to follow that connection into the Material plane where they lie in wait for their victim.

entries.name: Clustered Predators
entries: Interlopers seldom appear alone, preferring to attack in groups of three or more. Occasionally, they have been observed to bicker, fighting each other for the largest share of the spoils.

entries.name: Spell Snatchers
entries: Interlopers are feared by spellcasters because of their ability to Siphon Spells thrown at them. Once spellcasters recognize an area is infested with these creatures, they often commission Paladins of the Silver Order or grizzled monster hunters to hunt them down.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action study} an Interloper, revealing the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Multidimensional Senses
entries: You recognize the creature's {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} trait.

entries.name: (15+) Magical Entity
entries: You are aware of its Siphon Spell ability.

entries.name: (20+) Agile and Cunning
entries: You know the Interloper's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: An Interloper has only one objective, to feast on the spellcaster's magic that attracted it, and then to return to whence it came. It pursues the nearest spellcaster, prioritizing warlocks, assailing them until they are dead, or the caster's magic is spent It Teleports to evade physical attacks. If an Interloper drops below 10 Hit Points, it will {@spell Plane Shift}, retreating into the Space Between Worlds to recover, seeking to return to feast again, likely in greater numbers.

monsterFluff.name: Juggernaut Hulk

entries: The creature is composed of rippling muscles, with leather straps holding in place rusted pieces of armor forming a pauldron, bracers, and belt. Its head is enclosed in a massive metal dome with no discernable face. Still, the creature's heavy breathing can be heard from within the dome and it seems completely aware of its surroundings. In each hand it carries a makeshift metal blade, made from scrap beams from a house, or possibly the remnants of an old door, or part of a wagon. It's clearly filed these metal scraps to a fine blade caked in rust and dried blood.

The Juggernaut Hulk's iconic helmet is something of a mystery. It is unclear if they fashion it themselves or if these Haze Hulks are some form of eldritch experiment. They have been found wandering the Inner City near the Kleinberg Estates, which has led to rumors surrounding the Pale Man and his constant dabbling in mutation and contamination. Some believe the helm is fastened over their heads in an effort for them to hone their senses and force a mutation to adapt. Somehow their mutations allow them to be acutely aware of their surroundings, without relying on sight, smell, or sound.

The Juggernaut prowls the streets acting as a sort of sentinel. wIt sometimes bands together with other Dregs as a bodyguard, wand has been seen walking around the entrance to the Pale Man's estate. On rare occasions, a Juggernaut Hulk has been wfound closer to the city walls wandering aimlessly, drawn to wgroups of Dregs or places of strong contamination.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Juggernaut Hulk barrels forward in combat, slamming foes out of its way and swinging its blades wildly. Its main tactic is to knock enemies down and then drive its blades into them, bisecting them on the spot.
The Juggernaut Hulk does not flee and seems to shrug off most injuries. It will fight until its last breath with determination and ferocity.

monsterFluff.name: Kingkiller Hydra

entries: The patchwork form of the hydra appears to be fused together with metal scrap, and spare parts from large monstrosities. Its flesh is pale and discolored, with multicolored scales that have lost their luster over time. In many places patches of scales are missing entirely. The creature's multiple heads are all surgically attached, with milky white eyes placed in old and rotting sockets. Foul chemicals pump through the creature's body causing glowing veins to show throw the places where its scales are the most thinned. Sickly green salvia drips from the many and varied mouths of its lizard heads.

The Kingkiller Hydra is a beast created for a singular purpose. An Apothecary abomination designed by the maddened mind of Dr. Everett Freed, the Reanimator, the most infamous apothecary in the world of Drakkenheim. This beast was created from the slain corpse of a massive hydra with the intention of turning it against those who originally vanquished it. A tool of utter destruction let loose against the foes of the vile apothecary.

The creature has had its parts sewn back together, and in the instance of missing pieces, they have been replaced with the flesh, scales, fangs, and talons of other beasts. Its blood has been replaced with an acidic fluid that pumps through the creature, animating its lifeless corpse and filling it with only thoughts of malice and memories of pain.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB}, {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} the Kingkiller Hydra, learning the following based on the result:

entries: You are aware of the creature's Multiple Heads trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Kingkiller Hydra is relentless. It attacks with all its heads against any target in range. If there is distance between it and its foes, it Tramples them before unleashing Bite attacks with its heads, or it Spits Acid at them from afar while closing the distance.
If the hydra takes 75 or more Fire damage in a single round, it attempts to flee.

items.name: Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal

entries: Theodore Marshal is athletic and tall with boldly sculpted features, bronzed skin, and unkempt sandy brown hair. Unshaven stubble has grown into a beard over the criss-cross of scars on his face. A leather eye patch covers his right eye. He wears gleaming silver plate armor etched with golden trim, and carries a shimmering sword a broad shield engraved with the symbol of the Sacred Flame.

Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal is a decorated veteran of the Silver Order. Hand-picked by the Divine Matriarch to lead their mission to Drakkenheim, the valiant knight possesses a level-headed and clear-eyed faith. He would never ask his soldiers to undertake a task he would not brave himself, and prefers to lead from the front lines.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: Honorable. I treat all matters with great honor and respect, and I standing up for what I believe. I expect others to act similarly, respecting any who match my ideals and honor.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Tradition. I uphold the traditions of the Sacred Flame and the Silver Order. I take pride in my standing within the Order and the responsibilities that befall my position.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I will willing to lay down my life to reclaim the lost relics in Drakkenheim and sanctify the cathedral. I know that there is no cost too great if it means purging the world of the filth of this blighted city.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I trust those of my order and faith, and I believe whatever commands come from my superiors. I hestiate to trust those who do not swear to my faith, as there can be no other way that to follow its teachings.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Honorable to a fault, Theodore Marshal will always entertain parley and accept surrender, even if he doesn't expect the same from his foes. If it comes to blows, Theodore Marshal charges into battle and strikes hard with his warhammer, setting his enemies alight with {@spell Searing Smite}. Well aware of the dangers of spellcasters and monsters, he uses call the sacred flame to blind them so he can engage in melee with impunity.

entries.name: Knights of the Silver Order

entries: The Silver Order is an elite church-sanctioned regiment of paladins and ordained knights oath-sworn to combat supernatural evils, otherworldly incursions, and dark magic. As faithful devotees of the Sacred Flame, they believe delerium is a dangerous and contaminating blight. Led by the valiant Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal, the knights have been dispatched to eradicate Drakkenheim's corruption at its source.

The Silver Order are a well-known military organization hailing from the nation of Elyria in the southwest of the continent. Loyal to the Church of the Sacred Flame, the Silver Order are a well-known military organization they operate as a church-sanctioned military whose stated purpose is to protect the world from evil magical intrusions, to keep otherworldly threats at bay, and to protect the people against dark magic and abuses of power from mageborn. Many believe the Silver Order are a strict organization who upholds the letter of the law within the Edicts of Lumen, a legal document that dictates the balance of power between the church, the mages, and the royalty.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: What the Silver Order lacks in subtlety they make up for with sheer force. They are a military organization, and their soldiers are well trained and work together as a team. When they tackle problems, they do so in a uniform fashion, knowing when to rely on one another, complete tasks and make pushes in unison. The Silver Order has simple call signs, hand signals, commands, and strategies that they can rely on in the field.
Silver Order knights and paladins should work as a cohesive unit who know their strengths and how to protect their weaknesses.

Any Silver Order regiment is accompanied by at least one paladin or Flamekeeper, and usually at least one of each. Larger organized military missions will see griffon riders as well as entire units of paladins and several Flamekeepers or Pyre Priests. This means that no Silver Order unit is without moderate healing, protective buffs, and often forms of divination and holy battle magic. When push comes to shove, the order's divine spellcasters tend to have a few Fireballs and Flamestrikes amongst their options.

monsterFluff.name: Kronen

entries: In the shadow of the ruins, a pale, gaunt human appears. Their peculiar black cordlike hair shimmers strangely. With a bizarre gat they they stride forward revealing a monstrous form. Six skitterin legs hold up its sprawling torso resembling the thorax and abodme of a massive cockroach. Its chitinous shell gleams with a sickly sheen a pair of long twitching antennae sprout from its head, and it arms end in clawed, human-like hands. Small oculi dot its forhea surrounding large compound eyes. Opening its mouth reveals no a tongue, but horrific mandibles. Countless small cockroaches dar among weeping holes covering its torso

Drakkenheim's citizens were struck with panic and terror the day the city fell. While many tried to flee amidst the chaos, a few sought safety, barricading themselves in whatever shelter they could find. They hid in cellars, closets, outhouses, tunnels, and other seemingly secure places in a desperate attempt to survive. When the flames died down and the Haze took hold, a few chose to wait out the eerie mists. Who can say if they would have fared better had they attempted escape?

Isolated and alone, most tried surviving on contaminated water and subsisting on vermin creeping into their shelters. These fools did not realize the Haze could permeate their hiding places. Worse, the insects and rodents they consumed began to feed on them. Gradually exposed to contamination, the survivors metamorphosed into loathsome, vermin-like monstrosities befitting their wretched dwellings. Most knew that something had changed but they had little sense for how much time has passed.

Many of these unfortunates remain in their hiding places, confined within nightmarish conditions. Indeed, many are trapped within their shelters due to flooded passages, fallen rubble, or collapsing ruins. When discovered within deep cellars and sealed passages, they respond with panicked and confused violence. Explorers seeking to unearth treasure and lost relics within the city quickly learn to carefully inspect dig sites for hollows or buried chambers where a "Kronen" may dwell.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (5+) Infected Vermin.

entries.name: (10+) Speed and Dread.
entries: You learn of the creature's Loathsome Presence action and Scuttle Bonus Action.

entries.name: (15+) Broken Personality.
entries: You understand the creature's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Kronen is usually agitated and alarmed when encountered, and its first instinct in combat is to find a new hiding place or flee deeper into its lair. It uses its Loathsome Presence while clawing at any in the way of its escape using Scuttle, reflexively spreading roaches to attackers via its Infestation Reaction.

If it escapes, a Kronen is eventually drawn to return to its old hiding place. Should characters remain there, the Kronen will furiously attack to reclaim its shelter but won't pursue charac ters who leave it alone in its hideout.

monsterFluff.name: Lambent Dreg

entries: The creature glows with a pallid, soft light. At times it gives off-hues of purples, oranges, and greens, but on occasion the color seems wholly indescribable. Its mouth hangs wide open, that same glow emerging brighter from its gullet, and its eyes shine like two lanterns as it surveys the area around it, drawn to the contaminating energies around it.

Lambent Dregs have become so contaminated that they glow like delerium. They are drawn to the contaminated crystals, gathering around them in groups. Studying these strange glowing Dregs, it has become clear that they become more hostile towards already contaminated creatures. Something about contamination motivates them to chase, attacking anyone suffering from mutations or sickness caused by exposure in the ruins.

entries.name: (15+) Smart and Cunning

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Lambent Dregs tends to gather around delerium clusters throughout the city, often appearing in groups in highly contaminated areas. Creatures who have {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels are prime targets for Lambent Dregs. The Dregs chase them down, avoiding non-contaminated targets when possible.

If threatened, Lambent Dregs run into the middle of a group of enemies and expel their Wave of Contamination, attempting to render their foes into a state of {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, allowing the Dreg to easily engage with them.
Lambent Dregs flee if outnumbered and in a losing situation.

monsterFluff.name: Last Memory

entries: Seared into brick and cobblestone is the ashen silhouette of a human form. Not a trace of their body remains, the blackened stone capturing the last imprint of their existence, the moment they were incinerated by the meteor's eldritch fire. Inexplicably, the silhouette animates into distorted shapes, as distant screams and echoing anguished whimpers fill your ears.

These disembodied undead were formed the moment the meteor struck Drakkenheim. In a flash, those close to the impact were reduced to ash, but eldritch forces unleashed by the explosion trapped the memories of those it obliterated. Captured forever in that moment as silhouettes, a Last Memory is not a ghost or specter. They are not metaphysically connected to a living creature or its spirit—that creature is gone, annihilated body and soul by the eldritch fires which consumed them. Instead, these undead are pain, suffering, and misery given form in a gruesome instant. These spirits cannot be reasoned with nor spoken to, and cannot be aided or soothed. They are incapable of existing outside the singular event of their destruction, desiring only to force that moment into the minds of others, causing them to experience their anguish over and over again.

Even if the mere physicality of a Last Memory is destroyed, its lingering agony causes them to reappear, their endless torment a gravestone marking one lost to the meteor. Last Memories destroyed in the ruins of Drakkenheim return days later, emerging in a sorrowful chorus of screams that echo through the city.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Last Memory, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Deathless Memory.
entries: You know the creature's monster type, {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Painful Recall.
entries: You are aware of the creature's Anguish action.

entries.name: (15+) Weak Undead.
entries: You learn the creature's ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Last Memories can move along the ground or up walls, often hiding as shadows on the ground. They have even followed prey, appearing as a strange movement in one's peripheral vision, or a shifting shadow from an unknown source.

When they reveal themselves, Last Memories cry out in anguish, causing those nearby to suffer visions of their last moments, inducing emotional trauma to any who succumb to it. They grasp those nearby, terrorizing them with waves of sorrow. Last Memories seem to embody the raw emotions of their death, using those emotions as weapons against the living. They do not flee, for they do not cherish their existence. Their only purpose is to spread the fear and the pain of their own death before fading away, only to reappear days later to relive their agony.

monsterFluff.name: Lenore von Kessel

entries: The Haze transformed Queen Lenore into a monster. She stands six feet tall, clad in a once-opulent green dress adorned with gold filigree, now muddied and tattered. She wears an astonishing but tarnished golden necklace set with eleven emeralds. Her long, thin limbs and chalky skin are cracked and rigid like stone, and her hair is a writhing mass of thick, wet, tendrils, each ending in a toothy maw.

An emotionless porcelain mask obscures her face and a light shawl hides mutated hair. Her eyes are empty voids, swirling with magic and an occasional octarine glow. When the meteor fell, chaos quickly spread. Castle Drakken went to high alert, gathering the von Kessels to be escorted out of the city to safety. Queen Lenore was the first to be told to evacuate. She resisted, believing there was no safer place than the castle. But as screams erupted from the city and the Haze flowed from the South Ward, she finally agreed. Her handmaidens gathered her finest dresses, jewelry, and possessions, then used a secret passage to reach the sewers. They were wisked away by a royal boat on a private waterway to the Queen's Park Gardens but no further.

On arrival, the {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} had already reached the gardens. Terror and confusion were everywhere. After seeing a guard grotesquely transformed by the Haze, she fled with her retinue to a garden grotto, confusing familiarity with safety. They hid for some time, all becoming disfigured by the Haze. The Queen, afraid of her own reflection, had a mask fashioned to hide her features. She still resides within, waiting for her guards to return and say the danger is past. She is gripped by delusions that aside from her facial scarring, she has made it through the cataclysm unscathed.

This couldn't be more wrong. Her mind is broken and she clings to her delusionional view of reality. Anyone suggesting otherwise falls victim to her horrible gaze. She is a monster stalking the gardens, and like Drakkenheim's other horrors, she is dangerous and best left alone.

Before her transformation, the Queen was a strikingly tall and sharp-featured Caspian woman, with pale skin and vibrant orange hair. She married Ulrich IV to cement an alliance between House von Kessel and House Jones of Caspia, but refused to be a political pawn, asserting all of the royal privileges befitting a Queen. She was extraordinarily vain, hopelessly narcissistic, and frequently inebriated. She wore outrageously ornamented clothes, makeup, and jewelry, including a famous golden necklace set with eleven emeralds. She hosted parties and attended many social events where she delighted in her vassals' gossip, though was kind to her servants. She loved her children only as extensions of herself, and absolutely despised her husband.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I speak softly imagining myself to be in a tragic fairytale while casting others in fictional roles.

items.name: Ideal
entries: The world is a mirror held to my glorious reflection.

items.name: Bond
entries: I obsessively crave beauty, decadence, and relish all art. I especially love my garden and my lilies. They are all I have left.

items.name: Flaw
entries: I fly into an enraged fury at the sight of my own likeness or the names of my lost family members.
