entries: You recognize she is an Aberration.

entries.name: (15+) Deadly Gaze
entries: You learn of her Radiant Gaze ability.

entries.name: (20+) Formidable Foe
entries: You understand her highest and lowest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Lenore does not often outright engage in combat, throwing Dregs and her handmaidens at enemies who threaten her. She prefers to stay behind her minions where she is safe, relying on her Radiant Gaze to slowly disable and contaminate her foes..
If forced into melee, she uses her Tentacle Hair to attack and will take the first opportunity to escape if she can.

items.name: Lieutenant Petra & Captain Ansom Lang

entries: Petra Lang is a fit and nimble teenager with long black hair, a narrow, pointed chin, and bold features. She wears the Lanterns' hooded green cloak and light {@item studded leather armor|XPHB} with a lieutenant's insignia on her shoulder pauldron.

Ansom Lang is an athletic teenager with long black hair and a short neat beard, angular jaw, and rugged features. He is garbed in a hooded green cloak and {@item studded leather armor|XPHB} of the Hooded Lanterns that prominently displays a captain's insignia on his shoulder

Petra, the youngest of the two, has spent most of her life training under the Hooded Lanterns. She prides herself on her marksmanship and scavenging, and knows she is looked up to by many of the soldiers. She is a proud and friendly commander who the troops are happy to follow.
Ansom plans to become the Lord Commander once Elias retires. He is a stern commander who leads by example, displaying incredible discipline and unwavering loyalty to his adopted father

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I see the value in those willing to risk their lives in the ruins. I have great insight and trust in my own judgment of character.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: The right path is often the harder path, but it is always one worth walking.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I was adopted by Elias Drexel, who raised and trained me. I don't want to let him down.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I am too open and trusting of people who claim to be on the same side as me, and I put a lot of weight in counting on people who I assume are able to handle themselves.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Petra is a skilled archer and skirmisher. She prefers to keep her foes at range to gain a vantage point over them in combat. She is a cunning scout who is more likely to set up an ambush than attack directly. When pinned down, she tries to move out of melee into a more advantageous position. If she is low on options, she attempts to escape.

Ansom is a skilled swordsman who prefers to engage his foes in melee combat. He typically starts combat from a good vantage point by attacking with his bow and then moving closer to unleash a flurry of sword attacks. He is a confident and aggressive, and has pushed the Hooded Lanterns through many decisive victories over the horrors of Drakkenheim.
Ansom has enough sense to know when a combat encounter is threatening to cost the lives of his unit, and will fall back or retreat if his instincts tell him it is the better move.
Nothing like family to keep you honest. That and a sword that makes you tell the truth.

monsterFluff.name: Liminal Herald

entries: The amorphous form of the Liminal Herald quivers and ripples as it drifts through the air. Its many spider-like eyes glowing with incomprehensible colors, its flesh changing shape and color in dizzying displays. It whispers in the minds of those who approach it, telling them great truths of unknown worlds, and announcing the coming of its nameless masters.

Liminal Heralds are the scouts and messengers of unknown ancient entities that exist in the furthest reaches of the Space Between Worlds. Whatever the purpose is, their galactic information gathering remains a mystery. Liminal Heralds uncover unfathomable truths and whispered echoes of shattered realities as they seek out realms to beckon the coming of their masters.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (15+) Psychic Retribution

entries.name: (20+) Weak but Perceptive

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Liminal Herald is a contaminated entity from the deepest corners of the Space Between Worlds. It undoes creatures atom by atom with its Eldritch Beams. It targets the intellect of other creatures with its Mind Scramble, especially spellcasters {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on spells. The Liminal Herald harnesses the very fabric of magic itself and uses that force against mortals who would attempt to dabble in it.

When targeted by an attack, the Liminal Herald bends space and time around it using its Reflect Pain feature, causing the creature who attacked it to take on a mental payload of pain felt by the creature.
If it is reduced below half its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the Liminal Herald attempts to flee.

monsterFluff.name: Living Biohazard

entries: This gelatinous blob drips and oozes over the ground, rolling like a slow viscous spill. At times appearing liquid, at others like a gelation, and still others it appears to take a more solid form. Its colors change and shift in alternating hues, sometimes mimicking its surroundings until the thing almost disappears from view completely.

Living Biohazards are the failed experiments of Chemists striving to perfect alchemical concoctions of far greater potency. However, there is still value in their failures. Creating slivers of sentience within chemical compounds is no small feat, and the Living Biohazard, although not perfect, has provided Chemists with a chemical defense system of sorts.

The Living Biohazard is an insatiable ooze that slides around its environment like a spilled liquid looking for creatures to dissolve. The corrosive gelatin can stick to walls and ceilings and drop down on unsuspecting creatures. It is, even in its simple-minded nature, a persistent and deadly hunter.

entries.name: Combat Tactics

monsterFluff.name: Living City

entries: An eerie light shines within the oddly intact yet ramshackle house across the road. The door hangs ajar, gently banging open and closed as the mist and winds whip through the dark streets. As you step inside the building, the lurching floorboards creak and groan. The furnishings are bizarrely orderly, and you notice nary a speck of dust or debris accumulated in the otherwise ordinary rooms. After a moment you notice a strange glistening liquid seeping out between the timbers, and the odd reddish goo that melts between the mortar of the bricks. Suddenly, the door slams shut, the windows close and shutter, and the entire room warps and shifts. Hundreds of yellow eyes open across the walls, grin ning toothy mouths form on the ceilings and floors. Glistening barbed pseudopods reach up from the furniture, as you realize you have stepped right into the gullet of a patient predator.

Some say that the greatest threat adventurers and faction agents face in Drakkenheim is the city itself. The unstable magic of the Haze makes navigation through the city streets perilous and disorienting. It often feels like the alleys and buildings are changing position around travelers, as if Drakkenheim were slowly weaving a maze around them. Damaged buildings are filled with rubble, prone to collapse, and the perfect places for monsters to hide in ambush. Dangers and hazards abound from the transformed landscape, and tales are told of structures themselves magically transmuted into strange substances, the stone and wood becoming metals, glass, sand, or even partially made from flesh and bone, as if a twisted artist had sculpted the buildings out of macabre materials.

Just as the Haze has awakened unhinged sentience in the elements and guardian constructs of Drakkenheim, bizarre {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} occasionally cause the furnishings and buildings of the city to awaken. Eyes, mouths, and even tendrils may appear on surfaces within. Those who brave the interior rooms and halls hear whispers in their minds as the building develops its own personality. On rare occasions, however, the internal composition of objects mutates into a metamorphic goo, imbuing the structure with the ability to change its form and composition in nearly limitless ways. When this occurs to a normal object like a table or chest of drawers, the result is a typical mimic.

A Living City emerges when this happens to an entire building. Also called manor mimics or werehouses, these deadly creatures slowly meander through the city, finding empty plots or taking the place of ruined buildings. Once they find a suitable location, they may quite literally set up shop. Due to their nature, a Living City does not create the appearance of a damaged or ruined structure, so adventurers may be naturally wary of oddly intact buildings they encounter while roaming the ruins.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} a Living City, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (15+) Animated Building.
entries: You are aware of the Living City's Structural Form and No Exit traits, as well as its {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (20+) Escape Routes.
entries: You recognize that destroying the creature's walls and doors creates exits, but these are short-lived because of its Shifting Form Epic Action.

entries.name: (25+) Slow, Smart, and Tough.
entries: You learn of the Living City's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Living City takes the form of an oddly intact residence, workshop, or warehouse using its Structural Form trait, and waits for hapless creatures to wander inside. A Living City may deceive characters into entering it using its telepathy and Haunting Whispers. It suppresses its Digestive Aura and so it can take full advantage of its False Appearance trait.

Typically, a Living City shapes its body to create outer rooms that have walls bordering the edge of the Living City's space, and inner rooms deep within which do not have walls, ceilings, or floors immediately adjacent to spaces outside the Living City. The Living City will create doors, windows, or even stairs within it so that its prey can easily move from outside, to the outer rooms, and then further inside to the inner rooms. Often, the Living City might place any treasure or valuables it has collected in these inner rooms as bait.

Once a few characters have entered one of its innermost rooms, the Living City attacks and activates its Digestive Aura. When it rolls Initiative, it uses its No Exit trait to close all the doors and windows in its body, trapping characters inside. Then, it attacks them with its Grasping Tendrils, Bite, and Haunting Whispers, while using its Shifting Form Epic Action to slowly change its interior, separating the characters and cutting off their escape routes.

Should the player characters break a hole in one of its walls, the Living City uses its Shifting Form trait to plug the hole. Note that some area-of-effect attacks and spells (such as {@spell Burning Hands|XPHB}) can damage or destroy multiple sections of the Living City. However, a Living City can only take damage from one section being destroyed per turn. If characters manage to slip outside the Living City through a breached hole or exit, the Living City may use its Grasping Tendrils to pull them back in. It then tries to quickly seal them inside again with Shifting Form.

monsterFluff.name: Living Deep Haze

entries: The Haze enveloping you begins to churn and swirl, gradually coalescing into a dense mass of octarine fog. A ghostly visage emerges as a nebulous form takes shape, its features twisted in an eerie semblance of anguish. Flashes of contaminated energy crackle and spark inside the cloud, casting fleeting, sinister lights which mimic the movements of a tortured face. This roiling fog floats through the ruins, drifting like a specter haunted by its own turbulent essence.

True to their name, these Contaminated Air Elementals lurk within the thickest parts of the Haze, seamlessly blending in with the deadly environment. They exist to spread the contaminating mist and fog through their bodies, and delight in causing mutation and monstrous transformation.

entries: You understand its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: When it encounters an uncontaminated creature, the Living Deep Haze rapidly moves into its space thanks to its Fog Form trait. It then tries to remain there as much as possible so the creature is exposed to its Deep Haze trait. The Living Deep Haze wants to transform its targets into monsters, so it uses its Slam attacks to knock them Unconscious so they can awaken to a new existence as mutant horrors.

monsterFluff.name: Loathsome Gag Fly

entries: This massive fly buzzes through the air, bobbing and darting with a loud buzz of its wings. Its huge eyes make up most of its round form, saliva and mucus oozing from its small mandibles. Its abdomen is slightly translucent, with a purplish green liquid sloshing around inside its bloated form. It screams in a strangely human voice that sounds like it is crying for help.

The flies grow fat in Drakkenheim. Corpses do not rot, which makes them excellent sources of food for the rats, Garmyr, and bugs of the city. Many bloated corpses are now ripe with large green maggots that feast on the dead contaminated flesh. When these maggots evolve into Loathsome Gag Flies, they buzz around areas of death in the city. Attracted to fresh corpses, or piles of dead bodies, or even following along with a group of {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} or {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} hoping to munch on bits of their flesh. The city cistern and the old well in Slaughterstone Square is a known hot spot for a large nest of Gag Flies.

The Gag Flies are bloated and overgrown flies whose acidic mucus has now formed a pouch that occupies most of their large thorax. Like all flies, they use this acidic mucus to dissolve possible food and prepare it for eating. Due to their large size, this results in a horrible experience for adventurers wandering past a group of these flies, who all vomit sprays of burning acid onto their prey and buzz down to feed on the burning targets.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Loathsome Gag Fly, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Flying Monstrosity.
entries: You know the Gag Fly's creature type and speeds.

entries.name: (10+) Explosive Bile.
entries: You learn of the Gag Fly's Bloat Burst Reaction.

entries.name: (15+) Bestial Minded.
entries: You recognize the Gag Fly's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Loathsome Gag Fly is a simple-minded creature who wants to feed on flesh and lay larva on the corpses of the dead. It sprays acid on any creature that it sees nearby in an attempt to weaken it. It then lands on them and begins feeding.

Gag Flies usually attack in groups and care very little for the wellbeing of each other. As a matter of fact, when a Gag Fly is killed and explodes in a shower of acid, this usually causes other nearby flies to go into a feeding frenzy on targets sprayed in the gore, as they are drawn to any flesh dissolving in the acids of their mucus.

monsterFluff.name: Lob Frog

entries: The frog-like creature has sharp spines down its back, with mottled green and brown flesh; a large segmented mouth that bisects its face; and a large, black, soulless eye peering out from either side. Its insect-like pincers drip and gnash as it huddles close to a mound of translucent, sticky, octarine eggs throbbing and writhing with contaminated energy. It holds one of the throbbing spawn in its webbed hand, ready to hurl it directly at you.

The {@link Drann River} flows into Drakkenheim from the Kesselwald Forest to the northeast. On some of the especially quiet and warm nights, you could hear the chorus of croaking frogs from within the woods close to the river. These frogs were commonly found there, and large numbers of them would migrate down the Drann River into the northern parts of the city, especially around King's Gate. Today, the frog's migration continues, but now the contaminated waters of the Drann have caused the amphibians to bloat to horrific size, and also wildly changed their reproductive cycle.

These mutated monsters are now commonplace along the river and make crossing at any point dangerous. Their eggs do not hatch on their own but require a host body to feed on to complete the metamorphosis. For this reason, the frogs weaponize their contaminated eggs, tossing them at passing adventurers, scouts, and even other contaminated creatures, hence their moniker: "Lob" Frogs.

The Lob Frog produces hundreds of eggs and hedges its bets by throwing them at any creature it finds, hoping that a few of them have the opportunity to gestate into a newborn Lob Frog. Newly formed Lob Frogs always carry a minor element of the host. A Lob Frog formed from a Ratling may have rodent-like ears or whiskers, where one formed from a human may carry the host's eye color.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Lob Frog, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Poisonous Skin.
entries: You recognize the Lob Frog's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} and Poison Skin trait.

entries.name: (10+) Hurled Eggs.
entries: You are aware of the Lob Frog's Throw Frogspawn action.

entries.name: (15+) Assured Amphibian.
entries: You know the Lob Frog's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Lob Frogs are keen to keep their distance from predators and threats, but are constantly on the lookout for hosts for their offspring. They attempt to lob their contaminated eggs at potential threats, hoping to produce more Lob Frogs. If confronted directly, their Poison Skin acts as a defense while they use their Standing Leap to escape unfavorable situations.

If a Lob Frog has at least two or more targets with attached eggs, or if they are reduced below half Hit Points, they leap away to find somewhere safe and wet to hide. They would rather not risk their life, and simply hope to infect as many targets as possible to continue their species.

items.name: Lord Commander Elias Drexel

entries: Elias Drexel is a man in his early fifties. He is stocky and imposing with a furrowed brow and a grim frown on his wide and angular face. His harsh features are framed with a thick moustache, side chops, and mane of long braided brown hair. He is garbed in chainmail armor with heavy leather gloves and boots, worn under a fur-lined dark green cloak and iron pauldrons. He wears a pinned brooch depicting the Seal of Drakkenheim, the symbol of his office as Lord Commander. A quiver, a {@item longbow|XPHB}, and two longswords are strung on his back.

Elias Drexel was appointed to the office of Lord Commander of Westemr before the fall of Drakkenheim, and was outside the city leading training drills when the meteor fell. Afterwards, he took part in three military expeditions to reclaim Drakkenheim, and saw firsthand the city's horrors. When the expeditions failed and the nation fell into civil war, Elias Drexel found himself caught between mixed allegiances. He is haunted by the ghosts of his past mistakes and those who died under his command, and believes that his redemption will come only when Drakkenheim is reclaimed.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I have great responsibilities and have no time for senseless humor. I never cease to worry about our struggling militia's desperate task to reclaim these monster infested ruins. I have no patience for anything or anyone who doesn't further the Hooded Lanterns objectives.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Loyalty and trust are priceless. It must be carefully given, but staunchly held. There is nothing worse than betrayal and treason.

entries.name: Bond
entries: During the Civil War, I switched sides and killed several scions of House von Kessel who could have claimed the throne. I once believed it was for the right cause, but now
I feel personally responsible for breaking the royal line. My mission in Drakkenheim is penance and redemption.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I'm filled with rage and conflict because of my contradictory actions and beliefs, and I don't take defeat, setbacks, or even missteps lightly.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Elias Drexel typically leads several {@creature Hooded Lantern Veteran|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Hooded Lantern Veterans} into battle, using his Command action to grant them additional attacks while calling in artillery strikes as often as possible. Drexel himself operates as a skirmisher, switching between melee and ranged attacks to control the flow of battle.

monsterFluff.name: Lord of the Feast

entries: This albino Garmyr stands well over 12 feet tall, covered in yellowish-white mangy fur, bloodstained and scarred from countless battles and clad in a patchwork armor of leather, chain, and bladed plate. Mummified heads hang from his belt. A mane of bony spines and tufts of barbed hair jut from his head and run down his back to a long white tail braided with skulls and bone fragments. A snarling visage sports long, jagged fangs and smoldering red eyes. The Lord of the Feast holds an oversized longbow, stringed with thick sinew. A quiver on his back holds enormous arrows. Some bristle with barbed snares, others are connected to coils of chains around the beasts wrists, while others are tipped with {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shards}.

The Garmyr band together under a great warlord called the Lord of the Feast, who has grown a fearsome reputation as an expert hunter, tracker, and warrior. It seems that the Lord of the Feast enjoys hunting and killing for sport, and hanging his trophies in his grim cathedral. His favorite prey, of course, is adventurers—he revels in tracking them through the city and hanging their gear upon his trophy shelves.

The Lord of the Feast rose to power amongst the Garmyr when he emerged as a large, albino wolf amongst their pack. He was given the name Ghost due to his pale fur. Even at a young age, the Lord of the Feast was bigger than most other Garmyr. However, the creature was also cunning and smart. He knew he could best most foes with brute strength, but learned to control his insatiable hunger for bloodlust to focus on the skills needed to take down larger creatures. Through patience, a skilled hand with a bow, and using tools to modify his arrows, the Lord of the Feast began proving himself the strongest and most skilled hunter of all the Garmyr.

When the previous warlord, a gray Garmyr named Blood-Wolf, challenged Ghost to one-on-one combat, the Garmyr gathered to watch the contest. They speculated that Blood-Wolf called for the challenge out of fear of Ghost's burgeoning abilities and influence. Many Garmyr questioned Blood-Wolf challenging a pup half his age to a death match, but Blood-Wolf underestimated how powerful Ghost had already become. The match ended within seconds when three arrows penetrated Blood-Wolf 's chest. The first bound him in place, the second {@condition poisoned} him, and the third reeled him toward Ghost, who then tore his head off with his teeth. Holding up the head of Blood-Wolf, Ghost called for the Garmyr to feast on the corpse of their fallen leader. He was henceforth known as the Lord of the Feast.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the Lord of the Feast learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Difficult to Kill
entries: You know of the creature's Regeneration ability.

entries.name: (10+) Dangerous Archer
entries: You recognize that he carries special arrows revealing his Poison Arrow, Ensnaring Arrow, and Harpoon Arrow attacks.

entries.name: (15+) Cunning Combatant
entries: You learn their strongest and weakest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Lord of the Feast stalks the Temple Ward of Drakkenheim with his war dogs, searching for glorious kills. He seeks out the most fearsome monsters, and loves picking fights with faction agents and adventurers. When a band of plucky heroes enters his territory, the Lord of the Feast tracks and hunts them until they leave the Inner City or he has their skulls.
The Lord of the Feast uses a variety of arrows in combat:
Poison Arrow to debilitate foes, Ensnaring Arrow to stop them fleeing, and Harpoon Arrow to pull them toward him to engage in melee combat.
If the Lord of the Feast is reduced below 100 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, he attempts to escape, but regroups as soon as possible with more hunters in tow to continue the hunt.

items.name: Lucretia Mathias

entries: Lucretia Mathias is a willowy and wizened woman with piercing eyes and pursed lips. She is in her early nineties and keeps her graying black hair in a coiled bun beneath a linen shawl. Lucretia wears simple gray robes, and clutches a heavy leather-bound tome. A glowing golden crystal dangles from a silver chain around her neck. Her garb lightly conceals the delerium shard embedded in her heart.

The prophetic founder of the Followers of the Falling Fire was once a prominent Flamekeeper of the Sacred Flame. She was cast out and declared a heretic for her blasphemous insistence in the divinity of delerium.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I am devout. believe intensely in my faith and will give those seeking me a chance to speak. I care deeply for those who seek me out, bringing my full wisdom and passion to bear.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: The brightest lights shine in the darkest of places.
I will find my truth through my commitment to the light.
Those who follow me will be spared when the time comes.

entries.name: Bond
entries: The Meteor. I know the meteor is an early coming of the Tarnas comet, symbolizing all I base my faith upon. Only by coming to the Crater and finding yourself within can you be purified and cleansed of all your sins.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I only reveal the greatest truths I have seen to those I am certain can fully grasp and understand them as I do.

monsterFluff.name: Lurker on the Threshold

entries: Latching onto the Thin Places between realities, a cackling chorus of chaotic laughter in hysterical and dissonant tones tears through the minds of those who bear witness to the cosmic being. As it peers out with its three unblinking dark pools of eyes, it observes and surveys the realities as its mass of fleshy tendrils dangle from its slimy form. It ripples with black voidlike hues and splashes of deep purples and blues as if its flesh was a moving image of the cosmos.

The Lurker on the Threshold is a vile and maniacal being, drifting into our realm through Thin Places and screaming in the minds of those it witnesses. It wanders the Space Between Worlds and feeds on the raw arcane energy found in the rifts between realities, and on the shattered atoms of dead realms. It is a creature who exists on the threshold between places and non-places, between time and eternity. It exists as a personification of the roiling unfathomable nothing that is the stitches between the fabric of all things

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries: You know the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Arcane Beams
entries: You learn the creature's Cosmic Rays attack action.

entries.name: (20+) Enduring
entries: You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Lurker on the Threshold is a creature of pure arcane energy and twisted realities. It fires Cosmic Rays at mortal creatures,warping their minds, showing truths that drive them mad, or undoes their very existence on a cellular level. It grabs creatures with its Tendrils and blasts its beams while holding them in place, undoing the creatures from the inside out, before tossing them aside and moving on to the next. The Lurker on the Threshold only flees if it is reduced to under half its Hit Points, not because of any sense of fear, but because it finds specific enemies a nuisance.

monsterFluff.name: Lurking Dreg

entries: Draped in a dark cloak with the hood pulled up tight, the figure regards you with a cautious disposition. They pace back and forth, watching you, anticipating your actions and readying themselves for any sudden movement. From under the hood, you can make out a toothy smirk and pale flesh. Gently glowing eyes peer out from the shadows, observing you carefully and diligently.

It is not immediately obvious that a Lurking Dreg is a contaminated monster. Retaining most of their original appearance and personality, Lurking Dregs are often driven by a mad compulsion to deceive friends and loved ones into circumstances or places that will contaminate them in turn. Keen-eyed observers may be able to recognize subtle cues and signs of contamination in these creatures, such as discolored skin tones and a slight octarine glow in the eyes.

Hooded Lantern apothecaries who have examined Lurking Dreg corpses have discovered that the ruse is merely skin-deep: the creatures' innards are entirely contaminated and mutated, with almost all the internal organs rendered into unrecognizable shapes and configurations.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Insight|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check to {@action Study} a Lurking Dreg, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Something's Off
entries: You suspect this person may have been exposed to eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: (15+) Hiding Something
entries: You are aware of the Lurking Dreg's Cunning {@variantrule Action|XPHB} trait.

entries.name: (20+) Not A Humanoid
entries: You realize this is a Dreg appearing to be a normal humanoid and recognize the Lurking Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Some Lurking Dregs hide in the shadows, waiting for an opportune moment to strike. Others pose as human and attempt to converse with prey, hoping to draw them deeper into the ruins. Lurking Dregs have been known to use stories of lost allies, trapped children, and more to lure adventurers into an ambush.

When they attack, Lurking Dregs use their Furious Ambush right away to get as many attacks in as possible. They Disengage if they can and attempt to keep their enemies at bay, possibly having other Dregs tie them up while the Lurking Dreg darts in and out.
If Lurking Dregs find themselves outnumbered at any point, they run into the shadows and {@action Hide|XPHB}, attempting to escape.

monsterFluff.name: Magma Troll

entries: Its flesh is like molten rocks, accented by glowing veins of fire. Its eyes are two burning pools of lava. It lets out a roar that sounds like the grinding rock of an erupting volcano. Its steps leave behind pools of hot liquid magma, which drips from its hands and mouth as well.

Magma Trolls occupy the deep caverns of the earth, the vast Witherbleach desert, or the caldera of volcanoes such as the Dragon's Maw. They prefer places of sweltering heat and lava flows, and rarely leave these locations if they can help it. Naturally, the desire for food sometimes brings them out of hiding to attack mountainside communities or inhabited places near caverns and caves.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Magma Trolls hunt for food during the hottest days of summer or in places of extreme temperatures. Often accompanied by sweltering heat, they begin combat by unleashing their Sulfurous Belch before rushing in to maul foes with their claws and bites.
If a Magma Troll takes Cold damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

items.name: Master Mage

entries: Dressed in decorated ornate gold and purple robes, these mages carry a {@item staff|XPHB} of black steel with a delerium crystal encased in glass at the top. A book of spells floats beside them as they pull arcane power from the delerium orb atop their {@item staff|XPHB}.

The prestigious rank of Master Mage demonstrates the ability to cast level 5 spells or higher. This is a lifetime accomplishment for the few Academy mages who obtain it, representing decades of study, practice, and research. However, a few especially gifted and adventurous spellcasters have risen to this rank quickly.

Master Mages become instructors, project leaders, and representatives for the Amethyst Academy. They are often assigned to act as Court Mages to high-ranking or influential nobles, such as dukes and countesses.
The mages of the academy are very useful. Mostly for waving their hands and bending the world around you sort of thing.

monsterFluff.name: Maw Vermin

entries: A grotesque form lies before you. At first it seems to be just a mound of rotten meat, but its form becomes apparent when it turns toward you. A rat-like snout and eyes protrude from its rolling mass of pinkish flesh and patchy fur. It reaches for you with three long, gangly arms. Its midsection then opens with a yawning moan where a large purple tongue flops from between jagged teeth, slurping gobs of vile saliva as it drags itself towards its next meal.

The Maw Vermin's exact origins are still a mystery—are they horribly mutated ratlings who succumbed to Drakkenheim's {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} or something more sinister? It may have been a rat that fed on too much delerium or the sickly scavengers of another dimension. Some ratlings worship Maw Vermin as harbingers of the Rat God, assuming it is the closest a ratling can get to becoming a ratling angel. Some ratlings endlessly gorge on delerium, hoping to transform into a Maw Vermin to be closer to their god.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Maw Vermin, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Filled with Delerium
entries: You recognize that this creature gained the Magic {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} trait, and has {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Acid, Poison, and Necrotic damage.

entries.name: (15+) Chew and Spit!
entries: You learn the details of the Maw

entries.name: (20+) Dim but Enduring
entries: You know the Maw Vermin's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Maw Vermin is a primal creature that cannot comprehend anything beyond its next meal. Ratlings give them a wide berth, as it is just as likely to consume them as anything else. When a Maw Vermin senses anything it can eat, it lumbers towards the meal, using its Grasping Maw to pull targets closer so it can Bite them. Maw Vermin want to consume anything in sight, using its own food to secure even more. It uses Glob Launcher to spit half-digested morsels, happily eating whatever mess is left over.

monsterFluff.name: Minazorond

entries: The statue of a massive dragon sits coiled upon the tallest tower of Castle Drakken. Its cold demeanor shifts as the statue begins to tremble, waking from its slumber. Its cold eyes detect the slightest movement within the castle grounds. It stands, its wings unfurling, and cracks of octarine energy pulsing throughout its wicked form. As lightning forks behind it, illuminating its draconic form in all its majesty, it readies itself for the hunt.

Minazorond perches upon the spires of Castle Drakken, an ornate masterpiece of intricate metalworks of brass and bronze, fitted with glittering scales, diamond eyes, and jewel-encrusted wings. The great dragon was constructed by an eccentric artist from Liberio by the name of Nicoletti. The artist gained renown in Liberio for their incredible metal statues and art exhibits at the Conservatory of Creation. He was the artist responsible for the Statue of Goliath which sits in the central courtyard of the conservatory.

When commissioned by House von Drakken to build a statue befitting Castle Drakken, the artist first declined. Two months later, Nicoletti wrote back to the queen explaining that a great dragon had come to him in a dream. He claimed that the dragon emperor, Minazorond, had spoken to him, and that this mythical dragon of his dreams desired to watch over the city of Drakkenheim. The artist packed his supplies and moved to Drakkenheim to begin construction, which cost a queen's bounty in resources. Nicoletti believed that Minazorond would be the greatest work of his life, but a tragic accident occurred while hoisting the final piece of the statue to its place atop the castle. A pulley snapped, crushing Nicoletti beneath his creation. The great dragon Minazorond would be the last work Nicoletti ever created.
Now Minazorond is a contaminated construct, and swiftly defends the castle from any who dare to set foot within its courtyards or attempt to scale its walls.

entries.name: (20+) Tough to Kill
entries: You learn of its Construct Resilience trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Minazorond is an animated engine of destruction charged with the protection of Castle Drakken. The corrupted protector attacks any who approach the palace itself, opening with a terrifying roar and a barrage of shocking bursts before closing the distance to unleash its breath weapon. Under most circumstances, the dragon is too large to physically enter the palace proper, and is thus restricted to attacking targets in the castle baileys and courtyards.

items.name: Mind Leech
entries: Alienists have long dabbled with the manipulation of the mind. They have little use in their experiments for removing or transfusing blood. However, through occult magic and dangerous experimentation, they have broken ground on the possibilities of extracting thoughts.

The Mind Leech is an Alienist experiment wherein apothecaries have altered the genetics of their laboratory leeches into a Mind Leech. When placed on the back of a patient's neck, the Mind Leech sends tendrils into the spine and brainstem and pulls out the creature's psyche. This process has been used to both learn the patient's secrets and memories, as well as render them malleable to mind control, making perfect minions to Alienists.

items.name: Missionary

entries: The faith's missionaries are draped in white robes with leather belts and a sash hanging from their side adorned with the symbol of the Falling Fire. These devout missionaries lead pilgrims on their holy path to Drakkenheim, clutching the sacred writing of Lucretia Mathias in their hands.

These true believers of the Falling Fire's cause travel the continent, spreading the teachings of Lucretia Mathias. They often lead groups of pilgrims to Drakkenheim, where they hope their efforts to spread the word will be rewarded when they take up the Sacrament.
They believe their faith brings them closer to the flame. I have other ways to bring them closer.
I have often thought it would be pretty great to have an extra arm. I could swing even more swords!

With thick glasses, a white lab coat, and some rather mundane garb, the Mutagenist is an unassuming figure. The most notable thing about them is the strange potion they carry in their hand: an elixir that bubbles with purple and orange hues, swirls of shimmering blues and greens flow within it. In some fleeting moments, you swear you see the liquid take forms of grotesque faces within the bottle.

A Mutagenist has researched a serum that they inject to transform into a monstrous form. They use themselves as the conduit for this power and hurl themselves towards their enemies as a hulking abomination. They spend their lives researching and discovering new ways to improve and modify the serum in hopes of becoming the perfect Apex form.

entries.name: Mutagenist Minions
entries: The Mutagenist is constantly experimenting on other creatures before turning their concoctions onto themselves. First their tests involve small rodents, birds, or other unassuming livestock. Skinwings are one such example of a Mutagenist's early experimentation. When they move on to humanoid subjects, they create abominations like the {@creature Cerebrograft|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, while their failed experiments end up as Uncontained Growths.

Every Mutagenist strives to accomplish the ultimate goal of the Apex Formula, the elixir that will transmogrify them into the perfect specimen of humanity, at least in their altered and maddened view.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} I bury myself in books and research, and seldom talk to others.
{@b Bond:} My work is important, with my research I could cure so many of humanity's inherent weaknesses, and make us stronger as a species.
{@b Ideal:} Perfection is achievable if one just puts the time and effort into obtaining it.
{@b Flaw:} I know my view of the perfect human is flawless, I will not hear otherwise..

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study a Mutagenist, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Physiological Experts
entries: You recognize the Mutagenist's saving throws, as well as the Grotesque Gargantuan's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Forced Mutation
entries: You learn of its Mutant Strain and Transmogrifying Elixir action.

entries.name: (20+) Hulking Form
entries: You know of the Transmogrified Form's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Mutagenist relies on their spellcasting and Forced Mutation, attempting to cause debilitating effects on its foes while altering their forms.

If the Mutagenist is in a losing situation, it drinks its Transmogrifying Elixir to become its Transmogrified Form. In this form, it hurls rocks at its targets, knocking them {@condition Prone|XPHB}. The hulking Mutagenist then bounds up to them and slams them with its Meaty Fists.
She doesn't look so tough, now surrender before you...uh oh

items.name: Nathaniel Flint

entries: A simple looking man in his early thirties stands before you, one hand outstretched towards you in a gesture of friendly aid. He has curly brown hair, a warm calm upon his face, and wears dark gray robes and simple boots. Beneath his robes, the gentle octarine glow can be seen from his chest.

Nathaniel watches over the Hendrix Farm where Falling Fire pilgrims on their way into Drakkenheim rest or live. He sees to their needs, ensureing the commune is well stocked with bed rolls, firewood, simple food, and any other supplies needed for basic survival. The pilgrimage leader keeps the fires lit, and a bubbling pot of stew available on the communal fire. He is also the guide who brings many into the city to meet with Lucretia, and from time to time brings groups of pilgrims to the Crater's Edge to be sanctified. He takes his job very seriously, believing whole-heartedly in the teachings of Lucretia.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I speak in a warm and friendly tone, and often use metaphors of light and darkness to make my points. I want all who are in my presence to feel welcome and important.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Everyone deserves a real chance to see the light for themselves. No matter the darkness they carry, all darkness must flee in the presence of light once one lets it in.

entries.name: Bond
entries: Lucretia Mathias has led these people to something incredible, and the more one speaks to her, and sees her power, the more obvious it is that she is a prophet, and she speaks a truth few can understand. I believe in her more than anyone else in this world and wish only to do right by her teachings.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I assume the best in people and am willfully ignorant to the harm that could be done by trusting too easily.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Nathaniel is not a combatant, and rarely uses his divine powers to harm. However, if he must defend himself, or more likely, protect his pilgrims. Nathaniel uses {@spell Aid} and {@spell Bless} to bolster his allies, {@spell Spirit Guardians} to protect himself, and use {@spell Fireball||Fireballs} if absolutely necessary to put down his foes.
He will flee as soon as he can and help as many friends as possible do the same.

monsterFluff.name: Night Blade

entries: This shadowy figure is draped in a flowing black cloak with glowing red eyes peering out from the dark hood. A bandolier of blades hangs across their chest. The creature moves across the battlefield with an unnatural swiftness.

The Night Blades serve as elite assassins for their vampire lords. These powerful vampire spawn are tasked with eliminating anyone who threatens to expose the secretive existence of the vampires. When anyone delves too deeply into their affairs, these assassins act swiftly and silently to neutralize interlopers.

Expertly adept at navigating the shadows, Night Blades are not only assassins but also skilled spies for their nocturnal court. They excel at infiltrating enemy strongholds, gathering crucial intelligence, and remaining undetected. Their abilities to scale walls, meld into shadows, and vanish without a trace make them formidable opponents. It is wise for enemies of the vampire lords to converse in brightly lit rooms during daylight, as any discussions held under the cover of darkness are vulnerable to the ears of the Night Blades, who are the eyes and ears of the shadows themselves.

Within the Court of the Night, there exists a specialized faction known as the Night Sisters. The exact number of these vampiric assassins is unknown, but they have orchestrated numerous high-profile assassinations over the centuries. Working closely with the highest echelons of the court, the Night Sisters represent the pinnacle of the court's lethal capabilities and are tasked with eliminating particularly significant targets that the court seeks to dispatch.

entries.name: Combat Tactics

They attack their foes using their spectral weapons, using the Mindmuddler option against spellcasters. If the target is still alive by the 2nd round, the Night Blade takes the {@action Disengage|XPHB} action to escape.
The Night Blade flees if it is at a {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, is surrounded, or is in direct sunlight.

monsterFluff.name: Oak Troll

entries: What at first appears to be a large pile of autumn leaves rises up and reveals a grotesque carved wooden face and gnarled oaken claws and feet. Its body is cloaked in a thick array of leaves all in hues of oranges, yellows, and reds. As it lurches forward it sounds like the autumn wind blowing through a lush forest, the sounds of its grunts and moans like creaking boughs of ancient trees, and its thumping footsteps like wooden branches hitting the forest floor.

The Oak Trolls wander the woods of the Achtungwald, Trogrowth, and many other forests of the continent. They tend and speak to the forests and trees. When outsiders come through their territory, the trolls defend their trees at all costs.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: With their thick shroud of leaves, Oak Trolls are well protected from their enemies. They always look for an opportunity to send their leaves bursting off to Blind their enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Octarine Tree

entries: Trudging through the thick overgrowth of Queen's Park Garden, you come across a massive tree with dark, nearly blackened bark, branches swaying and bobbing in the Haze-filled winds of the city. Unlike its barren and dying cousins nearby, its bright and flourishing foliage is alive. The ribs and veins of its thick purple leaves are shot through with pulsing octarine. Gently glowing upon its branches in small clusters are {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}, sprouting from the tree like acorns. The whistling of the wind echoes through the delerium growths causing them to echo like eerie chimes. As you draw closer, the thick bough begins to shake and bend against the wind, and the tree's roots suddenly tear up from the soft earth. The massive shambling tree lurches up, and its darkened bark stretches and forms into a snarling grotesque face as it barrels towards you.

The trees surrounding Drakkenheim for miles in every direction are decrepit and dying things with blackened dead bark, thick knobby roots, and gnarled bare branches. Those traveling the dark roads to Drakkenheim remark how the trees appear like skeletal hands reaching up to the Haze-filled sky. As the trees sway in the wind, even when there is no breeze, the haunting rustling of their dead leaves and creaking boughs sounds like distant whispers.

Yet a few among the foliage carry a hint of life still, soaking up the contaminated rainfall and groundwaters of the toxic Drann River. Their deep roots draw up the delerium in the soil and they are altered in ways that defy understanding. As one approaches the city proper, these trees begin to form strange growths, and crystal fruit in unfathomable colors sprout in abundance upon their twisted branches.

Druids would always say that the trees spoke to them, that the plants and foliage of the land had stories. Now, the forests surrounding the city for miles speak of pain, suffering, anger, and fury. Druids who have come to Drakkenheim have sensed the foreboding of the flora within the city, warning against approaching those strange trees with delerium growths.

These Octarine Trees are terrible to behold, and a tragic sign of the corruption seeping into the earth. They have taken on a life of their own, rising from the soil in a hostile sense of hatred towards the living. They seek to spread their sickness, wailing and hurling contaminated delerium at all who get in their way.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (5+) Resilient Sapling.
entries: You learn of the Octarine Tree's type, its {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Flying Fruit.
entries: You are aware of the creature's Delerium Fruit action.

entries.name: (15+) Combustible Timber.
entries: You recognize the creature's vulnerability to fire.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Octarine Tree grows in clusters within Queen's Park Garden, or in the forests north of Drakkenheim, but lone trees have been spotted in advantageous positions throughout the city. Whether in market squares or growing on cliff sides overlooking parts of the city, the trees seem to keep watch over large stretches of road. The Octarine Tree is surprisingly fast when it decides to move but usually opts to root itself in a good position and throw Delerium Fruit at its enemies.

When engaged in melee, an Octarine Tree tangles up creatures in its Crushing Roots and Thwacks them. It will take an opportunity to lumber to a better position and plant itself in the ground to continue hurling fruit if it can.

monsterFluff.name: Oracle of the Rat God

entries: Wrapped in ritual robes and carrying a skull-tipped staff, this wizened, albino ratling chants hymns in high-pitched squeaks in praise to the Rat God. Her beady red eyes flare with zealous passion.

These devoted followers of the Rat God are amongst the most gifted and powerful ratling spellcasters. Among the most ancient ratlings, only a handful exist. Most were among the first to gnaw upon delerium and transform in the days after the meteor fell. They have seen the rise and fall of countless ratling warbands and colonies. They are welcome in any burrow being seen as an omen for feast and fortune, often driving them to self-destructive excess, believeing the oracle is a clear sign it's time to rise up against their rivals. While Ratling Oracles claim to have visions of the future, they are far from master planners. Possessed with a mad certainty, their fervent proclamations inspire fury and murder in their fellow ratlings

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} an Oracle of the Rat God, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Divinely Resistant
entries: You learn of the Oracle of the Rat God's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Fiendish Foresight
entries: You recognize the oracle's Death Toll and Squeak of Doom actions, as well as its Tail Barbs {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

entries.name: (20+) Aware and Commanding
entries: You know the Oracle of the Rat God's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: These revered figures are seldom encountered alone. Instead, they are often in the company of several Swarms of Ratlings and perhaps even borne aloft on a litter by a squadron of Giant Ratlings. They may even have several Warlocks of the Rat God serving them as underlings. These minions are disposable to the oracle, who commands their underlings to throw themselves against their foes with wild abandon.

In battle, a ratling oracle fights from the back, calling out proclamations of doom on their foes using Death Toll and Squeak of Doom. They mock their foes' attempts at any success, attempting to use Tail Barbs to turn an opponent's luck against them.

monsterFluff.name: Pale Man

entries: Standing impossibly still in the shadows, a tall, gaunt figure stares with eyes like dim lanterns. Its skin is chalk white, stretched tight over an emaciated frame. Its mouth curls into an uncanny smile far too wide for its face. Without a sound, it tilts its head, and you feel a cold wave of dread wash over you as its gaze locks with yours.

Little is known about the Pale Man, and less still is certain. Whispers speak of a spectral killer who stalks the ruins of Drakkenheim, appearing suddenly in the periphery before vanishing again into darkness. The few who claim to have survived an encounter speak of an unnatural stillness, of feeling watched long before the Pale Man was seen, and of an overwhelming urge to flee the moment his eyes met theirs.

Some believe the Pale Man to be a unique undead spirit, perhaps the remnant of a powerful mage who perished when the meteor struck. Others claim he is no ghost at all, but a living man who has been irreversibly twisted by the Haze and delerium, granting him supernatural resilience and abilities beyond mortal ken. A few dark rumors suggest he commands other horrors in the city, using them as his eyes and ears.

The Pale Man rarely strikes directly. Instead, he manipulates fear itself, unsettling his prey until they are too rattled to think clearly, then dispatches them with sudden and overwhelming violence. His motives remain inscrutable—he seems to kill without pattern, mercy, or need, as though compelled by a cruel instinct or sadistic amusement.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (10+) Unnatural Resilience.
entries: You learn the Pale Man's monster type, {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Fear Incarnate.
entries: You are aware of the Pale Man's Terror Gaze action.

entries.name: (20+) Predator's Precision.
entries: You know the Pale Man's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Pale Man is a consummate ambush predator. He prefers to stalk prey from concealment, sowing paranoia before striking. He uses his Terror Gaze to incapacitate or scatter groups, then isolates and eliminates targets one by one.

If pressed into open combat, he uses his unnatural agility to slip away, often retreating into darkness or vanishing from sight entirely, only to resume his hunt moments later. He never fights to the death unless cornered, and even then, he uses every trick at his disposal to escape.

This figure is draped in a heavy coat, with a bag full of tinctures, poisons, alchemical ingredients, and dried herbs. A gas mask and a drawn hood conceal their face. The Pathogenist draws a syringe filled with a glowing green formula as an acrid smell wafts from around them. They double check their pathogen, ensuring it is ready for their victims.

The study of diseases opens doorways to many dangerous scientific discoveries. As experts in both ridding the body of illness and the mutations of infectious disease, a Pathogenist brings their study to the battlefield by using monsters and enemies as test subjects for their infections. Long years spent carefully monitoring the causes and effects of such plagues has led to a mastery of disease mutation. A Pathogenist's creations can spread in a terrifying manner, riddling their foes with debilitating symptoms, crippling their bodies and rattling their minds.

entries.name: Pathogenist Minions
entries: An {@creature Injector|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} makes a great lab assistant for the Pathogenist, helping it administer disease and pathogens to its victims. {@creature Wretched Patient|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Wretched Patients} are often disease-ridden, bandaged individuals who are convinced that, if they aid the doctor, they will be cured. {@creature Plague Carrier|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Plague Carriers} are a common unfortunate product of a Pathogenist's experiments, used to deliver disease to its enemies in grotesque fashion.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} I love my pathogens and viruses, and speak to my babies as if they were my children.
{@b Bond:} Understanding the fine balance between what it takes to harm or heal is vital to the ongoing progression of modern medicine.
{@b Ideal:} Disease is often feared and misunderstood, but with understanding, comes control. You do not need to fear that which you control
{@b Flaw:} I am bound to my work and cannot fathom the idea that I am misguided in my research..

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Pathogenist uses poison and disease to disable their foes. When combat begins, they attempt to inflict Plague of Wind upon a target, and proceed to use Outbreak to spread that disease. The Pathogenist uses Poison Needle to subdue problematic targets. The Pathogenist will attempt to flee if they have fewer than 40 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and are outnumbered.
Pro tip, go for the eyes before it goes for your blood.

monsterFluff.name: Phage

entries: You glimpse a region of space that seems warped, as if something that doesn't belong in this existence is trespassing here. A glint of strange anatomy appears, a wilted sack of flesh propelled upon four leg-like appendages. Within the center of its form opens a large baleen mouth, gleefully gurgling as it shuffles towards you.

The Space Between Worlds is home to alien bottomfeeders known as phages, consuming any magical energy they can find. The barriers between realities become thin near Drakkenheim's Haze-filled areas allowing these creatures to leak through, hungry for mortal magic. They consume spells, storing some of this arcane energy for later ingestion. Sometimes spellcasters can recapture the arcane energy of undigested spells upon the death of a Phage.

On rare occasions, intelligent creatures have tamed Phages, using them as guardians against spellcasting threats. However, they can never be fully controlled and are nearly as likely to consume it's master's spells as any others.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries: You are aware of its Warped Space trait.

entries.name: (10+) Magic Eater
entries: You understand its Consume Spell {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} and Bite attack.

entries.name: (15+) Stored Energy
entries: You learn of the Phage's Spell Vessel trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Phages are compelled by their hunger for magic. They use their Consume Spell {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} at the first opportunity, regardless of the spell being cast.

Unfed phages stalk their prey, harassing them with Bites but attacking nonlethally as a dead spellcaster cannot provide them with magical energy. Sated phages often become docile, only using Bite or Spit in defense, disengaging to escape if given the opportunity. When their lives are threatened, Phages digest stored spells to reposition in hopes of getting an even tastier morsel.

items.name: Pilgrim

entries: Dressed in plain gray robes tied off with a frayed rope, and wearing little else but a pair of old sandals, these pilgrims carry little on them and have given up their possessions for a simple life dedicated to the Falling Fire.

The prophetic words of Lucretia Mathias have inspired hundreds of commonfolk to make their way to Drakkenheim. Their motives and reasons are varied: some seek meaning and purpose in life which they find in the righteous calling of the Testament of the Falling Fire. Others are devout adherents to the Faith of the Sacred Flame who are disillusioned by what they see as the corruption and meddling of the clergy. A few travel to join their friends and family members who have already taken up with the Falling Fire.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Untrained and unprepared for combat, most pilgrims can only operate as a mob, using their numbers to overwhelm threats. Faith strengthens their resolve, and their morale holds fast whilst their leaders spurn them to holy purpose.

monsterFluff.name: Plague Carrier

entries: These deformed and horrific abominations were once people, now covered in boils and sores. Festering wounds and large bubbling blisters cover their exposed flesh. Draped in ragged clothes, their swelling and sagging flesh is riddled with disease. Pus oozes from their wounds, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, they smell of foul alchemical agents, and decay.

The Plague Carriers are the unfortunate test subjects of Pathogenists who have taken to harboring their deadly pathogens within a living vessel for abrupt and grotesque delivery. Plague Carriers are often patients who came to the mad apothecary already sick with one disease or another, and signed off on experimental procedures without reading the fine print.

Pathogenists use these living vessels to incubate and foster new variations of diseases. Apothecaries sometimes use the mortal body as a lab for mixing and matching various diseases at once to see the outcomes they produce. For all the laboratory science a Pathogenist can do, there is no more accurate scientific procedure than a living test subject. Pathogenists often experiment on rats and small creatures first, but when they fail to bring their more complex reagents to proper formation, they move on to humanoid subjects, who in the process are rendered into mindless minions.

The Pathogenist doesn't dispose of their failed experiments. Instead, they often keep them festering, and in their madness, a small but dangerous idea forms. What if a single test subject is not a large enough experiment? What if this test subject could be sent into a populated area and unleashed, spreading the disease? Oftentimes this idea comes at the hands of a pathogenist who has been shunned from their village or town, who now sees the locals as their enemies, and is willing to use entire populations as a testing ground for their pathogens. The delivery method being a gory and gruesome display of sending a plague carrier in, and having them overflow with the diseases inside, causing a horrific and dangerous pandemic to emerge in their abrupt death.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Plague Carrier is a vile creature whose sole purpose is to spread its infection. It runs into a crowds and use its Bile Spreader to infect as many targets as possible, resorting to biting any who get too close. It cares little for its own safety and does not retreat

monsterFluff.name: Protean Abomination

entries: A mass of flesh and tissue quivers and wobbles. Its multiple appendages include outstretched humanoid arms, wriggling tentacles, gangly limbs with talons, and clasping claws. The creature pulls itself forward, squealing and whining from multiple deformed mouths. Numerous multi-colored eyes in misplaced arrangements move and shift across the form. Tumors bulge and shrink within its mass. As the creature spots you, a chaotic chorus of cries cascades out of its chomping mouths.

Often, when continued exposure to {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} corrupts a creature, it can no longer contain its wretched form. Drakkenheim's mutations often allow a creature to adapt to its surroundings, or exaggerates its already horrible features. Eventually however, successive mutations begin to fold on themselves, giving way to the wholly unrecognizable and completely alien Protean Abomination.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Survival|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) check to {@action Study|XPHB} a Protean Abomination, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Corpse Eater
entries: You know of its Absorption trait.

entries.name: (15+) Enveloping Mass
entries: You uncover the Protean Abomination's Engulf feature.

entries.name: (20+) Weak Minded
entries: You recognize the abomination's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Protean Abomination is a hungry creature that hides in dark ruins, old basements, or in piles of rubble, squeezing out to devour anything that comes by. No longer capable of strategic or nuanced thought, the Protean Abomination simply wishes to feed, grow, and survive. It is very territorial and once it has chosen a place to nest, it will stay there for months or years, only moving if it has gone weeks without absorbing a creature.
When prey does wander by, Protean Abominations will attempt to move up to the creature and Engulf it. It wants only to absorb the creature into its mass and grow stronger.
If brought below half {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the abomination might try to squeeze into a location where it cannot be followed to escape, waiting patiently for less problematic prey.

monsterFluff.name: Psychophant

entries: It begins in the eyes. A glistening veneer of tears that coagulate against the surface of the eye and begins to ooze. The white sclera dribbles in gelatinous rivulets down sagging cheeks. Its flesh is mottled. Browns, tans, greens, and purples color the unseemly visage. One side of the face twists downward in a cruel sneer, the other side, expressionless. Slack jawed, the mouth opens into a gaping expanse. It's quiet weeping turns into pleas for its life, frenetic cries, a cacophony of voices. The chorus of agony rises to a crescendo, culminating with an ear-splitting scream as its arms reach for you.

The earliest stories of this realm tell of a great winter when the desperate cried out to anyone who may hear their pleas. These calls echoed in the vastness of the Space Between Worlds, attracting the attention of things from beyond. Psychophants, scavengers drawn to misery, fear, and despair, entered the mortal world through Thin Places and learned to mimic their prey. These adaptive creatures integrate themselves among the vulnerable to feed upon their emotions.

Even now, Civil War veterans of Westemr, huddled in smoky bars recount scouring battlefields for their fallen allies, following distressed cries, only to be set upon by the wounded themselves. In the overwhelmed hospitals of Toddsfeld, contaminated patients insist they are being preyed upon by their nurses, only to have these accusations dismissed as madness. The wretched trenches of war, the blighted lands of natural disasters, the reeking sick beds of convalescent homes, and now, the ruins of Drakkenheim, have all fallen victim to these creature's appetites.

Psychophants are shifters, able to disguise themselves with ease. Some assume the guise of caretakers; such as clerics of the Sacred Flame and Falling Fire, apothecaries and their assistants, and even members of the Hooded Lanterns who watch infirmaries. None are safe from their nefarious infiltration. Psychophants seek positions where they can feed on the vulnerable, ensuring easy access to their victims.

One may quietly stalk a target for weeks, absorbing its mannerisms, and learning its speech, preparing for an opportunity to supplant them. Even when a Psychophant has time to prepare, their ability to deceive is limited. Only able to repeat phrases it has heard spoken by others, their speech is stunted and uncomfortable, their responses terse, or only loosely related to the subject being discussed. While their adopted form is indistinguishable from the original, they lack the skills a target may have possessed.

Pyschophants without the time or impetus to supplant an individual often create an amalgamated identity, combining personal lore overheard from many and pairing it with a stranger's shape. These patchwork creatures are unable to avoid scrutiny for long, frequently moving from town to town. In the ruins of Drakkenheim false pretense lasts only moments. In the ruins, they prey on wounded adventurers posing as an unfortunate survivor of a doomed expedition, begging for help and wailing in despair. Approaching rescuers usually realize too late that the screams coming from this woeful figure are the cries of its most recent victims.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Insight|XPHB} or {@skill Investigation|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action study} a Psychophant, revealing the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Feeding on Despair
entries: You are aware of its Life Siphon ability.

entries.name: (10+) Resistant Form
entries: You know its {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Escape with Prey
entries: You learn of the creature's Teleport {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Psychophant feeds on the weak and will avoid a fight with competent adventurers unless the right opportunity presents itself, or its true nature is discovered. In combat it will attempt to subdue aggressors with its Final Scream, then target the bloodiest opponent with its Psychic Grasp. Victim in hand, it will attempt to flee using Teleportation, repeatedly feeding on the target with its Life Siphon until the creature falls unconscious.

monsterFluff.name: Pyknic Maunder

entries: This horror is an amorphous mass of limbs, hands, mouths, and eyes. Among the disturbing mess are hands with eyes embedded in the palms that have mouths for pupils, fingers that end in hands with fingers that end in hands, eyes within eyes within mouths with wriggling fingertips for teeth, lips for eyelids, and grasping hands for tongues. Some of the many-colored eyes dart about in panic while others droop lazily as if falling in and out of sleep. Some of the mouths talk, citing obscure languages and bits of poetry, while the countless hands gesticulate frantically.

Eldritch contamination induces chaotic and random mutations that care little for form and function. The changes cause flesh to waste away, exposing raw muscle as skin melts; fingernails, teeth, tongues, and eyes fall out; the lips rot and fester; and the bones turn to jelly. Eventually, the cascading mutations result in total dissolution into a roiling mass of mutated flesh, flailing limbs, and disparate sensory organs known as a Pyknic Maunder.

Transformation into such a wretched creature is typical in cases of sudden, rapid, and overwhelming exposure to contamination. This was a common fate of those just outside the immediate blast of the falling stars who avoided vaporization but were instead exposed to the full brunt of contaminated magic. However, maunders can also be created when people or animals are exposed to intense contamination from {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly}, powerful contaminated spells, or are gravely wounded by delerium-infused weaponry. In particular, this may occur when multiple delerium-tipped arrowheads or bolts become imbedded deep into the body. In at least one documented case, a foolish adventurer who tried ingesting a delerium shard quickly mutated into a maunder. Rumors speak of maunders also being created from experimenting with delerium or trying to develop contaminated spells.

Maunders live out a pathetic and confused existence, grasping their way throughout Drakkenheim; they are found everywhere in the city. The creatures attack everything they encounter, including other maunders, absorbing more flesh and matter from their kills. A maunder that grows too large eventually collapses upon itself, and several smaller maunders emerge from the remains to shuffle through the ruins. On rare occasions, these maunders collect and form into a Protean Abomination, a much larger version capable of maintaining its form.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A maunder has no sense for combat tactics and exists only to eat whatever it can get within the grasp of its many hands. Once it has hold of a creature, it immediately begins to feed using its Bite. A Pyknic Maunder will attack an unconscious or downed character, uncaring about other attackers.
