items.name: Queen of Thieves
entries: The Queen of Thieves is a scheming mastermind who controls Drakkenheim's underworld. She transformed a hundreds of squabbling outlaws into a criminal empire. However, none know her true identity. She is most infamously encountered as lithe masked woman in swashbuckling attire with a wide-brimmed hat and jeweled rapier. However, she may radically change her appearance, as her mood and circumstances dictate. She typically confirms her identity by revealing a secret or by demonstrating her uncanny ability to alter her appearance.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: "I am never unprepared and have multitudes of contingencies. I casually expose secrets with rakish confidence, and flaunt my ability to be anybody or anywhere."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I relish mind games and manipulating people. Instead of spilling blood, I spill secrets. My enemies are worthless as corpses. When I steal lives, I spend them dearly first."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Law is powerless in the chaos of the ruins. As long as anarchy reigns, so shall I."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Anyone who trusts me is a terrible fool. Double-crossing is my nature. I expect everyone to betray me, and I'll relish the opportunity to defeat them when they do."
Few of the Queen's Men have met her, and even less have been in the Court of Thieves. Most only know that, if you get a Queen of Diamonds card with a note attached, you better do what it says.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Queen of Thieves never fights a battle personally unless she knows she's going to win. If you're running her in combat, she should attempt escape unless you are utterly certain she will defeat your player characters. She does not slay the player characters but should allow them to flee or take them captive. Either way, she mocks them mercilessly for trying to defeat her.
When the Queen of Thieves needs to escape, she uses her Dash and Misdirection Epic Actions, before using {@spell Greater Invisibility}, {@spell Dimension Door}, or {@spell Gaseous Form} to slip away.

entries.name: Queen's Men

entries: Who I am is not as important as what I am. I am quicker than thought, quieter than contemplation, and more slippery than a fading memory. I deal in secrets and lies as lesser thieves deal in larceny. I can fulfill your wildest dreams, or be your worst nightmare.

The ruins of Drakkenheim attract all manner of scavengers, looters, deserters, and fugitives. The anarchic and dangerous ruins are an ideal hiding place for those on the wrong side of the law, and there is no shortage of plunder and work for those who don't mind getting their hands dirty. The many disparate bands of brigands and outlaws have been brought together into a loose alliance under the thumb of the manipulative and enigmatic Queen of Thieves. Under her rule, the Queen's Men smuggle delerium to disreputable clients in distant lands, exhort and rob adventurers, shakedown pilgrims, and act as a constant thorn in the side of the other factions.

entries.name: Queen's Men Combat Tactics
entries: Amongst the Queen's Men, different groups may be organized as infiltrators, thieves, saboteurs, and assassins, who work unseen until the moment they strike. In contrast, highway robbers and enforces operate openly, trying to shakedown and intimidate their marks to give up any valuables without a fight. Regardless, members of the Queen's Men are seldom willing to stick around when a fight starts going against them, valuing their own lives first and foremost

monsterFluff.name: Rat God

entries: The massive floating figure resembles a large vermin with a thousand tails spanning out from behind it, shaped into six massive wings. Its large protruding belly is filled with a hundred small rat faces chattering, gnashing, and screaming. Its four elongated arms each end in eight vermin fingers and it holds two of its hands before it in a symbolic form of a rat head. The other two arms are held off to the side, each clutching a rusted chain; one chain ends in a censer gently glowing with purple flames and wafting incense, the other ends in a flail of bloodied rat skulls. Its head is composed of three vermin faces with glowing purple eyes and a large central eye upon an elongated forehead. Floating above it is a halo of jagged rotating blades that drips blood down upon its head, seeping and running down its body, pouring into oblivion below. It speaks in a chorus of endless rasping voices, echoing and reverberating in pitches and tones that form words out of an auditory mosaic of scurrying rat swarms and gnawing little teeth.

Often dismissed by adventurers and scholars as a fantasy conjured up in the minds of the superstitious ratlings, the Rat God appears to be a new figure amongst the multitudinous eldritch beings inhabiting the cosmos. In actuality, the Rat God has gnawed on the bones of reality for eons, growing fat and powerful on the remains of slain demon lords, fallen elder entities, and destroyed worlds.

The Rat God has followed the course of delerium throughout the universe, eager for opportunities to feast amidst the chaos the crystals bring in their devastating wake. The {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} and rampant mutations caused by delerium create the perfect conditions under which the Rat God can enter the Mortal World temporarily and glut itself upon contaminated flesh and magic. Drakkenheim and the world it rests upon has become the latest stop for this wandering interdimensional scavenger.

Acting through its warlocks and oracles, the Rat God has enthralled the ratlings of Drakkenheim, sweeping them into its apocalyptic plan to enter the Mortal World and devour it. Ratlings believe that the Rat God guides them through shadows and whispers, pushing them to grow in size and number so they can one day overtake the world. Indeed, the Rat God does send visions and messages to favored ratlings, encouraging them to breed and consume—a chittering throng is needed to conduct the Great Gnaw, the summoning spell to bring the Rat God out of the abyss and into the Material Plane. The Rat God makes pacts with ratlings who demonstrate a curiosity and aptitude for magic, especially those who foster a feverous worship towards the arcane arts, knowing that there must be talented ratling spellcasters to carry out the Great Gnaw.

Meanwhile, the Rat God is not without its foes. {@creature Eldritch Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Trolls} has hunted the Rat God throughout the cosmos, eager to itself consume the gluttonous Rat God. The two entities have played a great eldritch game of cat-and-mouse for countless mortal lifetimes.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The Rat God has destructive and apocalyptic motivations.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} You seem hungry. Are you hungry?
{@b Ideal:} Eat or be eaten. That is the way of things. Eat! Eat! Eat! It is all food when you need to survive!
{@b Bond:} What you have is not enough. If you kill and eat them all. What was theirs is now yours!
{@b Flaw:} Why does your friend get to have nicer things than you? Don't you deserve them instead? Betray them! Eat them! Make it yours!

entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill History|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the Rat God, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (20+) Fiendish Power
entries: You are aware of its {@sense Truesight|XPHB} and telepathy, its {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, and its Epic {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB}. You also know this Rat God is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed

entries.name: (25+) Cloud of Rats
entries: You are aware of the creature's Verminous Aura trait.

entries.name: (30+) Powerful Presence
entries: You know Rat God's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Rat God is a being of pure malice and appetite. It cares not for the whims of mortals, only for pure destruction and the chattering and gnawing of infinite rats as they devour the cosmos. It finds joy only in annihilation, and the screams of mortals as they are reduced to bone by the Rat God's writhing swarm.

The Rat God can use its Rodent Rift to move to where it can catch as many targets as possible in its Verminous Aura, then set them ablaze with its Flail of Skulls. It will target the weakest characters with its Warp Bolt, and the least intelligent with its Infernal Chittering. It performs a Great Feeding to replenish itself and uses Rodent Rifts to escape a dangerous situation.

monsterFluff.name: Rat King

entries: A writhing column consisting of a knotted mass of entwined rat-tails wobbles towards you. A score of drooling ratlings, their bodies twisted and merged together, support the bloated tail-spire. Their clawed feet scamper frantically to propel this horrendous heap of rat-flesh. Their beady eyes glimmer with eerie glow as the wiggling tails whip up volatile eldritch energy.

Not to be confused with the Rat Prince, a Rat King is a mutated fusion of multiple ratlings into a single being of psionic might. Often the result of a catastrophic {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} involving a swarm of ratlings that fuses their tails together into a horrific knot. The resulting pillar of rat-flesh is a writhing and wriggling abomination. Other ratlings find Rat Kings terrible to behold and shun them from their colonies.the accidental byproduct of a failed magical experiment, while certain cults whisper that the Rat King is a herald or servant of darker, verminous deities.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Rat King gains a bizarre hive-mind making it highly intelligent and almost prescient. In battle, it lurches forward launching a barrage of psionic attacks, using Tail Whip and Psychic Blast to shred its target's mind.

monsterFluff.name: Rat Prince

entries: This ratling stands head-and-shoulders over the others and has black-brown fur and a wicked grin; some of his frontmost teeth are {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}. He wears scavenged bits of light armor, tattered dark blue rags, and a gold crown, which is slightly too small for his head.

This fearsome ratling ringleader has self-styled himself as the Rat Prince. Dwelling amongst the Rat's Nest Tavern burrow, the Rat Prince and his posse are the scourge of rookie adventurers exploring the Outer City of Drakkenheim. He rules because he's the biggest, strongest, and killed the last ratling who called themselves the Rat Prince. He dreams of one day conquering all the other ratling colonies and demanding all the other ratlings bow down to him.

items.name: Personality
items.entry: The Epic Boss chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls {@dice 1d20}. On an 11 or higher, the effect ends on it. An Epic Boss can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

items.name: Ideal
items.entry: The Rat Prince loves killing, eating, breeding, and sleeping. Pretty much in that order.

items.name: Bond
items.entry: The Rat Prince wears a makeshift crown and claims he's the ruler of all the ratlings in Drakkenheim. This is far from true, but good luck convincing the Rat Prince otherwise.

items.name: Epic Resistance
items.entry: Logic makes the Rat Prince confused and angry, unless that logic involves food. The Rat Prince holds the Rat God in equal fear and awe. He is very superstitious about necromancy, illusions, and enchantment magic. He is afraid of ghosts but loves fire.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Insight|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} the Rat Prince, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Fearsome Leader
entries: You know he has the traits of a typical ratling, though he is much more formidable.

entries.name: (10+) Delerium Teeth
entries: You recognize the Rat Prince's Contaminated Bite attack.

entries.name: (15+) Adverse to Logic
entries: You are aware of the Rat Prince's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws, as well as the flaws noted in the Rat Prince's roleplaying traits.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Leading other ratlings into battle, the Rat Prince is a ferocious combatant. He uses his Sacrificial Pawn Reaction to avoid attacks while firing his crossbow or attacking ferociously with his Contaminated Bite. He uses Ratling Cunning to ensure that he remains adjacent to another ratling he can use as a body shield.

Caught alone, the Rat Prince doesn't fight: he flees. If he can't, he cries and begs for his life. He will sell out other ratlings if it means his own survival. When this rat is cornered, he offers anything he can think of to convince characters to let him go free, and will claim he can lead characters to fantastic treasures, secret passages through the city, vast amounts of "the shiny," and boasts that his favorable reputation amongst the ratlings can guarantee safety. Whether or not these are true is up to you. Unless the characters can make the Rat Prince loyal in some other way (through food, fear, or magic), he tries to escape at the earliest opportunity.

monsterFluff.name: Ratling Alchemist

entries: This ratling sports a pair of thick goggles and an impressive custom-built crossbow. The skittish rat wears a scraped-together, acid-stained leather coat and a bandolier of bubbling flasks and vials that hangs along its belt. It mixes glowing liquids that fume and sizzle, preparing to hurl a vial toward you.

All ratlings possess a wicked cunning, but a few among them are gifted with an inventive spirit, reckless curiosity, and explosive intentions. Often beginning with a fascination with fire or the strange and erratic effects of delerium, these ratlings use improvised materials, unstable ingredients, and scavenged tools to experiment and tinker, building crude devices and sometimes ingenious traps. Two out of three ratlings who attempt to become an alchemist die in their own explosions, but the one that makes it often becomes a horrible force against their foes.

entries.name: Study the Foe

entries.name: (5+) Chemical Exposure
entries: You are aware these creatures have an excellent sense of smell, {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, are capable climbers and swimmers and its unique damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (10+) Inventive and Cunning
entries: You learn of the ratling's Repeating Crossbow and Delerium Bomb actions.

entries.name: (15+) Nimble but Weak
entries: You recognize the ratling's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Ratling Alchemist is a ranged combatant who keeps to the backfield, where they can safely snipe their foes with their crossbow. They are happy to take pot shots when their bodyguards go down, using their Covering Fire {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.
A Ratling Alchemist doesn't care about the wellbeing or safety of their fellow ratlings, and will throw its Delerium Bomb at foes even if their allies are in the blast area.

monsterFluff.name: Ratling Burrow Warden

entries: This burly ratling stands a head taller than their broodlings, wearing a fearless expression upon their snarling snout. Clad in scavenged bits of armor, they carry a broad, makeshift shield which may have once been a window shutter, tabletop, or part of a door. They wield a long spear topped with a vicious chunk of sharp scrap metal that appears to be coated in some kind of toxic sludge.

Ratlings look to the biggest among their number for leadership, forming posses around the largest and loudest, called Burrow Wardens. These ratlings get the privilege of bossing their comrades around, taking a larger share of food, and first pick amongst the spoils of their raids and ambushes. While Burrow Wardens might act like petty tyrants, these bullies also must constantly prove their strength and bravery lest a rival rise up to take their place. Wardens are often found at the forefront of any battle to demonstrate their might and ferocity. The smaller ratlings quite like this arrangement, as it puts their bully-bosses on the front lines during a burrow invasion. If the ratlings grow tired of one of their Burrow Wardens and want to replace them, they are in the best place to stab the big one in the back, cut them down if they're wounded, or abandon them alone against a deadly foe.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Athletics|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Ratling Burrow Warden, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Powerful Ratling
entries: You know these creatures have similar senses and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} as a typical ratling but are physically tougher and much stronger.

entries.name: (10+) Aggressive Attacker
entries: You are aware of the Burrow Warden's Pack Tactics trait and Shield Shove action.

entries.name: (15+) Strong and Tough
entries: You recognize the Burrow Warden's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Ratling Burrow Wardens often form a tight formation during an attack, taking up their shields and poison-tipped spears to defend choke points. They especially like using their Shield Shove to push attackers into pits or other prepared traps in the burrow.

monsterFluff.name: Ratling Guttersnipe

entries: A cloaked ratling appears from out of the shadows, a wicked blade carved from delerium in its claws. A hand crossbow hangs at their side with a quiver of poison-tipped bolts. They fire at you, then dash from the shadows, lunging to attack.

The small survive in the ruins through stealth, cunning, and a solid repertoire of under-handed tricks. Ratling Guttersnipes possess hard-won skills learned through bitter experience, and are rightfully respected and feared amongst their comrades. These grim-toothed ratlings have learned to plan careful ambushes, place deadly traps, and lure their prey into unfavorable situations. Honing their senses to a hair trigger, they are ready to kill quickly.

Guttersnipes arm themselves with choice equipment pried from the corpses of dead faction agents and explorers. These skilled thieves are bold enough to sneak outside the ruins on occasion to steal supplies, equipment, and food from faction strongholds, and even occasionally make nighttime break-ins to isolated homes and farmsteads.

The Guttersnipes observed the impact delerium had on humanoid creatures, and found inspiration for using delerium as a weapon, knowing that beyond the cut of a blade, the {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is an even more deadly component to be dealt with. All Guttersnipes carry delerium weapons, often constructed simply by finding a sharp shard of delerium and fastening it to a makeshift hilt.

entries.name: (5+) Mutated Monstrosities
entries: You understand these creatures have an excellent sense of smell, {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, and are capable climbers and swimmers. They are Immune to Contamination, but have no other special {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (10+) Mob Attacks
entries: You learn of the Ratling Guttersnipe's Pack Tactics trait and its Ratling Cunning.

entries.name: (15+) Nimble but Weak
entries: You know the ratling's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Ratling Guttersnipes stick to the shadows, staying hidden as long as possible. They are likely to position themselves on rooftops or behind rubble, and often secure their locations with pit traps, flasks of oil, torches, or other devious traps when they are able. Once they notice their target is in position, Ratling Guttersnipes unload a volley of poison-tipped bolts, or unleash deadly traps. After their targets are weakened, the ratlings rushes in to surprise and stab creatures with their delerium blades, and then quickly dart back out.
As with all ratlings, if the fight turns against them, they will flee or beg for their lives.

monsterFluff.name: Ratling Pathogenist

entries: Cloaked in a thick leather jacket and a crude, custom-made gas mask, this ratling scurries forth clutching a worn satchel brimming with poisons and potions. An acrid smell wafts off the ratling, combined with burnt hair and something putrid and rotten. Its fur is mottled, and burned away in patches across its neck, arms, and legs. Its flesh is covered in sores, blisters, and infected wounds. It rummages through its bag before producing a vial and tossing it forcefully to the ground at your feet.

Ratlings are disease-ridden creatures, and the smartest amongst them have observed the effects these diseases have on their enemies. Studying the actual causes of diseases and learning to harness them against their foes is a point of pride for a Ratling Pathogenist. These twisted doctors consider themselves amongst the most brilliant ratlings.

The Ratling Pathogenist has several disease-ridden blades, needles, syringes, and a gas mask. It's surrounded by a haze of diseased gas and acrid fumes. Even getting close to one of these highly contaminated rats is enough to make one sick.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Ratling Pathogenist is a cunning killer and loves to riddle its foes with diseases. The ratling will release one of its deadly infections into a creature nearby and use Rampant Sickness to spread it to anyone nearby. Metastasis causes the disease to kill its target even faster.
The pathogenist prefers to keep their distance and will attempt to scurry away if cornered or forced to fight in melee. It will also run if it is alone, or if its allies are fewer than its enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Ratling Warrior

entries: A pair of glinting yellow-purple eyes appear down the dark tunnel ahead, then another, then more. A scurrying mass of furry bodies bound up in mud-spattered cloth and greasy leather surges forward. Their rodent-like claws brandish rust-caked blades as many squeaking voices erupt into a cacophony of chittering, chirping, screeching, and finally a howl of "Kill! Kill! Kill!"

Representing the overwhelming mass of ratlings in Drakkenheim, these warriors have little skill and even less bravery, living a desperate life of scavenging and violence. However, a Ratling Warrior who survives and thrives may often find their own specialization or niche, becoming a {@creature Ratling Burrow Warden|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Burrow Warden}, {@creature Ratling Guttersnipe|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Guttersnipe}, or {@creature Ratling Alchemist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Alchemist}.

entries.name: (15+) Swift, Weak, and Cowardly
entries: You know its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Ratlings fight together in large groups to surround and overwhelm their foes with Pack Tactics. They use whatever rusty weapons they can find, or use their teeth and claws when nothing else is available. Occasionally, ratlings carry makeshift slings and hurl anything they pick up off the ground at their enemies: rocks, bones, or even chips of delerium.

However, ratlings flee and hide using Ratling Cunning when they don't have a numerical advantage over their foes. Indeed, they won't start fights if they don't outnumber their foes at least two to one, but while they outnumber their foes three to one or more, the typical ratling warrior can become insanely brave. When ratlings overpower their foes, they may even grapple them down and take them as prisoners to eat later.

monsterFluff.name: Ravenous Flora

entries: This massive plant writhes forward on a mass of roots and vines. Its large leaves waving back and forth surround its great floral head. Glowing hypnotic octarine petals surround a central bulb that opens into a mouth oozing with saliva nectar as a leaf-like tongue licks in anticipation. Its maw is filled with hooked, jagged teeth. The creature looks ready to swallow you whole.

Some apothecaries specialize in the study of plants. These botanist apothecaries often experiment with delerium to affect flora growth cycles. The Ravenous Flora is one unfortunate creation of these efforts. It is a plant that has grown to incredible size, gaining a primitive sentience and a desire to feed. The plant seems singly focused on its hunger, with reports often claiming that the Botanist who created the monstrosity has fallen victim to the creation's insatiable hunger.

Because it is a slow-moving creature, it uses this to attract victims before attempting to Bite and Swallow its targets. If no targets are in range, it Spits Acid at them and does its best to move to an advantageous position.

items.name: Ravenous Ghoul

entries: Thick poison drips from the grimy teeth and claws of these feral, unarmored ghouls. Their sunken, stark white eyes glisten as they lick their lips with a long, slimy pointed tongue, hungry for their next meal.

Ravenous Ghouls make up the brunt of the undead forces of vampires. They are vile undead creatures twisted to the will of their masters, forced to starve for months at a time to put them into a frenzy when they are unleashed upon the vampire's enemies. Their vampire masters care little for their wellbeing, and simply use them as fodder to wear down their enemies.
A spellcaster can use create undead to animate a ravenous ghoul instead of a normal ghoul.

monsterFluff.name: Reality Cyst

entries: You come across a glistening mass of pustules that seem to grow  directly out of the physical structures of the city, as if the natural  wood, stone, and earth are alive. These cysts are a cancer growing  within Drakkenheim. The very air around the cyst changes, the  light refracts in incorrect patterns, and the lines and angles of its  surroundings seem to fracture in incoherent designs. To look upon  it is like looking at reality itself through a broken mirror. One  that is both present and not present at all, where your every move  and step are strained and confused. For a brief moment, you seem  to forget what you saw at all, and the landscape around you seems  unfamiliar. Have you been here before? How did you get here in  the first place? Your mind strains to grasp these questions.

The presence of delerium has caused Drakkenheim to become an epicenter for planar rifts. Commonly known as Thin Places, these tears in reality allow creatures to pass between dimensions and cause the magical qualities which define the linked plane to slowly seep into and change the Mortal World. Outside the ruins of Drakkenheim, most Thin Places are connected to the Faerie Otherworlds or the Shadowlands, but within the city, the Haze is especially prone to create pathways into the Space between Worlds.

This roiling realm of chaotic pandemonium and impossible reality floods the Mortal World with {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} and unfathomable horrors. When rifts to the Space Between Worlds appear in Drakkenheim, it sends a rippling magic outwards from its center, affecting all creatures, plants, and even stone and wood. Thin Places in Drakkenheim are like wounds in reality, and as the wound remains, it begins to fester and infect. Like a disease, the infection begins to cause growths and cancers to form in the area around it. The Reality Cyst is one of these cancerous growths.

Those who have glimpsed a Reality Cyst have seen them vanish from sight a moment later. There are reports of adventurers lost in the ruins for days trying to navigate a city street that become completely alien and unfamiliar, only to be found by another scouting party standing perfectly still in a daze. It seems those who are affected by the Reality Cyst enter a sort of trance. They are unable to perceive the Reality Cyst and instead find themselves in a confused landscape with the very fabric of reality shifting and altering forms. Colors beyond perception bleed from walls, objects appear and disappear at random, nonsensical angles and shapes form and alter before their eyes. People might believe they are moving in one direction and find themselves moving in a completely different direction. Gravity, time, space, logic, and all other concepts are skewed and broken.

For those who have glimpsed through the veil of a Thin Place, and caught that unhinged reality of the Space Between Worlds, the state of order in the bending existence of a Reality Cyst seems strangely familiar. Its wrongness, although completely unfathomable, seems to echo the confused state of the Space Between Worlds. Those who encounter a Reality Cyst and escape Drakkenheim's walls have bordered on madness. At best they suffer severe headaches for weeks afterwards. A mind can only handle so much when the reality you interact with pushes up against the rules and concepts of your own comprehension.

entries: You learn the Reality Cyst's creature type and speed.

entries.name: (10+) Draining Rejuvenation.
entries: You are aware of the creature's Feed Bonus Action

entries.name: (15+) Anomalous Influence.
entries: You recognize the cyst's ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Reality Cyst is less of a hunter than it is a disease. It feeds off the confusion of creatures trapped in its illusions. It mimics the bending realities of the Space Between Worlds and mirrors that into the minds of those who are close to it. After their target enters a trance, it drinks their mental energy and grows.

The Reality Cyst does only one thing: it feeds. It cannot move or defend itself well against attacks. It relies on creatures succumbing to its Unhinged Reality trait and devouring their minds. Once discovered, there is little the cyst can do to survive.

monsterFluff.name: Reautomata

entries: Charging towards you with unbound fury is a lithe human clad in a hulking suit of full plate wielding a pair of oversized scimitars. As they draw closer with a snarl, it becomes clear you face no mere warrior, but a monstrous abomination of metal and flesh. The emaciated figure is not wearing the armor: the plates have been riveted and bolted into their bones. Globs of weeping, infected scar tissue pulsate where the body fights against the metal fused into muscle and sinew. It does not hold its weapons: its forelimbs have been entirely replaced with scything talon-blades. Their metal helmets are smooth and featureless save for a single ocular delerium lens, and expose the creature's sickly mouth and sharpened teeth, its breath giving off a rank chemical odor.
First created by the Reanimator Dr. Everett Freed of Altbruke University, Reautomata were designed as the ultimate shock trooper. These armored warriors feel no pain, fear, or remorse.

entries.name: Constructs of Metal and Flesh.
entries: Despite their outward appearances, Reautomata are constructs, not undead: their organic components operate more like machines than mere flesh. Such is the composition of a Reautomata that they fight on despite grievous injury, unflinching even as they are dismembered. Stopping a Reautomata necessitates mangling its body past the point of physical operation. Reautomata are ultimately brutal and decisive combatants that fight without regard for their personal well-being.

entries.name: Created in Torment.
entries: Reautomata must be skillfully made by a master Reanimator using the finest components. It is essential the work begin on both a living and fully conscious individual. Typically, most apothecaries perform the work without anesthetic, instead opting to sever the vocal cords of their victims so as to not have their screams disturb the grim work involved. Limbs are removed and replaced, and metal is grafted into flesh and welded into the bone of the fully aware subject. Nervous tissue is pulled from the brain and distributed from the body, giving the construct nearly perfect proprioceptive awareness while excising unnecessary or superfluous brain tissues associated with cognitive functions. The process renders the Reautomata fully obedient, but not mindless.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Reautomata Each successful check reveals one of the following pieces of information:

entries.name: (16+) Dispassionate Metal and Flesh.
entries: You are aware of the Reautomata's Relentless Endurance trait, as well as its damage and condition {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (19+) Limb Weapons.
entries: You know of the Reautomata's Arm Blades and Entrapping Rend attacks.

entries.name: (21+) Focused Killer.
entries: You learn the Reautomata's Wisdom, Intelligence, and Charisma saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Reautomata fight with outward ferocity and aggressive attacks which belie the cold, unfeeling calculation at the core of each solider. In battle, Reautomata launch themselves towards their foes in great leaps, impaling their targets upon their rending arm blades. The rending blades flense into flesh and latch on like hooks, allowing the Reautomata to restrain their targets. They then use their great strength to rend apart their restrained victims.

Reautomata unquestionably obey the orders of their creator and will fight until destroyed without regard for their own bodies. However, even with only general instructions, Reautomata fight intelligently and know how to utilize the environment to their advantage, making use of their climb speeds and jumping ability to prioritize dangerous targets.

monsterFluff.name: Reautomata Wrecker

entries: This monstrous construct is the size of an ogre. It lets out a low bellow like the droning cry of an approaching whale. Suddenly, it breaks into a charge like a thunderous rhinoceros, racing forward with uncanny speed despite its onerous bulk. It is covered in armored tanks with hoses attached to its head, directly into the ears, nose, mouth, neck which pump its body full of strange chemicals.
Since the death of Dr. Freed, his knowledge and works were nevertheless disseminated, including an unfinished schematics for this advanced Reautomata prototype.

Built as more of a living siege engine than a shock trooper, a Reautomata Wrecker is a furious and destructive machine. Constructed from a collection of parts taken from trolls, ogres, and humans, the wrecker is reinforced with armored plating to carry the tanks and machines that power its frame. At the core of the wrecker is a powerful drive engine which when overclocked can set the construct on a path of wanton fury before it explodes in blaze of alchemical doom.

items.name: Reborn  Vladimir von Drakken

entries: Vladimir von Drakken stands awash in mighty power. Standing nearly seven feet tall, he is armored head to toe in ornamented and blood-drenched plate mail. The breastplate bears the ancient sigil of House von Drakken. Draconic wings unfurl from his back, the membranes colored a deep red like a dying star. His snarling face has the chiseled features of a calculating predator. He growls, bearing his long, sharp fangs which dribble fresh blood around his perfectly trimmed salt-and-pepper beard. In a single hand, he holds a vicious greatsword, which he points towards you, issuing a mortal challenge.
This is Vladimir von Drakken's normal form, once he has regained his full strength. In this form, he is a cunning and strategic adversary.

This massive creature is made up of mutated, stitched-together body parts. The process of joining parts and intentional mutations has rendered the former patient into a mindless beast, nearly swallowed by its own growths. Its oversized arms carry a great whirling bone saw that spins and whirs as it lumbers forward, spraying gore and soaking its aprons in blood, bone, and grey matter. They wear a blood-soaked medical apron and mask.

A Ripper is a creation of a truly mad apothecary, though one ostensibly created as a "surgical assistant" for dissection and autopsy. In truth, a Ripper's only purpose is as a butcher, carrying out the grim task of dismembering corpses and collecting severed parts to supply fresh materials to create more abominations. Transforming morgues into abattoirs and surgery rooms into charnel houses, having a Ripper amongst their servants enables an Apothecary to work with startling efficiency.
Due to their horrific appearance and grim purpose, Rippers are seldom encountered outside an Apothecary's laboratory. Given their size and brutal skill, Rippers make ideal guardians.

entries.name: Parts Collectors
entries: Apothecaries stitch all manner of extra arms, hands, and limbs to their Rippers, which the creature uses to gather severed body parts and hold down subjects.

entries.name: Fear Engine
entries: The Ripper's tortured mind sympathetically responds when it senses a victim's fear and terror, but its twisted brain responds with adrenaline and bloodlust.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Ripper is an unsubtle and unsophisticated combatant, but it can follow its creators' orders intelligently. Unless directed otherwise, a Ripper usually begins battle by using its Gory Display to terrify its victims. It then ponderously moves towards its chosen target before lowering its Saw Blade down, preferring {@condition Frightened|XPHB} targets to benefit from its Feed on Fear trait. During its turn, a Ripper continues attacking with its Saw Blade until it misses. If it reduces a target to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it does not stop making attacks until its target dies.

items.name: River

entries: River is a short tiefling woman in her late twenties. Her attire is practical and professional: a hip-length purple jacket with a high collar. Belted at her waist are several pouches and pockets. She wears five rings on her right hand. Two oddlyshaped dark brown horns sprout backwards from her flowing blue hair, creating the impression of two boats at sea. River has spotted brown skin and impish features: her teeth are too sharp, her tongue too long, and it's slightly unsettling when she smiles.

River is a communications expert and analyst. She aids the Academy's mission using spells such as {@spell Sending} and {@spell Rary's Telepathic Bond|XPHB|Telepathic Bond} to relay messages between field agents and Academy leadership, gathers information using {@spell Detect Thoughts} and {@spell Scrying}, and facilitates transportation of Academy assets from their distant strongholds to Emberwood Village via {@spell Teleportation Circle}.

entries.name: Personality Trait
entries: I converse using precise academic terminology, but amongst those I trust as competent and capable, I inject a wry and sardonic sense of humor.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I like people who are professional, deliver results, and don't ask questions. I cannot stand fools who waste my time with buffoonery, haggling, and excuses.

entries.name: Bond
entries: Eldrick Runeweaver is my mentor, teacher, and friend.
I've worked alongside him for years, and any success he has will be mine as well.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I grew up surrounded by the magical amenities of the Amethyst Academy, so I don't understand what life is like for those who had a more mundane upbringing.

River is not a combatant and never initiates violence. If she is attacked or finds herself in the midst of conflict, her sole objective is survival. Her first action is always to cast either {@spell Dimension Door} or {@spell Invisibility} and flee. She won't take risks with her own life, even to fulfill a critical objective for the Amethyst Academy or save someone she cares about. However, she will take the opportunity to help another ally escape by using {@spell Invisibility} on them or bringing them with her when she teleports.
The giver of gifts and knowledge—she is a strong ally and an old friend — weird brother.

items.name: Royal Assassin

entries: Dressed in black and red, with a large hood and mask concealing their face and a flourished cape trailing behind them, this assassin brandishes a series of poison-tipped throwing daggers. They are posed ready to strike.

The Queen of Thieves keeps these elite killers on retainer. Agents of death, Royal Assassins are ready to eliminate anyone the Queen of Thieves has deemed a problem. She often keeps one or two nearby at all times as her most trusted guard. However, even the Royal Assassins are kept at arm's length due to her untrusting nature.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Royal Assassins have a selection of potent poisons applied to their weaponry. They carefully prepare and select each dose for their intended targets. They use Silent Scream against spellcasters or when absolute quiet is needed, Sap Strength against warriors likely to put up stiff resistance of their own, and Sluggish Sinews against agile targets who may try to escape.

items.name: Sanctified Knight

entries: Clad in plate armor and carrying a longsword, the Sanctified Knight's delerium shard embedded in their chest glows through their armor as they protect the pilgrims from any threats.

The Followers of the Falling Fire have attracted a rare few paladins from amongst the Faith of the Sacred Flame to join their cause. Hailed as heroes of their movement, these knights readily embark on the quest to visit the Crater's Edge and become sanctified, then take up positions as mighty defenders of the nascent religious sect.
Self-righteous are those who follow the flame. Also they can't do as many push-ups as me.

items.name: Sanctified Monk

entries: Dressed in simple white tunics and loose trousers, these monks have sworn themselves to the Faith of the Falling Fire and have taken the Sacrament, pulling divine energy from within themselves and using it to channel their martial arts and combat capabilities

Commoners who complete the Sacrament of the Falling Fire are imbued with extraordinary abilities from their great show of devotion. Many become ascetics who reside near the Crater at Saint Selena's Abbey. There they prepare their bodies and minds for the tests of faith yet to come, practicing discipline, faith, and martial arts.
I don't like getting hit in the face and these guys end up being hugely disappointing. My face is my moneymaker.

items.name: Sanctified Soul

entries: Wearing no symbols of their faith, and dressed simply, the glow of their delerium shard embedded in their chest glows through their robes signifying their dedication to the Falling Fire. Carrying a book in one hand and speaking passages of the Falling Fire, Sanctified Souls gather flocks of pilgrims before them.

Just as paladins of the Sacred Flame have joined the Falling Fire, many Flamekeepers have also converted to the new religion. Occasionally, the process of sanctification awakens a divine connection in an individual with no prior ability. Either way, these powerful conduits for divine magic are among the great leaders of the Followers of the Falling Fire.

These creatures are draped in funeral dresses with blood stains and tears. Veils are drawn over their faces, hiding their features, but one can still make out the glowing red eyes and glistening fangs. Their spindly bony fingers twitch and flick as crackling unholy energy sparks and ignites around them.

entries.name: Twisted Mages
entries: When a mageborn is bitten by a vampire, the magical energies flowing in their now-tainted blood create a Sanguine Witch. A creature of both vampiric bloodlust and arcane might. These witches serve as right hands to vampire nobility and as generals and lieutenants in vampire armies.They are cunning and manipulative creatures who lure victims with deception and wit.

entries.name: Arcane Blood
entries: Sanguine Witches are mageborn but their magic energies are stunted and twisted; they can use magic to absorb life essence from their victims and live unnatural lives.
The more a Sanguine Witch feeds, the more the vampiric essence mutates with their arcane blood. Sanguine Witches often take on grotesque mutations from this otherworldly mixing.
Notably, many Sanguine Witches have acquired blood red glowing eyes and animalistic snouts and fangs.

entries.name: Mages of the Court
entries: Sanguine Witches stand as the chosen court mages to vampire masters. They perform all the duties a court mage would usually do, but their loyalty to the Court of the Night is unbreaking. Their mastery over undeath, and their ability to warp victims into vampiric thralls makes them a terrifying creature to behold

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks when taking the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Sanguine Witch, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Unnatural Resistances
entries: You recognize the creature's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Siphon Vitality
entries: You learn of the creature's Feast action.

entries.name: (15+) Arcane Caster
entries: You know the creature possesses formidable spellcasting abilities.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Sanguine Witch uses {@spell Darkness|XPHB} to hide themselves and attempt to enthrall subjects with {@spell Hold Person} before using Feast to feed on them. The witch's goal is to create thralls of their opponents.
If the Sanguine Witch is in direct sunlight, or at less than half their {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, they attempt to flee.

monsterFluff.name: Scrap Reautomata

entries: This zombie has been hastily enhanced, using scrap plating and arcane instrumentation. Rusted weapons and haphazard metal are grafted into its body.

Creating Reautomata is a time-consuming and delicate process, demanding ideal specimens and high-quality materials. Compromising on either results in a far inferior construct. However, discernment is a luxury under desperate circumstances. Regardless, these so-called Scrap Reautomata make far more effective, resilient, and obedient soldiers than conventional troops, and are ideal for use as cannon fodder.
Scrap Reautomata are animated by crude combustion engines, which are prone to overheating and malfunctions.

Everett Freed first created the Scrap Reautomata from the household soldiers and staff of House von Fritz prior to the Siege of Sodden Castle. Poisoning the water well of the castle itself, the Duke von Fritz led his men to believe they were being "treated" and "healed" by the doctor, who instead used their weakened state to turn them into monsters.

The process for creating Scrap Reautomata relies more heavily on occult necromancy to jump-start the reanimation protocol. Less of the original body is replaced to conserve materials. As a result, Scrap Reautomata are undead, not constructs.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Reautomata Each successful check reveals one of the following pieces of information:

entries.name: (16+) Dispassionate Metal and Flesh.
entries: You are aware of the Reautomata's Relentless Endurance trait, as well as its damage and condition {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (19+) Limb Weapons.
entries: You know of the Reautomata's Arm Blades and Entrapping Rend attacks.

entries.name: (21+) Focused Killer.
entries: You learn the Reautomata's Wisdom, Intelligence, and Charisma saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Reautomata fight with outward ferocity and aggressive attacks which belie the cold, unfeeling calculation at the core of each solider. In battle, Reautomata launch themselves towards their foes in great leaps, impaling their targets upon their rending arm blades. The rending blades flense into flesh and latch on like hooks, allowing the Reautomata to restrain their targets. They then use their great strength to rend apart their restrained victims.

Reautomata unquestionably obey the orders of their creator and will fight until destroyed without regard for their own bodies. However, even with only general instructions, Reautomata fight intelligently and know how to utilize the environment to their advantage, making use of their climb speeds and jumping ability to prioritize dangerous targets.

Foot soldiers of a necromancer it reminds me of when you left the dishes too long in the sink.

monsterFluff.name: Sentient Planetoid

entries: The surface of the planet drifting before you suddenly begins to swirl and shift, mirroring the human features of a face within the canyons and ridges of its form. A telepathic voice booms in your ears as it leers at you with a cold stare glistening with curiosity and mild disdain.

Drifting through the void of the Space Between Worlds are planetoids which possess a well of knowledge about the cosmos. They silently float through the void on an endless pursuit of understanding. Their eternal quest for ultimate comprehension of the meaning of all things is an impossible and foolhardy errand, but nonetheless they carry on, observing and learning all they can.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Sentient Planetoid, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (15+) Panoptic Arcanist
entries: You learn of the creature's All-Knowing Magic action.

entries.name: (20+) Unfathomable Strength
entries: You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Sentient Planetoids are not all hostile creatures. Some of them, who have knowledge of mortals deem them a pest or a problem, especially if traversing the Space Between Worlds. Like a mortal who finds a rat in their home, a sentient planetoid will attempt to remove the creature or kill it.

Some planetoids might wish to converse with mortals, wanting to learn information from them about simple concepts of mundane life, or ask questions they think a mortal would know, only to confuse them with esoteric concepts and broad ideas of the universe. This can sometimes frustrate a planetoid who may react by simply wanting to eradicate the creature who bothered it.

Would you believe that giant rock is alive? I would, because everything seems to have an agenda now. Can't sit anywhere.

monsterFluff.name: Sewer Thing

entries: The murky sewer waters churn as something below the surface stirs. A mass of debris, algae, and waste slowly rises from the water, and a sloping mass of sewage emerges with a gurgling hiss. Before you, a great shambling form launches towards you, grasping with its writhing tendrils, moving through sewage with surprising speed.

No one knows how the Sewer Thing came to be. Some speculate its a person who drowned in the sewers before {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} took their form and merged with the raw sewage around them. Others suggest the creature is {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, turning plants and debris into horrific monsters. Regardless, enough stories have spoken of avoiding the sewers for most to steer clear of those areas.

The Sewer Thing hunts in the sewers of Drakkenheim, absorbing anything that gets in its path. It is an unseen killer using its tendrils to pull victims into the sewage to be absorbed and causes others nearby to retch and vomit. It is depicted as a legend in the scrawlings of aquatic Dregs who call the sewers home. The Dregs and Ratlings speak of the terrible thing that feeds on their people.
Ratlings use the Sewer Thing as a cautionary tale for their young, telling them not to travel alone and to run when water churns.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Survival|XPHB} gains {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to Study a Sewer Thing, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Resilient Plant
entries: You know it's creature type, {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}

entries.name: (10+) Poisonous Engulfer
entries: You learn of the creature's Poison Absorption and Engulf features.

entries.name: (15+) Sense of Self
entries: You understand the creature's Wisdom and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Sewer Thing waits for the opportune moment to strike.

It lets creatures approach, appearing as plant matter over some sewer debris. Once its prey is close, it springs to life, lashing out with its tendrils at any it has surprised, attempting to Engulf them. This tactic works well if it is in water or sewage, where it can pull victims beneath the surface.

The Sewer Thing starts combat attempting to Engulf surprised targets. Once a creature is Engulfed, the Sewer Thing retreats into the sewer water and flees. It is a hunter, consuming its prey by dissolving them inside of it. Once it has its food, it has no reason to stay and fight.

monsterFluff.name: Shardmaul Manticore

entries: Swooping above on thick leathery wings is a large lion-like predator with a disturbingly human head contorted into an expression of fury. Its body bristles in a thicket of crystalline quills that painfully jut out through its mane, along its wing-tips, and down its spine. It has a long, chitinous tail ending in a cluster of wicked stingers. Each begins as a spike of blackened bone but ends as a glittering delerium shard.

Manticores were among the most commonly encountered monsters roaming Drakkenheim's hinterlands prior to the meteor strike. A few of the creatures would fly south from their nesting grounds in the Giantfrost Mountains to feast on the plentiful livestock and allegedly hapless travelers. Most folk would be able to tell a second-hand story about a neighbor or acquaintance who lost a prized animal to a manticore, or in more grim tales, a family member. Fortunately, their population was kept largely in check by the City Guard. As such, the only individuals regularly slain by manticores were usually would-be monster hunters looking to make a local name for themselves.

Once Drakkenheim fell and contamination caused people to abandon the towns, villages, and farmsteads near the city, the manticores found less easy prey. Growing bolder and more desperate, a handful of the monsters ventured into the city ruins in search of food and new lairs. The manticores were able to readily prey on the contaminated people and monsters inhabiting the city, but in turn, the corrupt flesh caused the manticores to mutate into fearsome Shardmaul Manticores.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain Advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} za Shardmaul Manticore, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Mutated Manticore
entries: You're aware the creature has no special {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} but is a capable flier.

entries.name: (15+) Death From Above
entries: You recognize the manticore's Stinger and Wing Shards attacks.

entries.name: (25+) Strong, Fast, and Tough
entries: You learn the manticore's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Shardmaul Manticore attacks from above, choosing whichever target looks weakest and the least armored. It descends from above suddenly, making Bite and Claw attacks against the weakest prey it detects. After its first descent, it lifts off again, using Wing Shards to cover its ascent. It then repeats its attack pattern.
A Shardmaul Manticore is bold enough to attack when outnumbered but typically flees if it faces stiff opposition that reduces it to half its Hit Points or fewer.

items.name: Silver Order Cavalier

entries: Garbed in heavy armor with blue capes lined in silver trim, embroidered with the symbol of the Silver Order, the paladin's helmet has a large blue plume. A quiver of javelins rests upon their back.

The cavaliers are the griffon riders of the Silver Order. They are trained in both ground assault and aerial combat. Having reached the rank of paladin, these warriors have chosen to train further in mounted combat. Each cavalier creates a unique bond with a griffon, whom they can summon to them using their divine magic, and often the two are connected for life.

items.name: Silver Order Paladin

entries: Garbed in heavy armor with blue capes lined in silver trim, embroidered with the symbol of the Silver Order, the paladin holds a large kite shield, and a glowing radiant mace.

The Knights of the Silver Order are world renowned as the defenders of the Faith of the Sacred Flame. Taking on holy quests and religious missions for the Divine Matriarch, these holy knights have been known to ride griffons into battle, or march forth in force armed with plate mail, swords and shields, and divine magic to bolster their combat prowess. To some, these paladins have a reputation of being divine protectors, noble warriors, and divine symbols of the faith. To others, they are a terrifying and ugly example of the power of the Sacred Flame.

items.name: Silver Order Recruit

entries: These simple foot soldiers make up the bulk of the ground troops for the Silver Order. Fitted with decent armor and shields, a longsword, and the emblems of the Silver Order, they are the first lines of defense against otherworldly monsters and magical threats.

Once graduating from the position of squire, a recruit is now a skilled combatant able to take on simple missions of the Silver Order on their own. They often accompany paladins on more important quests, and make up the guards of Silver Order strongholds, and the forward troops in their armies. They no longer tend to the needs of paladins and are now trained to care for their own gear.

items.name: Silver Order Squire

entries: Dressed in leathers, and carrying a short sword, shield, and shortbow, the young squire hefts a small backpack of gear for maintaining and patching armor and weapons, griffon care, ammunition, and other essentials that may be needed on the field. They are eager to serve, and to prove themselves in battle.

Squires are the new recruits of the Silver Order. They are often assigned to a paladin for training and although they can perform in combat and go through rigorous training with both sword and bow, they are more often assigned to patch the armor, sharpen the weapons, and tend to the griffons of their paladins.

items.name: Skeleton Archer

entries: Soft blue light glows in the eye sockets of this skeleton, who carries a bow made from bone and ancient sinew. Shards of frost form on its arrow tip as it takes aim.

In the armies of the dead, one must have both melee and ranged troops as the backbone to one's forces. Skeletal archers are imbued with elemental magic and given bows that harness the power to chill their enemies with each shot.

items.name: Skeleton Mage

entries: The tattered red robes worn by this skeleton reveal it as one of the vampires' failed thralls. Thunderous sparks and embers of flame dance around its boney fingertips as it prepares its next spell.

These mages are often former thralls, acolytes, or arcane prisoners to vampire lords. They are twisted in undeath into unholy mages, harnessing elemental magics against their foes and serving an eternal afterlife to the vampires who create them.

items.name: Skeleton Soldier

entries: This robust skeleton warrior is caked in mud and moss, it wears a skull cap, a single shoulder pauldron, and holds a thick rusted shield emblazoned with the arcane sigil of House von Drakken. In one hand It carries a long poison-tipped spear.

Most corpses on the continent are cremated; vampires must be clever about obtaining minions for their armies. Throughout the lands, there are ancient crypts of heroic warriors and divine soldiers. Sometimes, vampire lords have been known to infiltrate abandoned holy sites and old crypts to steal the dead, raising them as skeletal minions. Furthermore, they often keep prisoners in their own dungeons to feed on, leaving the bodies once they are expended to one day rise again as skeleton soldiers.

entries.name: Skeletons

entries: Ancient bones draped in rusted armor scraps rise up with unholy magic. Baring old weapons, they brandish their spears and charge toward you.

When a vampire is preparing for war, they have no shortage of soldiers. Their crypts are often filled with long-deceased thralls, remains of prisoners, vampire slayers, and anyone who mistakenly wandered into their manor or castle and was never seen again. The vampires use their dark magic to raise these skeletal remains from the crypt and into their legions. Clad in ancient armor and often given bows or spears, these skeletal warriors make excellent minions for a vampire. They do not need to be fed and are easily stored in tombs and crypts when not needed. Some of these skeletons possessed arcane abilities in life and carry that trait through to undeath, leading skeletal armies as mages. They harness what remains of their arcane fortitude to channel elemental fury at their foes.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks when taking the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a skeleton, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Deathly Violence
entries: You know the creature's basic attacks and Bonus Actions.

entries.name: (15+) Unliving Abilities
entries: You learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: These skeleton warriors are mindless foot soldiers in the wars of vampires. They march into battle with no care. They feel no pain. They only follow their orders and fight to the death on behalf of their vampiric masters.

monsterFluff.name: Skin Crawler

entries: Out of the shadows you hear a sloping and squishing sound like someone dragging raw meat across the ground. The first thing you see are two arms reaching out from the darkness, the flesh sagging and drooping. The hands grasp the ground and slowly pull the creature forward revealing a squished pile of flesh resembling a human body without bones, organs, or muscle: simply a bag of skin that drags itself across the ground. Its empty eye holes and open mouth hang agape from its flopped over head, its legs dragging behind it as it pulls closer to you. It lets out a low guttural moan as it grasps towards you, hungry to fill itself with your insides.
One of the more horrible forms of undeath reported from the ruins of Drakkenheim are Skin Crawlers.

When a person becomes contaminated in a very short time, mutations occur in such quick succession that their body simply cannot withstand the changes. This abrupt mutation causes the person's organs to liquify and they die vomiting a black bile. Even their bones, eyes, brain, and other internal organs dissolve into a thick black contaminated sludge. They retch until they collapse to the ground as nothing but a sack of dead flesh sitting in a puddle of delerium sludge.

The sack of dead flesh does not stay dead. Horribly contaminated, it awakens in a desperate and starved state. It seeks out living creatures for their meat, hoping to fill itself back up with new flesh and take on a more complete form. The Skin Crawlers have been known to consume an entire creature like a python eating its prey, only once the crawler is filled, it assumes the form of the creature it consumed. There are unpleasant and grotesque signs of the Skin Crawler's guise. A creature consumed and transformed by a Skin Crawler will appear to wear their skin like a loose suit. Their eye sockets will droop, their mouth will be too open, their arms and legs will have loose and sagging skin. They appear almost as the person who was consumed, but with their skin hanging off in odd and disproportionate ways.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Skin Crawler, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Unrestrained Undead
entries: You recognize the Skin Crawler's creature type, {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Squeezing Death
entries: You are aware of its Crush and Consume {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: (15+) Deathly Aware
entries: You learn of the Skin Crawler's mental ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Skin Crawler is a mindless creature. It is nothing but animated flesh seeking to consume. If it senses a living creature nearby, it crawls towards it with total disregard for its own life.
It only wants to bind the living and squeeze them to death while slowly devouring their flesh, consuming it into itself.
A Skin Crawler is too focused to flee and continues to attempt to devour a target until either it or their target is dead.

monsterFluff.name: Skinwing

entries: A flock of hairless, winged creatures, each roughly the size of a large dog, circle overhead. Each is a grotesque patchwork of various animals melded together through unspeakable magical experiments. Their bloated bodies are made from combinations of pigs, goats, and sheep torsos. Their featherless wings are poorly structured with visible bones and thin, tearing skin. Each has a ram-shaped head with mismatched, bulging eyes and twisted horns; the nose and mouth have been replaced with a curved avian beak, each disturbingly filled with rows of irregular teeth and leaking a foul, sticky saliva. The monsters move with an awkward gait, their strained bodies supported by sturdy but mismatched donkey legs, and forelimbs which end in a hodgepodge digits with different claws, talons, and claws.

Many apothecaries who delve into the secrets of reanimation and transmogrification are not bold enough to begin with human test subjects. Instead, most opt to begin their cruel experiments upon animals, knowing that these early investigations draw less suspicion and hostility.

Unfortunately, it is for exactly this reason that many apothecaries lose their sense of morality. In time, they come to view even humans with the same cold dispassion as their animal test subjects, seeing the cries of pain and mercy as no different from the barks, squawks, and howls of the animals they so cruelly tortured in their early days.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Skinwings look for opportunities to gang up on a single target, relying on their Pack Tactics to swarm and overpower an enemy.

monsterFluff.name: Skretch

entries: A looming avian creature perches on the rooftop above, its body cloaked in dirty, ragged feathers. It curiously regards you with its two featherless heads, each borne on a long, crooked neck. Each head has large, round, bulging eyes and a hooked beak that drips corrosive saliva which hisses as it strikes the ground. The bird launches from its perch, opening its broad wings and short, fanshaped tail, revealing a hanging, bloated belly that shudders with whatever half-digested contents rot within.
Skretches are mutated scavengers with features reminiscent of various birds, including vultures, pigeons, and crows.

These cowardly opportunists feed on corpses and {@condition weakened|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} prey while steering clear of more adept aerial predators inhabiting the ruins. Attracted to the sound of conflict, Skretches patiently circle at great heights until the fight ends, then attack any wounded, dying, or survivors caught off guard.

A Skretch's digestive system is a disgusting mess. It is filled with the partially dissolved remains of its last meal, churning into a contaminated slop inside its bloated belly. Skretches shower their meals—whether corpses or still-living targets—with acidic vomit and expelled waste. This noxious mixture dissolves flesh and bones, turning prey into digestible goop that the Skretch then easily consumes.
These beasts maintain a significant distance from the Harpies residing in the highest spires of Drakkenheim since the more proficient hunters are not averse to killing and consuming

entries.name: (5+) Flying Scavenger

entries.name: (10+) Acidic Vomit

entries.name: (15+) Dextrous and Sturdy

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Skretches keep to high perches and observe potential prey before attacking. A Skretch prefers to attack targets that are visibly injured, {@condition weakened|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, or otherwise vulnerable.

Once it finds a suitable quarry, a Skretch circles their prey overhead pelting them with Spittle while waiting for their Expel Waste to recharge. Since its attacks require the Skretch to be directly overhead its target, they prefer to keep well above their targets to avoid any projectiles or ranged attacks.

A Skretch never enters close combat willingly. If it is engaged up close, it uses the {@action Disengage|XPHB} action to flee. As lazy scavengers, a Skretch doesn't pursue its prey very far or into buildings and flees if reduced to half its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or fewer.

monsterFluff.name: Speaking Skull

entries: Resting on the apothecary's desk, amidst vials, surgical implements, and scattered anatomical notes tomes is a skull, ordinary at first glance. It lies motionless—but then it begins to stir, hovering an inch above the wooden surface. Its eye sockets, dark and hollow, seem to fix on you, its bony grin {@condition frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} in a sinister smirk.
The skull begins to speak, its voice a chilling murmur. " You're not one of the doctor's patients..." it hisses. " You should not be here..."

The work of an apothecary can be lonely, and the mind craves another good head to bounce ideas off. The Speaking Skull is an ideal companion, one who can carry on conversation with their creator, read out text from instruction manuals and tomes while the apothecary works, and offer advice and observations. The familiars also make useful and discrete sentinels, positioned carefully to watch over the apothecary's private notes, treasures, or experiments.

entries.name: Player Character Familiars
entries: Subject to GM approval, an apothecary with the Laboratory Assistant esoteric theory can create a Helpful Hand or Speaking Skull to serve them using the {@spell Find Familiar|XPHB} spell. A familiar created in this manner always acts in combat immediately after its creator's turn. It can use its special attacks in its stat block only if the apothecary uses a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on their turn to command the familiar to take one of those actions.

items.name: Spell Leech
entries: It is well understood by apothecaries, particularly Mutagenists, how arcane magical talents are the result of a nascent genetic trait borne in the blood. As such, Mutagenist apothecaries often experiment with blood and tissue samples taken from mageborn, hoping to discover the ways to enhance existing magical talents, or even imbue those without the inborn capacity for magic with spellcasting ability. Thus far, the best results have been either disastrous or temporary. Nevertheless, one result is the Spell Leech.

monsterFluff.name: Spined Dreg

entries: Long barbs of protruding overgrown bone and encrusted shards of delerium burst forth from the emaciated body of this Dreg, covering its spine and spindly limbs. Its cheek bones push through the flesh of its gaunt face, and its octarine-warped eyes shimmer with an unnatural glow. Its elongated fingers and toes similarly end in sharp, lengthy spikes.
Contamination has wreaked havoc on the skeletal systems of these Dregs, forcing spiked barbs to erupt from their flesh, which they can launch from their bodies or use as spurs to aid climbing.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Due to its agile nature and inherent {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB}, the Spined Dreg prefers vantage points on low roofs or second stories of ruined buildings. It tends to avoid openly traversing the streets, and usually attacks from a distance or to leap down upon its enemies and grapple them. They will climb up walls to escape if reduced below half their Hit Points and outnumbered.

monsterFluff.name: Star Warden

entries: A massive twelve-foot-tall creature stands before you draped in ragged and tattered cloth. The cloth covers its form except for four gnarled and gangly gray arms. Its twisted hands end in four long fingers. They clutch a wooden staff that sparkles with radiating cosmic energy. Two spindley gray legs stick out from under the cloak exposing three-toed feet. Its hunched form leans its weight onto the staff. The bulbous mass of cloth implies a massive head below the cloak, tilted forward. The cloth is filled with writhing tentacles, which dangle out from its depths, poking and prodding about.

The Star Wardens are ancient creatures who have traversed the cosmos for centuries. They care little for the multiple realities and their squabbles, nor the relevance of a mortal life. They are eternal beings who exist out of space and time. To them, relativity and dimensions are broken concepts which they can bend to their whims. They exist in multiple dimensions and times at once. They move and age in counterintuitive ways that no mortal can fully comprehend. To a mortal eye, they may appear to phase in and out of existence, or teleport from place to place, at times appearing more ancient, or more youthful. The Star Wardens may not be teleporting at all, but simply experiencing the interaction with a mortal at multiple points in time and space simultaneously. Their existence is wholly outside the standard flow of time or the movement of spatial reasoning. A Star Warden may exist within the past present and future of a mortal being all at the same time.

Their physiology and bizarre existence is utterly baffling to a mortal observer. The few who have witnessed a Star Warden have gone mad by the sheer incomprehensibility of their existence. One such academy mage, Randolf Carter, who practiced entering the Space Between Worlds via Dreamland, said that at several points throughout his life, he has spoken to a Star Warden. From the Star Warden's perspective, their conversation was a singular event, yet for Randolf, it happened in tiny dream-like snippets over the course of 50 years.

The Star Wardens shepherd the cosmos, observing and aiding in the flow of space and time. They view reality as a wavelength of interdimensional strands, and they see to the various timelines and branches of infinite realities. It is impossible to know the full scope of their purpose, but they seem to be protectors of timelines, and ensure no cataclysmic events cause the universe to collapse on itself.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Star Warden, learning the following based on the result.

entries: You know the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Transposition
entries: You recognize the creature's Outside Time and Space {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

entries.name: (20+) Otherworldly Intellect
entries: You learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Star wardens exist in multiple times and dimensions at once. A creature that tries to fight a star warden is at a loss for where and how the star warden exists before it. Both the Star Warden and the creatures facing it are constantly shifted around the battlefield, unable to grasp their sense of reality. The Star Warden uses its Outside Time and Space Reaction to let two creatures attack one another instead of landing a blow upon itself. It can force the truth of all reality into a creature's mind or have it experience the cold vastness of space. Star Wardens are clever and always flee a losing fight.

monsterFluff.name: Stitcher

entries: The creature before you has an oversized clawed hand of deadly scissors, blades, surgical instruments, and scalpels. The other hand is completely replaced with a set of interwoven needles on pistons. The figure is tall and emaciated, with tight skin stretched over lithe muscles. Its long and slender neck ends in a small bald head with beady black eyes and multiple straps that are connected to its mouth, keeping it pried open. A spool of fine thread is fastened into its gaping mouth, and its ribcage is splayed open with flowing bandages on a spool that is fitted into place within. It wears stained and stitched rags and carries a large burlap sack stained in blood, multiple severed limbs hanging out of the open bag.

The tedious process of suturing and knitting flesh to a capable assistant can prove time consuming and difficult. The Stitcher acts as a lab assistant and an extra set of hands for such tasks. Uniquely outfitted for quickly and efficiently attaching limbs, sewing up wounds, or making surgical incisions, the Stitcher can graft a limb onto a patient in mere seconds.

entries.name: (20+) Brainless Monster

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Stitcher has a singular, focused mind, and even when defending itself, uses its sewing and surgical skills to sew up its foes. The Stitcher often identifies what the most advantageous option is for its Sewing Needle, focusing on the mouths of spellcasters, the limbs of melee combatants, and the eyes of ranged combatants. It attempts to attach limbs to victims it has sewn up.
