monsterFluff.name: Storm Troll

entries: Its gray and white skin is stretched tightly over its muscular form. Its wide-set mouth shows rows of jagged teeth below beady, stormy, blue-black eyes set in the center of its large bald head. Ripples of electrical currents pulse through its body, its veins glowing electric-blue like a network of lightning bolts across its skin.

Storm Trolls can be found anywhere storms are common, such as the Rust Edge Mountains, along the coast in the Eastern Vales near Port Brynor, along the Crystal Coast, or down in Terene or the Southern Reach. Storm Trolls thrive in a raging storm, and often hibernate through sunny stretches. They are extremely sensitive to changes in the weather, emerging from their lairs when the winds change. They can sense an oncoming storm a day or two before it comes. Hunters and sailors that spot a Storm Troll know it's time to head back, as a storm is likely only a day away.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Storm Trolls hunt for food during heavy rainfall or bad storms. Often accompanied by cracks of thunder and flashes of lightning, they begin combat by hurling lightning at their foes before rushing in to maul them with their Claws and Bites.
If a Storm Troll takes Acid damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

monsterFluff.name: Striga

entries: The vampiric creature before you has shifted into a more monstrous form. Its clothes are tattered and hang off its bulky frame, its muscles bulge, and its face has morphed into a snarling animalistic snout. Its fingers and toes are now hooked, bony talons, and its monstrous fangs drip with blood. An octarine glow simmers within its eyes. Its growling and huffing breath heaves as it glares towards you, hungry for flesh, and craving mortal blood.

A Striga is a contaminated undead abomination which results when a true vampire or vampire spawn succumbs to eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} under the right circumstances, usually involving a backlash of {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly}, an exposure to delerium during the transformation, or consuming the blood of a powerful contaminated creature. Vastly more powerful than a Hazeblood Vampire, a Striga is completely mad.

However, a Striga can reverse its monstrous {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} by drinking the blood of a humanoid creature who has recently been the target of a purge {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} spell.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Striga is a vampire warped by delerium and {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. It loses its inhibitions and subtlety, becoming a ravenous bloodthirsty monster. The Striga charges into battle and aggressively pursues its foes, clawing and howling as it hunts its prey. The Striga attempts to single out a weak target and tears them to shreds before moving on to the next.
A Striga rarely flees as it is too bloodthirsty to consider its own life.

monsterFluff.name: Swarm of Ratlings

entries: A teeming mass of chittering ratlings roil forth. Fur and claws spill like crashing waves, surging forth with dozens of hungry, biting mouths to consume everything in their path.

An individual ratling is a vicious and craven creature, but seldom do they pose a threat to experienced adventurers. However, even veteran Drakkenheim survivors and explorers know to fear when ratlings gather in sufficient numbers. When dozens form a rampaging swarm capable of pulling down much larger foes with their amassed furry bodies, and stripping flesh from bone with hundreds of gnashing teeth and hungry bites.

entries.name: (20+) Neither Strong Nor Brave
entries: You recognize the swarm's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Swarm of Ratlings is an alternative way to represent a massive number of ratlings, rather than needing to use dozens of individually weak ratling minions in an encounter against higher-level characters.

In battle the Swarm of Ratlings moves like a rolling tide, using its Scurrying Horde {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to close the distance with as many targets as possible. The swarm tries to move into and over the spaces of its enemies, so it can Bite them with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} using its Chittering Mass trait. The swarm continues making Bite attacks against a downed character in its space as the swarm goes into a feeding frenzy.
The Swarm of Ratlings is impossibly brave until it's reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, at which point the Scampering Survivors usually try to run away.

monsterFluff.name: Tanker

entries: A hulking abomination of corroded steel and pallid flesh stands before you. A gas mask covers its face, firmly strapped and bolted onto its head. The creature hunches over a massive chemical {@item drum|XPHB} that makes up its gut. Tubes and hoses splay from the {@item drum|XPHB} like spilled intestines that connect the tank back into the spine and limbs of the monstrosity. The pumping hoses weave through its body, connecting to the large metallic nozzles which have replaced its hands. A confusing tapestry of rank chemical odors exude from it, the various smells irritate the senses and burn the eyes and nostrils.

The Tanker is the preferred lab assistant of {@creature Chemist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Chemists} and {@creature Pathogenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Pathogenists}. They are a construct made from a human corpse, built to function as a walking barrel of alchemical reagents. Traditionally meant to supply mixed chemical compounds in large quantities from one vessel to another, the Tanker can also be deadly when threatened as it is equipped with massive hoses that can fire globs of its substances at targets, as well as unleash a gout of toxic fluids. The creature stinks of acrid chemicals and even being near it can be disastrous without proper protective measures

monsterFluff.name: Tentacled Dreg

entries: Where the creature's arms should be, there are instead two writhing masses of deep purple tentacles, while four more protrude from its back. Its tongue lolls out as a long, wet, purple appendage. Throughout the creature's body, weeping wounds open to protruding smaller tendrils and growths. The Dreg's skin looks wet and saggy, and it moves with a strange wobble as it slops towards you.

In Drakkenheim, it seems tentacles are one of the most common monstrous mutations. Academy researchers have been unable to discern what specific reason tentacles may have for being such a consistent form of mutation. Theories have posited the idea that the Haze and Contamination originate in some distant watery plane of existence, or that the creatures best suited to survive in the Haze can use tendrils and tentacles to navigate easier. Whatever the reason, Tentacled Dregs are quite common throughout the ruins of Drakkenheim.

If outnumbered and below half of its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, a Tentacled Dreg will attempt to climb or swim to safety.

monsterFluff.name: The Algorithm

entries: It is a vast network of wires, tubes, and metal plating in an ever shifting and malleable form. This massive construct often appears as a giant robotic face floating through the void, with a tail of writhing mechanical tendrils drifting behind it like a massive inorganic squid. It uses the plates and chunks of liquid metal orbiting around it to reshape itself, creating limbs and changing features as parts remove or attach to its ever-shifting form. The whirring of electrical energy and mechanical sounds compile into a booming chorus of auto-tuned robotic voices. Its cold, unfeeling eyes analytically survey its surroundings, assessing the information before calculating the optimal way to reorganize its form in response to the situation.

The calculating entity known only as The Algorithm is a massive being made up of constantly reforming and phasing technology. Their form is a mass of wires, tubes, metal, and electricity that constantly shifts and transforms. It creates tendrils and limbs as needed to manipulate elements around it and constantly hums and buzzes with electronic melodies.

Very little is known of The Algorithm's origins or purpose. Speculation suggests it is obsessed with perfection and expectation; it deems the universe and all its planes a broken and imperfect thing in need of repair and reform.

The Algorithm is the master of calculations and realities. It can predict and evaluate every possible outcome to a course of action within an instant, and has the ability to shift and manipulate time and space to allow its most favorable outcome. If any goal can be surmised from such an unknown being, it is that it sees mortals, and most life-forms and planets as broken objects needing to bend to its whims of expectations and perfections. Anything The Algorithm deems undesirable it will adjust accordingly.

The Algorithm has no known origin—perhaps it was never made, but rather came into existence through the chaotic nature of the Space Between Worlds. It is impossible to say how a construct which was never constructed has gained the level of impossible sentience found in The Algorithm, but it is in its very nature a being of pure order, which itself causes mass chaos. It constantly restructures elements of the Space Between Worlds to suit its perfect vision. Entire planets drifting within the void of the Space Between Worlds have been repurposed into mechanical hubs, quantum spheres, time paradoxes, and machine factories. Whatever The Algorithm's intentions or goals are, they are something that could never be understood by a mortal mind. Its constant shifting of realities and obsession with perfection seems to a mortal to be total nonsense, and utter absurdity. But to The Algorithm, all things are planned, and all things are accounted for.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The Algorithm is nigh incomprehensible.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} "I speak down to mortal creatures, for they cannot begin to comprehend the depth of my knowledge, or the details of the cosmos. They are but simple accidents in a sea of chaos that must be corrected."
{@b Bond:} "I am bound to the order of all things, It is my cosmic ordained purpose to bring order to the chaos of the universe."
{@b Ideal:} "Order out of Chaos is perfection, I will achieve perfection."
{@b Flaw:} "No one is as humble as I!"

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Algorithm is a creature of order and consequence. It sees all of the Space Between Worlds and every reality as a confusing mass of chaos that must be rearranged and perfected. When The Algorithm encounters mortal creatures, it will attempt to organize them as best suits it using its wires and Algorithmic Manipulation to forcibly move them.
It will convert problematic creatures into obedient androids using its Reprogram ability, and any who threaten it are reduced to atoms using Deatomization.

If The Algorithm has created a cyborg using Reprogram, or if there are extra constructs from previous failed experiments nearby, The Algorithm can assume direct control of them, deatomizating itself and entering the construct to use as a suit of armor.

If the combat becomes too stressful or problematic for The Algorithm, and it is unable to control or organize the situation in a way that benefits it, it may get frustrated and begin Deatomizating everything. If that doesn't work, it flees into the void to find something more easily manipulated to work on.

monsterFluff.name: The Duchess

entries: This horrific monstrosity is larger than a whale. It has a long, serpentine body bristling with sleek fins, undulating barbed tentacles, and rubbery, purple-black flesh. It writhes through the waves with unearthly grace despite its bulk, and seeping from its flaps and vents are secretions of a thick, oozing oil which shimmers with prismatic hues. It has adorned its brow with fishing nets, coral, sea debris, and {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}, resembling a coronet and jewelry. As you look upon its form, you feel a slight headache, a buzzing in your ear, and a pressing in your chest; as if the psychic presence of this otherworldly creature has conjured the crushing pressure of the abyssal depths. It has a gigantic, fanged maw which it holds agape. Seaweed, fish entrails, and slime dribble from between its sharp teeth, and its bulbous eyes glow with octarine light.

The Duchess is a contaminated sea monster who haunts the shores off Ash Bay. However, the creature originally made its home in the sewer cisterns of Drakkenheim. As the Duchess matured and grew larger, it departed the cursed city via the Drann River in search of more plentiful prey and fresh thralls, bringing a new wave of {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} to Ash Bay. It deliberately destroyed the Empress Geraldine just off the coast of Drannsmund: the merchant vessel was transporting a vast horde of delerium to the far continent. The Duchess has slowly tended the new reef of delerium coral flourishing around the shipwreck, transforming it into her personal underwater palace.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The Duchess has powerful and otherworldly psychic powers.

They can communicate telepathically, read the thoughts of mortals, and use their psionic power to turn mortals into its contaminated thralls. It makes deceptive offers that appeal to characters' deepest desires, manipulating them into embracing {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Those under its control slowly mutate, taking on horrific aquatic features.
The Duchess hopes to open a dimensional rift so she can conjure other beings like herself, styling herself no longer as a duchess—but an empress.

items.name: Personality
items.entry: The Epic Boss chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls {@dice 1d20}. On an 11 or higher, the effect ends on it. An Epic Boss can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

items.name: Ideal
items.entry: "My magic will weaken the curse which holds you to the land, so you might swim through the waves of my court, and be welcomed as one of my loyal subjects! Perhaps you will be worthy enough to become one of my valiant knights!"

items.name: Bond
items.entry: "Come see the wondrous treasures of my Grotto! Gaze upon the opalescent, prismatic beauty of my prized coral. You may hold it in your hands, for a while, if you wish..."

items.name: Epic Resistance
items.entry: "I abhor the land, and will never set scale or fin upon it."

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Duchess never confronts her enemies on their terms, preferring to stay in her lair where it is safe. She ventures as far as the edges of contaminated water, knowing full well that the water sustains her. When confronting foes in combat, she uses her Deep Domination on her enemies while calling in reinforcements with Call of the Deep. She grabs foes and flings them away to keep her enemies focused on her dominated minions.

Unless in her lair, she flees the moment she doesn't like the odds of a fight. If she is in her lair, she flees only if she is reduced below 100 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} to attempt to find a new location in contaminated water to build a new lair.

monsterFluff.name: The Whispered Promise

entries: Blossoming tendrils of chaotic shadow-stuff dart and weave through the air along with a chorus of whispers, like the sultry hum of sweet nothings lulling in your ears. Coalescing into a briefly coherent form, the being you perceive is strangely familiar, taking the shape of your very heart's desire. You see within the oscillating mass the image of all you love and strive towards, every ambition you've held, every dream and hope you've longed for, and, most hauntingly, an image of yourself as you wish you could be.

The Whispered Promise is a demonic entity who appears before mortals of great potential, offering to fulfill their every ambition and desire. It is a mind-reader and shapeshifter, who appears before mortals as their own reflections, but in a grand and idealized form. In this way, The Whispered Promise preys upon their insecurities and dreams simultaneously, showing mortals both their grand potential and many shortcomings through contrast. To those rare few who do not feel ambition or self-doubt, The Whispered Promise appears to be a writhing bundle of hairs.

The Whispered Promise preys upon hopes, dreams, and ambitions, seeking to manipulate and seduce mortals into their web of schemes, and ultimately, make countless powerful mortals utterly indebted to the demon lord. Perhaps The Whispered Promise stands behind the great heroes and villains of history, having spurred their ambitions and supercharged their desires. In particular, the Sorcerer-Kings of the Arcane Empire sought out he Whispered Promise and made countless bargains with the demon to advance their wealth and power. Summoning circles and magic items found within their ancient ruins still allow mortals to contact The Whispered Promise. There are even some tieflings who claim that The Whispered Promise is a distant ancestor through fiendish pacts made in those days. It is unknown whether The Whispered Promise had any influence in ultimately engineering the fall of the Sorcerer-Kings.

There is little The Whispered Promise cannot offer. Knowledge and information are their most common currency: teaching mortals forgotten magic and sharing deeply kept secrets. They have dealt in magical artifacts, granting mortals powerful magical items, or simply vast amounts of material wealth. The Whispered Promise also enjoys helping mortals undo a past mistake, solve a guilty conscience, get revenge on a hated enemy, or seize the reins of power for themselves. In exchange, The Whispered Promise seeks to extract a promise of future service from the mortal—a promise for a promise. While they try to keep the terms of this service as open-ended as possible, they reassure mortals they will never ask them to do any direct harm to their friends or loved ones, nor perform any task beyond their own capability to fulfill. In this way, they build a web of interactions and debts, trading services for services. The Whispered Promise plots to use their collected debts to fulfill their future bargains.

While an expert in the desires of others, determining The Whispered Promise's motives prove vexing. The Whispered Promise does not lie, and they seldom reveal their full intentions. They seemingly wish to construct a tapestry of promises, never making one of their own, but brokering the promises of others. A broken promise is a broken thread, pushing the entity to always keep their promises. Yet within this web of desire, The Whispered Promise is always at the center.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Capable of sustaining multiple separate telepathic conversations at once, The Whispered Promise addresses each character individually. They show images of the characters' desires and dreams, depicting them with outrageous fortunes and with immense power.

items: {@b Personality Trait:}  I whisper softly in mortal's ears... What do you yearn for? I have no interest in using it against you... only in making it a reality. Indulge yourself for a change...
{@b Ideal:} I want one thing, and one thing only... to provide you the thing you want most. Ask me, and I'll give it to you. What can I give you that you truly desire?
{@b Bond:} If there's ever a stranger you can trust, it's me. Any deal we made would be signed and sealed. Other demons may utter lies, but I whisper promises... and I keep my promises.
{@b Flaw:} Are you certain you would deny me? I dislike being turned down...why wait for what you deserve? If you change your mind...you need only whisper...and I'll be there...

entries: You are aware of the creature's Alluring Aura trait.

entries: You know The Whispered Promise's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Whispered Promise regards battle as a physical expression of their ability to control others. It uses Alluring Aura to prevent attacks and they negate resistances to its psychic onslaught by grappling with its Unravelling Resolve trait. They sow discord using {@spell Mass Suggestion}, {@spell Dominate Monster}, and their Dominate power, revealing in the resentment, jealousy, disdain, envy, and anger its foes have towards one another.

monsterFluff.name: The World Ender

entries: A storm of black clouds and sheets of octarine lightning fill the air, and unnatural otherworldly thunder crashes as a steady contaminated rain begins to pour.

Rising from the shattered delerium heart in a plume of eldritch Haze, stands a creature as tall as a tower, its bulbous head adorned with octarine {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} that crackle and spark with arcane energy. These crystals protrude from its flesh down its neck and across its shoulders, as well as down its spine. Seven massive yellow eyes peer out from below a furrowed brow, over a reptilian snout with a wide set mouth that stretches across its head filled with rows of jagged teeth. Its large, elongated maw opens to reveal one hundred thin translucent tentacles that lash and dart out like one hundred tongues. Its wet skin is a mottled grayish purple, shimmering in unknown colors impossible to comprehend.

The Haze disperses in an instant as it rises from the Crater. Its four muscular arms end in hands with eight long spindly fingers, each tipped with a delerium clawed nail. Its large digitigrade legs end in veiny black hooves, and its rigid spine extends into three long, tentacle-like tails. The smell of ozone and sulfur fill the air, and a deep and booming voice utters words incomprehensible in a cadence unrecognizable to the human ear, merely coming through as a muffled tone of booming bass and high-pitched wails that causes your brain to seer in pain.

A colossal delerium crystal rests at the center of the Crater. This "Delerium Heart" is a piece of a distant unknown world utterly consumed and destroyed by the Haze. It is the largest source of the {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} spreading out from Drakkenheim. If there is any hope for stopping the slow progression of the Haze, it must begin with the destruction of the Delerium Heart. Characters mighty or foolish enough to accomplish this monumental task alone will not end the {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} of Drakkenheim, but instead unleash a destructive horror unlike anything the earth has ever known: The World Ender.

No two individuals who bear witness to the emergence of The World Ender can describe its arrival in the same terms. One hero perceives it breaking free of the Delerium Heart like a creature hatching from a great egg; another describes it suddenly appearing from the mist in a flash of thunder and lightning; while a third sees a small creature nearby haplessly mutate into a colossal being when exposed to the powerful forces released upon the destruction of the Delerium Heart.

The World Ender is only one possible moniker for this titanic engine of destruction. The Apocalypse, The World Eater, The Harbinger, Death, The Annihilator, The Last Nightmare, The Wrath of Gods, and The Chosen One are all other titles it may wear. It is unclear if the creature is a singular entity, or one of many which have appeared in the death throes of the countless worlds consumed by the Haze.

The World Ender cannot be reasoned with, bargained with, or understood; its origins and purposes remain shrouded in mystery—it simply is. The complexities of human civilization—the sprawling cities, political conflicts, bloody wars, and the rise and fall of monarchs, mages, heroes, and priests—are utterly meaningless before it. Once freed, it tramples cities without awareness or concern, obliterating armies and toppling nations with the same dispassionate ease with which natural forces reshape landscapes. Indeed, The World Ender's rampage is more akin to an unfathomable natural disaster, blind to the devastation it wreaks.

Efforts to understand or influence it are as futile as ants trying to comprehend a river that threatens to wash them away. In the face of such power, humanity is left scrambling for survival. Mortals become painfully aware that in the grand scheme of things, our existence might be as transient as raindrops in a storm, unnoticed by the forces that alter our world

entries.name: Horror from Beyond the Stars
entries: The mages of the Amethyst Academy have long researched delerium, and discoveries in the Crater enable them to paint a full picture about the origin of the stones. When delerium is left uncontained in massive quantities, it is possible it can slowly grow and seep into the heart of an entire planet, eventually rotting the core. The entire surface becomes a wasteland of octarine crystals as big as buildings, with a Haze-covered sky of eldritch storm clouds that blacks out the sun. Under these conditions, {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} runs rampant and no lifeform on the surface is free from endless mutation. As the planet festers and mutates to the point of destruction, the Haze and delerium cause all manner of abominations to grow and change. Given the hundreds of years it takes for delerium to infect an entire planet, the mutated monstrosities have ample time to grow to massive proportions. This creature is but the first of many which could be created if the Academy is not able to contain and control delerium.

Eventually however, the delerium begins to expand at an increased rate, and some of these creatures end up encased in the eldritch crystals, being forced into a state of hibernation. When the planet is fully contaminated, it explodes sending massive chunks of contaminated rock through the cosmos. Some of these meteors have mutated monstrosities housed within their cores, waiting for a time to break free upon a new contaminated world. We have received the remnants of a distant dead world, and we must contain it before the same thing happens to ours.

Grandmaster Wizard Eldrick Runeweaver postulates that containment of The World Ender is best achieved by sealing it back inside a massive delerium formation: essentially re-creating the Delerium Heart. Such a feat would require a massive flood of contaminated energy and a locus of {@item geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium geodes}.

entries.name: Catastrophic Mutation
entries: The Knights of the Silver Order are resolute that The World Ender confirms the destructive blight that delerium represents. It must be contained and destroyed lest it consume and contaminate the entire earth. This massive monstrosity is but the first of a new generation of titanic horrors which will devour the earth if delerium is not dealt with soon. The Knights have a blunt theory about how it was created: it's just another big mutant caused by the eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} of delerium. They cite the many documented instances when destroying or damaging a large cluster of delerium caused rifts between the planes or sudden surges of eldritch {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. If the Delerium Heart is the largest piece of delerium ever encountered, then it stands to reason that shattering it would cause the largest {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ever known. It's possible that the monster is the result of this catastrophe: it may have been conjured forth from some distant and unknown dimension of destruction, or perhaps a cascading mutation took root within a nearby creature.

entries.name: Harbinger of Sin
entries: The Followers of the Falling Fire believe a terrible sin has been wrought for destroying the Delerium Heart, and the salvation of this world is now in doubt. This cosmic being was meant to be The Harbinger of the Sacred Flame, but it has been unleashed before its preordained purpose. It is now an infant, mewling and raging at its destiny denied. Any hope we have must now be found in a monumental sacrifice.

Lucretia Mathias believes the only solution is to perform a special variant of the Sanctification of the Falling Fire upon the creature. Instead of using normal {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}, one of the player characters must sacrifice themselves before The World Ender, and the other characters must embed the sanctified delerium crystal bearing the sacrificed heroes' soul into The World Ender's body. Perhaps then, the righteous soul of the fallen player character will fill the creature and turn it into a divine vessel.

entries.name: A Grand and Cosmic Scheme
entries: Panic spreads amongst the Queen's Men as the scoundrels speculate that this creature came here on purpose. Mad rumors insist that it is a scout from a distant planet of huge lizard-creatures, and that The World Ender "piloted" the meteor into Drakkenheim with an intention to take over the world.

The Queen of Thieves laughs while dismissing such conspiracies, caring little about the origin of the creature. Instead, she sees opportunity. Instead, she sees opportunity and searches for a way to capture or control The World Ender. After all, if its power could be harnessed, if she could learn what the creature wants, tame it and use it against her enemies...well, who would be able to stop her then? She would have an even finer prize pet than Big Linda!

entries.name: Great Egg
entries: Amongst the Hooded Lanterns, a strange idea emerges that the Delerium Heart was in fact some kind of gigantic egg which bore The World Ender. Lain by some distant cosmic creature, its eggs shoot through the cosmos like meteors, eventually crashing into unknown and unsuspecting worlds. There, the egg incubates for a hundred or more years, changing the landscape around it into suitable conditions for its young. When the egg hatches, an infant version of this cosmic entity emerges, and the planet it finds itself on is its first hungry meal. This being cares not for the creatures inhabiting these planets, it won't even acknowledge them. It simply is following its own cycle of life, and we are unfortunate enough to be here when it awakens.

Lord Commander Elias Drexel is determined to destroy the beast by any means necessary, before it can spread destruction to the rest of Westemr. He looks to the characters and his soldiers to assemble a vast collection of siege weapons and artillery, which can be found in the arsenals of Castle Drakken. While it will take far more than these alone to bring the beast down, the cannons will no doubt be a useful distraction until The World Ender annihilates them.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} The World Ender, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (20+) Force of Destruction
entries: You recognize The World Ender's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}, {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, and its Immutable Form trait.

entries.name: (25+) Blast of Energy
entries: You learn of the Ender's Charge Eradication Beam and Eradication Beam actions.

entries.name: (30+) Nearly Unstoppable
entries: You are aware of the The World Ender's Rejuvenation trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The World Ender is a force of utter destruction. It cares little for the creatures or structures around it and merely tramples through them without hesitation or remorse. The World Ender unceasingly proceeds forward, and never halts unless it is somehow prevented from moving. It does not flee or hide and has no conception for surrender or fear. It is a force of nature that levels cities to the ground, leaving a path of utter destruction in its wake.

Few creatures pose an actual threat to The World Ender, and it is content to simply smash them with its Necrotic Claws or devour them with its Bite. Indeed, it may not even attack them directly, making most of its attacks against structures or the environment itself and letting the falling rubble crush any it encounters. When confronted with a large obstacle or building, it stops to unleash its Eradication Beam to clear a path forward with no regard for anything in its way.

However, if The World Ender is actually damaged by an attack or spell, it snaps into action and unleashes its Bellowing Roar in response. It follows up with its Ground Slam and then continue attacking until whatever injured it is slain. If it senses it is under attack by multiple foes (such as an approaching army), it aims its Eradication Beam to destroy them. The World Ender calls down Octarine Lightning Strikes against airborne opponents who target it from above, or against groups of foes on the ground.

entries.name: Mysterious origin
entries: Characters who confront The World Ender are the first to ever do so: none in the World of Drakkenheim have encountered this creature before nor know of its existence. There is no possible way to discover any information about this creature—not even its existence—until it is released. Even powerful divination magic fails to reveal anything other than a vague omen of unstoppable destruction and terrible consequences for destroying the Delerium Heart. For this reason, the details presented herein are framed as information that could be discovered following the emergence of the creature from the Crater.

entries.name: Destructive Rampage
entries: The World Ender's actions damage and destroy buildings and structures. A creature within 10 feet of a structure that is destroyed must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 28 ({@damage 8d6}) Bludgeoning damage. Any creature inside the structure when it is destroyed has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the saving throw.
My world changed from touching the Delerium Heart. The world changed from what was inside.

monsterFluff.name: Thing with the Writhing Tail

entries: This eldritch housecat possesses a sleek, undulating body that stretches out, impossibly long and sinuous, covered in a coat that swirls in blue and purple like the midnight cosmos, speckled with tiny flickering stars. Its fur seems to absorb light, creating a silhouette that shifts and wavers, as if its true form is utterly incomprehensible to your mind. The creature's striking eyes are large, luminous orbs that resemble nebulae, surging with vibrant colors that no earthly cat's eyes would possess. Its paws are tipped with claws made of a material resembling a dark, glassy substance, capable of tearing through the fabric of reality itself. Each step it takes resonates with a soft, eerie echo, as if it walks not just on the physical ground, but also treads through the layers of time and space. Its tail is elongated and flexible, flickering through the air like a dark, wraithlike appendage, constantly moving in patterns that defy the bounds of physical space.

This esoteric cat-like entity is known by many names and wanders the realms of Dreamland and the Space Between Worlds. It was the scholar Killgar Copperpot who realized its multitudinous identities were one and the same and named it the Thing with the Writhing Tail.

Almost every warlock of the Thing with the Writhing Tail was approached by the creature as a child, appearing before them in the form of a common housecat, though one marked by some strange coloration, demeanor, or smell. It seems to favor those in unfortunate, neglectful, or powerless situations, such as street-wandering orphans or the mistreated offspring of narcissistic aristocrats. It casts itself in the role of their imaginary friend and confidant, sharing reassuring stories, protecting them from danger, and spurring them to precociously seek knowledge and adventure.

Its eldritch pact occurs with a seemingly harmless promise to keep their bond an important secret. In turn, the Thing with the Writhing Tail grants its warlocks a special familiar in the form of a cat, which acts as a direct proxy for the entity itself. The familiar accepts any name the child-warlock chooses, often becoming known by names typical of a household pet, such as Bruce, Dinah, Felix, and others. Since the Thing with the Writhing Tail acts through these familiars, its warlocks are able to converse with the entity on a regular basis through their telepathic bond. As such, the warlocks often exhibit the strange behaviors of having one-sided conversations with their cats.

Although it has appeared throughout history to countless mortals, the motivations of this creature are uncertain, even to its warlocks. It oscillates between agent of chaos and custodian of secret lore known only to cats and may be metaphysically connected to all felines. The Thing with the Writhing Tail is utterly indifferent to the human constructs of morality or duty and observes the Mortal World with a detached curiosity and occasional boredom. While most of the time its desires are guided by hungry impulses, it may suddenly fixate its attention on seemingly innocuous or strange patterns or magical phenomena incomprehensible to its human warlocks.

The Thing with the Writhing Tail rests in places defying logic. It basks within cosmic rays shed by dying suns, languishes atop a shifting nebula, and curls up in the dark corners of reality, where time and space convolute into impossible geometries. Its slumber is deep and filled with dreams of ancient chaos.

It is said that a strange place known as Ulthar, where no one may kill a cat, is especially sacred to the Thing with the Writhing Tail. The Thing with the Writhing Tail is not without its rivals, however. It seems utterly obsessed with one day consuming the {@creature Rat God|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

Since it goes by so many names, two warlocks who are both pactbound may not realize it at first, believing them to serve different beings. The Thing with the Writhing Tail seems to enjoy this state of affairs, even though it means its warlocks often act against one another. This may in fact be a strange way of weeding out the weak or seeking the most promising and talented warlock amongst its servants.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: This cosmic entity's interactions are marked by caprice and whimsy.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} One moment, I might bestow affectionte purrs and nuzzles; the next, I display utter aloofness or sudden ire, swiping with claws of dark matter that rend the veil between sanity and madness.
{@b Ideal:} My actions are neither cruel nor kind. Mortals cannot know my unfathomable perspective, and that is why they will always be inferior.
{@b Bond:} I am endlessly entertained by the unpredictability of mortals; their fears, their surprises, and their schemes are like strings of yarn I cannot resist batting at with my cosmic paws.
{@b Flaw:} My boundless curiosity and the mere whim to explore the forbidden often lead me to stir chaos in realms both mortal and divine, sometimes unraveling threads better left untouched

entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the Thing with the Writhing Tail, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (20+) Eldritch Aberration

entries.name: (25+) Fear and Madness
entries: You learn of its Purring Aura, as well as its spellcasting Epic Actions.

entries.name: (30+) Brilliant and Nimble
entries: You know the Thing with the Writhing Tail's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: In battle, the Thing with the Writhing Tail uses Manifest Duplicate to create numerous copies of itself. It teleports and swaps places with its duplicates as its rends its foes apart. The many duplicates vastly expand the range of its Purring Aura, sowing terror and madness in any who try to oppose them.

The Thing with the Writhing Tail may grow suddenly bored in the middle of combat, deciding to inexplicably flee or change tactics to a new fixation. Other times, it plays cat and mouse with its foes, toying with them like living balls of yarn.

I know one that holds his cat above all others. Putting that much faith into anything beyond yourself can only lead to problems.

monsterFluff.name: Think Tank

entries: A severed head bobs gently aloft. The top of its scalp has been sawed off, exposing its pulsing brain, which is encased in a dome filled with bubbling, glowing liquid. A dozen thin mechanical arms emerge from its eye sockets. Around each delicate limb is coiled an elongated strand of the optic nerve, and upon the tip of each are curiously blinking human eyes of different sizes and colors. A haphazard bundle of tubes, hoses, and cables flows from its open neck along the still-attached spine, which connects via several sinewy strands to an array of fluid-filled glass tanks containing a throbbing heart, pounding lungs, and other nearly unrecognizable internal organs. Attached to the spine are spindly mechanical arms each ending in human hands.

Due to their dabbling in magical arts, many a maddened and maniacal apothecary has sought the secrets of elongating their life beyond anything deemed normal. Sometimes these studies do not begin with a malicious intent for greed or personal goals. Sometimes they are not targeted toward the apothecary at all, but a sick and dying loved one, the apothecary on the verge of finding the cure to save them; or a friend or colleague who is on their deathbed, whose research and assistance is the factor standing between a scientific breakthrough and absolute failure. It is in the desperate moments that apothecaries have pushed the boundaries of science and tested the limits on mortal physiology.

The Think Tank stands as a grotesque and hideous form of final desperation to an apothecary who has failed at all alternative options. Whether it be to keep a loved one alive, or an attempt to prolong the apothecary's own life, the Think Tank is a horrid and utterly dreadful procedure to endure, with no hope afterwards of being brought back to any resemblance of their former selves.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} Too many thoughts, all the time, my mind is free, uncontained!
{@b Bond:} I did what I had to! My mind was too valuable to let go to waste, I had to preserve it, to improve it!
{@b Ideal:} I avoided death to continue to pursue the vast unknown of my scientific study. My research will change the world, I just need more time!
{@b Flaw:} I cannot fathom the monster I have become, and to witness myself is a horror I cannot endure.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Medicine|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks to Study the Think Tank, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (15+) Tear the Mind
entries: You recognize the Think Tank's Nightmare Aura.

entries.name: (20+) Gravity Control
entries: You know of the Think Tank's Unbind Gravity Epic {@variantrule Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: (25+) Protected Regenerator
entries: You learn of its Shield Generator and Life Support System traits and identifies its location.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Due to the nature of its Life Support System, the Think Tank is seldom encountered outside its lair, which is always a well-defended and secret location. The mastermind surrounds itself with powerful abominations, and protects its sanctum with traps, defensible locations, and escape routes. A Think Tank's lair may include elements that are outright hostile to living organisms, such as radiation, {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, or deadly neurotoxin. As such, player characters encountering the Think Tank in combat must have already outmaneuvered it somehow to gain access to its innermost lair.

The Think Tank makes for a climatic encounter against a villainous foe. Before the player characters even get close to the Think Tank, it will have tested their abilities many times against its minions, using its telepathic eavesdropping to learn everything it can about them. The Think Tank knows when they are coming, how they are approaching, as well as their abilities, spells, equipment, and their expected tactics.

The Think Tank uses Unbind Gravity and Mind Cage to control the battlefield, while using Pluck the Puppet Strings to turn any remaining targets against its other foes. Its Telekinetic Grip can help it further control enemy positions while using Contaminated Blast to slowly contaminate them to death, picking on whoever has the most Contamination going into the encounter.

monsterFluff.name: Tower Dragon

entries: The bronze dragon coils around the top of the tower, its head outstretched toward the outskirts of the city, surveying the streets. Its body is meticulously crafted and beautifully detailed, as you think you notice it move its head ever so slightly toward you.
These dragons perch upon the towers and parapets of the city and Castle Drakken. Once noble protectors of the city, they are now controlled by the will of the Haze.
The tower dragons were all designed in unique forms and no two are the same, although they are made of bronze, many have noted that each dragon is modeled after a different dragon type.

Tracker trait.

entries.name: (15+) Simple-Minded Construct

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Tower Dragons defend strategic locations along the city walls. Most notably, these dragons animate to attack those who try to enter the city via the rivers, or any who attempt to fly above the walls of Castle Drakken. They are also drawn towards any extended engagement with Wall Gargoyles. Combat encounters lasting more than a minute against a gargoyles near the city walls will likely attract a Tower Dragon.

Typically, Tower Dragons attack from above, using their crackling breath weapons to devastate targets. Once animated, a Tower Dragon does not give up pursuit of their target until either it or is quarry is destroyed.

Massive mounds of rippling, warty flesh, covered in molds and fungal growths protrude from this troll's hunched back. Inky black scraggly hair frames her face and beady red eyes pierce through the darkness. The Troll Hag is covered in tattered burlap and decaying foliage that hide her features. She scurries about on swollen, stumpy limbs, carrying a massive cauldron and ladle as she stirs an acrid concoction.

entries.name: Mothers of Mushrooms
entries: The Troll Hags are the keepers of fungus in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia, and swamps all around the continent. They tend to mushroom gardens and carry large iron cauldrons filled with strange brews that they use to turn ordinary fungus into Trollings. Their gardens are family, and they protect them with their lives. If you go tromping through mushroom patches in a swamp, you best be ready to face the wrath of these mothers of mushrooms.

entries.name: Covens and Community
entries: Some Troll Hags are happy to live out their days undisturbed in the deepest reaches of dark forests and smelly swamps. They infest the forests with mushrooms and mycelia and keep their Trollings as family. Troll Hags have, in rare cases, formed covens of three. When these covens form it is often a problem, as three Troll Hags will overflow their territory with fungal growths, causing entire swamps and forests to decay, spilling hordes of {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trolls} into nearby villages and towns.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The following traits can be used to inspire roleplaying a Troll Hag:

items.name: Personality Trait:
items.entry: "I care for the fungal growths of the forest as if they were my own dear children. I speak to them, sing to them, and care for them as a mother would."

items.name: Ideal
items.entry: "I will protect my mushroom children with my life, for they are the sole reason I am here"

items.name: Bond
items.entry: "All things rot and decay. I am the one who aids the forest in that natural process."

items.name: Epic Resistance
items.entry: "I will not tolerate those who do not respect the forests and swamps. I will seek vengeance on any who harm the fungus."

entries.name: (15+) Potent Spellcaster
entries: You are aware of her Spellcasting and Spore Step actions, as well as her Regeneration trait.

entries.name: (20+) Dangerous Equipment

entries.name: (25+) Special Weakness
entries: You have insight into the troll's {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities}, as well as her low {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Troll Hag prefers to keep her distance from her enemies, letting her fungal minions do the up-close work. If the hag finds herself in melee combat, she uses her Fungal Staff and then teleports away using Spore Step to hurl Slimeballs at her enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Uncontained Growth

entries: The rippling mound of fleshy tendrils masks the humanoid buried within. With incoherent arrangements of eyes, mouths, arms, and legs, and the occasional half-absorbed creature, the Uncontained Growth's shape changes as it lumbers forward, while a muffled chorus of whimpers, screams, and agonized cries erupt from its orifices. Somewhere within is what remains of a victimized patient.

Not all Mutagenists formulae succeed. Often, before testing the Transmogrifying Elixir on themselves, they use patients. Sometimes these patients come willingly, looking to repair some element of themselves. They agree to experimental procedures, which the Mutagenist uses to try their newest elixir and to study untested strains.

The Uncontained Growth emerges as one of the more common side effects to transmogrification, where attempts to expand muscular tissue in a controlled way goes awry. The expansion proceeds unchecked, exploding into masses of flesh and appendages. Sadly, these test subjects are a lost cause: the elixir forever alters and expands their form. Some of the most vile Mutagenists keep these Uncontained Growths as minions, protecting their labs and work. As the muscular tissue expands through bouts of agonizing torment for the patient, it causes their mind to break, leaving them in a maddened frenzy of hostility. This rage can be directed at the apothecary's enemies.

entries.name: (15+) Persistent Growth

entries.name: (19+) Mindless Mass
entries: You learn the creature's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Uncontained Growth is a force of raw strength. In a single turn it can grab, crush, and throw a target.

monsterFluff.name: Undulating Polyp

entries: The strange creature appears to be a glistening growth of mucus-filled flesh upon a mass of boneless skin that slowly wriggles about. It shifts within its own reality, like a faded illusion, slipping between multiple locations. The growth jiggles and wobbles as it moves. Acidic mucus and saliva leaks from small, sharp mandibles. It hisses as it drips to the ground around it. Somehow, as the creature moves, reality around it seems to vibrate and fold as if the arcane energies found in Drakkenheim are concentrating around it like a slow and steady breath.

The Undulating Polyps did not emerge until after Thin Places began appearing throughout the city of Drakkenheim, which has led some to speculate these creatures are born in the Space Between Worlds. However, elements of their bizarre physiology appear somewhat human. They appear at times as a lump of human skin with a massive blister upon them that wriggles like a worm through the ruins, so others have speculated that these polyps are the product of humanoid creatures who are too heavily contaminated by the thin places and emerge from them as nothing more than a mass of undulating flesh.

Still, the essence of the Space Between Worlds is present in the way the polyps exist within space and time: it is entirely nonsensical and confusing and lacking any known laws of such things. Instead, the Undulating Polyps seem to transcend physical space in a manner that makes them quite difficult to pin down. They displace themselves constantly within an area, appearing in multiple places nearly at the same time, or teleporting from one location to another constantly. It is as if they exist in an almost constant state of flux. Their acidic mucus-filled growths allow them to spray acid bile onto anything it deems a threat as it not only teleports itself, but anyone who harms it to a more advantageous position.

These creatures' wants and needs are completely unknown. Like much that emerges from Thin Places, or many of the mutated horrors of the city, the mystery of the Undulating Polyp continues to baffle apothecaries and Academy mages. It seems content to wriggle through the city, dissolving creatures it comes across and multiplying through a form of mitosis, splitting itself into more Undulating Polyps as it endlessly grows.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} an Undulating Polyp, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Resistant Aberration

entries.name: (10+) Teleporting Terror
entries: You are aware of the polyp's Slip Space action and Confused Realities {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

entries.name: (15+) Pointed Vulnerability
entries: You recognize the polyp's {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Piercing damage.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Undultating Polyps are quite adept at staying away from predators. They use their various methods of teleportation to avoid dangers and move to a better position. The polyp constantly showers the battlefield in acidic slime as another method of protecting itself.
Undulating Polyps are not combatants and will do their best to escape combat if they feel threatened.

entries.name: Vladimir von Drakken

entries: None without this blood within may strike you down, and by this blood you shall not die.
entries.from: Prophecy uttered during the Sanguine Rite

entries: Vladimir von Drakken is dead, his broken form buried deep within the crypts beneath an ancient grove in the Brachenwald. Hidden there after he was defeated by his daughter Carmen, his undead body awaits the blasphemous magic needed to reanimate and restore him. Eternal life in undeath was bestowed upon him by the Sanguine Rite which transformed him into an Ascendant Vampire. Vladimir took the druids' words to mean that none could slay him: after the ritual was complete, Vladimir von Drakken could regenerate from any wound or magic.

In truth, he can be struck down by one of his own blood relatives, descendants, or any other who has his "blood" within them. Even in such cases, his undead form is also rejuvenated by their blood. He can be resurrected by performing the Sanguine Rite again upon his remains, a grisly ritual that demands the sacrifice of a powerful sorcerer, a true dragon, and blood descendant of Vladimir von Drakken himself.

Unfortunately for the Court of the Night, the means and materials to perform this ritual again have eluded them for hundreds of years. Not only did Vladimir von Drakken slay the original druids who performed the rite, but the subsequent fall of House von Drakken in the centuries since has made finding a suitable sacrifice challenging. Nevertheless, should that ever come to pass, a threat unlike any other would return to the world.

items: {@b Personality Trait:} Vladimir speaks with vile overconfidence, a sinister smirk, and a demeanor of a creature who believes himself a god, he does not tolerate others treating him as any less than a king of kings.
{@b Bond:} Vladimir will stop at nothing to conquer the continent and reclaim his throne in Drakkenheim. He made it, and it is his to rule, any other who attempts to sit upon it is an imposter.
{@b Ideal:} "This realm belongs to the dead, and the dead shall keep it. Any who stand in the way of my reign will join my legions by choice, or by force."

{@b Flaw:} Vladimir believes himself entirely indestructible and is blind to the loopholes within the rites that created him. Nevertheless, he is hesitant to trust anyone. He refuses to let anyone get close and assumes everyone is plotting against him.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks when taking the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine Vladimir von Drakken, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (15+) Deadly Foe
entries: You know of the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (20+) Renowned Swordsman
entries: You are aware of his Bloodmourne and Bite attacks.

entries.name: (25+) Nearly Undefeatable
entries: You recognize his Reborn or Ascendent Transformation trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Vladimir von Drakken is presented here in three forms. As the Ascendent Vampire grows in power he transforms into a new form until he returns to his full strength.

If he is successfully resurrected with the Sanguine Rite, Vladimir von Drakken first begins in his Crypt-Starved form. He remains in this form until he consumes the blood of a living descendant of House von Drakken, which enables him to turn into his Reborn form.
If reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} in his Reborn form, Vladimir von Drakken unleashes his Ascendant form.

In his Crypt-Starved form, Vladimir von Drakken is a craven and desperate combatant. He primarily aims to drink as much blood as possible using his Bite to transform into his Reborn form. He makes use of Shadow Step and Terrifying Glare to reposition himself and hold foes at bay.

Once he regains his Reborn form, Vladimir von Drakken is nearly unstoppable. He wades into melee with Bloodmourne, demonstrating his martial superiority by using his maneuvers. He uses his Claws and Bite as finishing moves and uses Dominate to bend his foes to his will. When surrounded, he uses Wing Blast to reposition.

Assuming his Ascendant form, Vladimir von Drakken becomes an engine of bloodlust and destruction, fueled by primal rage and undead power. In this form, he rips foes apart with melee attacks and flays their spirits whenever his Soul Rend becomes available.

entries.name: Slaying Vladimir von Drakken
entries: Vladimir cannot be fully destroyed unless he is wholly unmade at the place he was first transformed. Wholly destroying Vladimir von Drakken is difficult. Once he is defeated in combat, with the final blow struck by one who shares his blood, his heart must be cut out, and placed upon the altar within the Standing Stones in in the Brachenwald where he was transformed into a vampire.Under a full moon at midnight, a wooden stake made from a branch from Elenthas the Evertree must be driven through the heart by one of his blood descendants. Then, the heart must be left there until sunrise where it is destroyed by first light. Vladimir von Drakken's minions do not stand idly whilst this happens, and launch a massive assault upon the grove with the desperate aim of retrieving his heart before it is destroyed by the sun.

monsterFluff.name: Void Pirates

entries: The humanoids that stand before you appear wrong. The longer you look at them, the more unsettling they become. Although they resemble humanoid creatures, their features are twisted in peculiar ways. One is completely faceless, with nothing more than a smooth fleshy patch on its head. Another has arms that are too long, with two budding elbows, and insectoid eyes. Another still moves in a gaunt, sporadic pattern, leaving behind momentary blips of itself as if for the briefest of moments it exists in two places at once. All look pale, their skin taking on a faded bluish-purple tone, and those that have eyes have glowing octarine irises.

Many humanoids from the Mortal World, and even creatures from the Faerie Otherworlds, the Dreamlands, and beyond have slipped through Thin Places into the Space Between Worlds, and have been unable to return. Many of these unfortunate souls slowly succumb to {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, eventually disintegrating into contaminated dust that drifts back into the churning ether of the void. However, some survive the prolonged exposure to {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and find themselves in an altered state, becoming one with the Space Between Worlds and mutating into a being that resembles their former self, only changed.

entries.name: Stronger Together
entries: These altered survivors can no longer return to the Mortal World and need the chaotic contaminated environment to survive, but they are also regarded as foreign entities within the Space Between Worlds. Thus, many of the alien creatures inhabiting the twisted landscapes will attack, abduct, or obliterate them on sight.

These survivors have banded together into roving groups of scavengers, pirates, or gangs. They traverse the Void Sea upon scraped-together starships powered by elemental magics. These Void Pirates search and plunder the ancient ruins, caverns, and debris fields looking for anything that will help them survive. They wage war against alien entities and feed on the flesh of their kills, further inducing the never-ending descent into madness and {@condition contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

When they encounter mortals from another plane, Void Pirates are unpredictable. Sometimes they help lost sailors navigate the sea, hoping the dangerous voyage fails, and a new recruit can join their company. Other times, the pirates are less outwardly kind, kidnapping newcomers and holding them in cells upon their vessels. They use them as a distraction when they come across some horrible entity looking to eat, or as a bargaining chip amongst the other pirates, or even as payment to Far Dwellers for safe passage. A mortal life seems to be of value to many of the strange creatures, so having a few in reserve is often a key to survival.

entries.name: Ships of the Void Sea
entries: The vessels used by Void Pirates vary from group to group. They range from a small skiff with a sail and winged oars, housing a few pirates, to massive floating castles with elementally fueled propulsion systems housing hundreds.

Some void pirate ships resemble traditional pirate ships, while others appear as floating rafts with makeshift homes, or a series of roped together platforms drifting along. All these ships are bound together in a crude construction made up of junk and debris that has formed randomly in the Space Between Worlds or drifted into the void through Thin Places. Pirates hunt for better parts, or stronger materials to upgrade their vessels to defend against threats, or to exploit the other gangs of the sea.
Void Pirate ships are often equipped with extra nets, and sometimes ballistae or canons. Some even have more bizarre weaponry befitting the Space Between Worlds

entries.name: Myriad Forms of Chaos
entries: Void Pirates take on all manner of unusual quirks and physical attributes that represent their prolonged exposure to the shifting chaos of the Space Between Worlds.

entries.name: 1. No Face
entries: It has no face, only a smooth fleshy surface.

entries.name: 2. Eyes!
entries: Either not enough, or far too many, glow with an octarine haze.

entries.name: 3. Twinsies
entries: Two of these creatures are identical in every way.
They in fact are the same creature fractured in time.

entries.name: 4. Disjointed
entries: The creature's limbs have extra joints, or its joints bend the wrong way.

entries.name: 5. Cosmic Flesh
entries: The creature's flesh is a fractal distortion of light and energy.

entries.name: 6. Phasing
entries: The creature moves in and out of space, sometimes briefly appearing in two places at once as they walk around.

entries.name: 7. Impossible Dimensions
entries: The creature cannot be viewed from any perspective except straight on. Attempts to move around them fail as they seem to move with you, as if they are simply two-dimensional in a three-dimensional space.

entries.name: 8. Ventriloquist
entries: The sound of the creature's echoing voice seems to come from anywhere except their mouth.

entries.name: 9. Inside Out
entries: This creature appears to be inside out, their veins and organs exposed.

entries.name: 10. Insectoid
entries: This creature has taken on qualities of insects in their physical appearance, forming insect eyes, limbs, or mandibles.

entries.name: 11. Octarine Lamp
entries: This creature has a single eyeless socket, but instead of an eye, it emits a glowing octarine light.

entries.name: 12. Does this look infected?
entries: This creature is swollen and leaking puss and ooze from various open sores upon its body, at times bubbling or spurting with neon colored goop.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Void Pirate, learning the following based on the result.

entries.name: (5+) Mortal Survivors
entries: You learn the creature's type.

entries.name: (10+) Battle Readiness
entries: You recognize the creature's {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

entries.name: (15+) Varied Abilities
entries: They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Void Pirates often attempt to abduct creatures rather than kill them. They fight without honor, aiming to quickly outnumber and out maneuver opponents. Many target threatening enemies with ship-mounted weapons, or they move in close to use nets and shackles to capture other humanoids. They nearly always take prisoners unless forced to kill a target. If a creature persistently attacks or breaks free, they may decide to slit their throat and use them as bait. They flee if risking defeat. Their lives are more valuable to them than prisoners or treasure.

entries.name: Harvestable Components
entries: Due to their humanoid origins, these creatures cannot be harvested.

monsterFluff.name: Walking Delerium Geode

entries: A rich outcrop of {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} glimmer from the collapsed ruin nearby. As you approach, the debris begins to shift and move. A hunched, bulking form, one vaguely humanoid, rises up with a chorus of crystalline clinks and grinding rock. The central mass of stone and crystal is supported by two short, stubbly legs of rubble, its arms and shoulders shaped from large boulders of brick and wood that end in balled fists bristling with delerium spikes. Its head, an elongated crystal, is marked by angles and fractures that gradually form into a sorrowful face.

More than once has an inattentive prospector confused a rich delerium deposit with a Walking Delerium Geode, only to end up as a red smear on the streets of Drakkenheim. These Contaminated Earth Elementals are found throughout the ruins, and are frustratingly common near especially large deposits of the valuable crystals.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} a Walking Delerium Geode, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Dense Delerium
entries: You are aware of the elemental's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Pummeled Contamination
entries: Unsurprisingly, hits from this elemental's fists cause {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: (20+) Deadly Destruction
entries: You learn of the creature's Death Burst trait, as well as its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Walking Delerium Geode rests in wait unless disturbed by someone trying to harvest its {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}. Once awoken, it hammers targets with its Shard Slam.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Elemental.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Dust:
entries: Elemental Dust.

entries.name: Delerium:
entries: True to its name and nature, characters may be able to collect delerium from the remains of the Walking Delerium Geode, though its destruction tends to cause many crystals to shatter and break.

Roll {@dice 1d20} to determine what the characters can find: 1—nothing remains but broken splinters and ash; 2–9: {@dice 4d6} {@item chip|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium chips}; 10–12: {@dice 3d10} {@item fragment|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium fragments}; 13–16: {@dice 2d6} {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shards}; 17–19: {@dice 1d4} {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals}; 20: 1 {@item geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium geode}.

monsterFluff.name: Wall Gargoyle

entries: These winged creatures resemble fiendish bats, often with grotesque exaggerated grinning or snarling faces. They are made completely of stone and remain motionless, but you swear that one is looking at you—and it was looking the other way just a moment ago, wasn't it?

These gargoyles defend the walls of Drakkenheim. When the walls were constructed, the gargoyles were placed every 50 feet along the entire perimeter of the walls. Using the combined craftsmanship of the dwarven stonework as well as magic from the Amethyst Academy, the gargoyles were designed as a defensive measure if the city were ever attacked. Any attempt to scale the walls of the city would see the creatures animate and defend the city at all costs. However, the Haze seeping into their magically imbued bodies has caused their arcane programming to falter, and now the creatures attack anyone who attempts to pass the walls of the city. They no longer differentiate friend from foe, and are always set to defend their territory to the death.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill History|XPHB} or any kind of {@item artisan's tools|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they take the {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine a Wall Gargoyle, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Resistant Form
entries: You know the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Ceaseless Pursuit
entries: You learn of the creature's Faultless
Tracker trait.

entries.name: (15+) Simple-Minded Construct
entries: You are aware of the creatures highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Wall Gargoyles are found only along the city walls. They animate and attack characters who dare attempt any of the following: {@variantrule Climbing|XPHB} more than halfway up the walls or towers, flying within one hundred fifty feet of the city walls horizontally, or over them at any height, or lingering on the walls or towers for more than ten minutes.

The gargoyles attack directly, viciously, and without remorse. If they reduce their quarry to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, they spend their next turn tearing apart the creature's body before moving on to another target. The gargoyles pursue their quarry into the city to any distance until they or their quarry are destroyed, but give up pursuing characters more than three hundred feet outside the city walls.

monsterFluff.name: Warlock of the Rat God

entries: A small ratling cloaked in old rags carries a bone wand in one claw and a skull set with {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shards} in the other. An eldritch glow crackles in the ratling's eyes beneath its drawn hood as it incants a spell. Pulsing energy thrums in its small, clawed, hands.
Once we have all the shiny, the Rat God will come and help us! We'll get food! We will eat! Lots of food! All the food! We will eat the whole world! All the earth! Yes, yes, yes!

Arare few ratlings possess magical powers, which they claim are gifts from the Rat God. Whether their magic truly comes from an otherworldly pact or is just a product of their contaminated mutations is unknown. Indeed, Warlocks of the Rat God will lie or embellish any whisperings or insight they have to convince other ratlings they speak directly to the great Rat God. They make robes out of rags, while carying gnawed bone wands, occult trinkets, bone effigies, skulls, and scrawled drawings. The Rat God's warlocks often whisper to themselves and take notes that only they comprehend.

Most ratlings fear and obey these warlocks. Warlocks seldom share their power with others, making it rare for a colony to have more than one, unless they are underlings of a more powerful spellcaster. Often, the warlock will hand-pick the fiercest {@creature Giant Ratling|XPHB} to serve as a bodyguard, or keep a veteran {@creature Ratling Guttersnipe} as a personal assassin to remove potential rivals.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Warlock of the Rat God, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Otherworldly Pact
entries: You are aware these creatures have an excellent sense of smell, {@sense Darkvision|XPHB}, are capable climbers and swimmers and this ratling's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances}.

entries.name: (10+) Potent Spellcasting
entries: You learn of the ratling's Balefire and Conjure Swarms actions.

entries.name: (15+) Commanding but Frail
entries: You know the ratling's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Warlock of the Rat God does everything in its power to put "lesser" ratlings between it and its enemies. They deem themselves far too valuable to be put in harm's way, but are also inherently overconfident in their powers, convinced the Rat God protects them from harm.

A Warlock of the Rat God will have likely cast {@spell Mage Armor|XPHB} on itself prior to rolling {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, as most keep this spell active when venturing out of their burrow, or at the first sign of danger. They conjure a Swarm of Rats to pester their enemies, and use Balefire to pummel their foes. When their defenses are exhausted they cast {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} on themselves and attempt to flee using {@spell Teleport|XPHB}.

monsterFluff.name: Warp Marauder

entries: The creature has a lupine body composed of swirling energy that constantly shifts and changes, creating a visual effect that is disorienting and dizzying upon its sharp fine fur. The energy appears to be a mix of different colors and patterns, as if it is drawing on the chaotic magic of the Space Between Worlds. The beast has eight legs and no visible eyes or mouth, but in place of a head or tail, a mass of tentacles emerge from its body. The tentacles extend to great lengths, and along its back its spine splits open revealing a great maw of jagged bone and teeth that gives way to a temporal rift in space and time.

The Warp Marauder is a fearsome predator that lurks within the Space Between Worlds, preying on unsuspecting travelers who stumble into this realm. It is a creature with a body composed of swirling energy and tentacles, able to move freely between dimensions, planes, and realities.

A creature of pure instinct, driven solely by the desire to hunt and feed, these skilled hunters use their ability to navigate between dimensions to stalk prey before launching a surprise attack, and often preys on creatures that wander along Thin Places near the Space Between Worlds, drawing them into its own dimension where it can feast on their life force.

A Warp Marauder can detect dimensional portals and Thin Places, and will often wait near them for creatures to pass through before pouncing. Its tentacles are incredibly strong, able to crush bones and rend flesh with ease. It can also release blasts of eldritch energy, which can tear through matter and energy alike.

entries.name: (10+) Mentally Tough
entries: You learn the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (15+) Reality Distortion
entries: You are aware of the creature's Swirling Color Field trait.

entries.name: (20+) Strong and Nimble
entries: You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Warp Marauder has control over the reality around it. It grabs creatures and drags them into extraplanar realities where it feeds on them. The lupine alien isn't afraid to be hit, relying on its ability to alter time and space from an incoming attack, directing an essence of chaotic circumstance back towards the creature.
Warp Marauders flee if they are reduced below half their {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.
