monsterFluff.name: Warp Witch

entries: A lone figure draped in ethereal robes listlessly glides through the air, clutching a wrought iron lantern that glows in eldritch hues and green flames. A tattered hood conceals its face, but as you approach, they draw back their hood to reveal furious eyes and a hateful glare. Their mouth stretches unnaturally as they unleash an ear-piercing scream.

The Faith of the Sacred Flame says the souls of the departed gently pass from the Mortal World into the Shadowlands, where they wander until they find their final fate. Although their ultimate destination is a mystery, it is well understood that the Shadowlands are a dark reflection of the Material Plane. As such, occasionally wayward spirits slip back into the Mortal World near the places they died, where they typically manifest as incorporeal undead such as ghosts and wraiths.

However, the eldritch energies of the Haze weaken and disrupt the metaphysical fabrics that separate the planes. This wild magic conjures extraplanar energies and creatures into the ruins and has a particularly insidious interaction with the Shadowlands. The forces that draw the souls of the dead into the Material Plane are greatly magnified. Worse, the eldritch contamination corrupts the soul, fragments the mind, and distorts personalities, transforming these spirits into Warp Witches. Grasping for any memory of their former identities, the vengeful spirits of those whose lives were stolen by the Haze haunt the ruins of Drakkenheim. Their hatred and envy for the living manifests in a powerful compulsion to transform others into monsters.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Warp Witch, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Resistant Undead
entries: You learn of the Warp Witch's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Mutative Control
entries: You recongize the creature's {@variantrule Possession|XPHB} action and Mutate Host {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, but not the means to end the possession.

entries.name: (15+) Escaping Possession
entries: You are aware that the Warp Witch's {@variantrule Possession|XPHB} can be ended by reducing the possessed body to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or by casting {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Warp Witch begins combat by using its Psychic Scream. The witch then selects a target amongst their foes to possess.

While possessing a host, the Warp Witch will try to use the body to deceive or trick allies of its host into not attacking or harming them, trying to suggest useless, ineffective, and halfmad courses of action to "help" the host "drive out" the spirit, such whistling, dancing, clapping, singing, drawing pictures, and other bizarre commands. Meanwhile, the witch continues to use Mutate Host to contaminate them. The Warp Witch leaves the host after they undergo a Monstrous Transformation, and then moves to repeat the process with another.

monsterFluff.name: Winter Troll

entries: Its blue and white skin is encrusted with icicles that jut off its flesh at the elbows and knees, and form a mane of ice around its head. Even the creature's teeth look to be made of sharp icicles. Its breath, like a cold winter wind, is tinged with frost and snow.

Winter Trolls occupy the great mountain tops around the continent, but are especially persistent in the Giantfrost Mountains where they share their domain with their bitter rivals of the stone and frost giants. They hunt across the Barren Expanse in packs and have claimed a portion of the ruins of Glitter Peak. Winter Trolls rarely leave snowy environments. They pose a significant threat to settled lands in the dead of winter, when they leave their mountain tops to look for food.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study} a Winter Troll, learning the following information based on the result:

entries: You know the troll's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Hard to Kill
entries: You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait.

entries.name: (15+) Special Weakness
entries: You have insight into the troll's {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities}.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Winter Trolls hunt for food during heavy snowfall and long winters. Often accompanied by swirling snowstorms and freezing temperatures, they begin combat by unleashing their Freezing Breath before rushing in to maul foes with their Slams and Bites.
If a Winter Troll takes Fire damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.

These sickly figures look frail and weak, their flesh pale and sagging, and their eyes sunken and hollow. They wear little more than light fabric gowns, bloodor pus-soaked bandages, tattered rags, or dirty garments. Some of them are covered in blisters or soars, others bleed from the ears, nose, or mouth. They mutter to themselves mad gibberish and whispered ideas.

{@action Magic|XPHB} is beyond the means of most commonfolk in the continent. Few can afford the services of the Amethyst Academy, and priests of the Sacred Flame and Old Gods alike are selective with their divine magic, offering their boons to devout worshippers or those in dire need only. However, apothecaries are seldom so selective, especially those who operate in remote regions or clandestinely within large cities.

entries.name: Desperate Vanity
entries: Lesser nobles and vain merchants occasionally seek out apothecaries not for a cure to an ailment, injury, or sickness, but in the hopes of augmenting some quality of themselves they find deficient. These individuals may come to an apothecary looking for a miraculous means to become taller or more comely, reverse aging, or even gain supernatural or magical abilities.

entries.name: Medical Malpractice
entries: Unfortunately for their patients, unscrupulous apothecaries may be perfectly willing to offer an experimental method or untested procedure in exchange for an affordable price, seeking an opportunity to trial their latest concoction upon a hapless yet willing subject. When these ill-conceived techniques inevitably go awry, the subjects find themselves transformed into a grotesque mockery of themselves.

entries.name: Promised Cure
entries: The transformation leaves the patient half-mad. Some are manipulated in the hopes of being cured one day, or tricked into believing that they must remain in the care of their "doctor" until they have "recovered" from the procedure. Many lash out in rage, fleeing into the wilderness, back alleys, or hidden away in their homes. Those unable to return to their former lives in fear or shame may remain, however.

entries.name: Useful Lackeys
entries: Left without the means to restore their former appearance, these wretched patients accept roles as orderlies, guards, and assistants to the apothecary responsible for their tormented contention. Truly psychotic apothecaries may increase their control over their patients through invasive brain surgery, chemical conditioning, and forced indoctrination. These terrible procedures render these unfortunate individuals fiercely loyal to the apothecary, imbuing them with a fanatical drive to protect them even at the cost of their own lives.

entries.name: The Varied Victims of Many Malpractices
entries: Wretched Patients represent the unfortunate victims of apothecaries' experiments. No matter their area of study, the deranged minds of evil scientists know no bounds with their experimentation on willing subjects in the name of occult science.

entries.name: Alienist
entries: Often those with mental instability or muddled minds turn to an Alienist. These patients are rendered into mindless and obedient servants through mind control, mental conditioning, and mind-altering procedures. Alienists have been known to go as far as remove portions of their victims' brains or remove their brains entirely while keeping the subject alive.

entries.name: Chemist
entries: Those looking for tinctures and tonics to ease all manner of ailments have turned to Chemists, often unaware of the danger of their compounds. These patients are often subject to new experimental procedures that leave them burned, or scarred, disfigured by chemical research. In some cases, the chemical procedures can leave the victims hairless, blind, or cause their skin to muddle and scar over completely.

entries.name: Exorcist
entries: An Exorcists patients seek help with possessions that may or may not be real. These haunted people can find themselves at the hands of mad scientist and spiritualist who will use the willing patient to summon or trap demonic forces. Sometimes these patients are simply what remains after a demonic or spiritual possession, where after the removal, the victim is left numb and catatonic, having lost most of themselves to the entity that inhabited them. More sinister exorcists will perform this procedure on purpose, placing powerful entities into a patient, only to remove it and render the patient hollow and willing to become a subject to the apothecary.

entries.name: Mutagenist
entries: The failed experiments of a Mutagenist can leave all manner of strange disfigurations and abnormalities upon their patients. Everything from unusual growths, cankers, and tumors, to fully growing extra limbs, eyes, mouths, and other such strange occurrences. These patients become hideous mockeries of their former selves and over time, become reliant on the doctor to keep their growths and mutations in check.

entries.name: Pathogenist
entries: When sick with disease, or dealing with unknown poisons, subjects will go to a Pathogenist. Those who take their practices too far often use subjects as vessels for experimentation. Subjects are often riddled with diseases, sores, boils, at times losing their teeth and fingernails to unnatural decay, their skin turning shades of yellow, green, or purple. They appear sickly, carrying a many pathogens, toxins, and diseases.

entries.name: Reanimator
entries: Reanimators are sought out when a patient has lost a limb, or had severe injury that would leave them scarred or disfigured. The Reanimators who take their practice too far will use the subject as a means of experimentation. Attaching new limbs to them, testing the lengths they can go by adding multiple limbs, or a second head, additional fingers or toes, subjects over time can become a patchwork of various parts that have been removed, reattached, or swapped.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Wretched Patients are simple minions. They defend themselves and reluctantly fight at the command of their creator. If their creator dies, Wretched Patients flee or cower.

items.name: Zealot

entries: Dressed in gray robes with a tabard bearing the symbol of the Falling Fire, these protectors carry large greatswords of simple design. Fiery faith burns in their eyes.

Zealots are the warriors of the Falling Fire, sworn to protect pilgrims on their journey to the Sacrament. They accompany expeditions into the city, and act as guards for the strongholds held by the faith. Though still dressed simply, and giving up most possessions, these devoted warriors of the Falling Fire are the ones skilled enough to wield weapons and fend off the monsters and bandits of the city.

monsterFluff.name: Zealot of Morrigan

entries: This humanoid almost resembles a painted, weathered statue, adorned with tattoos depicting ravens, skulls, and lines of blood. It moves with inhuman speed and glares at you with its hungry, bloodshot eyes. Pointed fangs poke from their cracked lips and a look of a predator preparing for a hunt — and a meal — grows on their face. Saying not a single word, the zealot howls to the moon. Its quarry a faithful sacrifice to Morrigan, who witnesses from afar. Bearing no weapons but their claws, fangs, and brute strength, the zealot dashes forward, beginning the hunt!

As it is rumored that Morrigan is responsible for creating the first vampires, there are some amongst the Court of the Night that take to worshiping her in both body and soul. Viewing themselves as the apex predators, all creatures are beneath them. The Zealots of Morrigan pledge themselves to fighting against Morrigan's enemies, not least of which the druids and servants of Arwyn and Kromac. These warriors serve as the vanguard for much of the court's offensive operations, and are often sent in when they want an enemy utterly eviscerated.

The Zealots of Morrigan, as their order is called, give in to the primal nature their vampirism. They see the trappings of civilization and the kingdoms and empires that mankind has built as a blight upon the land, a perversion of nature. They do what they can to bring what settlements they can into complete and utter ruin. Reports of far flung, small villages disappearing overnight are often an indicator of their presence.

As they are vampires, Zealots of Morrigan like to attack and feed at night. There are rumored to be many Zealots of Morrigan dwelling in Netherwind, where the winter nights last several days, and the scarce population is a prime herd for the zealots to feast upon. The Reavers of Netherwind must stay especially vigilant during these times, and fighting them is a true test of their mettle. On occasion, the Zealots of Morrigan get a particular taste for giant's blood, and will coordinate an attack on a giant. This is usually done on Morrigan's holy day, and the blood feeds them for months.

Morrigan has infused these zealots with immense power and vitality. They rarely bother fighting with weapons, viewing their vampiric gifts as more than sufficient. The blood of their foes wraps around them, bandaging their wounds and forming a protective shield to keep them in the fight. The scent of spilt blood drives them into a frenzy, pushing them on into further savagery. There is often very little left of a zealot's quarry, as they get carried away in their bloodlust.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: As soon as a Zealot of Morrigan gets the scent of combat, they use their {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to enter Morrigan's Fury, amplifying their damage and bolstering them against assault. With their superior speed, they zone in on the easiest meal within range, assailing them with their claws and fangs. The blood spilt from these attacks then serves as a buffer, fueling their Blood Shield. In their fury, the zealots have no sense of survival or self-preservation, as they fight to the death.

variantrule.name: Epic Action
entries: An Epic Boss takes one Epic Action at the end of each player character's turn. At the game master's discretion, an Epic Boss may take an Epic Action after another non-player character combatant's turn, such as a sidekick or major NPC ally of the player characters.

Therefore, if an Epic Boss were facing five player characters, the boss would take five Epic Actions total during one round of combat, one at the end of each player character's turn. If a player character falls {@condition Unconscious} or dies during the encounter, the Epic Boss continues taking an Epic Action after that character's place in the {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} order.

Some Epic Actions can only be used once per round, and others may have a recharge condition. In addition, certain Epic Actions must be used as the first or last Epic Action the boss takes that round. For example, a {@creature Adult Delerium Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium Dragon} may only use its Breath Weapon as the final Epic Action it takes that round.

Epic Actions are not {@action Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}. Game effects which prevent an Epic Boss from taking {@action Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} do not work on Epic Actions, nor do game affects which limit a creature to taking only a movement, {@action Bonus Action|XPHB}, or action on their turn (such as the {@condition Dazed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition).

table.name: Arcane Anomalies
rows: A resonant cascade of eldritch phenomena! The resulting energies reflect, refract, and collide with another producing ongoing effects. Roll another Arcane Anomaly, then once more on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count 20 for the next {@dice 1d4} rounds.

Gravity breaks within a 100-foot radius area for 1 hour. Creatures levitate in midair and must push or pull against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling) to move as if climbing. Unattended objects float around randomly.

The nearest creature is affected by a {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB|Hideous Laughter} spell (spell save {@dc 15}) but instead of laughing, they repeat unfathomable syllables and words. Occasionally, a somewhat comprehensible but totally illogical phrase emerges, such as "...oh time thy pyramids!"

Time skips a beat. Creatures within 60 feet experience a palpable feeling of vertigo followed by a powerful sensation of deja vu and are {@condition Dazed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} for 1 round (no saving throw).

The nearest creature becomes unstuck in time. It is affected by the {@spell Blink|XPHB} spell for 1 minute. Instead of vanishing into the Ethereal Plane, the creature vanishes into a sliver of time in its past or possible future.

A prismatic burst of energy erupts in a 20-foot radius. Creatures in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 28 ({@dice 8d6}) Radiant damage and become {@condition Blinded|XPHB} for 1 round. The smell of ozone fills the area, and nearby wood and inanimate plants are transformed into solid glass.
Echoes of possible realities are briefly visible for 1 minute. When a creature within 60 feet is hit by an attack, a faint vision of the creature being killed by that attack appears.
Discordant music fills the mind of all creatures within 30 feet, who are affected by {@spell Otto's Irresistible Dance|XPHB|Irresistible Dance} (spell save {@dc 15}).
A section of stone, water, air, or energy becomes an appropriate {@area Contaminated Elemental|0eb|x} that is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to all nearby creatures.
An extraplanar creature is summoned. The GM either chooses the creature or determines it randomly. It is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} to the creature who triggered the anomaly.

All humanoid corpses with 120 feet animate as {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Husks}. The shrieking undead beg frantically for forgiveness as they rip apart the living.

The {@creature Shadow|XMM|Shadows} of {@dice 1d6} random creatures in the area animate and try to kill them while softly whispering "Guilty, guilty, guilty..." Once destroyed, the creatures don't cast a shadow for 24 hours.
All creatures within 60 feet gain the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition for 1 minute or until they attack or cast a spell.

Tendrils of life flow from the nearest creature to others. It must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Necrotic damage, or half as much on a success. The three nearest creatures within 60 feet each regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the damage taken.

A {@spell Hypnotic Pattern|XPHB} (spell save {@dc 15}) appears. It creates scintillating impossible colors in shapes which are simply wrong. Creatures {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} by the spell weep uncontrollably for the duration.
A {@spell Evard's Black Tentacles|XPHB|Black Tentacles} spell appears in the area for 1 hour (escape {@dc 15}).
Objects within 60 feet come to life for 1 hour, as if affected by the {@spell Animate Objects|XPHB} spell. They mumble awful truths but are not hostile.
Time slows down for up to six random creatures within 120 feet. They are affected by the {@spell Slow|XPHB} spell for 1 minute. (spell save {@dc 15}).
Time speeds up for one randomly determined creature within 60 feet of the anomaly. They are affected by the {@spell Haste|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.
The nearest creature is polymorphed into an {@creature Awakened Shrub|XMM} for 1 hour or until reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.
A bowl of flowers and a very surprised-looking aquatic mammal appear 100 feet in the air. "Oh no, not again..." thinks the bowl of flowers.

All creatures within a 30-foot-radius are affected by {@spell Mirror Image|XPHB}. Affected creatures do not know if they were the original or simply a reflection, and the feeling gnaws at the back of their minds forevermore.

The skin, flesh, and hair sloughs off all living humanoid creatures within a 30-foot-radius in a horrific display of gore, leaving behind only their skeletons and equipment. This doesn't kill or otherwise harm the affected creatures or change their game statistics. Their flesh, skin, and hair regrow slowly and painfully over the next {@dice 3d6} hours.

The sound of shattering glass is heard as the delicate webs of {@dice 1d4} {@creature Eldritch Crawler|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Crawlers} appear. Each spider appears with webbing which acts like the {@spell Web|XPHB} spell. The webs and eldritch crawlers remain until destroyed, or until the crawlers successfully obtain suitable prey.

A powerful magnetic force takes root in the triggering creature. All other creatures within 30 feet of the triggering creature must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, they are pulled up to 20 feet towards the triggering creature.

Each creature within 60 feet of the triggering creature (including the triggering creature) chooses a direction and rolls {@dice 2d6}. Each creature is then teleported to the nearest unoccupied space in that direction equal to the result times five feet. (e.g. 35 feet for a result of 7 on {@dice 2d6}).

Strange glowing fungus sprouts in a 20-foot radius around the triggering creature and hums softly with discordant tunes. Anyone who hears the tune mindlessly whistles the song in moments of idleness for the next {@dice 1d6} days.
A randomly determined mundane item worn or carried by the triggering creature flashes with brilliant energy, becoming an Uncommon magic item of the Game Master's choice.

A blast of raw contaminated energy explodes forth from the triggering creature in a 20-foot radius. All other creatures in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. They suffer 18 ({@dice 4d8}) Necrotic damage and gain one level of {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} on a failed save. On a successful save, they take half as much damage and do not gain any {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

The triggering creature is momentarily pulled into the Space Between Worlds. They vanish from their space until the start of their next turn. When they reappear, they must make a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, they take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Psychic damage and gain one random form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} (see {@area Conditions|8e3|x} later in this appendix). On a successful save, they take half as much damage and don't suffer from any madness.
The triggering creature's muscles bulge and its skin turns purple-green. It is enlarged as if affected by the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.

Wicked spirits flutter around the triggering creature. It is surrounded by the {@spell Spirit Guardians|XPHB} spell (spell save {@dc 15}), which deals Necrotic damage and harms all creatures except the triggering creature. The spirits taunt and jeer at the triggering creature.

The triggering creature gains {@dice 1d6} levels of {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Unlike normal {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, these {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels disappear after the character finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. If the character undergoes a Monstrous Transformation while it has any of these {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, it reverts to its original form when the new form is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or after 24 hours. It then gains a random form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} from the harrowing ordeal (see {@area Conditions|8e3|x} later in this appendix).
The triggering creature screams uncontrollably in horror for the next minute. Afterwards, it must make a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be unable to speak for the next {@dice 1d4} hours.
All creatures within 30 feet of the triggering creature (but not the triggering creature) gain the benefit of {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.

The triggering creature begins melting. Their skin sags and begins dripping off. Their bones turn to jelly and they become a puddle on the ground which quickly evaporates into a cloud of octarine mist. For 1 hour, the creature is under the effects of the {@spell Gaseous Form|XPHB} spell.

A burst of arcane energy lashes out to strike the triggering creature. While potentially lethal, if the triggering creature is a spellcaster they can attempt to absorb this energy to regain spell slots. If they do, the triggering creature regains {@dice 1d10} levels worth of spell slots. If the triggering creature doesn't have spell slots or can't regain the full amount, it instead suffers 18 ({@dice 4d8}) Force damage. Any spell cast using a spell slot regained from this effect automatically triggers another arcane anomaly.

All creatures within 60 feet of the triggering creature begin to transform into plantlike versions of themselves. Their skin becomes bark, they grow leaves and buds from their flesh, and creak as they move. For the next minute, each affected creature gains the benefit of the {@spell Barkskin|XPHB} spell but becomes {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerable} to Fire damage.

An 100-foot-radius octarine storm cloud emerges 300 feet above as pouring glittering rain falls for 1 minute. The area below the cloud becomes {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB}. A creature who starts its turn in the area must roll a {@dice d6}, on the result of a 1 they are struck by octarine lightning. They take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Lightning damage and must make a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

An {@spell Bigby's Hand||Arcane Hand} spell (spell save {@dc 18}, +10 to hit) appears in the area and assaults the triggering creature, trying to rip them apart, fling them from high places, or squeeze them to death.

The triggering creature is affected by {@spell Flesh to Stone|XPHB} (spell save {@dc 15}). Instead of transforming into stone, it slowly turns into solid delerium crystal. If it is wholly transformed into delerium, its body is equivalent in value to a {@item Geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium Geode}. While {@condition Petrified|XPHB} in this manner, the creature is fully conscious and aware of its surroundings. If the delerium geode is used to create a magic item, the creature's personality invests the resulting item with sentience.

A {@spell Simulacrum|XPHB}, as created by the spell, of the triggering creature appears. It claims to be a traveler from the future and insists the character must slay a randomly determined ally to prevent a terrible fate. If slain, the simulacrum melts into delerium sludge instead of snow.

A glowing crystalline orb appears hovering 10 feet above. Anyone within 30 feet of the orb hears the incoherent whispering of several voices. The first creature who touches the orb can communicate with the voices as if by the {@spell Contact Other Plane|XPHB} spell. The orb then disappears.

Each creature within a 30-foot-radius immediately hallucinates their own inevitable death in such a vivid manner that they are stricken with terror and a wave of lethargic hopelessness. Each creature must make a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition Stunned|XPHB} for the next minute. A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of their turns to end the effect, shaking off the terror and returning to reality.

Reminiscent of the flames which consumed Drakkenheim in the meteor's wake, a roaring wave of eldritch fire erupts in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. Each creature in the Emanation has the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ({@dice 3d6} Fire) condition.
All the heat is suddenly pulled from one random creature within a 30-foot-radius, who becomes {@area Frozen|8f0|x} (save {@dc 15}).

Your arms and legs gain the ability to detach for the next minute and they rejoin at the end of this duration. They gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} of 15 feet, you can control them as you normally would, they have an AC of 10 and any damage dealt to them is dealt directly to you.

The area erupts with unnatural, alien flora. Strange pulsing trees and octarine flowers emerge, twisting vines with pulsing octarine veins, rich plants that sparkle and hum softly, along with an abundance of various strange glowing fruit. Any creature who eats the strange fruit immediately gains the benefits of the {@spell Heroes' Feast|XPHB} spell. While under the effects of the spell, their eyes glow with octarine light, and their veins bulge and glow as well. They shed {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} in a 10-foot radius around them. The plants wither and crumble to dust after 1 hour.

The triggering creature explodes out of its skin and into a {@creature Delerium Dragon Wyrmling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} as if under the effects of {@spell True Polymorph|XPHB}. The creature reverts to its true form after 1 hour.

The triggering creature gains the ability to see through all of time and space, gaining unbound knowledge of all that has been, and all that will be. The creature immediately takes 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Psychic damage. If this damage reduces the creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it is knocked {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} but is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}. For the next hour, the creature gains the benefits of the {@spell Foresight|XPHB} spell as their mind is filled with visions of all possible futures and unbound realities. At the end of the hour, the creature takes an additional 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Psychic damage as they are flung back to a basic understanding of life, the universe, and probability.

table.name: Mutations
rows: Wave of Mutation. You gain any one mutation of your choice, then gain an additional randomly determined mutation. Then, all creatures within 60 feet of you gain 1 {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level. Instead of rolling to determine whether or not those creatures gain a mutation, each automatically gains 1 mutation.

Anomaly Locus. When you fail a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can reroll the {@dice d20}. When you do, you trigger an {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly}. You must finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} before you can do so again.

Sanguine Appetite. You develop a taste for blood which intensifies when you're wounded. While you have the {@status Bloodied|XPHB} or {@condition Bleeding|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} conditions, you gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on melee attack rolls against other creatures with the {@status Bloodied|XPHB} or {@condition Bleeding|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} conditions.

Fledgling Wings. Bat-like wings painfully explode from your back. You gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} of 40 feet during your turn. If you end your turn aloft, you fall. If you have 4 or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, your wings expand and your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} increases to 60 feet, and you no longer fall when you end your turn aloft.

Wretched Bile. Bubbling contaminated ichor unconformably builds up in your guts, which you can vomit forth periodically. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with an exhalation in a 15-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. Each creature in that area must make a Constitution saving throw ({@dc 8} plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 1d10} Necrotic damage for each {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level you have gained. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage. You can use your Wretched Bile a number of times equal to your {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level, and regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Terrible Stench. Your body emits a pungent odor which reeks of death and sulfur. Creatures who end their turn within 5 feet of you have gain the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of their next turn. Creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks made to locate or track you.

Explosive Demise. You feel volatile growths inside your body radiating intense heat. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Fire damage. If you are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} while you have the {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Contaminated} condition, you die and explode horribly in a shower of gore. Creatures within a 20-foot-radius must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. Failure: {@dice 4d6} Fire plus {@damage 4d6} Necrotic damage. Success: Half damage.

Hallucinogenic Visions. Your perception of the world around you twists into a miraculous landscape of rainbows, flowers, and vibrant colors, like walking through a pleasant dream. All creatures appear beautiful, friendly, smiling, and whimsical to you.

Cryogenic Shift. Your body rapidly disperses heat as ice begins forming on your flesh. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Cold damage, but if you don't move at least half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} on your turn, you have the {@condition Frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition ({@dc 15}).

Nascent Delusions. You gain a randomly determined form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, which persists so long as you have the {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Contaminated} condition.

Electric Discharge. Strange glands filled with crackling energy appear on your body. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Lightning damage. At the start of each of your turns, you deal Lightning damage to each creature within 5 feet of you. The damage equals a number of d6s equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. If you have 4 or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, the dice become d10s, and the range increases to 10 feet.

Hulking. If you are Medium or smaller, your size increases by one step (from Small to Medium, or Medium to Large). While your size is increased, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Strength ability checks. You return to your normal size when you no longer have {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

Shrinking. If you are Small or Larger, your size decreases by one step (from Small to Tiny, from Large to Medium). While your size is decreased, you have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength ability checks. You return to your normal size when you no longer have {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

Vocal Warp. Your voice takes on a strange pitch and resonance determined by rolling {@dice 1d6}. 1: Alien Resonance; 2: Wet Gurgling; 3: Demonic Baritone; 4: Constantly Singing; 5: Distant Echoing; 6: Rasping Whisper.
Wasting. Body parts begin falling out of you. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which: 1–2: fingernails; 3–4: teeth; and 5–6: toenails.

Rotting Extremities. One of your body parts begins to blacken and wither. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which: 1–2: your lips; 3–4: your nose; 5–6: your ears. If you reach four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, they rot and fall off. You can still speak and hear, however.

Transforming Skin. Your skin begins to change. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine the effect: 1: painful blisters which seep strange liquids; 2: cracking and peeling to reveal raw sinew; 3: strange patterns and runes; 4: welts and bruises which throb violently; 5: necrosis and rotting in patches; 6: lesions in otherworldly multi-colored hues.

Lambent Glow. You emit a dim octarine glow to a range of 10 feet. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you instead emit {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} to a range of 30 feet.

Shedding. Each time you gain a {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level, some of your hair falls out in patches. Once you reach four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, all hair on your body completely falls out.

Ocular Tumors. An eyeball opens somewhere on your body for each {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level you have gained. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you can see in all directions.

Alien Organs. You feel a bloated shift within your abdomen, as if something has been altered in your internal composition. Several of your organs have changed into something unrecognizable yet still functional. They're filled with alien black goo.
Shimmering Veins. Your blood veins glow through your skin, casting a faint octarine light.
Shadowless. You no longer cast a shadow, regardless of the light sources around you.
Flickering Presence. Your form flickers intermittently like a poorly tuned hologram.
Gossamer Hair. Your hair becomes fine and ethereal, floating gently as if underwater.
Sprouting Crystals. Small bits of delerium begin to erupt from your bones and through your skin. They itch painfully.

Burning Blood. FLAME ON! As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can give yourself the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition. The Fire damage is a number of d6s equal to half your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} (rounded down). While you have the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition, you gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. You can end the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition as an action. If the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} damage reduces you to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, your flesh burns away and only a skeleton remains.

Screaming Brain. You grow a sentient brain in your body, and it doesn't like you very much. It berates you and constantly questions your judgment, constantly wishing to escape the confines of your body.
Vestigial Limbs. Your body suddenly sprouts additional appendages. The limbs are not usable, however. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine what grows: 1: fingers; 2: toes; 3: leg; 4: Arm; 5: tail; 6: head.

Transmuted Flesh. Your flesh and body transform into an seemingly inorganic material but you remain animate and alive. This doesn't affect your game statistics. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which material: 1: iron; 2: wood; 3: glass; 4: stone; 5: water; 6: plastic.

Otherworldly Resistance. The {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} growing in your body makes you strangely resistant to similar forces. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to a damage type. Roll a {@dice d10} to determine which damage type: 1–2: Necrotic; 3–4: Thunder; 5–6: Radiant; 7–8: Psychic; 9–10: Force. You can gain this mutation multiple times, rolling a different damage type each time.

Chitinous Plates. Shell-like growths appear all over your body, giving you a +1 bonus to AC. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, this bonus increases to +2.
Amorphous Form. Your bones and organs become gelatinous. You can move through a space as narrow as 6 inches wide without squeezing.

Spiked Growths. At the start of each of your turns, you deal 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Piercing damage for each {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level you have gained to any creature you are {@variantrule Grappling|XPHB}.

Aquatic Adaptation. You sprout fish-like fins and gills. You gain a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} and can breathe underwater. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you can only breathe underwater. You can hold your breath outside water for up to 1 hour.

Cyclopean Vision. Your eyes merge into a single central eye, which you can use to cast the {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} cantrip. You use your choice of Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability.

Spatial Displacement. You can cast {@spell Misty Step|XPHB} once for each {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level you have. You regain these uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Tentacled Limb. One of your arms becomes a fleshy tentacle. When you make a melee attack on your turn, increase your {@itemProperty R|XPHB|Reach} by 5 feet.

Spider Climb. You gain a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your walking {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Whispering Voices. You gain telepathy to a range of 10 feet, but other people hear it as their own voice. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, the range extends to 60 feet.

Belly Maw. A toothy mouth appears on your stomach. You can use it to make a melee attack as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on your turn against a creature within 5 of you. Its attack bonus is equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice). If you hit with it, you deal Piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength or Dexterity modifier, plus an additional {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage for each {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level you have gained.

Eyeless Sight. Your eyes become milky orbs. You gain {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} to a range of 10 feet. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, your eyes rot out, and dim octarine light burns in the sockets. Your {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} increases to 30 feet.

Arcane Blood. You gain an additional spell slot of the highest level you can cast (to a maximum of 5th level). If you don't have spell slots, your {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum increases by an amount equal to your level. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you gain two spell slots instead of one or increase your {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by twice your level.
Reversed Limbs. Your base walking {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 10 feet and your {@variantrule Long Jump|XPHB} distance is doubled.

Chameleon. Your skin turns translucent and changes color to match your surroundings. As an action, you can give yourself the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition, which lasts until the end of your next turn or until you make an attack roll, deal damage, or cast a spell. You can use this ability only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use it, your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0 until the end of the current turn.
Magic Resistance. You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

Regenerative Flesh. At the start of each of your turns, if you are {@status Bloodied|XPHB} and have at least 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}, you regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to twice your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. The healed flesh regrows as knobby, scaled, alien hide.

Multiplied Senses. Your face sprouts additional eyeballs, ears, and noses. You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} checks as well as Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks.

Corrosive Mucus. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can spit acid at a creature within 30 feet. Make a ranged attack against the creature. On a hit, you deal {@damage 2d10} Acid damage and the creature is {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ({@dice 1d10} Acid).
Rampant Mutation! Roll twice, ignoring this result on subsequent rolls.

condition.name: Addled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma attacks rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Bewildered
entries: You can't cast spells, except for cantrips with a casting time of 1 action.

condition.name: Bleeding
entries: You're losing blood to an open wound.

entries.name: Ongoing Damage
entries: At the end of each of your turns, you lose {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. The number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} lost is indicated by the condition, such as "Bleeding {@dice 2d4}."

entries.name: Regaining Hit Points
entries: The condition ends if you regain any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Medical Treatment
entries: You or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action and use a healer's kit to staunch the bleeding (no check required), ending the condition.

condition.name: Burning
entries: You're on fire or covered in acid:

entries.name: Ongoing Damage
entries: At the end of each of your turns, you take damage. The damage type and amount are indicated by the condition, such as "Burning ({@dice 4d6} Fire)" or "Burning ({@dice 2d4} Acid)."

entries.name: Ending the Condition
entries: The condition ends if you or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action to extinguish the flames or scrape off the acid, or if some other effect douses the flames (such as being submerged in water).

condition.name: Clumsy
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Contamination
entries: While you have Contamination, you experience the following effects.

entries.name: Contamination Levels
entries: This condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain one or more levels of Contamination. You undergo a Monstrous Transformation if your Contamination level reaches 6.

entries.name: Contamination Symptoms
entries: A Contaminated creature suffers the symptoms from its current level as well as all lower levels. Conditions gained from Contamination end when those Contamination levels end. There is no other way to remove conditions caused by symptoms of Contamination.

entries.caption: Contamination Symptoms
rows: Halve the {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} you regain when you expend {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} during a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}
You do not regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: Each time you gain a Contamination level, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the result is equal to or lower than your current Contamination level, you gain a randomly determined mutation by rolling on the {@table Mutations|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} table. The effects of the mutation remain while you have Contamination levels. Unless otherwise specified, a creature can't gain the same mutation more than once. If a duplicate result is rolled, the GM chooses a different one or rolls again.

entries.name: Long Rests
entries: Each time you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} while you have 1 or more Contamination levels, roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 1, you gain a Contamination level.

entries.name: Removing Contamination Levels
entries: Only specific magic can remove Contamination levels:

items: The {@spell Purge Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} spell
{@spell Heal|XPHB} removes all Contamination levels and mutations in addition to its other effects.

Contamination is not a curse, poison, or disease. Spells such as {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Protection from Poison|XPHB}, and {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} do not remove Contamination levels.
Being raised from the dead reduces a creature's Contamination level by 1.

entries: When your Contamination level reaches 0, the condition ends, as well as the effects of all mutations.

Skin, hair, fingernails, and toenails lost to mutations regrow normally once Contamination is removed. However, a {@spell Regenerate|XPHB} spell or similar magic is needed to restore any other body parts (such as teeth, limbs, or eyes) lost due to Contamination. Appendages or limbs that develop as a result of mutations wither and fall off when Contamination is removed, and other warped body parts are restored to their original form.

entries.name: Dying with Contamination Levels
entries: If you die while you have one or more Contamination levels, your corpse reanimates as a {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} 24 hours later. A creature with six or more class levels or hit dice rises as a {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} instead.

entries.name: Monstrous Transformation!
entries: If you end your turn with six or more Contamination Levels, you permanently transform into a horrific monster controlled by the Game Master.

items: The Game Master chooses the new form, which is most often an Aberration or Monstrosity of some kind such as a {@creature Gibbering Mouther|XMM}, {@creature Delerium Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, or {@creature Pyknic Maunder|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
Your game statistics are entirely replaced by those of the chosen monster, including the new form's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}.
All Contamination levels are removed, though the GM may grant additional traits to the new form similar to any beneficial mutations gained from Contamination Levels.
The Game Master determines what remains of the original creature's personality and memories, if anything. Regardless, the creature falls under the Game Master's control.

entries.name: Reversing the Transformation
entries: A {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell or similar magic can restore a single transformed creature to its previous form, removing all Contamination and restoring the original creature's personality and memories. This is considered a stressful use of the {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell, and thus there is a {@chance 33} chance that the caster will be unable to cast {@spell Wish|XPHB} ever again if they use the spell in this manner.
Note that the means of reversing a monstrous transformation are completely unknown at the outset of the campaign. A Monstrous Transformation is widely regarded as permanent.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: You can move or take an action on your turn, not both. You can't take {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB|Bonus Actions}.

condition.name: Defenseless
entries: Attack rolls against you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

condition.name: Distracted
entries: You can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}.

condition.name: Drakkenheim Madness
entries: A character with Drakkenheim Madness gains one of the following traits:

items: "I wish I didn't have all these useless organs inside me."
"The contamination is a blessing which will transform me into a wondrous creature."
"The monsters are civilians trying to live a peaceful life! We need to protect them!"
"I must wear a flesh-coat made from my slain enemies to gain their strength!"
"My companions died in the ruins. I'm sorry friends, you are merely ghosts haunting me, you aren't real. Stop trying to talk to other people."
"I need to eat everything I can find. It's probably going to be my last meal."
"Drakkenheim is so beautiful at night. I could spend forever wandering the streets by moonlight. We should go tonight! Let's go every night!"
"Don't you fools get it?! If you die in Drakkenheim, you die IN REAL LIFE!!!!"
"A sinister cabal of disembodied hands is plotting against me."
"I must go into the ruins and kill. Rip and tear, until it is done."

condition.name: Enfeebled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Frozen
entries: You're partially encased in ice:

items: You're {@condition Immobilized|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@condition Defenseless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
You're {@condition Helpless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} against attacks made with a weapon that deals Bludgeoning damage.

You or another creature take an action to break the ice away. To do so, you must succeed on a Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the condition ends. The DC is indicated by the condition, such as Frozen (DC 15).
This condition ends on you if you take 20 Bludgeoning or Fire damage.

condition.name: Helpless
entries: Any attack that hits you is a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}.

items: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} becomes 0, and you can't benefit from any bonuses to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.
If you're flying when you become Immobilized, you fall.

condition.name: Jinxed
entries: Roll the die indicated by the condition, such as "Jinxed {@dice 1d4}" each time you make an attack roll or saving throw. Subtract the value on the die from the result.

items: You're {@condition Dazed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@condition Defenseless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
You drop whatever you're holding in your hands.
You must spend an action to draw, stow, or pick up an object.

condition.name: Sickened
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Constitution saving throws.

condition.name: Slowed
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved.

condition.name: Staggered
entries: You can't make more than one weapon attack during your turn, regardless of your class features, spells, or magic items.

condition.name: Valor
entries: Add a die to your attack rolls and saving throws. The die rolled is specified by the condition, such as Valor ({@dice 1d4})

condition.name: Weakened
entries: You deal half damage with weapon attacks and spells.

contents.name: Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds
Ancient Entities
headers: Using the Ancient Entities in Your Campaign

entries.name: Congratulations!
entries: This is the last book you'll ever read. This isn't because you will suddenly forget how to read but more likely you will lose your eyes, an arm, the ability to comprehend language, or just die, and it's because some of you won't take this seriously. My name is Pluto Jackson and I am the greatest threat to the monsters of Westemr and beyond. This is my book entirely written by me! Well, it was written by some lowly scholar but completely guided and dictated by me. In it, you will find a compendium of truths and treasures about the greatest foes found throughout the known worlds. I have walked, run, flown, jumped, and fallen through portals and pathways to discover the intricate understanding of how these foes are put together and more importantly how to pull them apart.

Some of the stories you've heard about me are completely under-exaggerated. I have found myself in deep dungeons facing the brightest minds who staple body parts together. I have ventured into forests to hunt my troll rivals. I have crossed barriers into places where time moves in all directions. I have found myself fighting off dark creatures with a strange fascination with my neck. I have even spent entirely too much time breathing in the toxic air of Drakkenheim—all so I could bring this great knowledge to you.

Do not leave this book on your coffee table. It is not meant to be ornamental; it is factual and brilliant. Filled to the brim with drawings of the most hostile creatures, along with their tactics and fears. I have assembled this once-in-a-lifetime encyclopedia to help the weak and helpless achieve something big, something greater than themselves. A chance to walk a mile in the greaves of Pluto Jackson.
You're welcome!
{@i Pluto Jackson}

entries.name: What's in this Book
entries: This book describes over 150 monsters from the terrifying World of Drakkenheim!

The monsters in this book are cross-compatible with both the 2014 and 2024 versions of the Fifth Edition Core Rules. When reading this book, text in {@b bold} usually references a creature or non-player character stat block, while text in {@i italics} often indicates spells or magic items.

{@b The material in this book is meant for Game Masters}! Many dark secrets and ancient conspiracies are explained in the lore entries for the monsters in this book! Here's what you'll find within these pages:

entries.name: Content Warning
entries: Drakkenheim portrays a dark fantasy world. We recommend players and Game Masters have an open conversation at the start of the campaign to discuss their lines and veils. In support of this conversation, please note references to the following are common in this setting:

items: Violence, murder, blood, gore, cannibalism, and body horror.
Degenerative mutations which cause physical disfigurement and madness/insanity.
Rats, spiders, insects, demons, undead, ghosts, and other monsters.
Natural disasters, large-scale loss of life, civil war, displaced persons, refugees.
Moral ambiguity, social/political manipulation, religious zealotry, military nationalism.

entries: Explicit sexuality, sexual assault, racial prejudice, systemic racism, homophobia, and transphobia are not topics we want to explore in this world. Any inferences of such are wholly unintentional.

entries.name: New Monsters
entries: Chapters 1 to 8 feature new eldritch monstrosities, mutated beasts, and undead horrors spanning multiple tiers of play from CR 1 to CR 30. Each chapter features in-depth lore entries about the monsters, unique roleplaying traits, deadly combat tactics, and adventure locations with tactical maps.

entries.name: Epic Bosses
entries: Among the creatures detailed in this tome are mighty adversaries called Epic Bosses. These formidable creatures present a potent variation on legendary monsters intended as a solo threat to an entire adventuring party. General rules for {@area Epic Bosses|00d|x} are described later in this introduction. In addition, {@book Appendix A: Ancient Entities|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|9} features Epic Boss game statistics for eldritch beings inhabiting the otherworlds of Drakkenheim!

entries.name: Dungeons of Drakkenheim
entries: This book also updates game statistics for many monsters introduced in {@adventure Dungeons of Drakkenheim|DungeonsDrakkenheim}. If you're running that adventure, we've created these new monsters to fit within the ecology and challenge within that adventure. Furthermore, {@book Appendix B: Faction Agents|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|10} describes humanoid NPC game statistics representing members of the five factions originally introduced in {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim}.

entries.name: New Conditions
entries: {@book Appendix C|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|11} includes a breakdown of the new conditions you'll find in this book and how they work in play.

{@area Bewildered|8e5|x}

entries.name: Contamination
entries: The rules for contamination are included in the section for new Conditions:

items: {@b {@i Expanded Mutations}.} Featuring {@b 50 horrific body-horror inspired mutations}, this {@area table|8ca|x} introduces new effects and reprints the original 20 mutations from {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim}.
{@b {@i Expanded Arcane Anomalies}.} This {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} expands the list of arcane anomalies from {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim} from 20 to 50.

entries.name: Save Ends
entries: Throughout this book, we've used the shorthand "(save ends)" to certain conditions and game effects caused by monsters. This means that the affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on themselves early on a success.

entries.name: Monster Harvesting and Magic Item Crafting
entries: This tome introduces a new way for player characters to craft magic items and equipment using components harvested from slain monsters.

The full rules are presented in {@book Appendix D: Crafting and Harvesting|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|12}. Our crafting system emphasizes adventuring to collect rare components, rather than spending gold, taking extended downtime, and making random skill checks. Instead, all characters need to do is find the parts required for an item, then bring those parts to an appropriate workshop.

entries.name: Harvesting Components
entries: Each monster entry in this book includes a Harvesting Components section, listing the components player characters can collect from it. Each monster's part has a {@b Rarity} from uncommon to legendary, defined by its challenge rating. These are detailed in {@book Appendix D: Crafting and Harvesting|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|12}.

entries.name: New Magic Items
entries: {@book Appendix E: Magic Items|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|13} features dozens of new magic items, and recipes for each!
They call it Dungeons of Drakkenheim, but I don't remember any dungeons! Are sewers a Dungeon? Are basements? This is confusing.

entries.name: Epic Bosses
entries: Introduced in this book are special monsters known as Epic Bosses. These unique foes are designed to pose a solo threat to an entire adventuring party.

entries.name: Epic Boss Rules
entries: Thanks to their unique abilities, Epic Bosses have additional game rules which set them apart from normal creatures:

entries.name: Turns and Initiative
entries: An Epic Boss always takes its turn on Initiative count 20 (and wins Initiative ties).

On its turn, an Epic Boss can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, an Epic Boss does not take an action or {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, Epic Bosses take Epic Actions as described below.

entries.name: Epic Actions
entries: An Epic Boss takes one Epic Action at the end of each player character's turn. At the game master's discretion, an Epic Boss may take an Epic Action after another non-player character combatant's turn, such as a sidekick or major NPC ally of the player characters.

Therefore, if an Epic Boss were facing five player characters, the boss would take five Epic Actions total during one round of combat, one at the end of each player character's turn. If a player character falls {@condition unconscious|XPHB} or dies during the encounter, the Epic Boss continues taking an Epic Action after that character's place in the Initiative order.

Some Epic Actions can only be used once per round, and others may have a recharge condition. In addition, certain Epic Actions must be used as the first or last Epic Action the boss takes that round. For example, a {@creature Young Delerium Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium Dragon} may only use its Breath Weapon as the final Epic Action it takes that round.

Epic Actions are not Reactions. Game effects which prevent an Epic Boss from taking Reactions do not work on Epic Actions, nor do game affects which limit a creature to taking only a movement, {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, or action on their turn (such as the {@area Dazed|8eb|x} condition).

entries.name: Epic Resistance
entries: Epic Bosses possess extraordinary resilience, willpower, and determination which allows them to rapidly recover from spells and effects which would incapacitate or debilitate other creatures. This Epic Resistance action is available to all Epic Bosses as an Epic Action:

items.name: Epic Resistance
items.entry: The Epic Boss chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls {@dice 1d20}. On an 11 or higher, the effect ends on it. An Epic Boss can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

entries: An Epic Resistance roll is not a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, that is, it is not an ability check, attack roll, nor saving throw. An Epic Boss can never have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} or {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on an Epic Resistance roll. Furthermore, no bonuses or penalties can ever be applied to an Epic Resistance roll. Finally, no game effect can replace the roll or the result of the roll, nor allow or force the Epic Boss to reroll an Epic Resistance roll.

An Epic Boss can use Epic Resistance to escape conditions and effects before their durations would otherwise expire. For example, if an Epic Boss becomes {@condition Stunned|XPHB} by a monk's Stunning Strike feature, it could use its Epic Resistance to end that condition. When Epic Resistance is used on the {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} condition, a successful {@dice d20} roll removes 1 level of Exhaustion.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: Each Epic Boss has a Hit Point value expressed as a base number, plus an additional amount based on the number of player characters in combat.

entries.name: Aura
entries: Most Epic Bosses project an {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} which deals damage to creatures which start their turns within its area. During its turn, the Epic Boss can choose any number of creatures to not be affected by its aura that round (no action required).

entries.name: Unique
entries: Another creature can't use the game statistics of an Epic Boss using {@spell Polymorph|XPHB}, {@spell Shapechange|XPHB}, or similar abilities and magic.

entries.name: Encounters with Epic Bosses
entries: Epic Bosses are designed to capture the fantasy of an adventuring party facing down a single terrifying creature in a climactic battle. These are meant to be difficult encounters where the player characters must expend every remaining resource if they are to survive. This is counterbalanced by the expectation that an Epic Boss usually represents the final encounter of an adventure or story arc, so the player characters will be able to take a long rest and recuperate immediately afterwards.

As such, Epic Bosses have also been designed with the assumption that they need to bear the full brunt of the player characters "big guns," such as {@spell Divine Smite|XPHB|Divine Smites}, Action Surges, and spellcaster's highest level spells.

When creating encounters with an Epic Boss, consider carefully before adding any minions to support them in battle. If you want to make the encounter more challenging, consider adding traps, hazards, or other environmental factors before adding additional creatures to the mix.

entries.name: Epic Bosses and Challenge Rating
entries: The table below shows the recommended Challenge Rating for an Epic Boss given the player characters' level. Note that since Epic Bosses scale to the number of player characters, it is not necessary to use a higher Challenge Rating Epic Boss for larger or smaller parties.

Characters of 4th level and lower do not have the Hit Points and resources to survive encounters with Epic Bosses, unless they are substantially more powerful than expected due to high ability scores, magic items, or player skill.

entries.name: The World of Drakkenheim

entries: Drakkenheim is no more. The once-proud capital of Westemr is a desolate urban wasteland, ravaged by an eldritch storm of falling stars fifteen years ago. The disaster that day was merely a prelude to the horrors that followed. Once the octarine flames that engulfed the city died down, a thick eerie mist remained behind. By night, a billowing aurora of prismatic light appeared, dancing over the city's corpse. Now, the forlorn streets are haunted by mutated monsters, twisted abominations, and undead wretches created by the otherworldly forces which have taken root in the ruins.

This book expands upon the setting introduced in our adventure {@adventure Dungeons of Drakkenheim|DungeonsDrakkenheim}, which details the ruined city and five factions warring over it. The wider world beyond Drakkenheim is detailed in the setting book {@i Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim}. Throughout this book, you may find references to locations in Drakkenheim itself, as well as places in the neighboring nations of Westemr, Elyria, and Caspia. While we recommend consulting these books for the full information, here are a few details about the setting.

entries.name: Dungeons of Drakkenheim & Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim
entries: This book further expands the world originally presented in our adventure {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim} and builds on the background lore for the wider world featured in {@i Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim}. If you own a copy of either book and are planning to run the campaign, you'll find a wealth of information herein to expand the campaign.

{@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim} is confined to the city of Drakkenheim itself, and covers the factions, conflicts, and locations within that city in detail. This book makes references to characters, locations, and the original five factions from that campaign, including the Amethyst Academy, the Followers of the Falling Fire, the Knights of the Silver Order, the Queen's Men, and the Hooded Lanterns.

If you don't have a copy of {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim}, don't worry! While the lore and adventure hooks for the monsters are created with the campaign in mind, you should feel free to use the new monsters in your own campaign, reflavoring or adapting their lore and appearance to suit your setting.

entries.name: Quick Facts About the Setting
entries: The setting of Drakkenheim diverges from the default assumptions of Fifth Edition in four key ways:

{@b The gods are silent and distant.} They don't manifest physically nor speak with worshippers, and do not interfere in earthly matters. Planar cosmology is mysterious and unknowable, but sages have still developed many conflicting (and wildly incorrect) theories.

{@b Gods don't grant divine spellcasting powers.} Instead, clerics, druids, and paladins tap into sacred energies through devotion, meditation, and resolve. Violating one's religious tenets won't result in a loss of these abilities, but a crisis of faith might.

{@b Individuals can't become wizards through study alone.} The arcane magic of both sorcerers and wizards alike is borne in the blood, which may be harnessed via practice and study. An important treaty between nations known as the {@i Edicts of Lumen} bars arcane spellcasters from holding noble titles.

{@b High-level NPCs and spellcasters are exceptionally rare in the wider world.} Despite their few numbers, such people still have a profound impact on society. However, Drakkenheim has attracted an uncommonly high concentration of such individuals.

entries.name: Delerium
entries: {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium crystals} are found throughout the ruined streets of Drakkenheim, jutting forth from piles of rubble, spreading along crumbling walls like crystalline moss, and glowing within the gaping crater. These iridescent stones radiate with vast magical energies which induce madness and mutate any matter they touch. While most deposits were left behind by the falling stars which devastated the city, the magical crystals slowly sprout and grow as their contaminated energies spread.

Although the crystals are dangerous, their tremendous magical potential makes them especially valuable to arcane spellcasters of all kinds. Delerium is readily used as the material component for nearly any spell, and the crystals can store and contain powerful magical essences which may in turn be used to power magical weapons, equipment, and other arcane contraptions. As such, the stones command a high price amongst mages and occultists alike, and an influential gray market has developed around prospecting, extracting, transporting, and selling the crystals. Nevertheless, the true origins and full properties of delerium have yet to be discovered.

entries.name: The Haze
entries: Swirling mists filled with indescribable colors of greenish yellow-purple settled over Drakkenheim. This magical mist is the visible byproduct of the intense magical radiation emitted by the vast concentration of delerium in the ruins. Normal creatures slowly gain contamination the longer they linger within the Haze and cannot benefit from a long rest while they remain inside it.

entries.name: Factions of Drakkenheim
entries: Five factions clash over the ruins of Drakkenheim, each vying for control over the ruins and the delerium found there. Their agents are regularly encountered in the world at large seeking to recruit new heroes to join their cause and additional resources to aid their embattled forces in the fallen capital.

entries.name: Hooded Lanterns
entries: Formally known as the 4th Provisional Expeditionary Force to Reclaim the Capital, the {@area Hooded Lanterns|8af|x} are an irregular military drawn up from veterans of the Civil War and remnants of the old Drakkenheim City Watch. Led by the dour {@creature Lord Commander Elias Drexel|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, they wage a guerrilla war against the monsters, bandits, and scavengers that have taken root in their nation's capital. Each has pledged their swords and lives to rebuild Drakkenheim and restore the Realm of Westemr. Several noble houses have set aside their feuds to support the Hooded Lantern's efforts. These families believe once the city is restored, evidence will emerge revealing the true heir to the throne of Drakkenheim... or enable a cunning house to seize the crown.

entries.name: Queen's Men
entries: The {@area Queen's Men|88a|x} are a loose affiliation between a hundred gangs of brigands, outlaws, and scoundrels, all owing fealty to the enigmatic {@creature Queen of Thieves|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. These reprobates prey upon the pilgrims, prospectors, and explorers drawn to the city, extort and rob adventurers, smuggle delerium to disreputable clients in distant lands, and plunder the fantastic treasures and incredible wealth left behind in the city. The Queen of Thieves dreams of building an influential and powerful criminal empire forged in the anarchy and lawlessness of the ruins, conspiring against the other factions at every turn.

entries.name: Knights of the Silver Order
entries: The {@area Knights of Silver Order|899|x} are an organization of oath-bound paladins and devout warriors sworn to combat supernatural evil, dark magic, and otherworldly incursions. The questing knights normally travel the realms in small bands and companies, and adhere to the Faith of the Sacred Flame, the dominant religion across the continent. They believe delerium is a contaminating blight borne of the darkest chaos, and have resolved to annihilate the corrupted crystals, slay every monster it has created, and hunt down diabolical mages who would wield its power to work evil magic. Now an entire regiment has been dispatched to Drakkenheim to carry out this righteous task, led by {@creature Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Followers of the Falling Fire
entries: The annihilation of Drakkenheim incited a serious religious schism within the Faith of the Sacred Flame. A new sect has emerged known as the {@area Followers of the Falling Fire|871|x}, who adhere to the prophecies of former Flamekeeper {@creature Lucretia Mathias|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. She attests that delerium is a divine gift, not a blight, and that these sacred stones will offer salvation against a greater darkness yet to come. The mainstream clergy have excommunicated Lucretia Mathias and branded her followers as an insane cult with heretical beliefs and blasphemous practices. Even still, masses of devout commonfolk now embark on a dangerous pilgrimage to Drakkenheim to take their place in a divine plan.

entries.name: Amethyst Academy
entries: The {@area Amethyst Academy|85c|x} is a magical school for sorcerers and wizards where students learn magic in remote castles and secluded universities. Directed by a shadowy cabal of powerful archmages, the Academy also operates an enterprising mage guild that controls the manufacture of magical wares and orchestrates an influential arcane syndicate that provides occult counsel to the nobility of the continent. However, the Academy was dealt a terrible blow following Drakkenheim's destruction, as the city was home to their greatest stronghold: the Inscrutable Tower. Archwizard {@creature Eldrick Runeweaver|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} leads the Academy's efforts to access the tower and safeguard the secret lore within. Meanwhile, their survey teams conduct ongoing research regarding delerium's supernatural qualities and unknown dangers. The mages plan to harness the crystal's vast energies to craft magical items and power new arcane spells.

entries.name: The Original Drakkenheim Campaign
entries: The material in this book is based on the {@i Dungeons of Drakkenheim} live stream campaign broadcast by the Dungeon Dudes, which ran from October 2018 to December 2019, and the follow up campaigns {@i Shadows of Drakkenheim} (which ran from January 2020 to December 2021), {@i Untold Tales of Drakkenheim} (played in 2020 and 2021), and {@i Fate of Drakkenheim} (which began in 2022).
It featured Kelly McLaughlin as Sebastian Crowe and Wilhelm Wolfsbane, Jill Danitis as Veo Sjena and Rudi Whittaker, Joe O'Gorman as Pluto Jackson and Wrath, with Monty Martin as Game Master.

You can watch it on the Dungeon Dudes YouTube Channel (youtube.com/dungeondudes) and find it on most major podcast platforms. Check it out if you're looking for inspiration for how we ran the adventures in this book, but be warned: spoilers abound! We've also created a wealth of instruction videos for players and game masters covering everything about tabletop roleplaying games, from character building to designing campaigns.

The World of Drakkenheim is a vast and ever-expanding place, and this book focuses the many monsters our heroes have battled over the course of the campaign. We've done our best to include as many monsters and nonplayer characters from the show in this book as possible, and we've included many more completely new ones for you to explore in your own game.

We think of our original livestream campaign as the "first draft" of our world, and as the World of Drakkenheim has grown, we've occasionally made the odd change, and several retcons too. If you've watched the original series and notice an inconsistency between this book and the show (there are many), the version in this book takes precedence. On the flipside, you should feel empowered to alter, change, and expand the material here, especially if doing so builds stronger connections or better stories for you and your players.

The events of our original campaigns are non-canonical with regards to this book, so several elements of Drakkenheim strongly connected to the original characters have been altered or removed. If you wish, the original "Drakkenforce" and "Duskwardens" characters may appear in your campaign as rival adventurers, but their stories have been set aside herein so your players may take center stage.

data.name: Chapter 1: Horrors of Drakkeneheim
entries: {@b Horrific Legacy}

That purple rock is very valuable. I used to carry it around in my pocket but it turns merchants into monsters and the ones I love into weird mutant spiders. That is what we faced as soon as we crossed the threshold into Drakkenheim, an endless hodge podge of inside out carcasses, spines in the wrong places, and a plethora of appendages.
