No matter for a Caspian with a quick sword. Although it reminded me of the endless battles with Hydras. You attack one long limb and suddenly two more in its place! This is why we hate math! The delerium spreads quickly and even the most gentle creatures turn into nightmarish abominations! I watched a soldier of Caspia get eaten by his own rations. I've seen veteran soldiers open their lunch boxes awaiting a fight! You must stick to the roads because you cannot trust the alleys. Sneaky bugs and behemoths wait to pounce with suckers and stickers looking for an opening. Be ready adventurer! For you are in the thick of it. The place where a rare sword freshly awaits a new set of hands to carry it further into the belly of the broken city known as Drakkenheim. If you didn't kick the horse may your god have mercy on your soul.

Though it was a metropolis of over a hundred thousand people, only a few hundred escaped Drakkenheim in the days following the disaster. Trembling as they spoke, these survivors recounted how they narrowly avoided the fire and ash that consumed the city, only to watch in horror as their loved ones, neighbors, and fellow citizens were twisted into grotesque parodies of themselves by the chaotic energies that followed the falling stars. All agreed that the only lucky ones that day were those who were swiftly incinerated in the initial meteoric impact. Ever since, those who perish within Drakkenheim or succumb to the contaminated Haze transform into hideous monsters.

Those who dismissed these claims as the distressed inventions of a few traumatized refugees were decisively proven wrong in the years following the disaster. Seeking to restore order as quickly as possible, the nobility of Westemr desperately mustered an expeditionary force to search Drakkenheim for royal survivors, recover the lost crown, and retake Castle Drakken. {@creature Lord Commander Elias Drexel|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} was placed in command of the mission, hand-picking a contingent of fifty elite House von Kessel soldiers to be the first team dispatched into the ruins. {@creature Captain Ansom Lang|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} was appointed to lead the squadron.

Although they were well-equipped veterans, this conventional military force was wholly unprepared for the conditions in the ruins. Arriving on the outskirts of the city, the troops found Drakkenheim cloaked in a thick opalescent fog, which came to be known as {@area the Haze|8dd|x}. When the mists did not abate, the soldiers cautiously proceeded into the ruins from the south, making their way along Champion's Way. The details are unclear about what exactly occurred next, since only a few scrawled notes from Captain Lang's logbook were ever found from that first mission.

Lang records that a few among their number began to fall ill shortly after entering the ruins and encountering a "gigantic and misshapen rodent" of some kind. Nevertheless, the unit pushed onward and ran afoul of "a throng of reanimated dead shuffling the streets." Lang notes that many were wounded in the battle against the undead after the creatures "violently exploded with some kind of strangely-colored magic" when slain. At that, the regiment decided to stop and rest to help their comrades recover. While making camp, a few of the soldiers presented Lang with "brightly glowing gemstones, which glimmered like nothing from this world" that they'd found amongst the rubble. Lang explains how he confiscated the stones, keeping them on his person "for safety, lest the troops get ideas about looting."

However, the soldiers were unable to sleep, haunted by whispers and nightmares of something in the swirling darkness. More began to fall sick, and that's when the changes began. One of the wounded soldiers started convulsing violently as their arms transformed into flailing tentacles, and their stomach opened into a gaping, toothy maw. Unsure what to do, a panicked Lang had "no other choice but to slay the poor wretch." At that point, Lang's writing becomes less clear, as he explains the affliction spreading amongst his soldiers taking hold in himself. That was the final entry in his log. The scribbled notebook was found by adventurers some years later amidst the remains of a terrible shapeless mass of monstrous flesh and limbs. None from Lang's unit ever returned from the ruins.

Since that time, many expeditions and adventuring parties have met a similar fate to Lang's unit, and rarely are records or remains ever found. However, a few were far more fortunate and returned from their missions. Through these few successes, the world was able to learn about the horrors of Drakkenheim, and the vast power—and danger—of delerium.

entries.name: First Contact
entries: {@i A report from Vanguard Captain Rose Walker, first expedition into Drakkenheim}.

We were crossing the river on the eastern outskirts, making our way up King's Road. As we approached the Drann, Faraday spotted strange eggs along the shore, colored unlike anything we had seen before. Similar, I think, to the fog hanging over the ruined city. Collins said they reminded him of tadpole eggs he saw as a child. We heard a low gurgling noise from the river and drew our bows. Collins was hit with one of the strange eggs. We saw a figure lurking in the water and unleashed our arrows at it, but it vanished beneath the surface. The egg that hit Collins had stuck to his neck. He was on the ground, writhing in discomfort. Faraday examined the egg, which had seemingly fused to Collin's flesh, appearing like a strange pulsing growth.

We were hesitant to attempt to remove it, and that hesitancy may be what cost Collins his life. I can't say for sure what happened next. We continued to travel towards King's Gate, keeping an eye on Collins, who claimed he felt alright; we would drop him off at a nearby Lantern waypoint to seek medical attention. Faraday observed a small creature within the egg, possibly a tadpole, disappear into Collins's neck as the egg merged even further. Collins lost consciousness only a minute or two later, and moments after that, began convulsing. His skin turned strange hues of yellow and green, his eyes grew pale, and he began to bleed from sores that appeared across his body. As we attempted to staunch the bleeding and tend to his ailments, Collins was lost to the disease that had quickly overtaken him. As we came to terms with losing one of our own to such bizarre circumstances, horrible events began to occur.

It's difficult to describe what happened to Collins's body. His skin began to writhe, and crack. His ribcage ripped open as a large frog emerged, its face split down the middle with a strange maw. It let out a horrible croak and leapt past us. We unleashed multiple arrows at the creature until it fell. Approaching the creature's body, we saw that it had already begun producing its own eggs, likely to use on the rest of us. However, the most unsettling thing was that its eyes were strangely familiar. They reminded me of Collins's.

entries.name: Eldritch Contamination
entries: It is now well-known that the {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} scattered throughout the ruins emit arcane radiation known as eldritch contamination (the game rules for which are described in {@book Appendix C: Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|11}). These energies also manifest the misty Haze that covers the city. Sustained exposure to this raw magic causes all matter to warp erratically. While living animal tissue is readily susceptible to contamination, over time even plant and vegetable matter, dead flesh, solid rock, metal, and even the elements themselves are affected by delerium. Overexposure to eldritch contamination induces a chain reaction of rapid mutation which changes humans, animals, and even inanimate objects into terrifying monsters in a painful and gory process. As the body betrays itself, the mind slowly unravels. A monstrous transformation drives even the most strong-willed individuals irrevocably mad, though a few retain a distorted facade of their intelligence and personality. Each creature described in this chapter has suffered this terrible fate.

The mutations caused by eldritch contamination are endless in possibility, and do not conform to any need for biological function or natural law. There is no telling what strange appendages, odd shapes, and unnatural abilities a contaminated creature could possess. While some mutations make for a fearsome abomination, many mutated creatures become a pathetic lump of flesh barely able to support their own misshapen bodies. However, within the churning chaos of change, occasionally patterns emerge. Even two creatures which share the same mutations and game statistics may have wildly different appearances and behavior.

entries.name: Hideous Beasts
entries: Humans are not the only creatures that have been transformed into monsters. The beasts that once inhabited Drakkenheim have also become abominations: the livestock and pets living alongside the citizenry, the vermin crawling in the streets and sewers, the skittering insects inhabiting every home, and the wild animals eking out a life amidst the pockets of nature found within the urban sprawl. Worse, even plant life has gained otherworldly sentience, animated by the eldritch forces taking root in the soil. Although monsters have always been known to exist, these horrific nightmares are unlike anything seen in any other place on this world.

Sometimes Drakkenheim's mutations are so bizarre and mind warping that they create an entirely new species. Although many mutated creatures appear related to the various animals and people who once inhabited the city, some have mutations so bizarre and mind warping that they create an entirely alien species. At times these changes manifest as masses of indistinguishable flesh, bloated tentacled limbs, or in rare cases they develop into a creature more uniform and recognizable in its makeup, but never before seen in the world.

entries.name: Walls that Talk
entries: It is a common misconception that eldritch contamination only affects living, organic creatures. The Haze infuses the atmosphere: conjuring bizarre and violent weather, polluting the earth and waterways, and even warping and changing the objects and structures within the city. Scouts claim the mists and fog have reshuffled the streets and thoroughfares of Drakkenheim into a shifting maze, but the reality is far more unsettling. Reports and rumors tell of walls of flesh, plants and trees turned to delicate glass, doorways opening portals to other realms, grasping tendrils emerging from seemingly inanimate objects, eyes and faces appearing amongst the stonework, and teeth, tongues, and hungry maws opening between the floorboards. Even time seems to flow erratically within the ruins, and on occasion adventurers thought lost in the ruins for months emerge suddenly, thinking they were only in the city for a day.

Given these strange effects, the monsters roaming the ruins, the hazards of rubble and wreckage, and the corrupt environmental conditions in Drakkenheim, nowhere in the city is safe. Anything, even the very walls of the buildings, are potential threats waiting for an opportune moment to strike.

entries.name: Haze Dependent
entries: Most contaminated monsters are dependent on the magic of the Haze to sustain themselves, as their unstable physiologies often defy the laws of nature. Brought outside the Haze, these monsters begin to rapidly wither and deteriorate, and seldom live much longer than a week. Once this was discovered, it was widely believed that the threats posed by the horrors of Drakkenheim were largely contained to the ruins. Nevertheless, the devastating effects on the countryside from spreading contamination and the danger of wandering monsters nearby was enough to see most towns and villages near Drakkenheim abandoned within a few years of the disaster.

Today, the only settlement within two weeks' travel of Drakkenheim is Emberwood Village. Fortunately, the large concentration of adventurous sorts and faction agents gathering in the town is more than enough to fend off most curious creatures who come to Emberwood, though no one questions what may have happened when a person disappears anymore.

However, contact or exposure to delerium can be enough to nourish these creatures for longer forays from the ruins. Worse, a significant concentration of delerium in any one place can cause a local manifestation of the Haze, which can maintain a great number of monsters. Bold and particularly lucid monsters seeking new hunting grounds may bring delerium with them on their own excursions outside the ruins, driven by an innate compulsion to spread their contaminated state.

entries.name: Corrupted Urban Ecology
entries: Drakkenheim has transformed over the last fifteen years into a nightmarish wasteland where urban decay meets the wild. The city's ruins are now more akin to a vast, untamed wilderness, teeming with violent and predatory creatures that have adapted to this new, harsh environment. These monsters have carved out their own ecological niches within the crumbled streets, decrepit sewers, and broken spires, turning the city into a landscape that is both alien and hostile.

These creatures have become the true inhabitants of Drakkenheim, mastering every aspect of their environment to their advantage. They use the dense Haze for cover, the labyrinthine ruins for navigation, and the scattered debris for shelter. The tunnels, alleys, and hollowed-out buildings serve as their nests, homes, and battlegrounds. To these monsters, Drakkenheim is familiar territory, their hunting ground where they thrive.

For any outsider venturing into the city, Drakkenheim offers no safe passage. Iconic landmarks such as towering spires, grand gates, city squares, and once-vibrant gardens have become twisted and unfamiliar. The city's layout is constantly shifting with fallen buildings blocking paths, broken and cratered streets, and contamination altering the environment unpredictably. This makes the city a labyrinth, constantly changing and challenging even to those who once knew it well.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The eclectic monsters presented in this chapter are diverse in their motivations, appearance, and behavior, but all share the same origins as creatures contaminated by the Haze. As such, the roleplaying traits below are common amongst them.

entries.name: Universal Mechanical Features
entries: Unless otherwise stated, non-humanoid creatures encountered in Drakkenheim possess the following traits. These do not change the monsters' Challenge Ratings (CR).

items: {@b Fully Contaminated}. This creature is immune to {@area Contamination|8c6|x} and has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.
{@b Haze Adaptation}. This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

{@b Haze Dependence}. This creature gains one level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

{@b Delerium Healing}. As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shard} to regain 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

entries: These features do not apply to creatures originating outside the Haze or who are recruited or conjured by the characters, such as familiars and summoned monsters.
If you are using these monsters in a setting that doesn't use {@area Contamination|8c6|x} or {@area the Haze|8dd|x}, you may disregard these mechanical features.

entries.name: Beyond Reason
entries: The monsters inhabiting Drakkenheim are irrevocably gripped by otherworldly madness. Most become predatory and instinctively violent as a result, but a few are lucid and capable of speech. However, even these creatures possess an unstable consciousness: they may be perfectly capable of carrying on a conversation for a short while, only to break out into rage, despair, or other extreme emotions without warning. Appeals to logic and reason often confuse and frustrate them, and they possess a twisted sense of empathy and alien logic. Few of Drakkenheim's horrors understand the origin of their malevolent predilections, and instead construct elaborate fantasies or incoherent narratives to explain their predicaments and behaviors.

entries.name: Struggle for Survival
entries: These monsters are often just as hostile to one another as they are to explorers who venture into the ruins. Although some have formed groups, many live a solitary existence wandering the city streets. Some are aimless, while others desperately search for something, be it food, their own memories, or some other delusion. A particularly empty or desolate area of the city may indicate that a powerful beast lurks nearby, as weaker abominations know to give the dangerous predator a wide berth.

entries.name: Motivated by Madness
entries: The monsters inhabiting the ruins have strange and incoherent motives.

items: {@b Territorial Guardians}. The monster is fiercely protective of specific areas within the ruins. Whether it has made the region its lair or its personal hunting ground, the monster attacks anyone who dares enter their domain. Their aggression may be linked to a compulsive need to protect a half-remembered memory, valuable object, or sacred place known only to them.

{@b Raw Hunger}. Driven by a primal need to consume, these monsters are motivated by an insatiable appetite. Whether they feed on flesh, blood, or even magical energy, they are relentless in their pursuit of sustenance.

{@b Murderous Impulse}. Sustained by the eldritch magic of the Haze, many monsters need no sustenance and have no real drive other than to kill and destroy. These aggressive creatures rarely respond to reason, and seldom flee even in the face of grievous injury.

{@b Confused Delusion}. Many monsters in the ruins, especially ones who retain a shred of their intelligence, do not fully comprehend their current state. They wander through the ruins, driven by fragmented memories and distorted perceptions of reality, often reacting violently to stimuli that remind them of their past lives.

{@b Spread Corruption}. These monsters have a compulsion to spread their contaminated state to others. If these monsters are intelligent and capable of speech, they may even deceive adventurers into helping them and fool them into becoming contaminated. Their manipulations are occasionally quite sophisticated and may include promises of power or feigned pleas for help.

{@b Compulsive Collector}. This monster is enthralled by something: perhaps delerium, or body parts like human teeth, eyes, fingers, ears, or hair. They hoard these obsessively and may attack simply to take what interests them and flee, rather than fight.

{@b Avoidant Survivor}. These monsters exhibit a high degree of caution and cunning, often avoiding confrontation unless absolutely necessary. They are survivors of countless battles within the ruins and have learned to hide, flee, or manipulate the environment to ensure their continued existence. Their primary motive is self-preservation, making them elusive and difficult to engage.

{@b Servile Worshiper}. Devoted to extraplanar entities, more powerful beasts living within the ruins, or even delerium itself, these monsters engage in ritualistic practices and strange worship. They view other beings as either potential converts or threats to their faith. Sometimes these monsters become communal and organized. They can be fanatically loyal to their cause, willing to sacrifice themselves or others to please their imagined or unseen masters.

entries.name: Aberrant Physiology
entries: The monsters presented in this chapter are typical of their kind, but even creatures with the same game statistics may have extreme variation in physical appearance. Consider using the following additional descriptions to distinguish creatures:

items: {@b Extra Heads}. This creature sports multiple heads, each possibly possessing its own unique thoughts and senses which vie for control over its body.

{@b Extra Limbs}. Sprouting from the creature's body are several additional appendages: arms, legs, fingers, claws, or otherwise. Most are functionally useless, though they may attempt to mimic the movements of the creature's main limbs.
{@b Eyes}. Numerous eyes dot the creature's body, each in different sizes, shapes, colors, and perhaps even from wildly different sources, such as insectoid or reptilian eyes.
{@b Multiple Mouths}. Toothy maws, slobbering lips, and gnawing mouths appear on the creature's body in random places. Some may even scream, babble, or speak.

{@b Tentacles}. Long, writhing tentacles extend from the horror in bizarre places, perhaps sprouting from its head or back like hair or spines. They may be smooth or covered in suction cups, or perhaps thin waving tendrils.
{@b Strange Coloration}. The creature's skin, scales, hair, eyes, or other body parts have bizarre, unnatural colors.
{@b Delerium Spines and Barbs}. The creature is covered in sharp spines and barbs that begin as bone and then crystallize into delerium.
{@b Inorganic Flesh}. Elements like glass or metal are fused with the monster's flesh. Perhaps even entire parts of its body are made of this material, which moves and bleeds like organic flesh.
{@b Conjoined Form}. This monster is a bizarre fusion of two creatures with a chaotic pattern of movement and attack.
{@b Wretched Fate}. A pitiful human part remains, partially absorbed and fully conscious, adding a gruesome and tragic aspect to the creature.
{@b Disgusting Secretions}. The horror leaks sludge, pus, blood, or other fluids from its pores, mouth, or other indescribable openings on its body.
{@b No Organs}. The creature's body visibly lacks organs, its existence powered by magical energies or other strange metabolism.
{@b Multi-Sectioned Joints}. The creature's limbs are segmented unusually, allowing for a range of motion that is both unnatural and disconcerting.
{@b Bioluminescent}. The monster emits a haunting light, useful for navigating dark environments or mesmerize its prey.
{@b Decaying or Sloughing}. Parts of the horror's body continuously decay and regenerate, a grotesque display that might be a strategy to shed parasites or damaged tissue.
{@b Melting or Stretching Form}. The creature's form seems unstable, constantly melting or stretching, which could be an adaptation for squeezing through tight spaces.
{@b Discorporated or Ethereal}. The monster appears only partially anchored in the physical realm, phasing in and out of existence.
{@b Translucent Skin}. Its nearly transparent skin reveals the horrifying workings beneath. Perhaps it has no skin at all, its outer body simply exposed muscle.
{@b Eldritch Flames}. The creature is swathed in flickering eldritch flames which do not consume its body.
{@b Pulsating Organs}. Visible muscle and organs pulsate grotesquely beneath the monster's thin skin.

entries.name: Otherworldly Effects
entries: The monsters are otherworldly and at times incomprehensible or horrifically bizarre. Rarely do the monsters of Drakkenheim speak or utter coherent words. Those that do are most likely humans who have mutated in the ruins. What bizarre and otherworldly elements occur when the monster is nearby?

items: {@b Remnant Thoughts}. The creature does little but incoherently spew the last remaining thoughts they had before they were transformed by contamination.
{@b Unnerving Susurrus}. From the shadows a whispered chorus of unknown mumbles echo through the streets, surrounding you.
{@b Vocalized Desperation}. The creature cries out for help or begs for mercy.
{@b Insectile Clamor}. The creature chitters and cackles, the clicking of its limbs against the ground reverberating in a chilling rhythmic clacking.
{@b Mystifying Visions}. Incomprehensible colors shift and float around the creature; they are confusing to look at.
{@b Bedimming Aura}. The sky darkens as the creature approaches, casting a false night over the city below it.

{@b Ephemeral Terrors}. Light visions, like daydreams, fill your head, only they are nightmarish and grotesque. In your peripheral vision you think you may see glimpses of melting faces, a ground of flesh, and strange obelisks jutting into a dark sky with octarine lightning, but only for a brief moment, and then it is gone.
{@b Trusted Voices}. You hear yourself, or a loved one having a conversation or yelling for help, but it is faint and distant, just on the verge of being incomprehensible.

entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Monsters find plentiful places to make their lairs throughout the ravaged streets, desolate plazas, crumbling structures, and flooded sewers of Drakkenheim. Here are a few ideas to keep in mind when designing encounter locations and lairs for the monsters in this chapter.

entries.name: Ruined City
entries: Amongst the city streets and back alleys are hundreds of buildings brought low by the rain of falling stars. Some buildings are more intact than others, but the devastation of the city is everywhere and the scars of the aftermath of that horrible day remain. Thick dust, octarine Haze, rubble-blocking paths, fallen towers and caved-in roads all have turned the great city into an endless labyrinth of twisting and turning passages.

entries.name: Monsters in the Dark
entries: There is always something hiding in the city's dark corners. An explorer may think they are in the clear and away from danger only to be ambushed unexpectedly by a hungry abomination. Nothing can be trusted, and if the city is quiet, that's even more reason to be on your guard—the worst terrors are the ones you never hear or see.

entries.name: Hazards Abound
entries: The city is always a dangerous place, even in the rare instance a mutated horror is not lurking just out of sight. Ruined buildings collapse, streets cave in, and the Haze can make navigation difficult. At any moment a terrible hazard can cause problems for adventurers trying to make their way through the city. Few buildings in the city stand unscathed. Most are in a partial state of collapse and heavily damaged. Shattered windows, splintered boards, and jagged rocks make up a large portion of the structures found throughout the city. Any encounter could be more lethal due to these constant hazards.

entries.name: Threats Above and Below
entries: The dangers of Drakkenheim's streets make many adventurers consider if safe routes may be found underground through the sewers, or by taking the high road along the rooftops of the city buildings. However, there are monsters and dangers on both routes. The choice to take the streets, sewers, or rooftops is more about the threats explorers are best equipped to handle, rather than a means to avoid monsters entirely.

Drakkenheim had a sophisticated sewer system running beneath the city. There are two types of tunnels in the system: drainage and sewage tunnels, which carry refuse and wastewater away from the city, as well as aqueducts and underground canals, which supply fresh water to the wells, cisterns, and fountains located throughout Drakkenheim. Of course, the damage and disarray to both systems means it's sometimes difficult to tell the difference. In these confined tunnels are all manner of horrible creatures. {@creature Lob Frog|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lob Frogs}, {@area Deep Dregs|3b5|x}, {@creature Bloated Hive|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Bloated Hives}, {@creature Drakkenheim Sewer Gator|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Drakkenheim Sewer Gators}, and {@creature Sewer Thing|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Sewer Things} all lurk in the fetid waters under the city.

Those agile and athletic enough to leap and run across the rooftops may evade threats in the streets below, but expose themselves to the wide range of airborne creatures who rule the skies above Drakkenheim, such as {@creature Skretch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Skretches}, {@creature Shardmaul Manticore|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Shardmaul Manticores}, and {@creature Eldritch Cataclysm|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Cataclysms}.

entries.name: Castle Drakken
entries: Built atop a high crag overlooking the city is this imposing military fortress and royal palace. It once stood as a glimmering beacon over Drakkenheim, and a testament to the majesty and royalty of the city. Now, the castle looms over the ruins, a dark and foreboding presence whose shadow casts an ever-present feeling of gloom and despair.

The castle is made up of two front gates along a winding path up the cliffside that leads to the upper and lower bailey. The lower bailey houses the castle stables and barracks. The upper bailey holds the castle chapel, gardens, and courtyard. The castle proper is composed of a long central building, with five great towers attached to it.

The castle is now overrun with demons, devils, vengeful spirits, and all manner of mutated monstrosities. Some of the most horrible monsters in Drakkenheim such as the {@creature Gravekeeper|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and the {@creature Amalgamation|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} reside in the castle, but the halls are filled with {@creature Warp Witch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Warp Witches}, {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Husks}, {@creature Dregs|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and a menagerie of other horrors, making it one of the most dangerous locations in the city.

entries.name: Drann River
entries: The wide Drann River flows southwest, and divides Drakkenheim into the North Ward and the South Ward. Averaging about four hundred feet wide as it travels through the city, the water is deep, slow-moving, and thoroughly contaminated.

The Drann River travels hundreds of miles before it empties into Ash Bay at the port city of Drannsmund. The Drann can accommodate lumber barges and small row boats, but seaworthy sailing vessels cannot travel this far upriver. While there are small quays and docks along the Drann, it does not support large ports.

The polluted waters of the Drann carry a steady amount of delerium downstream, and the river is now home to a wide variety of contaminated monsters, including {@creature Lob Frog|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lob Frogs}, {@creature Drakkenheim Sewer Gator|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Drakkenheim Sewer Gators}, {@creature Animated Delerium Sludge|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Animated Delerium Sludges}, and the {@area Deep Dregs|3b5|x} (see {@book Chapter 4—Predators of the Ruins|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|4}).

Four large bridges cross the Drann River from the north to south ward of Drakkenheim. All of which can be found in the Inner City, while the Outer City houses two ferries, one to the south, and one to the northeast.
{@i Author's Note}: The Drann River's width makes depicting both sides of the river on a typical scale battlemap impractical–the river would be nearly 100 squares wide!

entries.name: Champion's Bridge
entries: This decorated stone causeway is the largest in Drakkenheim at nearly five hundred feet long and fifty feet wide. It extends from Champion's Way in the south over towards the great Market Square in the Middle Ward. Five arched spans supported by stone piers hold the bridge thirty feet above the Drann. The bridge has an elegant stone guardrail, and overhanging balconies spaced along its outer edges each hold statues depicting mighty heroes from Drakkenheim's past. Today, the haunted bridge is home to countless monsters who occupy both the waters below, and the bridge itself. {@creature Lob Frog|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lob Frogs}, {@creature Bloated Hive|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Bloated Hives}, and even the {@creature Drakkenheim Sewer Gator|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} have been spotted in the areas under the bridge and some of these creatures wander up to its surface when hungry, looking for anything to eat.

entries.name: Temple Bridge
entries: This narrow bridge is made up of white cobblestone with seven stone arches supporting it twenty to twenty-five feet above the Drann River. The bridge is only twelve feet wide and has a slight arched curve to it as it extends across the river. A wrought iron fence flanks either side of the bridge, and every ten feet a tall, ornate pillar holds a torch. These torches have long been snuffed out, and the once pristine and bright bridge is now caked in dirt and blood. Garmyr (see {@book Chapter 4—Predators of the Ruins|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|4}) occupy the bridge now and hold a small encampment on the north side of it.

entries.name: Saint Selina's Bridge
entries: This bridge was under construction when the meteor struck, and sections made of thick wooden scaffolds are still set between the partially complete stone arches. The ruined bridge is extremely hazardous, with many of its support beams missing or damaged. A section of the bridge has crumbled and one of the arches is jutting out of the water below. Anyone daring the bridge must keep their wits about them, as any section of it could collapse at a moment's notice. Several {@creature Skretch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Skretches} who perch upon the city walls occasionally fly over and circle the bridge, waiting for an accident to grant them an easy meal, while {@creature Beetle Knight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Beetle Knights} skitter below the bridge, and a great {@creature Anomollusk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} occupies the stony debris below.

entries.name: Albrecht's Crossing
entries: The northernmost bridge is the oldest in Drakkenheim and was constructed originally as the main entrance to the city from the south, when the city was only the Old Town surrounding Castle Drakken. The bridge was constructed during the reign of the last House von Drakken monarch, Albrecht, and is made of finely crafted brass and iron into one of the most beautiful functional art pieces in the city. The bridge is lined with metal sculptures of dancing dragons that flow and coil around the railings, the long walkway etched with depictions of heroic deeds of long dead warriors. Now caked in debris and moss, the metal has lost its shine, but the bridge still stands sturdy against time. A {@creature Troll|XMM} encampment sits on the north side of the bridge while the south is close to the Crater, and well known for being a hot spot of {@b Undead} and {@area Dregs|1f3|x}.

entries.name: Stick's Ferry
entries: Old Sticks was a simple ferryman who ran a small rowboat crossing from The Sprawl to The Spokes in the southern stretch of the Outer City. He used to be a talkative sort, always wanting to hear the stories of the people he took across the Drann while sharing his own tales. Old Sticks was known amongst the locals as a jovial and kindhearted man, who simply loved being out on the water and enjoyed the steady, meditative nature of rowing. An elderly man in his late sixties, he would always claim that rowing kept his heart young, and joked that when he did eventually go, wherever he ended up he would likely just keep rowing if he could. Old Sticks didn't survive the initial blast of the meteor. He is now a {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} that seems to lack any of the normal hostile traits of the undead in the city. True to his word, he is content to just keep rowing people back and forth for an eternity.

entries.name: Abandoned Ferry
entries: The northeast stretch of the Drann in the Outer City has become a difficult place to cross. The ferry that once operated here is left abandoned. This old raft has been pulled up on shore with an old frayed rope that lazily stretches across the river. Now a self-service ferry of sorts, explorers can use the rope to cross the Drann. The river here is home to multiple {@creature Lob Frog|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lob Frogs} that hide under the two docks of the old ferry path and lay their eggs in large clusters there. A crude sign has been placed on the south banks by some unknown adventurer that simply reads "Don't."

entries.name: Outer City
entries: Stretching outward from the city walls in all directions, the Outer City itself comprises three main districts: Kingside, The Sprawl, and The Spokes.

entries.name: Kingside
entries: The area north of the Drann River to the east of the city walls is known as Kingside. Appropriately, the district is built along King's Way on the way to King's Gate. This once lush and beautiful landscape had the largest manors and houses outside the walls. It was also home to some well-known vineyards, inns, and the most luxurious stables, orchards, and cider houses in the city. Since the fall of Drakkenheim, strange magics have rested in the area. Twisted creatures haunt the old vineyards and inns, an eerie and constant chorus of wails and moans echo through the wide streets, and packs of {@creature Troll|XMM|Trolls} hunt the area looking for fresh meat.

entries.name: The Sprawl
entries: The large region west of the city walls is known as The Sprawl. Three main roads, Shepherd's Way, Temple Road, and College Street, all cross The Sprawl towards their respective gates. This stretch of small, packed together houses, street markets, taverns, and shops was always bustling with people prior to the collapse of the city. It was the most densely populated area in Drakkenheim. This unfortunately means that now it is also one of the most densely populated areas for the horrible, mutated monsters that roam the old streets and ruined buildings, filled with {@area Dregs|1f3|x}, {@area Ratlings|2f5|x} and {@creature Bojack|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Bojacks}.

entries.name: The Spokes
entries: The Spokes are the entire area outside the walls south of the Drann River. Champion's Way, leading to Champion's Gate, is the main road through The Spokes, and the only one that is paved. This large assortment of industrial buildings, warehouses, shops, mills, and taverns was where most of Drakkenheim's industry happened. Brewers, smiths, forges, lumber mills, tanners, granaries, and textile mills make up a large portion of the area closest to the walls, while many of the most established farms spanning out further south from The Spokes, connecting down to Emberwood Village five miles away. Now most of the buildings lie in ruin, shattered and broken by the initial blast of the falling star that landed right on the edge of where The Spokes meet the South Ward. The Spokes is the most ruined area in Drakkenheim—rubble blocks streets, buildings barely stand, and the place holds the Haze, dust, and debris thick in the air. The Spokes is a common place to find some of the more horribly mutated monsters such as {@creature Digipede|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Digipedes}, {@creature Kronen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Dark Growth|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Dark Growths}, and {@creature Effulgent Cnidarian|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Effulgent Cnidarians}.

entries.name: Inner City
entries: Protected within the walls, the densely packed Inner City features winding cobblestone streets and towering spires of stone. Decorated plazas and broad squares mark major landmarks, monuments, and important buildings. Major landmarks in the Inner City include the ornate Saint Virturvio's Cathedral, the Inscrutable Tower of the Amethyst Academy, the lush and verdant Queen's Park Garden, the once-bustling Market Square, the Cosmological Clocktower, and Slaughterstone Square.

entries.name: South Ward
entries: Once the most densely populated area of the Inner city, South Ward had rows of small shops, temples, and taverns along its main roads, with packed houses grouped together in small bustling communities. Now, it is nothing but smoldering, indistinguishable ruins. A wood beam, or a stone arch jutting from the ground amidst ash and rubble, is mostly what you will find as you draw closer to the great Crater Basin. From decrepit wooden skeletons of homes, to piles of shattered stone, heaped bodies, and half buried foundations, the landscape becomes increasingly sparse closer to the Crater. Finding a standing structure in the South Ward is rare, and often filled with monsters such as {@creature Kronen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@area Dregs|1f3|x}, or {@creature Last Memory|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Last Memories}. This ward is also a common place for {@creature Loathsome Gag Fly|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Gag Flies} and {@creature Hazewing Moth Adult|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Hazewing Moths}.

entries.name: Old Town
entries: Old Town stretches through the northeast of the Inner City and was the first area of Drakkenheim to be built. It is made up of well-spaced properties, each with a large manor house. Main roads are lined with stables, high end shops, and well-regarded establishments. Much of this area of the city remains intact, especially the old Kleinberg Estate resting against the cliffs that lead up to Castle Drakken. Although known as the wealthiest part of the city, in its ruin this area is now a prime haunt for malfeasant wizards to operate. Old Town is home to {@creature Belfray|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Belfrays}, {@creature Digipede|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Digipedes}, {@creature Effulgent Cnidarian|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Effulgent Cnidarians}, and has been known to be a hunting ground for {@creature Living City|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Living Cities}.

entries.name: Middle Ward
entries: The Middle Ward was a common place for inns, taverns, shops, and a few of the more prominent blacksmiths and woodcarvers. Sprawling through the west end of the city, it is the largest district in the Inner City. The Great Market Square rests on the inner border of the Middle Ward and was the most popular place for shopping in the city. The Middle Ward also housed many of the prestigious playhouses and brothels of the city. Now ruled over by the {@creature Harpy|XMM|Harpies} (see {@book Chapter 4—Predators of the Ruins|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|4}), and an abundance of undead like {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Husks}, {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Wights}, {@creature Arcane Wraith|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Wraiths}, and {@creature Warp Witch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Warp Witches}.

entries.name: Temple Ward
entries: The Temple Ward makes up the southwest portion of the Inner City around Temple Gate and Temple Road. The main attraction of the Temple Ward is Saint Virturvio's Cathedral, which towers high above the residential surroundings. Now packed with roving bands of Garmyr (see {@book Chapter 4—Predators of the Ruins|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|4}), this once bright and vibrant part of the city is littered with carnage and death. Besides the roving packs of war dogs, one can expect to find {@creature Kronen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Beetle Knight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Beetle Knights}, and {@creature Digipede|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Digipedes} roaming through the buildings or hiding in the darkened corners of abandoned homes.

entries.name: Queen's Park Garden
entries: This elegant park was built to commemorate the ruling monarchs of Westemr and their royal consorts. The garden was a social hub during the spring and summer, featuring bountiful fountains, secluded grottos, grand monuments, and lush gardens. Today, the entire area is covered by the Deep Haze (see {@area appendix C|8e1|x}). Queen's Park Garden has been transformed into a terrifying maze. Before the meteor struck, from its trellised paths, you could nearly see from one side of the park to the other, and most landmarks could be seen from the central fountain. Today, adventurers exploring the park speak of getting lost in the thickets; the once carefully curated orchards are now dangerously tangled forests.

items: {@b Lenore's Grotto}. An elegant, tiered garden with two rectangular pools marks the entrance to a wondrous grotto built for the Queen Consort to Ulrich IV.
{@b Lunar Meadows of Arwen}. This once lush green clearing was a prime spot for stargazing, or picnics dotted with small floral patches and a babbling creek.
{@b Fountain of Beauty}. The heart of Queen's Park Garden is a majestic, multi-tiered marble fountain which honors all the royal women of Westemr.
{@b Botanical Gardens of Mother Danu}. These vast gardens housed the largest assortment of flowers in all of Westemr, including unique species brought in from the Far Continent.
{@b Queen Eleanor's Lavender Fields}. A winding cobblestone path navigated through these beautiful purple flowers with small benches and statues dotting the walkway.

{@b Old Willow Falls}. Near the north end of the gardens is a natural three-tiered waterfall that flows into the winding river that snakes through the gardens, next to it is the oldest tree in Drakkenheim, a massive weeping willow.

{@b Weeping Angels of Gunhilda}. Not far from the willow is a clearing holding multiple statues of weeping angels gifted from Caspia to Queen Gunhilda years ago. Mists from the waterfall hang low around the moss-caked statues giving the clearing a fantastical ancient atmosphere.

{@b Dream-pools of Phantasia}. Several small bridges and walkways weave between ornate pools and fountains, the sound of flowing water filling the space. In the center, a statue of Phantasia watches over the pools, smiling.
{@b Statue of Nuada Vitrix}. This glorious statue depicts the Old God Nuada as a winged valkyrie striking down the enemies of Drakkenheim.
{@b Hildegarde's Arch}. This impressive victory arch on four columns commemorates Queen Hildegarde von Drakken I's signing of the Edicts of Lumen.

{@b Helena's Column}. Dedicated to House von Kessel's first monarch, Helena I, who used the Crown of Westemr's power to cure a plague ravaging the nation. Her deeds are etched upon the column, and a bust of her likeness rests on top.

{@b Carmen's Dragons}. This topiary garden depicts the famous draconic mounts of Carmen von Drakken, the first Queen of Westemr. Oddly, despite the garden's overgrown state, these masterpieces remain well-trimmed and pristine.
{@b Theresa's Grove}. A small clearing featuring several standing rocks and simple benches, all overtaken by creeping vines.
{@b Lily Ponds of Queen Beatrice}. The lily ponds once housed many different frogs and fish, as well as an old tower that one could climb to see most of Drakkenheim and overlook the gardens.

{@b Groundskeeper's House}. The gnomish head groundskeeper, Wilber Greenroot Pebblepond, and his many gnome gardeners kept their tools here, conducted garden business, and also rested here on night shifts.

{@b Corridor of Queens}. The main cobblestone road leading from the south entrance of the gardens up to the central fountain is flanked by large ten-foot-tall statues of every queen that ruled Drakkenheim.

entries.name: Crater Basin
entries: The meteor that annihilated Drakkenheim landed in the South Ward, shattering part of the wall dividing the Inner and Outer City. Little remains of the original buildings save wreckage and the gaping crater. Swirling mists fill the Crater while an eldritch storm rages overhead. It is perhaps the most dangerous and contaminated region in Drakkenheim. No expedition into its depths has ever returned to tell the tale—except for {@creature Lucretia Mathias|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, leader of the Followers of the Falling Fire. Today, the Chapel of Saint Gresha by the Crater's Edge is a destination for the faction's pilgrims seeking to partake in their most sacred rituals.

Exceptionally dangerous creatures dwell here, including {@creature Anomollusk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Anomollusks}, {@creature Crater Wurm|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Crater Wurms}, {@area Contaminated Elementals|0eb|x}, {@creature Eldritch Cataclysm|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Cataclysms}, and {@creature Arcane Wraith|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Wraiths}.

Pulsing at the Crater's center is the throbbing Delerium Heart, a massive formation of the magical crystals which was the core of the meteor itself. If it were ever destroyed, the resulting disasters would unleash the terrifying {@creature The World Ender|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|World Ender}.

entries.name: Mimic Mayhem
entries: The player characters are searching for a relic or heirloom lost in an old family estate. Unfortunately, the entire manor house has transformed into a {@creature Living City|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}!

entries.name: The Old Library
entries: An old library has been infested with contaminated undead horrors, but some of the books might be of value to one of the many factions. An old mage now resides in the library as an {@creature Arcane Wraith|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and the staff are all {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Husks}, {@creature Warp Witch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Warp Witches}, and {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Wights}.

entries.name: The Ruined Tower
entries: An old, dilapidated tower could make an excellent vantage point if it could be cleared out. Be wary of the {@creature Skretch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Skretches} and {@creature Belfray|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Belfrays} occupying it though.

entries.name: Crossing the Drann
entries: The Drann river has no means of crossing it on the north-east side of the city save for a raft and a rope to pull you across. Apparently, several {@creature Lob Frog|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lob Frogs} and sightings of a massive gator have made traversing that way even harder, so naturally, someone needs to check it out.

entries.name: Hunt for the Chimera
entries: Horror stories are spreading of the {@creature Cacophonous Chimera|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} killing large groups of faction agents heading into the city. The creature has been spotted all over the city, but none have been able to fell the dreadful beast.

data.name: Chapter 2: Delerium Dregs
entries: {@b The Lost Ones}

One minute you're getting a foot rub from your royal masseuse Peter and suddenly, because you asked him to grab something sharp to carve off the dead skin, he's transformed into a blobby monster. These poor souls used to be so important to my daily routine. My sword fetcher, my helmet fetcher, my servant fetcher, heck, even my flower arranger all turned into wretched twisted creatures. Good help is hard to find but when they become an amorphous killing machine bent on consuming your flesh it's time to find some new hires.

When a human is exposed to enough eldritch contamination to cause a monstrous transformation, the ensuing cascade of mutations most commonly results in a horrific mockery of their former selves. Countless inhabitants of Drakkenheim have suffered this horrible fate, transformed after the meteor fell. Others are fallen soldiers, lost adventurers, or faction agents who never escaped the ruins. Survivors and explorers often refer to these creatures as "wretches," "unfortunates," "the lost ones," but they are most commonly known as Delerium Dregs.

These monsters are hideously transfigured in both body and mind. They are trapped in a terrifying landscape filled with delusions and torment, left with only fragmented memories, unable to comprehend what has happened to them. Delerium Dregs have been driven mad by their transformations.

Occasionally, a Delerium Dreg may still be recognizable to their friends and loved ones, but are so stricken with madness that little remains of their former personalities. Others have changed so much they bear no resemblance to their former selves, though most retain some humanoid features and body proportions. No matter how they ended up in this horrific form, they are doomed to wander the ruins, disorientation occasionally wavering into anguish, distress, or violent outbursts.

entries.name: Multitudinous Mutations
entries: No two Delerium Dregs are exactly alike, as all are transformed in chaotic and unpredictable ways. Their bodies sprout all manner of twisted limbs, spines, and bones. Their organs, muscles, and flesh are resculpted, their faces twisted painfully into terrifying visages. Nevertheless, there are several recognizable and relatively common variations which all express a differing degree of danger to those exploring Drakkenheim.

Those who have studied eldritch contamination and mutations have theorized that certain factors may influence the types of mutations a contaminated individual may manifest. Perhaps the subject's physical or biological traits are the determining factor, especially in those who may already possess magical talents or who have been touched by arcane forces in some way. It may also be that the environment and conditions under which an individual gains {@area Contamination|8c6|x} affect the forms they develop, as {@creature Bloated Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Bloated Dregs} appear more commonly near flooded regions, and {@creature Lambent Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Lambent Dregs} are more common near the crater. It is also entirely possible it is all simply chaotic magic, and any patterns are mere coincidence.

Indeed, a {@creature Delerium Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} continues to mutate with continued exposure to eldritch contamination. Over time, the typical Delerium Dreg described here may change into one of the other forms. However, these continued mutations may eventually cause their form to destabilize, transforming them into a {@creature Protean Abomination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} or {@creature Pyknic Maunder|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Warped Minds
entries: While their new form may hold some uncanny resemblance to their original appearance, most often, a Delerium Dreg's mutations are so drastic and their behavior so radically altered that little trace is left of their former identity. Most Dregs wander Drakkenheim unfettered from reality and are easily provoked to violence.

Experienced soldiers amongst the Hooded Lanterns have observed how Dregs passively follow one another. As they aimlessly roam the ruined streets, more stragglers and lone dregs join a group, which eventually gathers into a large crowd. While occasionally infighting or hostility breaks out within the throng, left unchecked in the city, Delerium Dregs slowly start to form massive mobs that clog the city streets.

{@creature Hooded Lantern Scout|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Hooded Lantern Scouts} have adamantly patrolled the western parts of the city near their barracks, slaying any small group of Dregs on sight. If they can keep their numbers down, it is less likely that uncontrollable swarms of them will gather. Dreg cleanup is one of the most harrowing duties for the Lanterns. More often than not, the Dregs in western Drakkenheim are fallen Lanterns, friends, or even family.

Adventurers incorrectly believe Delerium Dregs are cannibalistic, driven to feed on flesh. All evidence suggests Delerium Dregs are physically sustained by the magic of the Haze. They do not need to eat or drink, and do not sleep. They do, however, need to breathe. Consequently, they do not consume the bodies of their victims; rather, they attack out of madness-induced aggression. As such, a Delerium Dreg won't be lured into a trap by meat and usually can't be bargained with using food.

entries.name: Haze Hulks
entries: Occasionaly, these transformations include tremendous growth. Although studies of this are scarce, it seems that a common change is an instant increase in both muscle mass and ferocity. These violent monstrosities are known as {@creature Haze Hulk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Hulks}, huge cousins to the twisted Delerium Dregs.

The delerium affects the flesh of the creature, immediately toughening a creature and increasing its inherent strength, while diminishing parts of the brain that process emotions such as anger or frustration, and completely neutralizing the concepts of fear and greatly diminishing pain. The effects of this are a massive hulking beast that shrugs off attacks, is violently territorial, and shows no fear in the face of danger.

entries.name: Advanced Mutations
entries: Some creatures grow beyond the confines of standard mutations, where a rare few no longer fit into the obvious categories of Delerium Dregs or Haze Hulks. These creatures possess traits that separate them from the mutated hordes of the ruins, often because of their ability to maintain control of their sentience and sense of self in a way most others cannot.

The danger occurs when these creatures believe they are still human despite terrible transformations. These advanced mutants are often twisted by misguided goals, such as gaining control over their mutations. Others are just unfortunates who cling to the shreds of self remaining in their slowly fragmenting minds. These may be the most dangerous of all. They still possess a cunning intellect while slipping into a madness they cannot fathom.

Although rare, encountering these forms of advanced mutations is always dangerous—they have been known to control Dregs, or unite the mutated monsters to fight on their behalf. Two of these advanced mutants are described in this chapter: the malfeasant wizard known as the {@creature Pale Man|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and the former Queen of Drakkenheim, {@creature Lenore von Kessel|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: These traits can be used in tandem with those described in the {@area Horrors of Drakkenheim|0a3|x} chapter. In particular, consider items from the {@area Aberrant Physiology|02f|x} section to add additional variation to individual Delerium Dregs.

entries.name: Shattered Psyches
entries: Rookie adventurers often liken {@creature Delerium Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium Dregs} to the mindless undead such as zombies. While the comparison is apt in some respects, Delerium Dregs are not brainless creatures or reanimated thralls. Rather, these mutated humans retain a broken consciousness drifting in and out of a lucid state. These horrible shreds of sentience can be difficult to witness, as the once human creatures mumble phrases of their last moments. Some cry for help, others beg for safety, while others call to loved ones and old companions. There are a few reports of Delerium Dregs have apparently coherent conversations for a few minutes before returning to their incoherent mumbles and ravenous cries.

Over the years, many have attempted to communicate with Delerium Dregs in search of their former humanity. Occasionally, Delerium Dregs respond to such appeals, but the effect is short-lived. The madness gripping their minds is all-consuming and isn't readily treated with words or even powerful magic. More than once have well-intentioned individuals sought out a transformed friend or loved one and tried to coax them back into a cogent state, grasping at whatever shreds of humanity remain. Unfortunately, these attempts ultimately fail; at best gleaning a fleeting moment of recognition before the terrifying realization of their wretched state becomes apparent. Often, such efforts only succeed in triggering frenzied outbursts, but there is no doubt that a handful of Dregs are kept captive in the hopes that one day their condition may somehow be healed or reversed.

entries.name: Lasting Memories
entries: Dregs may not be coherent, or even human anymore, but a small sliver of their former selves remains. Many have strange quirks that reveal their former selves, often displayed while tearing their victims apart.

items: In a deep, bellowing tone, the Dreg exclaims "Meat."
It begs for release, "Help me! I need to get out of this city!"
"Please, please, help! I'm sick... are you a doctor? Bring me to the Flamekeeper!"
It recites a list of its former comrades-in-arms: "Jenkins. Watson. Lang. Wagner. Livingston. Hayes."
"Miserable weather. Just dreadful. Awful. Won't stop raining. When will we see the sun?"
It cries out for its parents or family "Where is my daddy? I want my daddy!"
It hums or whistles fragments of songs from time to time.
It won't stop giggling horrifically. Between laughs, it says "Who wants tickles?!?"
It keeps speaking about a plan it had, such as an event, or party it was meant to attend. "I'm going to be late for the masquerade ball! I have my finest suit pressed and ready."
It seems confused and lost and keeps requesting directions to a specific location. "Do I turn left at Copper Street? Where's the wainwright's shop? Around the corner?"
It screams accusations at the top of its lungs constantly "Thief! You dirty thief!"
The Dreg recites a children's nursery rhyme or poem with an eerie, echoing cadence: "Ashes, ashes, we all fall down..."
"I'm late... I'm late... oh bother... I should have left sooner... the Queen will have my head for sure."
The Dreg gestures or points at itself, crying out "Guilty! Guilty! Guilty!"
It regards you as a long-lost family member. "Are you my mommy?"
"Where did I leave my glasses? I thought they were right here... there was time now..."
It apologizes constantly and profusely. "I'm sorry, I am so sorry!"
This Dreg used to be an old construction worker who keeps mumbling "Tear down the wall, tear down the wall..."
The Dreg chases you yelling in a cackling screech "I'll swallow your soul!"
"We had porridge yesterday! I don't want porridge again. We had it yesterday!"
The Dreg holds a large wooden spoon and keeps repeating in a defeated voice "My spoon is too big."
As you cut into the Dreg with your weapon, it says in a satisfied voice, "I like it when the red water comes out."
The Dreg follows you slowly, in a monotone voice repeating "Come play with me."
The Dreg seems fearful of its surroundings and keeps looking at the rooftops with darting eyes muttering "Can't stop here, this is rat country."

entries.name: The Streets of Drakkenheim
entries: Dregs do not build lairs or burrows like many of the other creatures that occupy Drakkenheim. They do not have a specific preference to the types of environments they inhabit. Once a creature succumbs to {@area Contamination|8c6|x} and is lost, they stay within the Haze and tend to gravitate to areas of contaminated magic, such as delerium clusters and Thin Places. However, they can be found almost anywhere throughout the city. These Dregs wander in groups throughout Drakkenheim, attacking anything not touched by Contamination.

entries.name: Dark Corners and Old Ruins
entries: Many Dregs tend to stick to shadowy areas, such as old ruins or abandoned buildings. They wander through the dimly lit streets often enough, but any venture into an old building is likely to find a conglomerate of various Dregs.

entries.name: Gathering at the Source
entries: Dregs will gather around clusters of delerium. It is unclear why they are instinctually pulled to delerium. Perhaps because Dregs were initially created by the {@area Contamination|8c6|x} produced by delerium, they constantly seek more as a means of fulfilling some sort of advanced transformation. Regardless of why, large groups of Dregs have been known to gather around clusters and remain in the area.

entries.name: Predatory Instincts
entries: Few Delerium Dregs possess the clarity of mind to execute any strategy or tactic beyond pure direct aggression. However, a few are patient predators who are more cunning in their approaches. Some of the smarter, or larger, Dregs will stalk their prey and know to stick to the shadows, hiding behind rubble. In very rare instances, Dregs may plan an ambush.

entries.name: Herding Creatures
entries: It is rare for a Dreg to be found alone, unless it has recently transformed. Dregs who find one another tend to band together and form wandering groups. Often the largest or smartest of the Dregs will lead the group, while others follow aimlessly. In the instances where Dregs surprise and ambush an adventuring group, it is often a smaller group of smarter Dregs.
The rank and file soldiers in the now twisted city huddle together to attack those who haven't changed yet. Don't become one, use your sword.

entries.name: The Hog Town Butcher
entries: A butcher on the outskirts of Drakkenheim is feeding his livestock with delerium infused meat and selling cuts of the contaminated beasts at the market. His farm is now a twisted menagerie of mutated horrors; his family are unrecognizable masses of mutated flesh.

entries.name: Hulk Smash
entries: A small group of {@creature Haze Hulk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Hulks} have been on a rampage and need to be brought down. They are picking off Followers of the Falling Fire who try to venture into the city. If they are not stopped, they will cause major problems for the Followers.

entries.name: Night's Watch
entries: {@creature Hooded Lantern Scout|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Hooded Lantern Scouts} have barricaded the barracks and are trying to last the night. A horde of Dregs is approaching and will smash against their fortifications through the night. Any aid could turn the tides of battle for the Lanterns.

entries.name: Folktales of the Pale Man
entries: Those who go seeking the {@creature Pale Man|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} in Drakkenheim only do so with good reason. Stories have spread of a strange man who snatches up those dying of contamination in the city, never to be seen again. Children sing little rhymes about him as a chilling legend of Drakkenheim's very own version of the boogeyman.
{@i The noble man, in his noble home.}
{@i Withered, old, and all alone.}
{@i His stare can chill you to the bone.}
{@i A Pale Man, on a pale throne}.
{@i For who goes wandering here or there,}
{@i they best watch out, they best beware}.
{@i It's better then, to stay at home.}
{@i The Pale Man, on his pale throne}.
{@i If you fall ill he comes for you}
{@i And takes you to his mansion to}
{@i Make you into something new}
{@i The Pale Man is watching you}

Variations on the rhyme crop up from time to time. Though made by parents in Emberwood Village to keep their children from daring to wander near the ruins, the simple rhyme has struck fear into the hearts of adventurers and scouts alike.

The Pale Man has a compound within the Kleinberg Estates, a wealthy arrangement of large manor houses in the northern parts of Old Town, deep in the Haze, in the shadow of Castle Drakken. There, he houses all manner of Dregs. They serve and follow him, believing him to be their savior, and caring little for the constant experiments he performs on them. The Dregs the Pale Man houses do not attack visitors on site, however. The Pale Man welcomes those brave enough to seek him out, and will even offer aid to those who are sick. But he is always looking for the moment to turn a situation into an opportunity to acquire new test subjects for his brutal transformations and horrible experiments with eldritch contamination.

data.name: Chapter 3: Ratlings
entries: {@b Verminous Multitudes}

Dirty plague-bearing vermin that feed on even the leftovers of the scavengers. Surprisingly resilient! Quite the little tunnelers too. I think it's a numbers game with them, making rabbits look monogamous. It must be the delerium that drives them mad. I have seen them grow, talk and even build. As pets they are quite loyal but they quickly outgrow the care you can provide and you end up throwing them in a sewer with the rest of their lot. They swarm and bite with razor sharp teeth. The little ones can squeeze through the plates of your armor and find the tender spots. Nasty little rodents with big appetites. I've watched lesser men become simply an appetizer. Not me, Pluto Jackson is like a banquet! All you can eat and I never close! These delerium rats are something to behold as they rival the intellect of even our sharpest Caspian minds. They study the wizard books and write as they chatter their teeth but it is all for nothing as their furry little bodies fall upon the swords of my Caspian brothers in arms for they are simple pests that must be exterminated. That being said, no harm will come from tucking your pants in your boots.

Drakkenheim was notorious for its rat infestation. The back alleys and basements of the Sprawl teemed with rats, and countless more prowled the sewers. As a result, many households kept cats, and the city even commissioned a Rat Trapper's Guild to help control the rat population to little avail. When the city fell to ruin, the problem grew much, much worse. Delerium mutated the rats into ratlings, hideous monsters imbued with a malevolent cunning, and driven by a mad compulsion to consume and multiply.

Ratlings grow to the size of a gnome or halfling, with big eyes and ears, and large, pointed noses. They are slender creatures, covered with matted, coarse fur, and with thick hairless tails longer than their bodies. Today, thousands of ratlings dwell in Drakkenheim, lurking in underground burrows and subterranean tunnels. An individual ratling is far from the most fearsome threat in Drakkenheim, but these verminous multitudes present a creeping, gnawing danger that could one day grow beyond any other.

entries.name: Mutated Vermin
entries: Ratlings begin their lives as ordinary rats. Born in the contaminated sewers and subterranean tunnels of Drakkenheim, their pups feed on carrion tainted with eldritch contamination. The continual ingestion of delerium accelerates their development and mutation, allowing a ratling pup to reach maturity in just a few weeks. A ratling can live for five to seven years, although many die from infighting or accidents within their first year or two.

Granted a warped intellect by delerium, ratlings suffer from a constant internal struggle between their cowardly survival instincts and violent and impulsive urges. Ratlings dream of eating everything, and will eat anything, but especially love eating people. They have acquired an appetite for humans that are easy to capture, kill, and devour such as children and the elderly, and especially babies. While they can subsist on carrion, ratlings prefer fresh meat, and will take captives back to their lairs.

Despite their innate madness and violent predilections, ratlings are industrious and will fashion makeshift gear from scavenged equipment, favoring long knives, rusty spears, slings, and crossbows. They rarely wear armor, although they have been known to strap scrap metal pauldrons or an occasional breastplate onto their matted fur. Ratlings sometimes carry makeshift shields that once were shutters, tabletops, or parts of a door to defend themselves. Crafty and resourceful, a rare few ratlings have even learned to master the contaminated magic that created them, becoming powerful spellcasters.

entries.name: Cunning Cowards
entries: Ratlings display inherent naivety towards basic human concepts, especially kindness, empathy, and bravery. Many adventurers have made a grave mistake thinking ratlings are simple-minded fools. While ratlings care little for the lives of others, they value their own hide above all and will do just about anything to survive. Most are cowards who will flee at the first sign of a losing battle, willing to throw their best friend in the way of a hungry gator, a swarm of harpies, or a battle-ready group of adventurers if it ensures their own escape. When cornered or trapped, ratlings often break down in tears to beg for their lives, and offer delerium, information, or help infiltrating or sneaking through the city in exchange for their life. Those who have survived the longest usually become cunning warriors and clan leaders, and tend to develop skills in manipulation, lying, and bargaining.

Occasionally, adventurers exploring Drakkenheim make deals with ratlings they capture to act as guides into more treacherous parts of the city. Almost every time, the ratling eventually attempts a horrible betrayal. Ratlings are always waiting for the moment they can turn the situation in their favor, and lead their enemies into an ambush, or deliver them to the lair of a much more horrible monster.

entries.name: Teeming Mass
entries: Ratlings form colonies consisting of several closely related families. They work together to dig maze-like burrows that incorporate multiple entrances and tight looping passages. The biggest ratling usually leads the pack, though in some cases the smartest and most cunning can find themselves as leaders as well. Individual ratlings easily recognize others from their colony by scent, a trait which often foils adventurers trying to use disguises or trickery to infiltrate ratling burrows.

However, ratling colonies are quite hostile to each other, fighting over food and territory. Indeed, ratlings spend more time fighting each other than any other creatures or factions in the ruins, which is probably why they haven't taken over Drakkenheim yet. Successful colonies grow in number rapidly, as ratlings mature in a matter of weeks when ample food and delerium are available. The largest and most powerful ratling colonies bully others into submission and rule over them. Fortunately, intense competition with other ratling colonies over a limited food supply, predation from other monsters, and constant clashes with explorers and the Hooded Lanterns keeps their population in check. Lacking these constraints, their numbers would quickly swell beyond all hope of containment.

entries.name: The Shiny
entries: Ratlings call delerium "the shiny" and value the crystals highly. It acts as both a food source and a means to induce quick and aggressive mutations. Ratlings scratch out their burrows around delerium deposits and bring a steady flow of delerium into their burrows. It's the ratlings' obsession with delerium that generally causes them to forgo their inherent cowardice in exchange for wild aggression. Researchers or even a group of adventurers harvesting or carrying delerium are a prime pick for an ambush. Ratlings will kill just about anything to get their hands on more delerium and continue expanding their colonies.

entries.name: The Rat God
entries: Many ratlings worship a fiendish entity they call the {@creature Rat God|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Ratlings construct crude effigies to the Rat God, who whispers to the most cunning and intelligent ratlings, granting them magic through eldritch pacts. This nightmarish and malevolent demon encourages the ratlings to multiply, collect delerium, and consume everything. Ratlings believe that the Rat God grows in power and size as they themselves feed and breed, and that one day the ravenous entity will emerge in the Mortal World to eat everything in an apocalyptic feast known as the Great Gnaw. The ratlings seem indifferent or oblivious to the implication they too will be devoured by their hungry god.

The Rat God is one of many powerful fiends inhabiting the cosmos that claims to be divine. Scholars of religion and the arcane postulate this being is likely not a true god and is more likely a rising demon lord. This technicality is utterly irrelevant to the Rat God's ratling worshippers. Although the Rat God cannot grant divine spells to its followers, they can create eldritch pacts, imbue ratlings with sorcerous powers, and inspire faith in a rare few truly devoted priests.

Beyond these details, Ratlings understand surprisingly little about the Rat God, and make up stories and fables about the ravenous god's exploits (see the {@area "Beliefs About the Rat God"|2ff|x}). Even warlocks and oracles devoted to the strange being speak more lies than truths about its depiction, deeds, and desires. The full game statistics for the Rat God are described in {@area Appendix A: Ancient Entities.|845|x}

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The ratlings' goals seem simplistic to most: first there is the Great Feeding and then the Great Breeding until ratling numbers swell into an insurmountable army. Thousands upon thousands of vermin will pour from the sewers, ruins, burrows, and tunnels and into the streets and houses and, with the aid of the great Rat God, they will devour the world.

entries.name: Murderous Monsters
entries: As creatures born of otherworldly contamination, the ratlings are, above all else, gleeful and remorseless killers. They care little for their own wellbeing and the feelings and needs of others. The only thing a ratling cares about is their own goals, and how they can most easily obtain them. Although they will listen to reason, they only agree to cooperate with non-ratlings if they see an opportunity for themselves. Otherwise, they would rather simply murder every humanoid they see.

entries.name: Manipulative and Cunning
entries: Ratlings may not be the smartest creatures, but they know that other creatures are also driven by their goals and needs. When cornered and with little options left, they plead to the needs of their captors and promise anything, if it means their own survival. Oftentimes they are lying, but they will see their promises through until they can devise a better plan to backstab and murder their foes. Some ratlings have gone as far as being hired as guides and scouts to help adventurers enter Drakkenheim. They lead those parties safely through the maze of ruined streets, only to spring a ratling ambush, or bring them to the den of a more horrible monster and turn on them the moment the numbers are favorable.

entries.name: Murderous Tendencies
entries: Most ratlings are driven towards violence, though their motivation for doing so can vary from one to the next.

items: I cannot help but stab humans. If I see a human, I must stab it. Stabby stab-stab!
I love finger foods! Every creature I kill, I collect their fingers for snacks!
The more ears you keep on your person, the better you can hear, it's why I keep so many ears from my kills, no one can sneak up on me!
I love guts! Spilling guts, eating guts, wearing guts. Cut their bellies, then do the guts dance! Guts, guts, guts.
Always attack their face! I wear the faces of my enemies as a fun hat.
If you bite it, it's yours, so I always start by biting any victim or prisoner to make sure it has my mark.
No, you need to eat them before you kill them! It's best raw and wriggling!
I learned this fun trick: if you show them their own organs while they are still alive, they HATE that!
Why would you ever clean your weapons? The old rotting blood adds extra flavor.
Sometimes I put on the skin of a human and chase the young ratlings around the burrow yelling "Look at me, I am a HUMAN!" and they all scream and laugh.

entries.name: Beliefs About the Rat God
entries: Ratlings make up fantastic stories about the Rat God's wrath and cunning. In truth, they know little about the Rat God except it likes the shiny, and they perform cannibalistic rituals in its name. Ratlings love eating, so they love these rituals.

items: The Rat God wants us to eat everything we can. One day, Rat God will eat the world. It is going to be amazing!
The moon is made of cheese! It will be a special snack for the Rat God when they come to eat the world.
The Rat God sometimes gives the very bestest ratlings magic powers to help them get food and get shiny.
Every shadow is a spy for the Rat God. So, if you have something you need to tell them, whisper it to your shadow.
Every shake and shudder of the earth is the Rat God digging, digging, digging deep below!
One day, in the Great Gnaw, we are going to burrow all the way to Castle Drakken and eat everything inside!
Don't displease the Rat God. They will turn you into a ghost that can't eat, and you'll watch us grow fat and happy.
The Rat God stole the shiny from a big mean cat with too many tails and sent the shiny here to make the ratlings strong and smart so we can kill all the cats!
