The shiny are the bones of the Rat God. Once we eat all the shiny, the biggest ratling will turn into the Rat God.
The Rat God loves dancing and fire, but hates math and iambic pentameter.

entries.name: Irrational Fears
entries: Many ratlings are driven by irrational fears, causing them to act in unusual ways.

items: Refuses any affection and especially hugs, since they think it's just a ruse to stab them in the back.
Afraid of bugs, especially big ones.
Avoids brightly colored flowers, believing such plants are poisonous traps set by evil spirits to lure and capture them.
Terrified of their own reflections, convinced that their mirrored self is a malevolent doppelganger sent to usurp their life.
Dreads the sight of a single crow, interpreting it as an omen that the Rat God has marked them for death, causing hysteria and chaos whenever a crow is spotted.
Abhors cats in all their forms, which prompts a screaming fit of panic as they flee to wherever they can hide.
Loathes being unclean and is obsessively afraid of filth, making them awkwardly tidy amongst their fellow ratlings.
The ratling has a deep fear of a mutated pickle that hunts ratlings in the sewers. The other ratlings tell them the so-called "Pickle Man" doesn't exist.
Believes that ghosts that travel in threes are a sign of doom!
Absolutely hates chairs, especially ones with cushioned seats, and breaks them on sight.

entries.name: Ratling Trinkets (What's in Their Pockets)
entries: It's rare to find a ratling without something unusual kept among their personal effects.

items: ({@dice 4d6}) human fingers.
({@dice 2d4}) human eyes.
A chunk of rock that sparkles.
A crude wooden effigy of a rat.
({@dice 6d6}) teeth from various creatures. Some look human.
A claw-made scented candle; it smells like blue cheese when lit.
A horde of buttons, with the ratling's name etched on them.
A collection of jangling house-keys.
A large sock, bits of cloth have been crudely stuck to it to resemble a face, and the name "Socko" is written lovingly inside.
A well-loved children's blanket and a carving of a toy piano.
A chef's hat. Inside is a collection of various types of dried pasta.
A ball of hair and blood.
Four dolls made of small turtle shells holding wooden weapons: a longsword, a quarterstaff, two short swords, and a club.
A book about philosophy and history, many of the pages have bite marks, others have crude drawings over the words.
A crude drawing of a yellow ratling with rosy cheeks shooting lightning out of its hands and killing humans.
A small carved statuette of a wooden toy soldier, and a rat dressed up in royal garb wearing a crown and brandishing a sword as well as a handful of nuts.
A roughly carved flute. When played, {@dice 2d6} {@creature Giant Rat|XMM|Giant Rats} emerge from nearby holes to follow whoever played the flute.
A doll of a haggard looking rat wearing a small jacket, the name "Rizzo" scrawled on its bottom.
A black cap with large, black, exaggerated mouse ears on it.
A worn, leather-bound tome titled {@i The Dungeons of Drakkenheim}, penned by Martyn Mac Lochlann I.

entries.name: Ratling Names
entries: When it comes to names, Ratlings tend to be very simple and disorganized in their naming conventions. Ratlings will sometimes name other ratlings at a young age, other times they completely forget to name the young and a ratling will name themselves once they can speak. Ratlings have been known to change their names from time to time based on the deeds they have accomplished, or their most notable achievement.

Ratling names are usually inspired by the sounds they make, the things they do, or a notable deformity or oddity they have. For example, the {@creature Rat Prince|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} simply gained that name by declaring himself as such after leading a horde of ratlings into the Rat's Nest Tavern and eating the Dregs swarming the streets in that part of the city. In the process, he found some jagged metal that resembled a crown, conquered the Rat's Nest Tavern, and declared himself the Rat Prince. entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Ratlings form vast labyrinths of intricate tunnels beneath Drakkenheim. Beginning from empty cellars, maintenance tunnels, and sewer canals, ratlings then dig their own passages and chambers. A ratling burrow is a looping maze filled with overlapping routes, dead-ends, traps, and dozens, if not hundreds, of hungry defenders.

Unbeknownst to surface-dwellers, ratlings occasionally dig tunnels extending out from the city limits, allowing them to slip away from the ruins to plunder the few remaining farmsteads nearby, and even threaten Emberwood Village. Perhaps one day, other cities in Westemr, or throughout the world, will hear a gnawing beneath their feet.

entries.name: Burrows and Dens
entries: A ratling lair is often composed of networks of winding tunnels, small hollowed out rooms, and multiple passages between them. Oftentimes these dens and burrows can be labyrinthian and cramped to outsiders, but to the ratlings they offer multiple positions to attack from, or to flee.

entries.name: Strength in Numbers
entries: Ratlings know that their strength is in numbers, and often design their burrows for quick access for fighting or fleeing. When they can, they will group together to fight as a large force. Attempting to use the winding and multiple passages to surround and overwhelm enemies.

entries.name: Traps and Tunnels
entries: Ratlings are notorious trap builders. Traversing their lairs is often more of a threat than actually facing the ratlings. Ratlings protect their lairs by building spiked pit traps, rolling barrels, and dug out holes in the walls and ceilings to fire from if they are infiltrated, as well as devising multiple other ways to thwart their enemies. They use poisons and fire to try and trap enemies inside areas of their burrows and burn or gas them to death. They lead intruders into trapped rooms or narrow corridors before dropping wooden gates down and lighting the hallway ablaze. Ratlings generally don't care about the damage their own traps do to their lairs, since they are happy to dig themselves out once the battle is over.

entries.name: Sample Traps
entries: Some common ratling traps are listed below.

entries.name: Spiked Pit
entries: A creature who enters the space of a spiked pit must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or fall in the pit, taking 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Piercing damage, and 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Bludgeoning damage. Climbing out of the pit requires an action and a successful {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Collapsing Tunnel
entries: All creatures in the area of the collapsing tunnel must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Bludgeoning damage and become {@condition Prone|XPHB}. In addition, creatures that fail their saving throw by 5 or more become partially buried, gaining the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until they escape. A creature can use their action to make a {@dc 10} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check to escape the rubble. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw may choose which side of the collapse it wishes to be on.

entries.name: Spike-bomb
entries: All creatures in a 15-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} from the trap that are not behind {@table Cover|XPHB|Total Cover} must make a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@dice 4d4}) Piercing damage.

entries.name: Poison Spray
entries: All creatures within a 15-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone} from the trap must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} (save ends).

entries.name: Cage Trap
entries: All creatures within 5 feet of the cage trap must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or become {@area Immobilized|8f2|x}. A creature can break out of the cage by spending an action and making a successful {@dc 18} Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check.

entries.name: Roller-crusher
entries: Any creature in the path of the roller-crusher must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or take 13 ({@dice 3d8}) Bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB}.

entries.name: Pot of Acid
entries: Any creature within 10 feet of the pot of acid must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@dice 3d4}) Acid damage and become {@area Burning|8e8|x} ({@dice 3d4} Acid).

entries.name: Flame Bottles
entries: The ratling using the flame bottle must make a ranged attack against a target within 30 feet. On a hit, the target takes 9 ({@dice 2d8}) Fire damage and is {@area Burning|8e8|x} ({@dice 2d8}). Hit or miss, the bottle shatters. The target and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Fire damage.

entries.name: Ratling Burrow
entries: Groups of related ratlings live together in burrows. They often dig out the burrows to form networks of interweaving tunnels, trap filled hallways, and several small rooms that they use for storage, sleeping, or gathering. Below are several common rooms you would find in a ratling burrow.

entries.name: Altar to the Rat God
entries: A Rat God's altar often includes a crude effigy of varying depictions. Where one depicts a massive, bloated rat, another shows a demon-like figure with wings and horns, and others might present an almost angelic form. Regardless, these effigies are crudely made, involving horrifyingly graphic depictions of the Rat God devouring humans, or other murderous acts.

Ratlings leave offerings in the form of well-gnawed bones, bits of old food, delerium chunks, unusual looking rocks, and other trash few would find valuable. On rare occasions there may be {@dice 1d4} copper, or a common gemstone worth 1 silver.

entries.name: Ratling Hovels
entries: These small chambers are where the ratlings sleep. Hovels are burrowed out as a network of small adjoining rooms, each lined with garbage, rags, hay, grass, and mud. Anything a ratling can find to make the hovel more comfortable for them to sleep in.

entries.name: Food Storage
entries: Ratlings enjoy fresh meat, so they occasionally take prisoners back to their burrows to consume later. To the ratlings, this storage space holds an assortment of fresh and old meat that needs to be regularly rotated out. To non-ratlings, it is a prison cage where they wait among the dead and half-dead to be eaten. They can clearly see their fate before them. Hung up on hooks are dead creatures, loose limbs, and half-eaten people struggling to survive.

entries.name: Delerium Storage
entries: Ratlings will keep {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|shards} and {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|crystals} of delerium, or even build their burrows around underground delerium veins; these become valuable parts of any ratling home and a place for the ratlings to gather in worship, or for planning. Sometimes {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} will lightly illuminate the ratling burrows like tiny octarine lanterns.

entries.name: The City of Drakkenheim
entries: Ratlings first mutated in the contaminated ruins of Drakkenheim—here the impact of their unchecked growth has had the most impact. They clog the sewers and streets of the city and every venture into the ruins is bound to put adventurers up against a swarm of ratlings. As their numbers swell, the prospect of the growing ratling horde grows more and more daunting.

entries.name: The Sewers of Drannsmund
entries: The city of Drannsmund has had several reports of large rats seen lurking near sewer entrances, and stories of monsters snatching children. People who stay out too late sometimes go missing when taking the back roads or quiet streets. Faction agents fear that the ratlings of Drakkenheim have made their way along the roads and into the sewer systems of other major cities as well.

entries.name: Every Advantage
entries: Ratlings will use everything they can to gain the upper hand in battle, and never fight fairly if they can avoid it. If the environment can be used against their foes, or if they can lure their foes into a trap, they will. They will light things on fire, throw debris, cover the ground in oil, toss poison vials, and roll flaming barrels down ramps. Ratlings will surely take any opportunity to turn the tide in their favor.

entries.name: Cowardly
entries: Ratlings will not fight if they are outnumbered, or if a few of them go down in combat. Instead, as soon as the battle seems to turn against them, they fall back and regroup with more ratlings, trying to overwhelm and outnumber their foes with replenished numbers. If they do not stand to win the battle, the ratlings either plead for their lives and surrender, waiting for the right moment to backstab their foe, or flee. If the battle is lost, they will scurry off into the darkness and return to their burrow at a later time to rebuild.

entries.name: Vermintropolis
entries: The Ratlings have occupied an entire city block within the city of Drakkenheim. All the houses, towers, and sewers below are one giant ratling nest.

entries.name: Missing Persons
entries: Children in the city of Drannsmund keep going missing when they are out past sunset. Rumors are spreading of strange people whispering from the sewers.

entries.name: Maw Vermin
entries: There is a rat in the old clock tower that has grown so fat with delerium contamination and mutations that it has now become a horrible Maw Vermin. Other ratlings are flocking to it. It needs to be destroyed.

entries.name: Rescue Mission
entries: Several Hooded Lantern scouts went missing near the sewers. They believe a ratling burrow has been made nearby, and those scouts might still be alive and in captivity.

data.name: Chapter 4: Predators of the Ruins
entries: {@b Monstrous Clans}

It's a funny thing being in Drakkenheim and not being at the top of the food chain. It adds an extra thrill as you clunk clunk your way through the streets trying not to end up a snack. If you're looking for a fight it's best to close your eyes, take a deep breath, and listen for the screams of terror from those becoming a meal.

Though contamination is wild and unpredictable, its transformative effects sometimes manifest consistently across certain animal species or individuals exposed under similar environmental conditions. These special circumstances have produced several unique groups of monsters which operate in a much more unified and coherent fashion—at least, compared to the ravening horrors and Delerium Dregs wandering the Haze. Initially banding together with others in order to survive, the most successful packs have carved out their own domains and territories within the ruined streets of Drakkenheim. Each has proven their mettle in battle against each other, the Hooded Lanterns, and expeditionary groups alike, each securing their own niche within the predatory hierarchy of the ruins.

While the ratlings are among the first of such groups most adventurers encounter in the Outer City of Drakkenheim, this chapter introduces several other notable monster families dwelling in Drakkenheim: the furious {@area Hazewind Harpies|3c9|x} who rule the high spires, the ferocious {@area Garmyr|3d4|x} wardogs who make their hunting grounds within the embattled Cathedral District, and the fishlike {@area Deep Dregs|3b5|x} lurking within contaminated waterways beneath the city. In addition, contaminated energies have even gripped the old statues and defensive guardians of the city, granting these constructs a malign sentience.

A delicate equilibrium now exists where the competition between these monstrous warbands and faction soldiers has plunged areas of the city into a deadlocked state of guerilla warfare. As each monstrous faction has grown, formidable leaders emerge amongst them who seek to challenge this balance and emerge atop the pile, defeating their mutated rivals—and extending their territory beyond Drakkenheim.

Beyond their similar ambitions for power and dominion, each group is described in this chapter with their own background details, roleplaying traits, combat tactics, lairs, and game statistics for several variations found amongst them.

entries.name: Garmyr
entries: Although once believed to be related to {@creature Gnoll||Gnolls}, these bipedal canids are unique to the Haze-ridden ruins of Drakkenheim. Covered in thick fur, Garmyr coloration and features vary from houndlike to wolflike, but all bare sharp teeth and claws. They form hyper-aggressive and predatory warpacks equipped with weapons taken from the many failed attempts to reclaim the city.

The Garmyr revel in their countless battles with adventurers, the Hooded Lanterns, and the Knights of the Silver Order for control over the Inner City of Drakkenheim. Although the roving warpacks make this district their primary hunting ground, Garmyr raiders have sallied forth from the ruins to plunder the countryside with increasing frequency. They live for the thrill of the hunt, taunting their prey as they pursue them into merciless ambushes. Though the warpacks are prone to infighting, a massive beast known as the {@creature Lord of the Feast|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} rules the Garmyr as their overlord. When this terrifying monster calls the packs to battle, all the Garmyr set aside their enmity for one another to join the blood hunt.

Where exactly the Garmyr came from isn't clear. The popular belief amongst the Hooded Lanterns is that the Garmyr originated from mutated stray canines left behind in the city during its destruction, since the appearance and behavior of the Garmyr is not dissimilar to packs of wild dogs. However, amongst the Garmyr have been sighted hunters and thaumaturges bearing the symbols similar to Kromac, the old god of beasts and slaughter, suggesting the Garmyr have some sort of connection to the bloodthirsty deity.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Although they are cunning hunters, Garmyr care little for conversation, and even less for parley—and they seldom show mercy. Garmyr speak bits of Common, but typically communicate with one another through barks and growls. Adventurers and faction agents who have attempted to communicate peacefully with Garmyr are ignored at best, and more often eaten.
However, a few bold explorers have managed to observe Garmyr where they make their encampments, recording their behavior when not on the prowl.

entries.name: Trophies
entries: It seems that amongst the warpacks, strength and skill in the hunt is shown utmost respect. Garmyr display their trophies proudly to demonstrate their kills not only to their prey, but to each other. A twisted sort of hierarchy has formed, with the most accomplished and ferocious Garmyr leading the pack

items: A rope of skulls hanging over the shoulder.
Fingers of dead adventurers worn like a necklace.
A helmet hung from a belt, filled with clattering teeth.
The skull of a giant alligator worn as a helm.
A ratling pelt, with the skull mounted upon the Garmyr's head.
A feathered cloak, each feather taken from a harpy.

entries.name: Scars of Battle
entries: The fear of all Garmyr is to become wounded or decrepit with age, so that they can no longer partake in the hunt. However, elder Garmyr wear scars that identify their experience. The more battle-worn a Garmyr is, the more respect they garner from their peers.

items: A large scar over one eye that has gone milky white.
A body lined with scars, a mosaic of red wounds mottling their fur.
A crudely made peg leg with spikes and shrapnel stuck in it.
A skeletal face of sinew and muscle, stripped of fur and skin.
An ear crudely stitched back on.
They have burn marks across half their body where no fur grows anymore.

entries.name: Warpacks
entries: The Hooded Lanterns have encountered several distinct warpacks within the ruins, identified by these names.

items: {@b The Gray Hounds} are a pack of gray-furred hunters who have taken up positions along the city, holding Temple Gate. They wear rusted armor scraps taken from the city armories, and even adorn themselves in tattered green cloaks to mock the Hooded Lanterns.
{@b The Blood Fangs} are a vicious group of Garmyr wandering the Outer City, known predators of ratlings who adorn themselves in ratling pelts and skulls.

{@b The Tower Dogs} are an Inner City pack in a constant state of battle against the {@area hazewind harpies|3c9|x} near the Central Market Place. They wear feathered capes and harpy talons around their necks.

{@b The Lord's Butchers} are the personal warpack of the {@creature Lord of the Feast|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. They wear human skull pauldrons and cloaks stitched of the flesh of adventurers, covering themselves in the blood of their enemies.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Garmyr are skilled hunters, and know how to use the ruins to their advantage. They have hunted the streets of Drakkenheim for years and know when and where to strike. They do not hide in the shadows, but rather howl and yip their way through the streets, surrounding prey and flanking with staggering precision. They revel in the fear they cause, and the thrill of the chase, the hunt, and the kill. Groups of adventurers, larger beasts, and some of the more iconic monsters of the city require a bit more tact. When it comes to this, the Garmyr lay clever ambush paths, sometimes sending some of their pack to lure a group of adventurers or a beast into a strategic location where they can surround it and ambush it.

entries.name: Temple Gate
entries: A shanty town of crude hovels and wood platforms surround the once proud gate. This is now the forward command post of the Garmyr, and they use it to ward off adventurers and any creatures aiming to enter or leave the city proper. The streets leading to the gate on either side are rigged with death traps, pits, spiked logs, and all manner of crudely made effigies of bone and blood.

entries.name: Temple Ward & The Sprawl
entries: These are the prime hunting grounds for the Garmyr and throughout them are many forward camps and burrows dug into old, abandoned buildings or piles of rubble and ruins. A Garmyr camp is easily identified by the smell of cooking flesh and hanging bones and meat on hooks. The Garmyr decorate their favorite campsites with such symbols as to inform other Garmyr that this is a good place to set up camp for a hunt in the area.

entries.name: St. Vitruvio's Cathedral
entries: This is the home of the Lord of the Feast and his most loyal dog soldiers. The cathedral is covered in blood and gore, with the many victims of the lord's hunt hanging on meat hooks throughout the cathedral. The once divine building now lies in ruin, more akin to a slaughterhouse than a place of worship. The brazier that once held the sacred flame is now a monument of skulls and blood, identifying the grim blasphemy of its new occupants.

entries.name: Hunter / Hunted
entries: A rather aggressive warpack has been hunting in the sprawl and making travel dangerous for all adventurers, prospectors, and many of the factions. Someone must track down this warpack and put an end to their hunt.

entries.name: Dog Soldiers
entries: A group of {@creature Hooded Lantern Scout|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Hooded Lantern Scouts} find themselves cut off. They send up a flare for aid, locking themselves inside an old cabin. They must survive the night with a group of ravenous Garmyr making every attempt to break in and eat them.

entries.name: Garmyr Warriors
entries: A pack of grizzled, bipedal canines charges toward you, howling with fury. They brandish scavenged weaponry and wear patchwork armor stitched together from the rotting hides of their previous kills. Some wear macabre jewelry made from fingers, ears, bones, and teeth. Their frothing mouths are filled with jagged teeth as they bark and growl.

entries.name: Deep Dregs
entries: Curiously, creatures transformed by exposure to the contaminated waterways of Drakkenheim often develop piscine features and aquatic adaptations. Although they have similar origins to Delerium Dregs, many of these so-called Deep Dregs have become thralls to an eldritch entity dwelling deeper in the sewers of Drakkenheim known as the {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess}. This nightmarish horror lurks deep below Drakkenheim's forsaken waterways, slowly amassing contaminated minions while fostering dark dreams to usurp control of the surface.

The Deep Dregs patrol the sewers and waterways of Drakkenheim while making forays onto the surface to gather supplies or take captives. Despite the ambitions of the Duchess, Deep Dregs are peculiarly social, and frequently do not attack explorers and faction agents when they encounter them. Rather, Deep Dregs can be indifferent or even helpful in some cases. However, beneath the surface lurks a monstrous plot, as the Duchess commands her Deep Dregs to seek out fresh subjects.

The Duchess's body secretes contaminating mucus. When this slime is combined with delerium and used to contaminate a humanoid creature, that individual transforms into a Deep Dreg should they succumb to a monstrous transformation. Mortals with significant martial or magical talents may instead become deep knights or deep sirens. These transformed mortals dimly remember their former lives, but are stricken with madness and are forever cursed to serve the Duchess. They look back on their land-bound lives with scorn, and unquestionably follow the Duchess's will.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Refer the following traits when roleplaying the Deep Dregs and the Duchess's thralls if the player characters attempt to converse with them:

items: "We are the servants of the Duchess. Come see our customs and partake of our strange ways, and all will be revealed. The water holds great secrets; drink deeply of its knowledge."
"Our blessed offerings help the Duchess in her quest to open the way and the gate."

"We offer a miraculous cure for the horrific condition which afflicts the surface-dwellers! How awful must it be that you cannot live in the wonderful waters! This is a terrible curse which keeps you bound to the land!"
"Delerium is the wondrous treasure of the Duchess's vault! Her prized coral—she lays claim upon it all. We must bring it to her."

"We can't trust you until you are cured! Drink deep of the waters. You will hear the Duchess's summons! Her magic will weaken the curse which holds you to the land so you might swim through the waves to her court! She will break the terrible curse which you are suffering, and welcome you as one of her loyal subjects! Perhaps even declare you among her valiant knights!"
"One day, the Duchess will flood the world with her miraculous waters, curing all flesh of the befouled ailments which grip the land!"

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Deep Dregs prefer to fight in areas where they can take advantage of their aquatic capabilities, such as contaminated sewer canals, rivers, and pools. While a few of their number might begin to parley, others lurk in the water, waiting for an opportune moment to strike. Especially when facing uncontaminated humanoids, Deep Dregs prefer to attack from the water since they know their foes are hesitant to risk contamination.

Often, Deep Dregs attempt to subdue their foes instead of killing them so they can bring live captives back to the {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess}, where she will transform the captives into fresh thralls. Deep Dregs also use the watery environment to their advantage, and may sometimes drag a {@condition Restrained|XPHB} target into contaminated water either as an attempt to mutate or drown the creature.

entries.name: Sewers of Drakkenheim
entries: Throughout the sewers of Drakkenheim are many old tunnels, clogged waterways, and wide sewer passages that the Deep Dregs have transformed into small villages or encampments. Often small groups of the Dregs occupy these locations, collecting food and resources to bring back to the {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess}, or luring lost adventurers or faction agents to join them. These camps, although not immediately hostile, often house a handful of guards and knights who protect the Dregs that dwell there.

entries.name: The Old Town Cistern
entries: In the heart of Drakkenheim sits the Old Town Cistern, right below Slaughterstone Square. This old well is now filled with the bloated corpses of the {@creature Executioner|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Executioner's} kills, and the Deep Dregs pick through the bodies looking for good meat and valuable trinkets to bring back to their {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess}. The entrance to the Duchess's lair is in the Cistern and leads to a great cavern hidden underground where the Duchess and her minions plot their inevitable takeover of the city.

entries.name: Guests of Honor
entries: A friendly {@creature Deep Dreg Warrior|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} has offered to guide the player characters through the sewers, in exchange all that they ask is that you come and meet their leader, a {@creature Deep Siren|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} named Cookie who is about to hold a special ceremony. The ceremony of course is to indoctrinate newcomers with the contaminated mucus of the {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess}. If they refuse, they will be given the serum by force.

entries.name: The Duchess's Departure
entries: The {@creature The Duchess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Duchess} has abandoned Drakkenheim, either by being discovered and forced to flee, or because the situation in the city became unfavorable to her ambitions. Fleeing the city down the Drann River, she escaped to Ash Bay, where the delerium of the city flows and rests along the bottom of the ocean, creating a massive reef of contaminated sea life. Here the Duchess plots her revenge on mortals, and slowly her minions have begun to creep into the homesteads and small villages along the Crystal Coast.

entries.name: Guardian Constructs
entries: The ancient and imperial city walls of Drakkenheim are decorated with baroque architectural features, including impressive columns and sculptures, iron-studded spiked trim, and carved corbels supporting the battlements. Most impressive are the grotesque gargoyles of stone, marble, and cast bronze which resemble winged fiends or ferocious dragons. However, these are no mere ornamentations. Centuries ago, the reigning monarch of Drakkenheim, Hildegarde von Drakken I, secretly used the power of the {@item Crown of Westemr|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} to bring these statues to life to serve as protectors for the city. These magical constructs were bound to the will of the monarch, but also answered to the commands of any who bore one of the six Seals of Westemr. Although rumors swelled about the living statues of Drakkenheim, the common folk never truly knew the full extent of the stone guardians watching over them.

During Ulrich von Kessel IV's last moments as the meteor overwhelmed the city, a final command was given to the constructs: "Protect Drakkenheim and its people!" However, the magical energies of the Haze have contaminated even these guardians, and the ambiguity of the king's last order has been corrupted in their construct minds. They enact a twisted interpretation which sets them upon any who dare trespass into the city, and view the mutated inhabitants of Drakkenheim as the very citizens they are charged to protect.

This has made adventuring into the city even more dangerous, and getting into the Inner City has proven difficult as scaling the walls or attempting to fly over them immediately draws the attention of the defenders. Approaching the castle has proven nearly impossible, and as for Slaughterstone Square, the small handful of survivors who have seen it simply encourage any traveling into the city to avoid it at all costs.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: In the former glory of Drakkenheim the constructs of the city were bound to the crown and the holders of the seals of Drakkenheim. There are those who believe that obtaining all six seals would allow some control over the situation. Others think the contamination and Haze has caused an irreversible problem that can no longer be contained or controlled.

items: An ornate crown of jewels fused to its head.
Golden filigree that extends throughout its body.
Many gold rings, some of which house large crystals.
Two faces, one gleeful and sneering, the other twisted in a sorrowful frown.
A stone blade and shield.
Three statues: one with its eyes covered, another with its ears covered, and the third with its mouth covered.
A heroic pose, as if ready for some great painting to be made of it.
Its face crumbled away, yet it still moves as if fully aware.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Guardian constructs feel no pain, and know no fear. They are simply designed to protect the walls of the city, or the castle proper. They are relentless in their pursuit within the domains they occupy, but rarely chase a creature beyond their designated locations. The {@creature Wall Gargoyle|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Gargoyles} and {@creature Tower Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Tower Dragons} stick to the city walls. Still, those who find themselves within the territories of these constructs are pursued by unflinching horror determined to protect its territory at all costs.

entries.name: City Walls, Gates, and Towers
entries: During the construction of Drakkenheim, the outer walls of the city were built with large {@creature Wall Gargoyle|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Gargoyles} facing both inside and outside the city. The towers along the walls were each constructed with a beautiful ornate {@creature Tower Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} perched atop it. Across Drakkenheim's walls, there are approximately 500 beautifully constructed statues. They now guard the towers and walls from anyone who attempts to climb or fly over them, and hunts any intruders with vicious determination.

entries.name: Castle Drakken
entries: When Castle Drakken was constructed, it followed suite with the design of the city walls and housed {@creature Wall Gargoyle|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Gargoyles} perched along every tower and roof, as well as several alcoves and niches throughout the building. Each tower was placed with a bronze {@creature Tower Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} coiled along its roof. The central tower houses a massive statue of a dragon much more ornate and well decorated than the rest. The statue, named {@creature Minazorond|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, was built by the eccentric Liberio artist Nicoletti, and animated by a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell. It now acts as the sworn protector of the castle.

entries.name: Slaughterstone Square
entries: A great construct built by the Glitterpeak dwarves, recovered from the ruins and brought to Drakkenheim, was deemed {@creature Executioner|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|"The Executioner"} and designed to carry out the death sentence in Drakkenheim. The massive construct was a spectacle that many who traveled to the city would stop to witness. Now it haunts the square, consumed by a need to execute any living creature that enters its domain. Its original programming is confused—it deems anyone who sets foot in Slaughterstone Square a criminal worthy of the harshest sentence.

entries.name: Scale the Walls
entries: Climbing the walls of Drakkenheim might still be one of the better ways into the city, and if a patch of the walls can be cleared of its constructs, perhaps there is a way to make a permanent entry point for those hoping to enter the city.

entries.name: Reset
entries: Perhaps there is a way to reset the programming of the constructs of Drakkenheim. If all the seals can be uncovered and brought to the throne room, control over the constructs could be a turning point in saving the city.

entries.name: Hazewind Harpies
entries: The harpies who occupy the towers throughout Drakkenheim can be heard singing their discordant hymns throughout the streets, luring lost adventurers to their doom. The harpies are some mutated combination of humanoid and avian, though it is believed many of them were once birds who occupied the towers in the city, now twisted by the Haze and corruption.

You can find these creatures nesting in the tallest structures throughout the city and prowling the skies, making aerial travel within the city exceptionally dangerous. The harpies have managed to make uneasy alliances with other flying monsters throughout the city and are known to befriend {@creature Manticore|XMM|Manticores}, who they often use as brute protectors of their territories, as well as keeping the awful skretches nearby as additional problems for any who would threaten them.

Their songs echo through the streets of the city and have a haunting effect on those who draw close. From a distance, travelers may feel a building tension or a sense of unease when the chorus of disarming melodies hits them. Those closer to the harpies may be drawn in by the tunes, or even find themselves entranced by them. Some who have heard the songs have felt a strange sense of dream-like wonder, only to snap out of it by being plucked off the ground by the harpies. Most who hear the melodies do not live to share their stories.

The clock tower has become the roost of their leader, the {@creature Crimson Countess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. While the harpies hunt the streets of the city and attack anything that attempts to fly in or out, they all answer the call of the Crimson Countess, who loves plucking adventurers from the streets, and protects her tower with ferocity and cunning. She enjoys the tower for its open concept—perfect for flinging foolish adventurers who dare challenge her domain.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: The hazewind harpies are loyal to their chain of command, and all serve the matriarchs and crones of their communities. They are proud warriors who are well trained combatants and skilled hunters.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Hazewind harpies stick to the skies and high towers, relying on ranged attacks to down their foes. Stronger harpies swoop in and pluck their enemies off the street, lifting them into the air before dropping them to their death. When possible, harpies find perches, rafters, balconies, or other higher vantage points to take cover, attacking from these optimal positions.
Harpies attack as a unit and almost always travel in a flock. If a harpy is alone, it usually means it is lost or it has allies nearby.

entries.name: The Cosmological Clock Tower
entries: The {@creature Crimson Countess|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} makes her lair in the great clock tower in Market Square. Her and her greatest champions occupy the tower, claiming the central streets of Drakkenheim as their territory. Any who have opposed the Crimson Countess must climb the tower's dangerous stairs while fending off harpies. The Crimson Countess herself has knocked many would-be heroes to their death from the highest balconies of the clock tower. It is an incredibly defendable position for flying creatures, and one not easily taken.

entries.name: Old Town Towers
entries: Many ancient towers now lie in ruin within Old Town. These were once command posts for the original city guard and older temples in the city. Most of these locations have been occupied by harpy nests, and the streets are now a hunting ground for the avian huntresses

entries.name: Disturbing the Nest
entries: A group of harpies led by a deadly crone has occupied a small watchtower in the sprawl and the surrounding area has become a death trap for navigating or traversing. Someone needs to put those harpies down and make travel through the sprawl at least mildly safer.

entries.name: Break a Few Eggs
entries: An apothecary in Drakkenheim is paying good money for anyone willing to obtain a harpy egg for them for an experiment. It needs to be undamaged and unhatched in order to work. So whoever gets it needs to also make it out of the city without taking more than half their Hit Points in damage, otherwise the egg will be ruined.

entries.name: Out to Lunch
entries: The harpies have plucked a group of Queen's Men or Hooded Lanterns from the city streets and taken them back to their roost. We need someone to go get them out, but the roost is likely swarming with harpies, so stealth will be key.

data.name: Chapter 5: Apothecary Abominations
entries: {@b Manipulating Life}

That creature just stabbed me with a needle full of green! The only terrible green thing I put in my body is salad. Classic apothecaries and their weird experiments and torsos chained to walls, there's no way those working conditions are viable. They are just trying to scare some would-be adventurer. I, the great Pluto Jackson, do not fear torsos. I have the greatest torso of all! My torso is carved from the relentless pursuit of perfection and red meat.

Through occult science and eldritch magic, apothecaries manipulate life and death itself. Most use their skills to cure ailments, mend injuries, and save lives. Superstition and rumors abound regarding their practice and abilities, these healers and doctors are often well-regarded within their communities. Experience and curiosity inspire apothecaries to experiment, seeking out new knowledge and advanced techniques.

Well-intentioned exploration turns to dark practice when an apothecary discovers that the same magic that repairs the body can also reanimate dead flesh, transmogrify muscle and bone, animate inorganic matter, manipulate the mind, and even create new life. It begins in small ways: the apothecary offers an experimental concoction made from dangerous materials to a desperate patient, or transplants body parts harvested from the dead to save a grievously wounded friend. Perhaps next they attempt to reanimate a beloved pet, create a laboratory assistant from mud and chemicals, or use a new technique to gently dissuade local authorities from investigating their laboratories. Most stop there, content to close the book on their occult discoveries and return to more humble and reliable methods. However, unforeseen circumstances or boundless ambition drive a rare few to take these studies even further; to push the boundaries of science and magic with no regard for ethics, morals, or safety.

Tragically, though the vast majority of apothecaries harness science to aid others, heal the sick, and change the world for the better, a rare few among them become villains who unleash nightmares from their laboratores. These monsters perpetuate a vicious cycle when their masters send them out into the world to collect body parts and unwitting victims for use in further experimentation. Even after their creators are brought to justice, the horrors they created remain hiding in the dark corners of villages, in underground lairs beneath cities, or in secret and forgotten laboratories.

The twisted and unusual abominations crafted by the minds of apothecaries who have thrown away morals in exchange for scientific advancement are becoming an unfortunate byproduct of their avenues of study. These monster maker's vile experiments have unleashed a new generation of wicked creations upon the world. Tales spread around campfires and amongst children that tell of the things that go bump in the night: stitched-together corpses, their limbs replaced with medical instruments; grave-robbing body-snatchers stealing away in the dead of night; strange monstrosities lurking in the shadows seeking fresh victims; and patients who got more than they bargained for in a desperate plea for help.

entries.name: What is an Apothecary?
entries: The apothecary is a new class for Fifth Edition introduced in {@i Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim}. These Intelligence-based spellcasters and medical experts use their knowledge to both heal and harm, augmenting their conventional skills with alchemy and occult magic. They mimic magical effects using the right combination of natural ingredients, chemical reagents, and occult practices. Many monsters in this chapter are inspired by the six subclasses available to apothecaries: Alienist, Chemist, Exorcist, Mutagenist, Pathogenist, and Reanimator.

Some apothecaries might first attempt treatment with traditional means like medicinal herbs and surgical techniques. When these methods are not enough, they use arcane magic and eldritch forces to restore their patients. Apothecary magic revolves around the body: healing it with tinctures, modifying it via transmogrification or psychoactive compounds, or harming it with poisons and diseases.

Though much rarer than sorcerers and wizards, apothecary techniques are spreading through the continent from master to apprentice, as well as in a few institutions for higher learning. While their magic isn't forbidden, the Amethyst Academy does not take kindly to magical instruction outside their schools. Thus, knowledge about apothecary magic has spread largely in secret. These desperate circumstances have often inspired less ethical apothecaries to carry out unsavory magic and methods to continue their research, gain power, and protect themselves and their techniques.

entries.name: Occult Creation
entries: During their training, many apothecaries develop skills used to create strange creatures, be that through modifying the dead, stitching together flesh into something new, or harnessing the essence of a creature and transforming it into something else. Apothecaries have, at times, strayed from their paths of scientific study for the betterment of mortals, and gotten carried away with the possibilities of if they could accomplish a new feat, disregarding if they should. Often these practices have been used in creating brainless lab assistants, minions to help and perform menial surgical tasks or bodyguards who need no rest to protect and safeguard the important works of the scientists. All manner of bizarre creations bending science and the arcane have been noted as apothecary inventions. The most ambitious and insane apothecaries may even use themselves as a canvas for their experiments.

entries.name: Alienist
entries: The mind is a malleable thing to an {@creature Alienist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. To the untrained and ignorant, the methods of an alienist may appear little more than cunning charm and subtle words. However, they know potent occult techniques for mental manipulation including hypnosis, suggestion, telepathy, and telekinesis. When their practice moves on to test subjects, they use mental projection, indoctrination, and even brain surgery to brainwash their victims, altering mental capability, memory, and thought patterns.

An Alienist will use their vast and expanding intellect to create monsters from the severed and broken minds of their patients. {@creature Disembodied Psyche|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Disembodied Psyches}, {@creature Cerebrograft|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Cerebrografts}, and {@creature Mind Leech|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Mind Leeches} are notable Alienist creations. They have also been known to implant victims with aberrations to take control of the host's body, removing the brains of patients and using them in further experimentation—and other more unfathomable things.
I don't know if I want these guys poking around in my head! That's where I keep my thoughts!

entries.name: Chemist
entries: {@creature Chemists|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} often start with mixing mundane acids and compounds in a laboratory. They practice harnessing heat, cold, and electricity in new and unique ways. As they move on to larger projects, Chemists begin experimenting with more destructive forces, attempting to perfect what combination of the least ingredients results in the biggest elemental reactions. They also create sentient alchemical mixtures, creating life from the very core and raw alchemical elements. Eventually a Chemist learns the skills to raze buildings to the ground with little more than a flask of chemicals used in the right way.

Chemists often create various forms of oozes or elementals as lab assistants or defenses. {@creature Black Pudding|XMM|Black Puddings}, {@creature Gelatinous Cube|XMM|Gelatinous Cubes}, Mephits, and all manner of elementals are common creations. The {@creature Tanker|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} acts as a common lab assistant to the Chemist, but no creation is as deadly as the {@creature Chemystral|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, the ultimate creation of chemical sentience, adaptable and durable; they are the pride of any Chemist.
Word of advice, if the doctor you go to looks like this guy, maybe find a new doctor.

entries.name: Exorcist
entries: {@creature Exorcist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Exorcists} have long been an outlier in the branches of scientific study. However, in a world full of portals to other planes, creatures from the Hells and the Shadowlands, and even the fairy Otherworlds constantly slipping through, the scientific study into these planes is a discipline many will undertake. They do not share the devotion of a paladin or cleric, but instead research the origins of divine power, and how to harness it to manipulate extraplanar beings. Many Exorcists begin their path banishing simple spirits or communicating with ghosts. Eventually they master the ability to vanquish possession and banish much more powerful foes. Exorcists who are driven to more sinister paths can reverse engineer this knowledge to summon entities from other planes, and even allow these beings into themselves, using their bodies as a vessel.

Exorcists could be accompanied by {@creature Ghost|XMM|Ghosts} or demons of any sort, but their true vile powers come to light in the form of possessions. An Exorcist on a path for power may let a demonic being into their body to try and harness and control the power of that creature, these {@area Soulbound Host|5b1|x} often struggle, and often fail to maintain control over such power.
Listen, I don't care if you call yourself a scientist or a doctor, if you put a demon in you, I'm going to kill you.

entries.name: Mutagenist
entries: A {@creature Mutagenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is practiced controlling mutations and altering of the flesh of creatures. They are less crude in their implementations than a Reanimator, and often their experiments will lack the stitched-together nature of other apothecaries, instead containing growths, misplaced appendages and orifices and other grotesque mutations. Mutagenists often begin their practice on small rodents and other creatures, testing their transmogrification to see if they can bend these creatures to be stronger and faster, or mutate them to grow new beneficial properties. It's when a Mutagenist turns to human experimentation that things tend to take a dark turn. For every successful experiment, there are a handful of failures.

The {@creature Skinwing|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is the byproduct of a Mutagenist tampering with smaller creatures, while creations such as {@creature Cerebrograft|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} are a much more advanced creation. Sometimes their failures do remain beneficial to the doctor in the form of {@creature Uncontained Growth|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Uncontained Growths}. Ultimately the end goal of any Mutagenist is to create the Apex Formula and use it on themselves, transforming into what they deem to be the perfect version of humanity. However, there are always side effects.
I have often thought it would be pretty great to have an extra arm. I could swing even more swords!

entries.name: Pathogenist
entries: The {@creature Pathogenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} studies viruses, diseases, poisons, and pathogens. They usually begin their careers with innocent intentions, such as attempting to perfect combating deadly pathogens and viruses by creating cures or medicines. However, some turn more toward harnessing the powers of poison and disease for harmful purposes. When they begin experimenting on test subjects, using them as breeding grounds for their new mutant strains begins their path toward creating horrible abominations.

Pathogenists who use human subjects as testing grounds for their diseases often create {@creature Plague Carrier|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Plague Carriers} as a means of delivering these diseases, while {@creature Injector|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Injectors} act as loyal lab assistants, ready to deliver the Pathogenist's deadly toxins to their often unwilling patients.

entries.name: Reanimator
entries: Reanimators are often first practiced in the art of reattaching severed limbs, or moving body parts from one creature to another. As their desire for perfection in their creations grows, their path to deadly experimentation begins. Their minds blossom with wild ideas to attempt physical manipulations that no being should endure.

Reanimators will often be accompanied by {@creature Reautomata|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} as their first foray into human testing, but they create all manner of {@creature Stitcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Stitchers}, {@creature Ripper|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Rippers}, and {@creature Injector|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Injectors} as lab assistants to help them with the production of new creations.

entries.name: Apothecaries and Delerium
entries: When delerium first arrived in Drakkenheim on that fateful day, it left behind devastation and death in its wake, but it also left opportunity for those willing to seek it, and determined enough to harness its power.

While the vast resources and institutional organization of the Amethyst Academy were fully leveraged to research and obtain delerium, the mages were not the only ones interested in learning about and exploiting the strange crystals. Apothecaries of all stripes sought samples of their own as whispers of the magical potency and corrupting influence of delerium spread. Most purchase delerium from traders, prospectors, and smugglers, but others go as far as hiring adventures or mounting their own expeditions to the ruins to collect the stones.

There can be no doubt that the boundless magical power and contaminating influence of delerium has sharply increased the scope and horror of apothecary experimentations. Practitioners of all sorts have begun to use delerium to further extend their scientific research, as it offered magical potency to places that were without it before. Apothecaries have long wished to harness the abilities of mages, and in many ways were able to mimic those examples through blending the right chemicals, or the use of carefully practiced procedures. However, when delerium was added into the mix, it amplified the capabilities of apothecaries to new heights, allowing them to push the nature of scientific study into realms hitherto unimagined.

Commonfolk can often no longer tell the difference between a mageborn spellcaster and an apothecary twisting science to their will. Both the Academy and Silver Order have frowned upon the back-alley practices of many apothecaries. These traditionalists fear that as science grows ever closer to the realm of magic, the provisions of the Edicts of Lumen begin to blur. Delerium is showing up in places it should not, and its presence is always cause for concern. Experimenting with delerium brings inevitable danger, and the pathway to things beyond mortal comprehension. Still, apothecaries aim to harness this power to modify and enhance their capabilities—with understanding comes power. The more an apothecary understands delerium, the less there is to fear from it, and the more power they believe they can have over it.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Though many apothecaries began working alone keeping their creations closely guarded secrets, over time their knowledge of these horrors has spread through whispers and desperate collaborations. Increasingly, ambitious young apothecaries beginning their careers with noble-minded altruism are tempted by the power and promise of these occult secrets. However, one does not so easily meddle with the secrets of life and death itself without compromising one's moral compass. Who knows what dire and desperate situations may cause good-hearted young doctors to find themselves tempted to take up a less ethical choice?

entries.name: Twisted Motives
entries: What once-noble reason caused the apothecary to create such horrible monsters?

items: My loved one was terminally ill, and I sought the science and power to save them or bring them back, going to any lengths to accomplish this goal.
I started research that would improve life for my town or village. If I could just perfect the science, I could create something that would help thousands of people.
I was hired by a military force to help create a weapon that could neutralize my nation's enemies. I know the science is possible, I just need to harness it before another nation does.
The thirst for knowledge drives me to look into occult history that others have yet to uncover, and drives me to push what could be done with that knowledge
After countless failed experiments, I have abandoned petty things like "ethics" and "morals." Any means is justified to accomplish my goals.
A terrible experiment left me scarred and deformed. I vow to find a way to restore myself... no... I will improve myself, so I am never weak like that again!
I was embarrassed and humiliated by the accomplishments of a skilled rival who stole my genius ideas. I will have my revenge and prove myself to be the more brilliant mind.
I was working as a healer in my hometown but was driven out and branded as a malfeasant for my magic by the Faith of the Sacred Flame.

entries.name: Intelligent Masters
entries: The apothecaries themselves are smart and cunning scientists and they do not often put themselves in situations where they do not have the upper hand. What does the apothecary think of its adversaries and how do they engage with others?

items: When I do converse with others, it is usually laced with scientific jargon, multisyllabic words, and an air of arrogant sophistication.
I know that often I am the smartest person in the room and treat others as such.
I am sly and cunning in my conversations with others, I know how to make small talk and discreetly manipulate conversations in my favor while remaining civil.
I am boisterous and arrogant and want everyone in the room to know of my unparalleled intelligence.
I see those of equal intelligence to me as possible allies and someone worthy of upholding conversation. Those who do not share my intelligence are not worthy of my time.
Anyone who appears smarter than me is a threat who must be eliminated immediately!
Those of lesser intelligence to me are easily manipulated and may be convinced to join my cause as a lackey, or a brute I can use against my enemies.
Those of lesser intelligence than me are nothing more than waiting test subjects that I will perfect using science!

entries.name: Voiceless Horrors
entries: Few of an apothecary's minions are intended for conversations or deep thought. They are more often creatures designed with a singular focus. They obey the demands of their masters without faltering.

These creatures are the things that go bump in the night. They are the monsters of classic science fiction literature, black and white monster films, and horrors found in dark corners. Roleplaying the minions should bring to life the classic concepts of horror and fear. What odd quirk does the Apothecary Abomination possess?

items: Wears a piece of clothing or carries a tool from its former life.
Constantly repeats words or a specific phrase, such as its own name.
Believes it is still living out its former life and acts accordingly despite carrying out horrible tasks, such as talking about washing laundry when ripping people apart.
Tears at its own stitches, scars, or body parts, confused at its current physical state and necessitating constant repair.
Tries to speak but can only ever produce a gurgling, moaning, or wailing sound.
Hums or sings an old and simple song repeatedly over and over again.
Walks with an uneven shuffle that scrapes and clanks along the ground
Believes every creature it encounters is trying to harm it and reacts with immediate hostility.

entries.name: Imprinted Instincts
entries: What traits or mannerisms from the former victim has the monster inherited?

items: Attached to a toy or stuffed animal and becomes aggressive when separated from it.
Responds with care and empathy to a specific kind of animal.
Jovially dances or passively listens to a particular kind of music or poem.
Irrational fear of an otherwise innocuous household object, such as spoons.
Driven into a rage or deep malaise whenever it encounters a person from its former life (or someone who bears similar traits to them).
Cannot bear to look in a mirror or see its own reflection, recoils and flees.
Is calmed or soothed by the sight of its favorite flower or being in places of natural beauty.
Lacks object permanence like a small child and forgets about things quickly when they are not immediately in front of it.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Apothecary Abominations are ruthless in battle and obey their apothecary creators without fail. They are deadly and precise creatures who are skilled as both medical lab assistants and defenders. With their surgical tools or unbound strength, they pose a deadly threat to any who dare meddle in the affairs of the mad apothecaries who created them.

entries.name: Mindless Minions
entries: Most abominations are specifically designed to feel no pain, and lack a mind of their own. They will often fight until they die, relentlessly attacking until they cannot anymore. Oftentimes, these minions operate on the commands of their apothecary masters, performing the orders they have been given to the best of their abilities.

entries.name: Eyes and Ears
entries: Apothecaries can often use their experiments as a means of gathering intel. Whether through psychic links, telepathic connections, or other more inventive means, it is common that when an apothecary's minion spots a threat, the apothecary will be alerted to that threat immediately. The minions frequently act as a security system for an apothecary's lair.

entries.name: Sample Encounters
entries: Apothecaries often collect an eclectic mix of creations and experiments, so it is common for several different monsters in this chapter to be found together. Here's a few thematic encounters with Apothecary Abominations:

entries.name: Sample Collector (Level 3+)
entries: An {@creature Innocent Harvester|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} with a sack full of various {@area Leeches|556|x} is collecting body parts from a recent battle.

entries.name: Violently Volatile (Level 7+)
entries: A {@creature Tanker|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and two {@creature Scrap Reautomata|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} prepare chemicals in a lab.

entries.name: Failed Experiments (Level 9+)
entries: A discarded gaggle of {@creature Skinwing|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Skinwings} and an {@creature Uncontained Growth|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} are lurking in the wilds near an apothecary's hideout, attacking travelers.

entries.name: Spooky Science (Level 10+)
entries: An {@creature Exorcist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, two {@creature Ghost|XMM|Ghosts}, and 3–4 {@creature Specter|XMM|Specters} working on summoning a demon, using the Exorcist as a host, in an old, abandoned church. If they are not stopped, the Exorcist will become a {@area Soulbound Host|5b1|x}.

entries.name: Out of Sight, Out of Mind (Level 12+)
entries: A {@creature Body Snatcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} collects victims from a nearby town under the watchful eye of a {@creature Cerebrograft|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and a {@creature Disembodied Psyche|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Surgical Team (Level 15+)
entries: A {@creature Ripper|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, an {@creature Injector|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and a {@creature Stitcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} are working together in an operating theater, preparing the next subject for experimentation by their master.

entries.name: The Perfect Specimen (Level 15+)
entries: An {@creature Apex|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and his team of {@creature Wretched Patient|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Wretched Patients}, unleash an {@creature Uncontained Growth|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} within their lab.

entries.name: Adventure Hooks
entries: The abominations made by apothecaries pose a threat to unsuspecting villages. The secret scientific research they brew up in hidden labs cause all manner of problems for the regular folk residing nearby. Apothecaries in need of fresh subjects for experimentation are the center of unease in any community when people start going missing in the middle of the night. These missing people are often accompanied by reports of strange creatures on the outskirts of town.

entries.name: Infiltrating the Guild
entries: The Amethyst Academy is concerned with the scientific research happening in secret at the {@area Mobius Facility|4c3|x}, located in the Drakeclaw mountains. The Academy needs a team of adventurers to find the hidden entrance to this facility, infiltrate it, and find out if any illegal magic is practiced there. Unfortunately, the facility is overrun with demons, most dangerous of all a {@area Soulbound Host|5b1|x} being overseen by an {@creature Exorcist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} Apothecary.

entries.name: Can I Copy Your Homework?
entries: As an aspiring apothecary yourself, with curiosity about the multiple studies of science happening across the continent, you wish to travel to {@area Altbruke University|4c2|x}, {@area Lento College|4c4|x}, the {@area Liberio Institute|4c5|x}, and the {@area Southern Reach Research Centre|4c6|x} to learn what you can from a master apothecary at each institution.

entries.name: Elyrian Bonesaw Massacre
entries: There is a {@creature Ripper|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} on the loose in one of the smaller towns of Elyria. A local apothecary had created a lab assistant to help him with his medical practices and research, but the creature became violent and vengeful. Now the Ripper is on a rampage through the countryside and needs to be stopped.

entries.name: The Blob
entries: A {@creature Chemystral|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} has escaped its lab and devoured the apothecary who created it. Now it wanders the countryside, consuming everything is passes and growing larger. The key to stopping it must be in the apothecary's notes in his lab.

entries.name: The Lost Ones
entries: People have been going missing in the dead of night, and reports of those very people being seen wandering the woods nearby are causing quite the stir. A nearby Reanimator Apothecary has been kidnapping victims using a {@creature Body Snatcher|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and turning them into {@creature Reautomata|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@creature Wretched Patient|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Wretched Patients}. The Reanimator is hidden in a wilderness tower and must be stopped.

entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Apothecary lairs are often labs and workshops, hidden from the public eye. These places hold the mysteries of science and occult lore. Finding an apothecary's lair is often a difficult task, as they go to great lengths to conceal their work; the monsters that inhabit the dank workshops and occult labs are the stuff of nightmares.

entries.name: Repurposed Facilities
entries: Whether working alone or in small groups, apothecaries typically repurpose an existing structure to serve as their lair. They may choose a disused old manor house, abandoned fortress, or a remote sanitarium. Often their lairs are unknown to most, in long forgotten facilities, in remote locations, or in secret chambers below a town.

entries.name: Institutional Facade
entries: Apothecaries who make their lairs in towns and cities may provide legitimate medical services and healing to the community while concealing their experiments from public view. Their lair may outwardly operate as a school, hospice, or clinic open to those seeking the apothecary's talents, while housing their real work in hidden chambers below ground. Less scrupulous apothecaries may use this as a scheme to transform unwitting patients into test subjects.

entries.name: Science-Fiction Furnishings
entries: An apothecary lab is often filled with bizarre alchemical ingredients, various types of lab equipment, and strange chambers filled with occult secrets. Strange contraptions: tesla coils, cadavers, half-finished experiments, and all manner of science-fiction staples can be found in their labs. No matter the type of apothecary inhabiting the lair, it is a bizarre place that fringes on the borders of what is science and magic.

entries.name: Nothing as it Seems
entries: There is no way of knowing when you are walking into a horrible trap when exploring an apothecary's lair. Cadavers may get up and walk around, the vat of bubbling liquid may be a sentient ooze, and the multitudes of experiments and equipment may cause elemental traps and hazards. With the numerous forms of science that apothecaries experiment with, there is no telling what mind-bending contraptions they may have at their disposal.

entries.name: Minions and Monsters
entries: Many of the monsters in this chapter operate as minions to powerful apothecaries. Depending on the type of apothecary you are using, there are monsters it may use more often than others. Regardless, an apothecary uses its experiments and mastery of arcane science to protect themselves and their valuable research.

entries.name: Puzzles and Protections
entries: Apothecaries do not easily allow access their labs and research. They often have powerful locks, puzzles, and various ways to outsmart and confuse those trying to infiltrate to their secret lairs.

entries.name: Laboratory Features
entries: This lair is based on the secret apothecary laboratory found beneath {@area Altbruke University|4c2|x}, but could be adapted to the lair of any apothecary. The descriptions of the rooms are left ambiguous in nature, as different apothecaries may decorate their rooms in different ways.

items: An {@creature Alienist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} may have more texts on psychology, simple puzzles and games, abstract ink blots with sinister interpretations, a Newton's cradle on the desk, or a classic brain in a jar.

A {@creature Chemist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} will likely have vials and vats of chemicals, alchemical equipment, tongs, furnaces, barrels of water, safety equipment, and lots of test samples. They may keep a small ooze in a contained space.

An {@creature Exorcist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} will have summoning circles in place of operating labs, books on undead, demons, specters, and hauntings. Macabre dcor decorates the laboratory, such as skulls and bones, along with religious items relating to the Sacred Flame or Old Gods. They may even have a ghost or spirit contained in a warded vessel.

A {@creature Mutagenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} will often have books of biology, diagrams of the human form, test samples of their formulae, alchemical equipment, and perhaps even a failed test subject kept as a minion or pet.

A {@creature Pathogenist|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} may have more vials and toxins lining their shelves, books about viral infections, pathogens, healing, and occult lore. They could have microscopes, petri dishes, and all manner of scientific gear for studying and creating pathogens.

A {@b Reanimator} will likely have the most grotesque gear in their lab: bone saws, knives and scalpels, and preserved body parts in jars. Nondescript meat hanging from hooks or severed limbs in piles are not unheard of.

entries.name: 1. Doctor's Office
entries: This private office is where the apothecary retreats for some light reading of their own.

A small wooden desk covered in writing supplies, specimens, and scientific knick-knacks sits in the far corner. A comfortable looking chair, and a few bookshelves filled with occult lore and scientific texts forms a comfortable reading nook. A rather plain rug sits upon the floor and artwork on the walls depicting various scientific or medical procedures relating to the apothecary's field of work

entries.name: 2. Laboratory
entries: This large chamber can be set up for a variety of alchemical and scientific experiments, involving both organic and inorganic materials. It may even be appropriate for creating magic items.

Shelves of samples and equipment line the walls with long tables in the middle of the room, each equipped with alchemical gear, or strange instruments for performing scientific experiments and research.

entries.name: 3. Library
entries: This library contains rare and exotic works on medicine, occult magic, science, nature, and may contain forbidden lore or secrets mortals were not meant to know.

entries.name: 4. Operating Theatre
entries: This grim chamber is a horrifying laboratory dedicated to mad science. At the center of the room is a pedestal in the middle of a large magic circle. Four sconces bearing {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} surround the raised pedestal. A massive dissection slab flanked by two great machines crackling with arcane energy resonate with the slab, which sits atop the pedestal. There are sets of dissection tables all about the room, with various corpses and bodies in different states of dismemberment placed upon them. Along one of the walls are several jars containing preserved brains and body parts.

entries.name: 5. Materials Storage
entries: This organized chamber contains chemicals and reagents used for the apothecary's work.

entries.name: 6. Subject Containment
entries: A prison by any other terms, these rooms are used to hold test subjects for the apothecary's work—or their failed experiments.

entries.name: 7. Morgue
entries: A room for storing the dead, often for use in grim experiments.

entries.name: 8. Patient Ward
entries: This room is filled with beds for the apothecary's more willing patients to convalesce and rest.

entries.name: 9. Waiting Room
entries: Some apothecaries run functional businesses where patients will come to seek their aid. The waiting room is a place for those waiting to see the doctor to pass time.

entries.name: Notable Apothecary Lairs in the World of Drakkenheim
Altbruke University
entries: One of the continent's finest institutions for higher learning, Altbruke University offers programs in the humanities, natural philosophy, mathematics, physics, and medicine. However, the curriculum at Altbruke University concerns mundane topics only. Under the Edicts of Lumen, none save the Amethyst Academy may operate a school for instruction in the arcane.

Nevertheless, the school is home to the Guild of Conscientious Practice and Scientific Discovery, an organization of philosophers, scientists, and doctors, who share knowledge, collaborate on research, and clandestinely operate an occult study of apothecary magic. The guild took advantage of the political turmoil in the years following the Westemr Civil War to work largely unnoticed by school authorities, amongst the nobility, and, most importantly, the Amethyst Academy. Working in hiding for almost a decade, the guild instructed promising students in occult magic and repurposed the subterranean chambers below the Lena Leuven Laboratory of Medicine and Natural Philosophy into an extensive secret school and lab.

The intense secrecy surrounding their hidden labs enabled several guild members to conduct truly dark and horrifying experiments, contrary to the group's mission statement. The psychic manipulator Dr. Sina Rienks, aided in concealing the mutagenic experiments of Dr. Johanna Veers, while Anton Jonge conspired to create deathly pathogens. It may have continued had not the reanimated experiments of one {@creature Dr. Everett Freed, Reanimator|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Dr. Everett Freed} begun wreaking havoc on the student body.

entries.name: Mobius Facility
entries: Rumors throughout Westemr speak of a facility deep in the twisting peaks of the Drakeclaw Mountains. Known as the Mobius Facility, its location is kept secret by the apothecaries who wish to hide their research from the rest of the world. It is said that the Mobius Facility's internal structure is built around optical illusions, making it a mind-bending place to navigate. Inside the deep lab's seemingly endless rooms are scientific atrocities that push the boundaries of fathomable knowledge.

entries.name: Lento College
entries: Lento College in Caspia is known mostly for its arts programs. The school produces many of the continent's well-known bards, but it also provides standard studies, including a few small labs and science facilities. Although not as well known as Altbruke, a small group of Caspian apothecaries formed their own research facilities after graduating from Lento College.

entries.name: Liberio
entries: The arts and sciences flourish in the Free City of Liberio, sponsored by wealthy aristocracy and merchants who flock to the city. Many apothecaries see themselves as artists, and they thrive in Liberio. The cosmopolitan city has no shortage of ailments, and skilled doctors readily establish themselves by treating sick sailors, healing injured commonfolk, or doting on a vain noble. Liberio is a mercantile crossroads; apothecaries here have no trouble procuring rare ingredients and materials, especially those of a less-than-legal nature thanks to the smuggling and piracy flowing from the city across the Middle Sea.

Liberio's political independence also means apothecaries can work more openly here than anywhere else in the continent, despite the direct presence of the Amethyst Academy and their Enigma Ziggurat. Interestingly, occultists in the city find working under the Academy's nose beneficial. First, the mages' presence means that willing adventurers and rare curiosities pass through the city regularly, especially delerium. Second, Academy mages seem to tolerate apothecaries in Liberio, unwilling to disturb the peace where their great stronghold sits. Indeed, it's not unknown for apothecaries and Academy guildmages to gather, trade, and occasionally collaborate here.

Although many apothecaries operate their own clinics, the city is home to one of the few purpose-built hospitals in the Continent: the Sanatoria Obscura, led by two prolific apothecaries, Isidora Venefica and Lucius Noctis. The hospital none-the-less is the subject of many rumors about what happens in the extensive morgue and research labs housed beneath the public-facing medical wings.

entries.name: Southern Reach
entries: The coastal side of the Southern Reach is far enough away from the rules and regulations of Elyria, that although those in Lumen consider the Southern Reach part of their nation of Elyria, they hold little control or sway over what goes on beyond the Witherbleach Desert. Those in the Southern Reach have, for a long time, considered themselves their own separate nation. One that is free from the rule of many of the other nations, and very seldom looked at even for maintaining the Edicts of Lumen. The Black Lambda Facility, one of the largest facilities of science and research resides in the base of the Pale Teeth Mountains. Dozens of apothecaries practice and study here, performing occult rituals, dangerous science, and brutal experiments.

data.name: Chapter 6: Court of the Night
entries: {@b Night Born Undeath}

They appear in a lords court, a tribunal, a ceremony. Just ready to suck the life out of some prominent member of society or influence some noble. What a bunch of shadowy cowards.
