I do my best work in the daylight, and with an audience. These leeches go after the rich and powerful but I'd like to see them face a true Caspian.

Hidden within the political squabbles of the continental nobility is an ancient conspiracy swathed in darkness and bound by blood. A few highborn houses have been ruled by vampires for centuries, their family leaders gifted with undead immortality yet cursed with sanguine cravings. Secretly preying upon their mortal subjects whilst concealing their undead nature from their noble peers, these vampire lords have in turn transformed their heirs, lieutenants, courtesans, and staff into obedient spawn to secure their lineage and loyalty.

Yet their dark ambitions do not end there, for the vampire aristocrats desire complete control and total domination over the people of the continent. Together, thirteen vampire-ruled noble houses established a sinister cabal and shadow government collectively known as the Court of the Night, a shadowy alliance that aims to influence and manipulate political affairs and eventually seize power. The Court of the Night works in the shadows, pulling noble puppet strings across the continent. Originally founded in the kingdom of Westemr, the Court of the Night's influence has spread, infiltrating the noble ranks of neighboring lands such as Caspia and Elyria.

The elusive vampires have managed to keep their plot undiscovered for hundreds of years. During this time, however, a few amongst the court and even entire vampire households have been exposed—sometimes by intrepid monster hunters, other times by the devout paladins of the Silver Order, or occasionally by the mages of the Amethyst Academy, or astute mortal nobles. While many exposed vampires have been eradicated, others have managed to escape and reestablish themselves elsewhere under new identities.

The few mortals who have come dangerously close to unraveling the full extent of the vampire conspiracy have faced grim fates. Some have disappeared without a trace, swallowed by the shadows that cloak the Court of the Night's operations. These unfortunate souls stumbled too deep into the vampires' secrets, provoking a lethal response to ensure their silence. Others, however, suffer a fate arguably worse than death: they are captured and transformed into thralls by the vampires. Stripped of their will and enslaved, these thralls serve their vampire masters, their former lives obliterated by vampiric compulsion and dark magic. This sinister practice ensures not only the continuation of the vampire's secrecy but also a sadistic reinforcement of their dominance over humans.

However, within the secretive bounds of the Court of the Night, an atmosphere of constant suspicion and ambition breeds endless betrayal and intrigue. The vampire households, each led by ancient and cunning undead lords, vie fiercely for influence and control. Alliances are as fleeting as they are strategic, formed to stabilize power or to execute swift betrayals when advantageous. The stakes of this internal power struggle are exceedingly high, as supremacy within the Court can grant unparalleled control over both the vampire and human realms. These internal conflicts often manifest in covert sabotages, assassinations, and intricate plots that further complicate the dynamics within the Court, making the hierarchy within this shadow government both volatile and deadly.

entries.name: Vampiric Origins
entries: Legends claim the vampiric curse first fell upon mortals who, hungry to extend their own lives, fed upon other's life essence through sanguine rites. Though they attained their coveted power and immortality, these first vampires were forever banished to the shadows for their dark predations. Ancient stories amongst those who keep the Old Faith attribute the curse to the fickle goddesses Morrigan, who laid the punishment upon heretical druids blasphemously seeking immortality in her name. Amongst the Faith of the Sacred Flame, vampirism represents a twisted and fallen soul utterly consumed by darkness and bloody impulses, one so completely shunned by the light they are destroyed by its very presence.

Though vampirism is unquestionably a curse, it is one that brings great power through unnatural abilities. As such, ambitious mortals have themselves often sought out the curse willingly. Unscrupulous warlocks have made dark pacts with demonic entities and become vampires in the process. Indeed, the tyrannical Sorcerer-Kings were masters of blood magic, wielding dark power to imbue their bloodlines with draconic and fiendish lineages. Many amongst them sought to establish an eternal empire through some form of immortality. Academy scholars speculate that several Sorcerer-Kings attained undeath through vampirism or lichdom, though their dreams of everlasting rule ended in betrayal by their own rivals.

As the Faith of the Sacred Flame rose in Elyria, these vampires and surviving blood mages fled its spreading light for other lands where they could more safely hide in the shadows. Meanwhile, in the deep forests of the lands which would one day become Westemr, descendants of the druids cursed by Morrigan still practiced their sanguine rites in secret, until a bloodthirsty ruler emerged who sought their cursed power for himself.

The legendary Vladimir von Drakken was a peerless swordman and ruthless warlord born in the late sixth century, who forged the nation of Westemr through bloody conquest over three decades of brutal invasion. Vladimir von Drakken carved a gore-streaked path through his neighbors and built a kingdom born out of genocidal massacres and brutal subjugation. He established himself as the Lord of Castle Drakken, naming Drakkenheim for his household. History tells that Vladimir von Drakken ruled as a despot and had imperial ambitions upon his neighbors in Elyria and Caspia. However, he was cut down by his rebellious daughter, Carmen, who succeeded her father's throne. While sensational stories about Vladimir von Drakken's bloodthirsty nature are scrawled into the margins of history, no records remain that tell the full story: Vladimir von Drakken was in fact a powerful ascendant vampire.

Two decades into his conquests, Vladimir von Drakken became paranoid that he would be betrayed and usurped by one of his lieutenants, or worse, by one of his own family members. Fearing his own death most of all, he sought out forbidden magic to grant him power and immortality. He found it in the form of vampirism. Deep within the Brachenwald, he was transformed in an unholy ritual known as the Sanguine Rite.

When he returned to Castle Drakken, Vladimir von Drakken turned his vassals into vampire spawn so that none could ever stand against him, holding them as thralls in his Court of the Night. Over the next ten years, he continued his cruel and merciless campaign to dominate the lands of Westemr and beyond. Although he was struck down by his daughter, many members of his Court of the Night survived to carry on his legacy.

entries.name: Calling of the Court
entries: Originally comprised by the surviving vampiric vassals and lieutenants of Vladimir von Drakken, the court has grown over the centuries, both in power and influence, silently manipulating events and entities from behind the scenes as its members dispersed themselves across the continent.

Once every thirteen years, a malevolent meeting of the Court of the Night is held. During the founding decades of the Court, the families gathered in the Brachenwald of Westemr, at the ancient grove where the Druids of Morrigan transformed Vladimir von Drakken into a vampire. However, a more organized and central location space was needed as the vampiric court grew and the families spread throughout the continent and beyond.

Now, the secret meeting is held in the heart of the Free City of Liberio at Rossovino Manor. The cosmopolitan port and independent city-state is located on the Middle Sea, and represents a melting pot between the major nations of the continent. Given its inherent bustle of travel and trade, Liberio is no stranger to fantastic sights and sounds. Visitors from faraway places, mages, and all sorts of strange folk and adventurous types gather in the democratic city. Vampires can easily conceal their presence here and find no shortage of activities or appetizers during the warm nights in Liberio.

Each vampire family dispatches a delegation to attend once every thirteen years to discuss the next steps for the court. Though they often send grand contingents of vampires, spawn, and thralls, each family chooses two representatives to speak on their behalf. The vampires meet for nights, punctuated with dark revelry, macabre masquerades, and grisly feats which stretch into the long hours of the night. During these events, the vampires openly discuss their plots, their triumphs, their struggles, and how their goals may further the Court of the Night's longevity and prosperity. They review their plots and deception for their continued infiltration of the Mortal World.

Amongst the vampires, the Calling of the Court is a neutral ground, where all families must put aside infighting, backstabbing, past betrayals, and schemes against each other under penalty of true death. Yet, the vampires are conniving and clever—the Calling of the Court is the time to strengthen their shared goals and gain the support they need. If a rival or two can be eliminated before or after the gathering itself... so much the better.

entries.name: Vampiric Ideologies
entries: Although to mortal eyes the Court of the Night appears to be a united faction, in truth, the vampiric nobility is deeply divided internally. Amongst their number have emerged three competing ideologies.

entries.name: Resurrectionists
entries: Steadfast in their oaths of eternal fealty to Vladimir von Drakken, the Resurrectionists plot nothing more than the return of the legendary vampire. Keepers of lore and ancient artifacts, the Resurrectionists are the most reclusive. They dream of the return of the mighty vampire lord, when he will bathe the world in blood and establish a true empire of the night, where mortals are lorded over like livestock to feed the ambition and power of the vampiric nobility.

entries.name: Inheritors
entries: The Inheritors arose in response to the slow and ponderous pace of the Resurrectionists plans. Impatient to await a long-dead lord of the night to return and command them, the Inheritors seek to claim the legacy of Vladimir von Drakken for themselves. Instead of returning the dread lord to power, each Inheritor instead dreams of usurping the might of the Vampire King for themselves. The Inheritors are a fractious and scheming organization. Each member ultimately wishes to rise in power over their peers, and so their grand plans are often fraught with subterfuge and sabotage.

entries.name: Libertines
entries: Growing in power and influence amongst the Court of the Night are a contingent of vampire lords who reject both the old ways of the Resurrectionists, and the scheming politics of the Inheritors. Instead, the Libertines seek to live out their undeath with lavish decadence and unholy debauchery, unfettered by the morals and responsibilities of mortal life. They crave wealth and power only because it fuels and supports their existence of excess. Avarice, lust, and pride prompts the Libertines to defend themselves and their holdings, often using the mortals they live so easily among to do their bidding.

entries.name: Vampire Strains
entries: There exist three main strains of vampiric affliction and two sub-strains. Each cause different physical manifestations and behavioral impulses, while granting diverse vampiric abilities. All three strains are present in the Court of the Night; typically, all the members of a household possess the same strain, though the strains occasionally mingle amongst one another and many courts and houses contain vampires from different strains.
Regardless of their strain, all vampires possess the same classic vampire weakness: vulnerability to sunlight.
These monsters have a face only my blade could love.

entries.name: Vampyre

entries: The regal vampire standing before you scoffs and smiles devilishly as its fangs protrude. Its eyes take on a crimson hue as it gracefully lifts into the air, hovering slowly towards you, its cape billowing behind it. The well-dressed noble who stood before you is gone, now revealing its true form: that of a hungry vampire.

The Vampyre consider themselves the purest descendants of Vladimir von Drakken, believing they were crafted in his perfect image. They appear almost humanoid until they choose to reveal themselves and are the most well equipped for infiltrating human settlements. With their charm and wit, they blend in by standing out, becoming important members of the communities they intend to take over. Like a parasite, they infiltrate, spread, and devour until they have claimed the entire settlement, leaving behind a husk now filled with an undead army bent to the will of the vampiric family.

Many of the Vampyrs are positioned as powerful nobles in some of the greatest cities on the continent, and through them the Court of the Night has eyes and ears in every major decision, plot, or scheme made throughout the continent. Unbeknownst to the vast majority, the Vampyre are everywhere, leading the Court of the Night in their efforts for complete domination.

This is the most common and well-known strain of vampirism, the Vampyre are often represented by the game statistics for {@creature Vampire|XMM|Vampires} found in the {@book Core Rules|XMM}. These vampires appear as regular humans with sullen and pallid flesh, sharpened features, crimson-hued eyes, and sharp fangs that they use to feed on blood. They possess greatly enhanced physical endurance, strength, speed, and intellect thanks to their vampiric curse. Their subtle and easily concealed features allow most Vampyres to blend in with mortal society. Many Vampyres consider themselves the most pure and refined of their kind, and many claim to be blood-borne descendants from Vladimir von Drakken, meaning they were transformed by the legendary vampire personally or turned by another vampire who can trace their own vampiric lineage back to Vladimir von Drakken.

The Vampyre are at the forefront of the Court of the Night's infiltration of civilization. They lurk in the shadows of established communities, pulling the strings in major cities throughout the continent. Using their cunning illusion and wit, the Vampyre have masterfully built a network of noble vampires leading the court in their goals of bringing about a revolution of blood.

entries.name: Nosferatu

entries: The creature before you is humanoid in shape, appearing almost elven; they are slender and tall, with pointed ears. However, their complexion is sickly pale, and their sunken back crimson eyes give their gaunt face an almost skeletal appearance. Their fingers are gnarled elongated and end in dirty clawed nails. As the creature opens its mouths, its teeth are all fine points, razor sharp.

Amongst the Druids of the Old God Morrigan, several heretical sects emerged in ancient days, their origins shrouded in blood magic and sanguine rituals. These blood-drinking druids used magic to prolong their life indefinitely. They developed the vampiric curse that they shared amongst their small circles in the deep wilderness of the Brachenwald.

The Nosferatu are the descendants of these first druidic vampire cults. Over the centuries of blood drinking and sunlight aversion, they have developed extremely gaunt features, sunken eyes, and often skeletal appearances, pointed ears, and their teeth are all sharpened fangs.

Unlike their vampiric cousins, they cannot be killed by piercing the heart. They cannot enter a home without permission, cross a stream of running water, and are cursed to never see daylight again. More than most vampires, however, daylight destroys them almost instantly, so the Nosferatu tend to stick to shadows and dark places more than most.

entries.name: Nosferatu Traits
entries: Any vampire from the Nosferatu strain has the following traits.

entries.name: Cursed By Sunlight
entries: The Nosferatu takes 50 Radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and ability checks. If the Nosferatu is reduced to 0 Hit Points by sunlight, it erupts in flames and disintegrates in a matter of seconds, leaving nothing but a pile of ash. This trait replaces Sunlight Hypersensitivity.

entries.name: Creature of Shadows
entries: The Nosferatu is resistant to all damage except Radiant when they are in darkness.

items.name: Spellcasting
items.entry: The Nosferatu casts one of the following spells, using Charisma as their spellcasting ability

entries.name: Vrykolakas

entries: The beast before you is half man and half bat. Its bald head has two bat-like ears and beady red eyes above a snout and a fanged mouth. It walks in a hunched gaunt, sometimes pulling itself forward on its burly forearms with long taloned claws, while its legs are shorter with wide-set clawed feet.

These monstrous vampires have taken on the bat-like qualities of vampirism to a place where they are no longer recognizable as humanoid. They still speak, walk, and carry themselves as well as other vampires, but their demeanor tends to be more ravenous and enraged. Rather than drinking blood, the Vrykolakas vampires gain their energy by consuming living flesh. They are more prone to outwardly attack their prey, and feast upon them while they scream.

The Vrykolakas vampires hunt in packs, and rather than hide themselves with illusions, they live in secluded castles and remote isolated caves. They sweep into small farming communities and villages in the dead of long winter nights and devour every living creature they find. There are some reports of entire communities going missing overnight, with nothing left but blood splatters in the snow.
The Vrykolakas vampires will change their appearance to appear as more humanoid when engaging in affairs with non vampires, but prefer their more animalistic appearance when they are on the hunt.

These vampires developed from a twisted form of undeath. The vampiric curse creates an eternal hunger for mortal blood, and a vampire who does not feed regularly develops more monstrous qualities over time. The Vrykolakas developed over years of starvation amongst sects of vampires, and as they became more twisted forms, the vampire spawn they would produce carried that hunger, and developed a taste for raw flesh, and could not come back from their monstrous nature.

entries.name: Vrykolakas Traits
entries: Any vampire from the Vrykolakas strain has the following traits.

entries.name: Bloodthirsty
entries: The Vrykolakas has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against targets with the {@area Bloodied|8e7|x} or {@area Bleeding|8e6|x} conditions.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, the Vrykolakas can move up to its speed toward a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} creature that it can see.

entries.name: Blindsense
entries: A Vrykolakas vampire has {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Spawn
entries: These lesser vampires use the {@creature Vampire Spawn|XMM} game statistics from the {@book Core Rules|XMM}. Vampire spawn are intermediate, they are under the control of the vampire who created them, but not yet granted full independence from their master. However, many develop unique abilities to fulfill their roles. The {@creature Crimson Knight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Dark Confessor|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Grim Custodian|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, {@creature Night Blade|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, and {@creature Sanguine Witch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} all represent vampire spawn with specialized capabilities used to achieve their master's goals.

A vampire spawn becomes a full-strain vampire when they can partake in the blood of a full-blooded vampire. Often this is a gift granted by their own creator, and these stray spawn are often led to believe that only the blood of their creator can grant them their full vampiric powers. However, this is not the case: consuming the blood of any vampire will accomplish complete the transformation. A vampire spawn whose master is destroyed regains their autonomy but does not become a full-strain vampire.

entries.name: Ascendant Vampire
entries: Legend claims that a fourth strain of vampirism exists: the Ascendant Vampire. This mighty form is supposedly granted vast power encompassing all three lesser strains. Furthermore, it is claimed that such a vampire could walk unharmed in the light of the sun, and that their every word is a command to any other vampire. Members of the Court of the Night know this is no mere legend; Vladimir von Drakken was the first, and thus far, only vampire to gain this power. None since have been able to attain this form, though many have sought it over the centuries.

entries.name: Vampire Families
entries: The Court of the Night was founded by thirteen vampiric noble houses. Although some of these families have been uncovered, and in some cases eradicated, the dead houses' legacy lives on through vassals and thralls. The remaining families all hold positions of importance within the current political landscape of the continent, and unbeknownst to the wider world, are subtly manipulating the ebb and flow of power within the continent. In addition, several lesser families have sprung up over the centuries as a vassals in service or cadet branches of a higher household.
Usually I love a free meal, but these are family dinners I'd rather not be part of.

entries.name: House Kleinkessel
entries: House Kleinkessel is a cadet branch of House von Kessel, who were in turn themselves distant descendants of House von Drakken. The household formed shortly after Helena I von Kessel took the throne to separate the royal household from their extended family in matters of succession. Nevertheless, the Kleinkessels have perhaps one of the stronger claims to the throne of Westemr since they can trace their ancestry back to Helena I. In fact, when the main House von Kessel line ended during the Civil War, they took up the royal family's ancestral castle in Kesselholm.

Constance Kleinkessel is in fact the sister of Helena I. Originally known as Camilla von Kessel, she has passed through a series of identities to hide her vampiric nature. Every few decades, she marries a hapless nobleman, slowly draining his life force so that he appears to expire from old age. Shortly thereafter, her so-called daughter inherits the estate and the cycle continues. During the Civil War, Constance Kleinkessel used her vampiric abilities to manipulate and scheme alongside Cecilia von Kessel and Lord Commander Elias Drexel to plot the murder of Mannfred von Kessel. She had planned to follow through and murder her co-conspirators, but the subsequent death of Cecilia von Kessel was an unexpected development. Constance had been planning to target Cecilia's future children with her replacement scheme to seize the throne of Westemr.

Constance also witnessed the impact of delerium firsthand when a fleeing family of vampires came to her for help after the meteor fell. Impressed by its potency and effects on vampiric blood, but disheartened by the negative impact it had, she began studying the strange rocks, buying delerium in large quantities and experimenting on her lesser thralls, attempting to make a new breed of vampire. Her creation, she hopes, would be strong enough to rise above all the others.

Since undead creatures are not immune to the effects of delerium contamination, Constance Kleinkessel befriended and made close alliances with her Apothecary, the malfeasant wizard and mad chemist Deidrick Mors. Since then, they have been creating an army of delerium-infused vampires in secret in the chambers under Kesselholm Keep.

entries.name: House Crossbruke
entries: Baron Viktor Crossbruke was a steadfast captain who served Vladimir von Drakken in life, and was among the first of Vladimir von Drakken's vampire spawn, and among the first the Ascendant Vampire granted the boon of full-strain vampirism. Victor Crossbruke survived Carmen von Drakken's rebellion against her father, and was instrumental in securing Vlad's remains in the aftermath. He has been dedicated to the cause of restoring his old master ever since.

Viktor founded the village of Crossbruke four miles southwest of Drakkenheim. After Vladamir was struck down, he quietly secluded himself into a life managing the sleepy village. When the city of Drakkenheim was destroyed, much of the surrounding area was left a corrupted landscape. The farmland all withered and died, the weather turned into a constant overcast gray, and daily rainfall on dead crops meant there was little left for those within several miles of the cursed city.

The village of Crossbruke was assumed to be abandoned. The ghost town, however, was not. Viktor seized the opportunity to transform Crossbruke's villagers into vampires and other undead in the aftermath of the fall of Drakkenheim. He maintained the illusion by traveling to Drakkenheim and meeting with Elias Drexel of the Hooded Lanterns. Viktor desired to remain in the town of his namesake, and offered it to the Hooded Lanterns as a meeting point and supply chain. Crossbruke served as a military camp where Hooded Lanterns could stop for the night before bringing wagons of food, water, armaments, and other supplies to Drakkenheim. Viktor was also a prominent benefactor in the multiple Hooded Lantern expeditions into the city, and remains their primary noble contributor.

The Hooded Lanterns have a saying amongst their ranks: Crossbruke Quitters. The first task of a new recruit is always to be stationed in Crossbruke to see that the trade route remains open, and to do counts of goods passing through. It's common that amongst every batch of new recruits, a handful of them do not last the first week. They disappear without a word in the middle of the night, assumed to have abandoned their post in the dreary town, unable to cut it for what it means to be a Lantern. What the Lanterns do not know is that the recruits never leave. They are taken in the night by the vampires hiding in the shadows and turned into thralls or undead servants for Viktor's secret undead army.

entries.name: House Jovovich
entries: As vassals of House Joplin, the Jovovich name has been held in high regard in Caspia for some time. Never as notable as the six great houses, the Jovovichs were a small noble house who bided their time to rise to power. The former marquis, Revati Jordan, held the position in Duelcross for seventy years. In that time, Revati had six children, which were assumed to carry on her legacy. In her fading years, Carina Jovovich befriended Revati and the two became very close. In the time they spent together, Revati began to fall ill. The children grew suspicious of Carina, who encouraged them to keep their distance, and she would tend to their mother's needs as she passed. In the final days, the children report Revati spoke as if possessed. They said she stopped sounding and acting like herself. When she passed, she left everything to Carina. Her wealth, her house, and her servants all went to Carina—the children were left with nothing.

The Jovovich children promptly began an investigation into Carina, believing she somehow fooled their mother into leaving her the family's wealth. Strangely, all six children passed away from illness within the next year and the Jovovich family became one of the most powerful lesser houses in all of Caspia. In truth, the children are alive as thralls, chained up in Carina's dungeons below her castle, where they are used as a supply of blood for her and her other thralls. She controlled and manipulated Revati and fed on her until she died, combining the two families' wealth ensured the Jovoviches a position of power in Caspia. Along with her ties to the Joplin household, Carina Jovovich may very well be one of the most influential people in the nation.

entries.name: House Devero
entries: The Devero family acquired great wealth during the Glimmer Mountain gold rush and established themselves in Geldstadt as a prominent noble house. Their riverside manor is known as the wealthiest and most opulent house in an already wealthy city. Known for collecting rare artifacts, and old tomes, the house is somewhat a museum of ancient literature and historical antiques. The walls are lined with world renowned paintings. Four times a year, Gorman opens his house to the public, allowing paid tours where he boasts about the history of the items in his collection.

The Devero family also were early investors in Altbruke University, and one of the main study halls is named after them. Many Devero, and their cadet branch the Veers, have studied at Altbruke, becoming some of the most renowned apothecaries in the continent. Few would guess the deep connections the court has in the study of alchemy, and the few renowned vampiric apothecaries that operate in secret.

Through the centuries of his family's longevity, Gorman has managed to acquire nearly half the land in Geldstadt, and now the main strip of shops, studios, taverns, and inns all pay high rent to the Devero family for the privilege of being on the main road in the wealthiest city in Westemr. Because the Devero's own so much of the land, they do not need to be invited in to prey on their tenants. Rumors amass among the shop owners and late night talks at the Inns of bats in the city, and people seeing figures standing over their beds in the middle of the night.

entries.name: House Wolfenbach
entries: Vassals of House von Baden, House Wolfenbach have held their position in the city of Drannsmund for some time. Known as elite sea captains, their vessel the Crimson Fang sails the Crystal Coast, fending off raiders from Skye.

Unknown to the people of Drannsmund, the ship raises a different flag, one of blood-soaked teeth instead of Drannsmund's crest. House Wolfenbach defeated a fleet of raiders from Skye some years ago and reanimated them, using them as their proxy crews. These undead warriors now crew a fleet of ships who stay out at sea, away from the eyes of the city. They are known to send their ships down as far as the Elyrian coast to plunder seaside villages, and none realize the connection the house has to Drannsmund.

They also have established a cadet branch in Skye and have raided many small villages within the island, claiming the forgotten villages as towns of undead. Winchester Wolfenbach hopes to raise an undead fleet that could sail the oceans and conquer the world. Winchester believes himself the true inheritor of the power of Vladimir von Drakken—where Vladimir failed, Winchester will not.

entries.name: House Graveworth
entries: House Graveworth is an ancient bloodline that does not partake in the typical schemes of the Court of the Night. They are more monstrous in appearance due to the Vrykolakas strain, and do very little to hide their traits. Rather than infiltrating a community and sneaking in the shadows, the Graveworth family have an old castle deep in the woods north of Dregden's Ferry. There they rule over the wilds, hunting loggers, miners, hunters, and travelers heading along the Dawnbreaker trail. They only use illusions to disguise themselves as regular humanoids when they need to enter a town to meet with other vampires, such as attending the Court of the Night, and only ever when in public. They drop their guises whenever they can, feeling like hiding themselves is a mark of shame amongst the vampires, and that their form is perfect as it is.

The monsters of the Iron Woods are now a folktale passed around the Eastern Vale, and many steer clear of the woods after sunset. But there are always those who venture too deep or get lost in the thick pines and muddy grounds. Those who dwell too late are often never heard from again.

entries.name: House Rossovino
entries: The only known halfling family of vampires, House Rossovino descends from Milos Rossovino, the steward who loyally served Vladimir von Drakken. After Vladimir's fall, the Rossovino family made its way to Liberio, establishing themselves as wealthy moneylenders, bankers, and benefactors of arts and culture. They quickly became well known nobles in Liberio, accumulating incredible wealth and building a manor house rivaling most kings on the continent. Yet these efforts are not for vanity or personal power, as the Rossovinos command considerable power amongst the Court of the Night and have led the efforts to resurrect Vladimir von Drakken. To further collaboration between the vampire houses, the Rossovinos constructed a massive secret auditorium below their manor where the Court of the Night gathers once every thirteen years.

Those who borrow money from them and fail to pay it back in time mysteriously go missing in the night, often ending up as thralls working in the secret depths of the Rossovino manor. They use their manor home as a lush museum for ancient art and old artifacts, and no one questions a rich halfling family of bankers collecting old tomes and art, but really, they are searching for relics that can aid in their plots and bring about vampiric domination.

entries.name: House Crane
entries: House Crane is the only surviving vampiric family in Elyria, and notably stand apart from their rivals in the Court of the Night: the family is deeply committed to tenets of the Sacred Flame in spite of their cursed nature. Forming their own shadowy cult, the family's strange faith preaches that darkness and light exist together in careful balance, and that through blood, both shadow and flame coalesce into transcendence. They revere undead creatures as holy guardians whose role is to safeguard life from otherworldly and demonic forces which aim to utterly destroy it. Their cult attracts mortal followers who partake in so-called sacred rituals in secret chapels where they willingly offer a blood-tithe to a vampire-priest, teaching that this is a sacred offering which shows respect for the great curse and responsibility borne by undead who protect the living. Their agents operate throughout Elyria as the secret Society of the Bat, aiming to convince other undead creatures to take up their purportedly noble cause. Although House Crane's goals are noble-minded, their peers on the Courts of the Night tolerate their strange religion since it still situates undead as the masters over mortals.
Too many family names to remember, I have a hard enough time remembering the 6 Caspian Houses.

entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Vampires are often creatures of refined taste, elegance, and opulence, but require secretive places to indulge their dark desires and violent passions. It is not unheard for lower vampires to dwell in abandoned homes or secluded caves. But more often vampires attempt to spend their years acquiring great wealth and working their way to the higher positions of societies. Noble houses, manors, and castles are all common places for a vampire to make their home. Many of the locations of the Court of the Night are a complete mystery. It stands to reason that nearly any lonely castle, secluded town, misty fishing village, or abandoned home could be a space for nighttime rituals, dark offerings, and secret meetings amongst vampiric nobility.

entries.name: Service of the Dead
entries: A vampire's first order of business is to clean house once they have acquired a suitable castle or manor house. This usually involves draining the blood of the staff, guards, and any other people who frequent the castle. Instead turning them into thralls, knights, or assassins. A vampire castle is usually occupied by multiple forms of undead. Sometimes skeletons or zombies can perform menial tasks. More intelligent and human-looking thralls provide the vampires eyes and ears in the surrounding towns, and allow them to keep the guise of normalcy throughout the castle.

entries.name: Illusions Hide Decay
entries: Often vampires will use powerful illusion magic to hide the blood, refuse, and general disarray of their homes. They may even disguise themselves or their staff with illusion magic to ensure they appear as normal as possible. Vampires are all about trickery, charm, and deceit, and will use any magic at their disposal to ensure their secret remains hidden from the public. Those who happen to see through the disguises are often moments from joining the ranks of the vampire's thralls themselves.

entries.name: Treasures and Trinkets
entries: A vampire's castle is often filled with opulent and ornate decorative treasure. Fine rugs, unique paintings, rare books and tomes, vases, statues, and jewelry. With their long lifespans they tend to acquire wealth and are avid collectors of items that few mortals would be able to obtain in a single lifetime.

entries.name: Known Lairs
entries: Vampires of all sorts can be found throughout Westemr, with several families stretching into Caspia and Elyria. The most prominent name associated with the Court of the Night is House von Drakken. Although it is rumored that it has seeped into other noble names as well.

entries.name: Rossovino Manor
entries: When the Court of the Night is called to meet, they gather at Rossovino Manor in the Free City of Liberio. Located in the hilltops outside the city proper, when Rossovino Manor was constructed nearly 250 years ago, it was among the largest estates in the region. Now, the manor sits inconspicuously among many grand villas in the countryside near Liberio, able to keep its secrets without drawing any unwanted attention. The sight of several black carriages drawing up to it once every thirteen years is thought no stranger than any of the galas, balls, or parties thrown by their wealthy neighbors. Indeed, the Rossovinos are a well-regarded house who play host to many gatherings. The meeting of the Court of the Night is a wonderful opportunity to invite some of their mortal peers to join the exclusive society.

Deep below the sprawling estate lies a secret dungeon accessed via the great library. Playing the right notes on a baroque piano (a specific chord known well to children of the night: G F# B E) causes the back wall of a massive fireplace to open into a stone staircase that spirals down. There, a vaulted chamber houses a great auditorium which can fit a hundred guests. Round tables with lavish chairs fill the chamber, decorative skull-adorned chandeliers hang from the high ceiling, and ancient flags bearing the thirteen family crests line the gray stone walls. A hundred candles and torches alight with everlasting magical flames flicker and illuminate the room, and a large stage and podium sit at the far end with crimson curtains set behind it. The feasts are supplied by a wine-cellar stocked with blood wine and a pantry filled with preserved hearts, with the many bottles labeled like vintages of the year it was bottled and the surname of the mortal who provided it. Appropriately, the high rafters house several bats that flitter about and add to the macabre atmosphere. It is here in this dark chamber that the Court of the Night holds its midnight seances.

entries.name: Brachenwald Grove
entries: This ancient grove is the place where the dark druids of Morrigan performed the Sanguine Rite on Vladimir von Drakken. In the depths of the forest is a place where the thick trees create a canopy over an old grove. No sunlight penetrates through the old branches. There, nestled between moss-caked cliffs, is a circle of standing stones. They rise up out of the earth covered in ancient symbols and dried blood. Thorny, blood-red vines wrap around them and twist like veins through the grove. In the central clearing is an old stone tablet set out like a stage, covered in splashes of blood. A series of caves along the cliff faces are makeshift hovels for druids to sleep and rest.

entries.name: Kesselholm
entries: The city of Kesselholm has recently fallen victim to a curse. The castle staff don't seem to be present during the day. No one sees the nobility anymore, many townsfolk are complaining of strange nightmares, and odd shapes in the dark. The Kleinkessels rule over Kesselholm as a cadet branch of House von Kessel, which itself has ties to the von Drakkens. So naturally there are rumors abound on the possible cause of all these mysteries.

entries.name: Crossbruke Castle
entries: The lonely castle sits atop a hill in the ghost town of Crossbruke. A dark husk of its former glory, the dark and dreary keep lays decaying in the decrepit, rain-soaked village. The town itself is mostly deserted, save for a Hooded Lanterns encampment on the edge where a series of reinforced houses and an old barn form a makeshift military outpost. A line of wagons carrying goods and cargo to Drakkenheim are hitched while scouts survey and count the contents to ensure delivery to their comrades in Drakkenheim.

Aside from the small bonfire the Lanterns keep, the only other light in the town comes from the uppermost windows of the old castle, where the dim candlelight signifies Lord Crossbruke's presence. The town is prone to eerie noises, bats, and strange movements in the dark streets and hidden corners. Everyone who stays in Crossbruke describes a general feel of unease, and the itching sensation of being watched.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Vampires of the Court of the Night are patient predators, who strike when the situation lies in their favor. As the name implies, they are better suited to battles at night, or in the dark. They will seldom be foolish enough to fight outside during the day. Vampires are smart and have lived for centuries by not taking unneeded risks in battle. If they are discovered, and being hunted, they will draw the hunters to their castle, where their armies, minions, and dark corridors aid them. The vampire's thralls and soldiers create a slaughterhouse for those who believe they can face a vampire. If vampires fight in open military combat, they do so under moonlight.

The Court of the Night seldom operates alone. The entire operation of the court is to infiltrate a community and turn as many key members of that community to their will as possible. This includes transforming priests, mages, nobles, and any others they can into vampires. These vampire lords create {@creature Crimson Knight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Crimson Knights} from castle guards, {@creature Sanguine Witch|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Sanguine Witches} of court mages, {@creature Night Blade|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Night Blades} from assassins, {@creature Grim Custodian|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Grim Custodians} of loyal house servants, and a {@creature Dark Confessor|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} from local clergy. Vampiric nobles use these allies to incite a cult following to their cause, selecting any who wish to "ascend" into the ranks of being a vampire thrall. So, to face down a single Vampire Lord or Vampire Master, one must expect that they are facing an entire entourage of vampiric figures, complete with their own networks of thralls, cultists, and minions.

entries.name: Vampire Weaknesses
entries: All vampires in this chapter have the following mechanical traits unless otherwise indicated, such as through their specific vampiric strain.

items: {@b Forbiddance}. The vampire can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.
{@b Harmed by Running Water}. The vampire takes 20 Acid damage when it ends its turn in running water.

{@b Stake to the Heart.} If a Piercing weapon made of wood is driven into the vampire's heart while the vampire is {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} in its resting place, the vampire is {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB} until the stake is removed.
{@b Sunlight Hypersensitivity}. The vampire takes 20 Radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and ability checks.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Vampires are cunning and deceptive and when they choose to infiltrate a city or town—they do so with cunning plots and the benefit of time. Vampires do not age or die like other mortals; vampires construct plots that capture power for centuries. Once a vampire has selected a place to rule, they begin feeding on the townsfolk. Most begin only feeding as needed, leaving victims alive with nothing more than bad nightmares and strange bite marks. The vampire may turn some into thralls and soldiers for their army, allowing them to keep more eyes and ears around the area. Eventually the vampire's insidious plot comes together and they become leaders in the area, often from castles bearing noble names.

The Court of the Night does not stop at nobility. In many cases, as vampires seek to gain dominance over a settlement, their first task is to dismantle and control all pillars of a community. This means they create vampiric loyal servants of the castle stewards, the guard captains, even the Flamekeepers of the church, and court mages. If they can turn each known pillar of the community into a vampire, then there is nowhere for the townsfolk to turn that is not part of the expanding network of the Court of the Night.
Anyone that does that much business at night should be a suspect. When do they even get their beauty sleep?

entries.name: Charming Hosts
entries: Members of the Court of the Night conceal their undead nature from their mortal peers through several means. Many establish themselves in remote fiefs, claiming backwater domains and distant castles where their isolation allows them to simply go unnoticed. They seldom treat with others, but carefully comply with their feudal obligations to their liege lords. Over time, they slowly manipulate and turn their household staff, family members, and vassals into their own thralls, leaving none in any position of power to expose or stand against them. Others instead prefer to use misdirection and trickery to integrate with mortal society in a more conventional manner as befits their noble station.

Many vampires of the court hold lavish parties, open their castles to the public, and attempt to maintain a helpful and kind position in the community they inhabit. The more the people of their community look up to them, the easier time they have infiltrating it. They are charming and seductive, charismatic and powerful. Vampires carry themselves with a grandiose persona and have centuries of anecdotes, wit, and tales to weave into conversation.

entries.name: Masters of Deception and Illusion
entries: The Court of the Night maintains their position through powerful illusions, often kept in check by the court's {@creature Grim Custodian|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Grim Custodians}. They disguise their vampiric traits and hide the parts of their castles and manors that would give away their vampiric tendencies. The vampires weave such intricate lies and illusions that even a full on investigation of their homes, or a face-to-face study of one of the undead lords themselves, may reveal nothing out of the ordinary to those not sure where to look, or what to look for.

Due to their undead immortality, vampires do not appear to age, cannot sire heirs, nor will their reign end upon expected natural deaths. This prompts many to rely on a clever scheme whereby they play the role of both ruler and heir apparent: pretending at some times to be one or the other. Then, at an appointed time, the heir appears to announce the "death" of their "parent" and take up the title as ruler. Thus, many vampires have lived under several different names over the centuries, taking up a new identity every few decades as their own children or grandchildren to maintain the ruse of noble succession. Alternatively, some vampires opt to rule from the shadows, often appointing a favored thrall as a decoy or puppet for any meetings with mortal nobles.

entries.name: Purveyors of Fine and Rare Items
entries: With centuries of wealth and warfare under their belts, the Court of the Night often find themselves in noble positions. They enjoy these lifestyles of privilege and wealth, and take every opportunity to show off their collections of fine arts, tapestries, rugs, vases, weapons and armor, and anything else they have managed to procure in their long lifetimes.
Some artifacts and symbols of wealth in a vampire's manor may include:

items: The Book of the Dead, well preserved and on display.
Artwork by famous painters from Liberio.
A golden chalice said to be owned by Vladimir von Drakken himself.
The tooth of an ancient gold dragon.
An old tome titled Vampires Will Never Hurt You by famous vampire hunter Mik C. Roosevelt.
A jewel encrusted, double fingered ring in a glass case that dates back to the Age of the Sorcerer-Kings.
The complete writings of Stoker von Abram on the undead.
A perfectly smooth orb of delerium, encased in glass.
A blade once held by Karn the Conqueror
A taxidermied werewolf.

entries.name: Vampiric Cravings
entries: When a vampire grows hungry, they begin to manifest traits that may give them away to prying eyes. Vampires often try to be well fed when going out or engaging with mortals as to not reveal themselves. A hungry vampire who catches the scent of fresh mortal blood may begin to manifest certain attributes, including:

items: Eyes suddenly take on a crimson hue at the sight of blood
Nails suddenly extend by an inch, appearing sharper
Breath begins to come out as low growls and snarls
Teeth sharpen and they begin to salivate uncontrollably
Skin pales a few shades and tightens across the body
The face warps slightly into a more animalistic snout and fangs
The vampire cannot stop tapping their feet or fingers, and their eyes dart around manically
Bouts of anger and hostility seemingly out of nowhere

entries.name: Common Vampire Roleplaying Traits
entries: Giving your vampires roleplaying traits can help define what kind of vampire they are, and how they treat their allies and enemies. Below are some suggested roleplaying traits for Court of the Night vampires.

items: "I am a creature of few words; I let my fangs do the talking for me."
"I mutter and wail in arcane babblings as I weave the very fabric of undeath before me."
"I use twisted versions of scripture when I speak, creating a holy elegance around my vampiric nature."
"I am quiet and cryptic. I speak in ancient tongues and long forgotten scripture of ancient gods. Many find my ways strange."
"I am seductive and alluring, my kind demeanor is a disarming quality to put mortals under my spell."
"I am the life of the party, everyone knows me and gravitates towards me—it makes it easier to lure in prey."
"I am loyal to the one true vampire, Vladimir von Drakken, and I will do everything to serve him."
"The Court of the Night serves me well, and in turn, I work to keep its secrets."
"I serve my family unwaveringly, and will gather the sheep to their flock, growing our numbers."
"I serve the ancient gods Morrigan and Shegorach. I keep their ancient rituals alive in secret, and very seldom share my ways with outsiders."
"I have spent a century acquiring great wealth and a masterful, historic collection. I will preserve and expand it any chance I can."
"All vampires are bound by blood, and we must do what we can to serve the court."
"A blade to the throat silences all, be they king, mage, or peasant."
"In undeath we gain truth that cannot be discovered in a mortal life."
"One certainty in this world is that all things must die, and when they do, that is where we come in."
"Immortality is a gift of gods, one that will always come with a price. But our payment ensures we keep their teachings alive for all time."
"To live eternally, one must live deliciously and enjoy the finer carnal pleasures they can."
"Through shadows and secrets power is gained, one must know when to strike, and when to hide to survive."
"I cannot stand being talked down to or shown up."
"I despise the Sacred Flame, and its blasphemous light."
"I must follow the path of our gods in all things, and fear falling astray from my beliefs."
"I strongly believe the court is impenetrable, and nothing can get past me."
"I am easily distracted by an attractive face."
"The sight of blood makes it nearly impossible to contain my true self."

entries.name: Adventure Hooks
entries: Consider these ideas when building adventures involving the Court of the Night.

entries.name: Finding the Sanguine Rite
entries: The ultimate goal of the {@area Resurrectionists|5fa|x} faction within the Court of the Night is to perform the Sanguine Rite again and resurrect Vladimir von Drakken. This adventure hook lays the groundwork for an entire high-level campaign, and makes for a great potential follow up to a {@adventure Dungeons of Drakkenheim|DungeonsDrakkenheim} campaign.

None know for certain who taught the heretical druids of Morrigan the Sanguine Rite. Perhaps it was the Old God Morrigan herself, as her faithful often hold power over life and death, and trade knowledge and magic for blood and souls. Yet, the Druids of the Sanguine Rite are remembered as outcasts and blasphemers amongst many of Morrigan's worshippers even today, and so it's possible the knowledge they possessed came from another, darker source, an evil power that finds joy and mirth in death and the macabre: the demonic entity known as {@creature He Who Laughs Last|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

Whatever the source, the Court of the Night has thus far failed to obtain knowledge of the Sanguine Rite. It's possible that the ritual may be taught again to a powerful individual who wins the favor of Morrigan or He Who Laughs Last, or instead the secrets of the ritual were indeed recorded. However, if written details of the Sanguine Rite do exist, they would be far flung and closely guarded—agents of the Court of the Night have sought them for centuries. A fragment may be held in the library of the Inscrutable Tower in Drakkenheim; another may have been sealed away by the Faith of the Sacred Flame; one key piece of text has been sequestered away to the Far Continent; and the final scraps of knowledge have been banished to another world entirely, drifting lost in the Shadowlands or the Space Between Worlds.

Perhaps the cunning Court of the Night could seek out a competent band of adventurers to help them find these pieces, posing as double agents of a trusted faction, and falsely claiming the rite is used to prevent Vladimir von Drakken's return? It would be deliciously ironic indeed if among those adventurers were suitable sacrifices, or an unwitting descendant of Vladimir von Drakken...

Along the way, a faction of Inheritor vampires seek to infiltrate the mission, usurping the knowledge to use for themselves. If the player characters fall for the ruse, they may just end up being the ones responsible for unleashing Vladimir von Drakken again!

entries.name: Night Terrors
entries: A local community living under the shadow of an old castle is complaining of several townsfolk having horrible nightmares, reporting demons standing over them in their sleep. The local guard and the priest seem to wave these stories away.

entries.name: Army of Darkness
entries: A neighboring town from where the party is based has been discovered to be entirely composed of vampires and their cultist minions. Knowing they have been found out, the locals are concerned that the army of vampires will march upon their home at the next full moon.

entries.name: The Longest Night
entries: A thrall has arrived in town and is being held at the local sheriff's office. He has come with a warning. That on the longest night of the year, in 3 days, his masters will be arriving to feast on the town.

entries.name: Vampires in Drakkenheim
entries: Rumors exist that a small family of vampires are operating out of the city of Drakkenheim, or possibly from a small nearby town. They are very keen to find a means of placing themselves on the throne and bring the corrupted city into a new age of blood and terror. Luckily the dangers of the city offer its own problems for anyone after the throne to overcome, even vampires seem unable to claim the city without help.

data.name: Chapter 7: Trolls
entries: {@b Ever-Present Threat}

What has two arms and I hate them? Trolls! They are stupid, violent creatures, and as a Caspian I would know! They come in many different forms, but the smell is pretty consistent. Before your empathy pours in, remember the countless Caspians I personally sent to deal with the trolls, who never returned to their families.

When the commonfolk think of monsters, trolls are often top of mind. Although slumbering dragons, hulking giants, and the eldritch horrors of Drakkenheim loom large in tales and imaginations alike, seldom do such terrors invade people's everyday lives. Trolls, however, roam far and wide throughout Caspia, Elyria, and Westemr. They are by far one of the most common and well-known monsters plaguing the continent; children hearing of trolls under bridges or as a cautionary tale to venturing into the woods at night. Indeed, those in rural villages, farmsteads, or unwary travelers taking the backroads, may sometimes run afoul of a hungry troll. Many such communities have their own stories about local run-ins with trolls, ranging from the comedic to the tragic and occasionally the terrifying.

entries.name: Origins in the Faerie Otherworlds
entries: Trolls tell few tales about their own origins, and so it falls to mortal scholars to speculate how they came to this world. Legend says that trolls came from the Faerie Otherworlds long before a great winter fell upon the world. Accounts vary on why and how; some tell of how they were driven from enchanted realms by fey tricksters. Other stories say that trolls are a curse sent by a vengeful Faerie King or Queen for some half-remembered trespass made by mortals millennia ago. Perhaps foolish warlocks accidentally summoned the trolls here in attempts to bargain with their patrons, opening rifts that allowed entities from the Otherworlds to enter the Material Plane. Perhaps the first few trolls simply got very, very lost searching for their next meal, and wandered through a Thin Place only to find that a local farm made for a fortuitous feast. The Faerie Otherworlds are after all the closest "neighbor" dimension to the Mortal World—creatures stumbling through the thin veil that separates these planes is more common than through any other.

Regardless of how they got here, trolls arrived so long ago that there is not a wild place on the continent that isn't home to some form of troll. Every major city and settlement has their stories of why you shouldn't traverse dark forests, old swamps, or deep caves alone, and the heroic deeds of great heroes who have rescued such wayward travelers from the clutches of these great beasts.

entries.name: Caspian Legends
entries: In the realm of Caspia, slaying a troll is considered a crucial test of valor and a rite of passage for proving one's worth as a warrior. Troll hunting has evolved into a sport among the Caspians, and many ale houses resound with tales of brave knights confronting fearsome trolls. Distinct varieties of trolls inhabit different parts of the region—the trolls of Trogrowth Forest, the cave dwellers of Caspian Canyon, the Storm Trolls of Bladeshatter Bay, and the Magma Trolls in the deep caverns beneath Dragon's Vault—each with their own legends deeply embedded in Caspian lore.

Caspians take great pride in recounting their battles with these formidable creatures. They decorate their keeps with the skulls of slain trolls, and confronting a troll is widely regarded as a fundamental milestone for those aspiring to be recognized as true Caspian warriors.

entries.name: Appetites and Bargains
entries: Trolls are creatures defined by their insatiable hunger, often driven by the pursuit of their next meal. This relentless appetite shapes their interactions, behaviors, and societal structures. Securing food is paramount in their daily existence. Despite their fearsome nature and formidable size, trolls typically avoid complex strategies in favor of straightforward approaches to satiating their hunger. This simplicity in motivation, however, does not mean they lack cunning or adaptability when opportunities to feed present themselves without substantial effort. Trolls have a particular craving for fresh meat, wealth, and captives, reveling in the manipulation and terror they can instill in those they encounter, aiming to extract as much as possible before brutally dispatching their victims.

Trolls often rely on their imposing stature, strength, and fearsome reputation to intimidate travelers into relinquishing goods, food, gems, or other valuables in exchange for safe passage. This method allows trolls to amass supplies without the need for hunting. When interacting with humans, trolls make demands they know will be unpalatable, such as threatening to devastate a farm unless the farmers surrender their prized livestock or even a family member. They have been known to demand adventurers sacrifice an arm and a leg for safe conduct, resorting to violence against those who cannot meet their steep demands.

Trolls are largely solitary creatures, but occasionally form their own secluded communities, creating tight-knit groups that operate as small hunting packs. Strategically, they set up camps or outposts near pathways frequented by wagons or lone travelers, or at narrow passages like gates and bridges where travelers have little choice but to confront them.

entries.name: Elemental Evolutions
entries: Trolls inherently possess extraordinary regeneration. Their bodies rapidly heal any injury, even regrowing lost limbs and body parts in mere minutes. However, a troll's regeneration is somewhat flawed, prone to leaving behind scar tissue and imperfections which, over time, result in the knobby hide and thick outer skin of most trolls. However, in rare cases, a troll can develop bizarre mutations when they regenerate, such as sprouting additional limbs. Over time, this trait has driven rapid evolutionary developments among trollkin based on their environments. Trolls can adapt to thrive in remote and hazardous settings simply by surviving anything these places can throw at them, even taking on the elemental traits of their surroundings.

In the dense forests, {@creature Oak Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Oak Trolls} have evolved as a dominant species, while the overgrown brushlands and marshes are frequent havens for {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trolls}. {@creature Winter Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Winter Trolls} navigate the lofty peaks and the desolate expanses of Netherwind, while {@creature Storm Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Storm Trolls} roam along the shores of the Crystal Coast and Bladeshatter Bay. The fiery Drakeclaw Mountains are home to {@creature Magma Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Magma Trolls}, and the strange city of Drakkenheim has given birth to {@creature Eldritch Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Trolls}. Importantly, these diverse types of trolls are not restricted to these areas alone and can be encountered throughout the continent in a variety of settings.

entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Trolls build their burrows or camps in secluded, hard-to-reach areas such as great mountain caves, or deep within treacherous swamps. They often live in small groups and hunt the areas surrounding their homes for wildlife or wandering adventurers.

entries.name: Traps and Hazards
entries: Trolls know their environments well and often purposely build near natural hazards or outfit the areas surrounding their homes with traps formed of natural elements. They are smart hunters and know how to protect themselves. Use traps and hazards freely when designing troll environments.

entries.name: Scavenged Goods
entries: Trolls are collectors. They keep anything shiny or that they deem interesting from adventurers they have killed. They often have sacks filled with combinations of mundane trinkets and potential magical items. Almost anything can be found amongst a troll's collection.
Some items commonly found in a troll's bag are below. Choose 2–3 or roll a {@dice d12} twice.

items: A severed hand or foot
A gold ring
A large dead rodent
An uncommon potion or scroll
An ornate dagger
A common magic item
A ragged doll
An uncommon magic item
Spoiled food
A rare magic item
A human eyeball
A very rare magic item

entries.name: Natural Networks
entries: Trolls build their homes in natural environments, preferring lairs that have more than one exit, possible secret passages, and multiple ways for them to get the drop on any unwanted intruders. They may not be the smartest creatures around, but they are good at defending their homes, and eating humans who try to trespass in them.

entries.name: Minions and Pets
entries: Trolls are known for taming creatures to aid them in hunting. Oftentimes these creatures are beasts or monstrosities that they keep as pets. {@creature Dire Wolf|XMM|Dire Wolves}, {@creature Owlbear|XMM|Owlbears}, {@creature Giant Lizard|XMM|Giant Lizards}, or more exotic creatures can be companions to a group of hunting trolls.

When it comes to their lairs, oftentimes trolls find habitats with natural wildlife that can act as guards to their own burrows and camps. Finding a cave with a {@creature Gelatinous Cube|XMM} already residing in it, or a swamp filled with {@creature Giant Crocodile|XMM|Giant Crocodiles} is perfectly fine for a troll. They try to use these natural predators to deter unwanted guests.

entries.name: Known Lairs
entries: Trolls typically reside out of the way of humanoid civilizations, knowing very well that humans and trolls do not often get along, they tend to occupy less hospitable locations. Trolls have a rare ability to regenerate, and this regenerative gene has made them quick to evolve and adapt to almost any environment.

entries.name: Trogrowth Forest
entries: The Trogrowth forest of Caspia is one of the most well-known locations for Caspian sport troll hunting. The woods are filled with all manner of trolls. Many of the typical trolls reside there, but one of the most fearsome troll types to be discovered in the forests are the {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trolls} whose numbers swell quickly and can easily overwhelm an unprepared Caspian hunt.

entries.name: Elvenmire Wetlands
entries: Many of the continent's swamps are home to {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trolls} as well. In any place where fungus is common, there is a chance of a {@creature Troll Hag|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} starting a garden of {@creature Trollings|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Swamps are seldom inhabited by humans, and so make prime locations for Fungal Troll farms, and burrows of all sorts of trollkin.

entries.name: Ruins of Drakkenheim
entries: It's well known that many trolls took up at King's Gate and Queen's Park Gardens when Drakkenheim fell. But these trolls are of lesser concern than the ones who got lost in the city itself. Several trolls who fell to contamination still roam the city streets as mindless {@creature Eldritch Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Trolls}.

entries.name: Hagatha's Lair
entries: Between the sister lakes of the Eastern Vales, deep in the murky Shadow Fens, lies a little cottage made of old, moss-covered wood, a quaint cobblestone walkway leads up to its yellow oak door. A stone chimney spouts puffs of black-gray smoke, and a canopy of green leaves cover it from the sun. mushrooms big and small grow upon the wooden exterior, and cover the mossy roof, some as small as a gold piece, others as big as a wagon wheel. The crude wood fence around Hagatha's cabin has an old wooden sign pointing down the swampy road that reads "Snaggletooth Road." All manner of frogs, flies, gators, and other critters poke their faces out from the algae-covered waters surrounding the winding narrow path.

Hagatha is a {@creature Troll Hag|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} who delights in growing mushrooms of all shapes and sizes, using her magic to imbue them with sentience to employ them as minions around her cottage. She makes occasional journeys north to the main road and small villages to offer villagers some of her fine brews. She's known for making dangerous propositions to folks in desperate situations, and many have lost children, wealth, or health to her bargains.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Trolls are aggressive hunters. They defend their territories, and often hunt in packs. It's likely that using trolls in groups of two or three is going to pose a great threat to most parties.

entries.name: Regenerative Abilities
entries: Trolls have the ability to regenerate. Depending on the type of troll, they have different {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities} that stop their regeneration. Pay attention to what damage types are being used against the trolls. Some parties may be ill-equipped to take on some types of troll if they do not have the right spells, items, or abilities.

entries.name: Harsh Environments
entries: Trolls often look for an edge in battle by fighting in an environment that favors them and not their foe. Mucky swamps filled with toxic gases, burning volcanoes with falling magma, a treacherous storm with high winds. Keep environmental effects in mind when using trolls and think of the places they inhabit, and how they might use that to their advantage.

entries.name: Aggressive Persistence
entries: Unless a troll is facing foes who are using the proper damage types against it, they have no reason to let up. A troll who can regenerate is not afraid to die, as it will keep growing back and closing its wounds. They are territorial in nature, so as long as a threat remains in their territory, they defend it and continue their assault. A troll only flees if it receives damage it cannot regenerate and it has a chance to actually die.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Trolls may not be the brightest creatures roaming the wilderness, but they are cunning hunters with rudimentary social structures.

entries.name: Angry and Hungry
entries: Trolls are straight forward with their goals and demands. They sometimes let humanoids pass if they are offered good food, or something they see as valuable for their collections. If travelers or adventurers try to bargain with them, trolls may ask to eat one of them as payment, unless offered something tastier or more valuable than a delicious adventurer.

Trolls do not enjoy being fooled, ignored, or talked down to, and oftentimes those who try to converse with trolls soon find out the hard way what happens when they don't get their way. Although their requests are often simple, if they are not met, the troll will just as quickly club the lot of them for wasting its time.

items: "All you gotta do to pass is give up one of your arms or legs. We are reasonable folks, so it can be your left arm. You don't need it much."
"Give us your horses, all of them. We need to stock up on meat for the winter."
"If you give us a nice big gem, we won't squash you to jelly."
"Let us eat one of you, and the rest can go without question."
"Go get us a cow, or two goats, nice big ones. Bring them here and we'll let you through."
"Give us something nice, magical, and shiny and we'll let you carry on your way."

entries.name: Different Trolls, Different Personalities
entries: Not all trolls follow the same ideals or personalities. A troll who is heavily contaminated might be nothing more than a mindless monster, whereas the Fungal Trolls could care more about protecting the natural environments than clubbing and eating adventurers. Pay attention to the types of trolls in your adventure and think about what they might want to help them survive or what causes they may care about.

entries.name: Caspian Troll Hunt
entries: A group of Caspian knights are hiring a hunting crew to go deep into the heart of the Trogrowth Forest in search of a massive {@creature Humongous Fungus Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.

entries.name: Grim Harvest
entries: {@creature Fungal Trolling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Fungal Trollings} have been seen in larger numbers than usual on the outskirts of the woods. Someone needs to go in and find the hag responsible and destroy her troll farm.

entries.name: Stormy Weather
entries: A {@creature Storm Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is causing all sorts of problems for a small village on the road.

entries.name: Barren Hunters
entries: A group of {@creature Winter Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Winter Trolls} have made hunting in the Barren Expanse of Netherwind problematic. Someone needs to clean them out.
Trolls come in many shapes and sizes but they can all do one thing well; die.

data.name: Chapter 8: Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds
entries: {@b The Realms Beyond}

I knew something was wrong when I started smelling color. An old tea set grew to the size of a mountain, exploded into just letters like words from a page and dripped off into the ground before me. I don't know how to leave this place, I can't remember how I got here. I'm constantly looking at my feet to make sure they're still there. I'm probably gonna have to kill a creature with a bunch of limbs. I can hear distant screams that turn into birds that become the songs of my youth. I'm gonna just start swinging my sword at things and hope they weren't friendly.

Even the most learned sages and mightiest archmages of the Amethyst Academy understand little about the realms beyond the Mortal World. Through centuries of research, a few have gleaned scraps of knowledge, as scholars attempt to catalog the planes and discover the means to reach them. It is known that beyond the Mortal World are countless planes, side realms, and parallel dimensions: the verdant Faerie Otherworlds, the grim Shadowlands, the fuming Elemental Planes, and more. Though few mortals ever visit these other worlds, their influence permeates the material plane through magic and creatures that slip though the metaphysical veil that separates one reality from the next. However, sewn within the seams of the planar fabric is a realm unto itself, one more incomprehensible and bizarre than any other: the roiling non-place known as the Space Between Worlds.

The Space Between Worlds is a tumultuous expanse of raw magical potential, a surreal landscape where crystalline obelisks rise at bewildering angles beneath a sun shaped like a square circle setting into an endless horizon. This horizon never touches the psychedelic, octarine sky. Logic and reason fade from meaning and the paradoxical reigns—here chaos and order are one and the same.

Often thought of as the borderland between planes, or a void that collects the detritus of failed realities, broken timelines, annihilated universes, and collapsing dimensions, the Space Between Worlds is believed to be the source of all arcane magic, and metaphysically connected to every other plane. In this endless tundra of incomprehensible chaos, creatures beyond mortal understanding glide through the void or linger within pockets of semi-coherent reality. Void pirates navigate the cosmic seas, while elder beings traverse shattered dimensions. Sentient planets engage in celestial wars across a nebulous cosmic landscape, and inscrutable entities study and abduct mortals for obscure purposes. Within this tumultuous realm, various self-proclaimed gods manipulate mortal lives, viewing them as trivial playthings. To these beings, mortals represent mere ephemeral and erratic blips in the vast, ever-shifting expanse of the universe.

These few scraps of information are the totality known to mortal scholars in the World of Drakkenheim about the Space Between Worlds. The remaining information on the Space Between Worlds is for the heroes to discover themselves during play.

Conventional understandings of space, time, and causality do not necessarily apply in the Space Between Worlds. Indeed, the foundational laws of logic itself do not hold here. The entire Space Between Worlds is a contradiction unbound; the excluded middle made manifest; a place where whatever is, is not, and is also something else, and that which is not, is. The realm is spatially multi-dimensional, extending into the fourth, fifth, sixth, and potentially infinite spatial dimensions. Similarly, time flows freely forwards, backwards, stands still, accelerates, and slows down. Finite mortal creatures confined to three spatial dimensions and a linear timeline cannot experience the full spatial and temporal breadth of the Space Between Worlds in its utterly infinite potential. Within the Space Between Worlds, everything extends endlessly everywhere all at once, while being simultaneously compressed into a singularity.

The Amethyst Academy mages Adama Borgess and Killgar Copperpot as well as apothecary Mathias van Buskirk were leading minds in the study and understanding of the Space Between Worlds. The deeper these brilliant minds delved into the knowledge of the Space Between Worlds, the more they began to lapse from reality. Copperpot died after his breakthrough into understanding the entities of the realm. Borgess published multiple books on the topic, each more esoteric and confused than the last. In his final years, he became reclusive and isolated, speaking at length about dimensions and reality in an increasingly confounded manner. Van Buskirk is a modern practitioner and is still alive today. His study is focused on Thin Places, and the entities that emerge through them, dealing with the protection of our realm from such creatures.

Beyond these brilliant minds, other entities exist that have a firm grasp of the Space Between Worlds, but these entities are just as rare to encounter as the realm itself. What secrets these incredible beings of vast intellect may know they care little to share with mortals. Three such entities have a deep understanding of the nature of the Space Between Worlds. The first is {@creature Eldritch Troll|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Eldritch Trolls}. Second is {@creature He Who Laughs Last|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, the demon lord from the Hells speculated to have existed since the origin of time, and destined to be the last creature to exist at the end of all things. Last is Amaranthyst, The Ultraviolet, archmage of the Amethyst Academy Directorate, a being who transcends time and space. There might be other incomprehensible entities that traverse the Space Between Worlds and know it as no others could, but those entities are beyond a mortal's perception and understanding.

entries.name: Order Out of Chaos
entries: In the rare instances of communication between beings of the Space Between Worlds and mortals, very little has been gained. The gnome wizard Killgar Copperpot used a planar contact spell to communicate with a being from the Space Between Worlds. Upon making contact, his fellow mages witnessed a one-sided discussion that went as follows.
I, Killgar Copperpot, reach out to you now to seek understanding." "I do not understand." "I do not understand." "Oh..." "I understand.

Which promptly ended with the mage standing up and walking to the edge of the sea ten miles away. For twelve days he spoke not a word and silently wept.
