None of his fellow mages could get him to communicate. After sunset on the twelfth day, during a full moon, the mage stood from his place in the sand. Witnesses transcribed what he said:
The gibbering and entombed wretches, by the twinkled pointed stings of dusks settling, hark, cast ye into the sea so I shall be swept into foam upon the waves and be Killgar Copperpot no more.

The mage's eyes then melted into mush, and a strange octarine glow came from within the empty sockets. He then walked into the sea and was never seen again. Some who observed the act say that as the waves crashed over him, he slowly dissolved as if he was made of sand.

Many philosophers, mages, and priests have thus speculated that the void found within this chaotic realm is little more than incomprehensible nothingness, one that mortal minds were not meant to bear witness to, but simply is a space between the pockets of functioning realities that we are intended to exist within.

However, the mad mage Adama Borgess suggested that rather than existing between worlds as befits its name, the Space Between Worlds actually contains all of reality and existence itself. Under their utterly baffling model, the entire multiverse—all planes of existence, timelines, and worlds—are merely thought of as "islands of order within a sea of chaos." Borgess theorized that the fate of such islands is inevitably to be broken down and consumed, returning to primal chaos. To Borgess, order is merely a temporary state cast against the natural chaotic state of the multiverse, a chance snapping together of cogent components forming randomly within the ether.

entries.name: Fundamentally Contaminated
entries: The raw magic within the Space Between Worlds is intense and manifests as unrestrained eldritch contamination, transforming matter and energy into everything beyond imagination. The chaotic magical landscape produces constantly fluctuating arcane energy that forms a swirling nebula of contaminated energy.

Not dissimilar to the Haze found over Drakkenheim, the Space Between Worlds is a contaminated place; {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystals} can be found in the Space Between Worlds in massive quantities. A form of concentrated raw arcane power turned into a solid form, delerium is an inevitable constant in a realm of churning arcane power. Growths of it dot every landscape and structure found in the realm, and in other regions it dominates the terrain, shaped like colossal mountains, crystalline forests, octarine obelisks, and strange edifices. Entire planetoids of delerium drift through the void. Delerium may have very well originated from the Space Between Worlds, shifting into the various realms and realities through Thin Places, or arcane gates.

The creatures that inhabit the realm are born from this contamination, and their alien physiologies and incomprehensible arrangements echo the horrible mutations occurring in Drakkenheim. Adama Borgess's theory suggests that delerium is the inevitable return to chaos that all realities will eventually suffer. The process of returning order to its natural state of chaos is caused by the swirling arcane void and delerium is simply a catalyst for this destruction caused by the inherent nature of magic itself. The realms floating within the Space Between Worlds are at all times deathly contaminated, and it is perhaps the epicenter of the chaotic whims of contamination.

entries.name: Cats of the Moons
entries: One of the strangest noted occurrences within the Space Between Worlds is the relative frequency in which cats occur. Multiple accounts from those who have traversed the Space Between Worlds and lived to tell about it mention cats, or similarly feline creatures, guiding them back to their mortal realms. No mortal being alive has been able to surmise how, or why, of all the possible creatures, within realms of unfathomable arrangements of possibilities, we have found multiple occasions of cats, or creatures closely resembling cats.

Speculation suggests perhaps all cats are from the Space Between Worlds, and have in fact infested our reality, observing humans for reasons we could never know. Others think the opposite may be true, that cats slipped from our reality into the Space Between Worlds, and somehow found a home there, multiplying and occupying the pockets of space within the chaotic realm.

Whatever the reason, cats have seemingly guided mortals through the twisted chaotic realms on multiple occasions, though their true nature is a mystery. It is unclear what dealings those who never made it home had with the cats, and whether they were nefariously involved in any way.
The problem with cats and their "owners" is discerning at any given time who is in charge. I would consider myself a dog person.

entries.name: Roleplaying Traits
entries: Creatures from the Space Between Worlds are often beyond comprehension. Many possess forms and consciousness so bizarre that mortals do not recognize them as creatures at all. They view mortals similarly, nothing more than inert matter and whose souls are little more than passing thoughts. Still, these otherworldly creatures interact with mortals in more cogent and physical ways. The plane's inscrutable inhabitants include sphinxes, gemstone dragons, and countless aberrations. Those humanoids who have been lost to this realm are forever changed by the {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} of the Space Between Worlds.

entries.name: Paradoxical Physiology
entries: The native creatures of the Space Between Worlds often have physical features that defy the laws of physics:

items: Features that change as they move, appearing as every person you've ever met.
Limbs and joints bend in unusual directions, at times completely altering the movement of the creature.
Appearing like a cubism painting, existing in both two, three, and seemingly four dimensions, impossible to fully grasp.
An excessive number of eyes—many forming as you watch.
Unsettling blends of insect, animal, and human traits.
Everchanging shapes and colors that are difficult to recall.
A faint, eerie glow that varies without pattern or source.
Body parts that vanish momentarily, only to reappear unexpectedly in a different form or location.
Shadows that behave independently, moving in ways that do not align with any light source.
Skin that shows swirling patterns and otherworldly landscapes, captivating and disorienting onlookers.

entries.name: Inscrutable Minds
entries: Dwellers of the Space Between Worlds behave and think in ways incomprehensible to mortals. Consider using the following mannerisms and traits to capture their bewildering nature:

items: It speaks in sounds that instantly induce headaches—sounds so foreign that they feel fundamentally wrong to hear.
The creature shows a complete disregard for mortal beings, casually passing by as it goes about its mysterious activities.
It communicates with patterns of light or color on its skin, conveying complex messages indecipherable to mortals.
Their thoughts, if telepathically intercepted, seem like chaotic storms or serene voids, with no in-between.
They recall events from multiple timelines or dimensions, discussing them as if they were a single coherent history.
It reacts to unknown events suggesting a perception of time and space that defies mortal understanding.
Sometimes, it pauses inexplicably, as if listening to or observing something invisible and inaudible to others.
It exhibits emotions that have no mortal equivalent, manifesting physically in bizarre and unexpected ways.
It exhibits a fascination with mundane objects, treating them with reverence or fear without apparent reason.
It repeats actions or phrases, as if stuck in a temporal anomaly or experiencing a reality glitch.
It demonstrates indifference to pain, injury, or the environment that would typically provoke strong reactions.
It occasionally creates complex geometric patterns in the air or on surfaces, which might be a form of art or communication.

entries.name: Locations and Lairs
entries: Mortal spellcasters are seldom able to physically travel between differing planes of existence; for in the entire world only a handful of tuning forks for the {@spell Plane Shift|XPHB} spell are known to exist, and only a few living people are able to cast unfathomable spells such as {@spell Gate|XPHB}. Instead, most interplanar travel occurs via happenstance. Rifts in reality appear seemingly at random throughout the Mortal World and on occasion creatures have been known to slip through.

entries.name: Travel to the Space Between Worlds
entries: Physical travel to the Space Between Worlds is a deadly prospect for all but the most seasoned and powerful mortals. Rather, it is more common that the influence of the Space Between Worlds appears in the Mortal World in the form of Thin Places.

entries.name: Thin Places
entries: These are spots where the borders between worlds are especially weak. Emerging under extraordinarily rare magical circumstances, Thin Places form a connection between the Mortal World and another plane of existence. Thin Places often mark sites where creatures from the worlds beyond step into the Mortal World. Powerful planar magic can be harnessed here; Thin Places are characterized by a subtle influence of their corresponding plane.

Thin Places can wax and wane over time. An object such as a doorway, arch, stone circle, bridge, wardrobe, or looking glass can act as a fulcrum for a Thin Place, and even spontaneously form a planar portal. Animal burrows, lakes, and trees can act in the same manner, becoming places where mortals and extraplanar creatures slip between worlds. When Thin Places wane, they can leave planar travelers trapped in another dimension, unable to return home. Academy scholars claim this is how gnomes, goblins, and many anthropomorphic peoples came to the Mortal World, as well as monsters such as lycanthropes, trolls, and worse.

Most commonly, Thin Places connect to the Faerie Otherworlds or the Shadowlands, but the presence of delerium can trigger much more wild rifts that open to never-before-seen realms. Since the emergence of delerium, the Thin Places connected to the Space Between Worlds have appeared, mostly in and around Drakkenheim. These places are especially dangerous, as the monsters and wild magic that leak into the Mortal World from the Space Between Worlds are far more deadly and hostile than those of other realms. Worse, the eldritch contamination from the Space Between Worlds tends to slowly cause these conditions to worsen over time.

entries.name: Plane Shift
entries: There are only three known tuning forks that allow one to venture into the Space Between Worlds via {@spell Plane Shift|XPHB}. One is a tesseract, another a mobius strip, and the last is a melting pocket watch. The locations of these mythical items are known only to a select few. The Directorate of the Amethyst Academy knows of one. Another is said to be held by the great dragon Opularis the Wise, though none have ever been able to confirm this with the dragon. The third is a mystery. Some believe it was lost in Drakkenheim; others say the Divine Matriarch holds it in a secret vault; still others believe some great demonic entity houses it within the hells.

entries.name: Temporal Disjunction
entries: There is no meaningful concept of time in the Space Between Worlds beyond the perception of mortal creatures. Traveling through this place is a journey of eons which can unfold in mere minutes within the Mortal World. Many who find themselves lost in the Space Between Worlds have returned to the Mortal World having found the world completely changed. Although they believed themselves gone for months, they came home to a century of time passing. Other rare stories speak of an apothecary claiming they were lost in the Space Between Worlds for at least forty years, returning unaged only 42 minutes after they entered. With the absence of time within the realm, it has been observed that those who enter go through physical and mental changes that are disproportionate to the time spent in the realm. Where one creature might age, another may not. These inconsistencies continue to prove difficult to map or speculate upon due to their inherent lack of reason or consistency.

entries.name: Visions of Madness
entries: The sights of the Space Between Worlds are so bizarre and incomprehensible that few mortal minds can withstand beholding them. The landscapes leave those who witness them with severe headaches, dizziness, and in some cases have caused lasting bouts of madness, lethargy, and death. The Space Between Worlds is so utterly devoid of reason or logic that no mortal mind that dares imagine such a place could ever conceivably fathom the true reality of it. Those who have spied its landscapes and been coherent enough to document their findings have struggled to do so by any words or phrases of any language. The few recorded documentations are also wildly inconsistent amongst one another, further proving that there is no perceivable way to draw conclusions about the Space Between Worlds besides its utter chaotic incomprehensibility.

entries.name: Impossible Vistas
entries: The terrain of the Space Between Worlds varies greatly. Within it are some common groupings of matter that have been observed and mapped amongst the otherwise impossible to comprehend landscapes:

entries.name: Desert of the Unreal
entries: Trackless dunes of hourglass sands engulf the ruins of forgotten civilizations. Ancient bone-white monuments and half decayed structures jut out of the dunes along with strange jewel toned rocks that reach towards a purple sky. The rocks reshape at incoherent angles depending on how they are observed, and the howl of unnatural winds billow through the sands under an eternal blazing sun.

entries.name: Hyperdimensional Caverns
entries: A network of caves and dungeons extend past the third dimension, comprising chambers with four, five, six, or more spatial dimensions, all overlapping one another. With no consistent path to take or to map, the caverns seemingly reform and reimagine themselves at any given moment. Journeying down a straight corridor may very well lead you in a circle, and descending into a pit may lead you to the top of a mountain.

entries.name: Void Sea
entries: A great roiling mass of eldritch storms, the Void Sea is not quite outer space, not quite ocean, and not quite landless sky. Floating rocks drift through the sea in various shapes and forms, some as small as a pebble, others large enough to house entire structures or cities. Void Pirates roam the sea surviving off the drifting debris seeping in from the Thin Places of other realms. The Void Sea is a terrifying space where gravity is broken in illogical ways. Stepping off the edge of a cliff might cause you to fall in any direction, or float through the air gently, or even have gravity shift so you are still walking on solid ground in a new direction. Navigating this eternal sea is an art few can comprehend besides those born in the Space Between Worlds, or those forever altered by it.

entries.name: Monolith Plains
entries: The Monolith Plains are made up of vast fields of orange grass upon rolling hills that shift and move like waves upon an ocean caught in slow motion. Stretches of land are spotted with great monoliths of black obsidian stone formed in perfect geometric shapes. Scattered perfect cubes of rock orbit the largest of the great stones, giving off a slight ringing hum. The sky is a deep crimson, filled with churning green clouds that flash with purple lightning in an ever present storm. Occasional torrential downpours of contaminated rain cause flooding and form rivers and lakes along the landscape.

entries.name: Temples of Ulthar
entries: A series of vast islands within the Void Sea house ancient temples of white stone with bizarre architecture unlike that of any mortal creature's making. Great statues of cat-like creatures stand upon ancient pedestals or within carved vistas throughout the geometrically baffling hallways. The temples are both ancient and pristine, standing out of time, and oddly fathomable amongst the otherwise chaotic landscapes.

entries.name: The Screaming Heads
entries: Dead gnarled trees, some resembling bony human hands or petrified tentacles burst forth from a blackened marshland of wet ground. Trickling waterfalls flow upwards into a darkened sky. Amongst the dribbling black waterways, thousands of circular stone tablets jut out of the ground. Many are perfect circles and each one contains two smaller circles punched through the stone and one large circle towards the bottom, giving the strange stone monuments the appearance of screaming faces. The stone surfaces are perfectly smooth, as if it was polished and finely crafted.

entries.name: Towers of Gears
entries: Amongst the Void Sea are a collection of epic towers that stretch for eternity in length. These towers are composed entirely of metal mechanical workings: gears, belts, levers, buttons, wires, segmented tubes, bolts, and dials constantly turning like clockwork, grinding and clicking. The towers are alive with metal creatures of geometric shapes and shifting metal workings who continually rearrange and restructure the machine workings of the towers. The towers are pulled apart and its nodes and conduits powered up by great floating mechanical beings with wires and tubes flowing off of them like a squid. The purpose of these towers is completely unknown, and seemingly inconsequential. Nevertheless, the creatures are determined to continue their work.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The creatures of the Space Between Worlds do not engage in combat with the mentality, motives, or tactics of any mortal being. Some are motivated to simply consume and persist while others are driven by entirely alien goals. Their incomprehensible nature means that engaging in combat with these strange entities will often prove as chaotic and confusing as the landscapes they inhabit.

The beings of the Space Between Worlds often have utter disregard for the wellbeing of mortals. They see mortals as little more than another assortment of chaotic matter in their way to either be moved, destroyed, or studied. These aliens attack unfamiliar creatures simply to remove them from their presence and return them to the nothingness of the void. Others find the occurrence of mortals curious and take to abducting them and performing bizarre experiments in service to some otherworldly science for reasons that the helpless subjects could never understand.

When their physical forms are injured, creatures from the Space Between Worlds will often bend reality around them or alter space and time as a reaction to violence. It is unclear if this is a defensive measure, or simply the byproduct of physically harming a creature that exists within a multi-dimensional space that is beyond human comprehension. These alien creatures have been known to phase in and out of existence, split into multiple timelines, completely change shape and form, or slip through space and time to another location when attacked.

These alien creatures do not leave behind parts or organs that mortals might understand. Many of their remains are inconsistent with any grasp one might have on biology. On occasion, bones, organs, limbs, and fluid can be gathered all the same, but more often than not, the purpose of these remains and how they relate to the creature's physiology remain a complete mystery.

entries.name: Aberrant Traits
entries: Given the contamination and delerium present within the Space Between Worlds, all creatures who dwell there are the product of contamination and unaffected by the normal dangers of delerium. All creatures in this chapter benefit from the following traits.

items.name: Fully Contaminated
items.entry: This creature is immune to {@area Contamination|8c6|x} and has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

items.name: Delerium Healing
items.entry: As an action, a monster can touch a {@item shard|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium shard} to regain 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

items.name: Alien Intellect
items.entry: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

entries.name: Pirates of the Void Sea
entries: Captured by {@area Void Pirates|808|x}, you hear whispers from the crew of a great treasure hidden in temples beyond the Void Sea. If you escape and get their map, maybe you can find this ancient relic.

entries.name: Dwellers Domain
entries: A {@creature Far Dweller Mastermind|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and its {@creature Far Dweller Abductor|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Far Dweller Abductors} and {@creature Far Dweller|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Far Dweller Corruptors} have kidnapped someone close to you, intent on experimenting on them.

entries.name: Star Warden
entries: While lost within maze-like caverns, something follows you. It seems to navigate the labyrinth better than you. It may be a threat, but it may also be your only chance to find an escape.

entries.name: Lost in Space
entries: You find yourselves stuck in the Space Between Worlds trying to navigate your way home. A {@creature Sentient Planetoid|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} has agreed to give you directions—sadly, they take you through multiple dimensional rifts that involve traversing several strange vistas of unfathomable creatures to get back to your plane of existence.

entries.name: Blade Between Worlds
entries: Within the islands of the Void Sea is an astral forge said to use stars to temper incredible weapons. There you can find plans for a sword that cuts through the very fabric of time and space.

entries.name: Triumph of Order
entries: The Space Between Worlds is the source of delerium. Seeking to prevent a disaster like that which befell Drakkenheim, the player characters embark on an epic quest to seal away the Space Between Worlds. This interdimensional odyssey takes them to the edge of reality, where they must defeat and bind elder beings such as {@creature The Algorithm|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@creature Thing with the Writhing Tail|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|The Thing with the Writhing Tail} to a locus of {@creature Sentient Planetoid|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Sentient Planetoids}, constructing a powerful planar matrix to separate the Space Between Worlds from the Mortal World. Opposing the players are {@area Far Dwellers|798|x} and {@area Delerium Dragons|789|x}, who wish to return the Material World to a state of primal chaos. Whether factions such as the Followers of the Falling Fire, the Amethyst Academy, and the Silver Order aid or oppose the characters may depend on their actions and knowledge of the consequences for their success. The repercussion this adventure would be cosmic in scale, fundamentally altering the fabric of the multiverse.

The cost for their success would be high indeed: the Space Between Worlds is the source of all magic, and magic cannot exist without delerium. Separating the Space Between Worlds from the Material Plane irrevocably banishes magic from the world and severs all forms of planar or interdimensional travel between the Material Plane and other planes. Mageborn and priest alike lose their spellcasting powers, and the pacts between warlocks and patrons are forever snuffed out. Any whispers from old gods, eldritch powers, celestial beings, and demons are silenced. Every thin place is destroyed, and magical creatures, such as trolls, giants, fey, and dragons slowly go extinct as the magic intrinsic to their nature fades from reality. The world of Drakkenheim would be safe from Delerium, but it would become a mundane place, utterly devoid of all magic.

data.name: Appendix A: Ancient Entities
entries: {@b Extraplanar Powers}

Described herein are a few of the mightiest extraplanar beings known in the World of Drakkenheim. Although they are not gods, their vast powers and incredible knowledge often allows them to masquerade as such to naive or unwitting mortals. Indeed, these entities can seal eldritch pacts with those who seek their favor and patronage; some of their warlocks even revere and worship these patrons. Other spellcasters may seek forbidden lore from them via magic like the {@spell Contact Other Plane|XPHB} spell. Perhaps some of these entities may have come to mortals in ancient days and made some of the first warlock pacts which brought magic to the Mortal World.

Promising and ambitious mortals, such as courageous adventurers, often attract the interest and ire of these ancient beings. Their plans and machinations stretch on for countless mortal lifetimes, and so these ancient entities often appear to adventurers as patient patrons, offering information, aid, magical powers, and insights. However, they extract their own costs, for these entities seldom share human values, instead following their own amoral principles and alien perspectives. Often, they demand a service performed at a perpendicular purpose to the heroes' own objectives—their reasons or purposes may not become apparent until years, decades, or centuries have passed.

entries.name: Inscrutable Origins
entries: These ancient entities are intrinsically connected to their planes of origin. The metaphysical tethers mean that such beings normally cannot travel physically into the Mortal World without extraordinary amounts of magical energy. However, their planar connection also makes them nearly impossible to permanently destroy. Since they are part of the essence of their planes of origin, they will re-form if their physical forms are slain, although it could take centuries before they regain their full forms. Nevertheless, even in this disembodied state, it is still possible to interact with their consciousness via magic or their intermediaries. Instead, mortals who wish to end these otherworldly threats investigate ways to bind or imprison them indefinitely, as their complete destruction is impossible.

If these beings possess any true knowledge regarding the fundamental nature of the cosmos or the existence of the gods, it is not clear. They only speak to mortals of such topics in a cryptic manner, and often in metaphorical or figurative language which deliberately obfuscates their meaning.

entries.name: Using the Ancient Entities in Your Campaign
entries: Although presented here with their game statistics as Epic Bosses, these Ancient Entities should {@b not} be cast in the role of the ultimate villain in a Drakkenheim campaign! These beings care little for mortal affairs, and who triumphs in the contest between the embattled factions of the Continent matters very little to them. They do, however, have a profound interest in delerium, but only because its chaotic influence creates fertile ground for their own schemes.

While player characters may speculate as such—and you should certainly feed into this suspicion—none of these ancient entities are responsible for sending the meteor that annihilated Drakkenheim. They did not create delerium; the crystals are a much more fundamental property of the way magic works in the Drakkenheim cosmos. However, some are entertained by what that notion prompts in mortals. Others, such as the {@creature Thing with the Writhing Tail|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@creature The Whispered Promise|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, seek to use delerium to advance their agendas and power. Other beings ultimately desire the destruction or domination of the Mortal World—such as {@creature He Who Laughs Last|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and the {@creature Rat God|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}—but those plans are centuries from fruition and will come at a time when no heroes live to oppose them. Even if the player characters manage to slay one of these beings, such an event is ultimately an insignificant setback to their longstanding plans.

Instead, these beings are best involved in the campaign as patrons, manipulators, and puppetmasters, orchestrating schemes far beyond the comprehension of the player characters. Not only do they make excellent patrons for warlocks of all stripes and great targets for the {@spell Contact Other Plane|XPHB} spell, roleplaying interactions with the Ancient Entities are also delightful opportunities to test the principles and desires of the player characters. These Ancient Entities can offer the player characters shortcuts to knowledge and power if the characters are willing to make bargains or pacts with terrifying eldritch creatures. These entities could offer characters the chance to "correct" a past mistake, or a direct path to achieve a key objective related to their personal quests—but the possible cost and consequences should give the heroes pause.

All you need to do is place a statue, shrine, mysterious portal, or magic circle along the adventurers' path to facilitate a telepathic interaction between the entity and the player characters. Play to the characters' desires, fears, ambitions, and regrets. Cryptically offer them everything they want and more, but without answers or explanations. Take delight in playing the entities with a sense of alien distance, nonchalant superiority, and arrogant assurance. After all, the heroes are but insignificant pawns in a grand game for them—and all the characters' struggles and victories aren't even a key play in the overall strategy for these enigmatic beings.
I have killed a lot of weird monsters in my day, but these things eat my toughest foes for breakfast. Still, I'd love to mount one of their heads in the halls of Jackson's Keep some day.

data.name: Appendix B: Faction Agents
entries: {@b Allies or Enemies}

entries.name: Amethyst Academy
entries: The wizards of the Amethyst Academy perform all sorts of arcane tasks throughout the nations. They study ancient ruins, maintain their magical strongholds, accompany nobles on errands, or participate as members of their council. These mages are well known throughout the continent and are identifiable by their purple-robes and academy rings.

entries.name: Academy Combat Tactics
entries: Broadly speaking, Amethyst Academy mages eschew combat, valuing their own lives too highly to take such risks. They view themselves as researchers, craftspeople, and scholars, not war mages—few bother learning damaging spells beyond simple cantrips, instead focusing on practical magic for their academic and industrial pursuits. Nevertheless, they know that magic is still a dangerous vocation, and ready themselves to flee perilous situations with {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} spells or teleportation magic.

When violent confrontation seem inevitable, Amethyst Academy agents often hire mercenaries or adventurers, or dispatch summoned creatures in their stead. Nevertheless, there are bold explorers who take to field research and prepare themselves for dangerous expeditions—particularly, those who personnally study the ruins of Drakkenheim. They often utilize constructs such as {@creature Shield Guardian|XMM|Shield Guardians} or summoned elementals bound to service with {@spell Planar Binding|XPHB}. Mages usually begin combat with defensive or control spells as befits the situation, such as taking to the air with Fly or subduing foes with {@spell Slow|XPHB}. Only once they are certain the situation is under control will they use their signature Prismatic Blasts or area-of-effect spells like {@spell Fireball|XPHB} and {@spell Lightning Bolt|XPHB}. These mages almost always flee once they've become {@area Bloodied|8e7|x}, viewing a temporary setback or mission failure as a preferable outcome over their deaths.

entries.name: Followers of the Falling Fire
entries: The Followers of the Falling Fire are a religious sect who believe the meteor signaled a celestial prophecy. These fanatics consider delerium a holy sacrament. Called to pilgrimage by the prescient testament of their leader, {@creature Lucretia Mathias|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, zealous masses of devout commonfolk now journey to the Crater's Edge to take their place in a divine plan.

entries.name: Falling Fire Combat Tactics
entries: Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.
There comes a time in every man's life where he wants more. Delerium in your chest is the wrong way.

entries.name: Queen's Men

entries: Who I am is not as important as what I am. I am quicker than thought, quieter than contemplation, and more slippery than a fading memory. I deal in secrets and lies as lesser thieves deal in larceny. I can fulfill your wildest dreams, or be your worst nightmare.

The ruins of Drakkenheim attract all manner of scavengers, looters, deserters, and fugitives. The anarchic and dangerous ruins are an ideal hiding place for those on the wrong side of the law, and there is no shortage of plunder and work for those who don't mind getting their hands dirty. The many disparate bands of brigands and outlaws have been brought together into a loose alliance under the thumb of the manipulative and enigmatic {@creature Queen of Thieves|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. Under her rule, the Queen's Men smuggle delerium to disreputable clients in distant lands, exhort and rob adventurers, shakedown pilgrims, and act as a constant thorn in the side of the other factions.

entries.name: Queen's Men Combat Tactics
entries: Amongst the Queen's Men, different groups may be organized as infiltrators, thieves, saboteurs, and assassins, who work unseen until the moment they strike. In contrast, highway robbers and enforces operate openly, trying to shakedown and intimidate their marks to give up any valuables without a fight. Regardless, members of the Queen's Men are seldom willing to stick around when a fight starts going against them, valuing their own lives first and foremost.

entries.name: Knights of the Silver Order

entries: The Silver Order is an elite church-sanctioned regiment of paladins and ordained knights oath-sworn to combat supernatural evils, otherworldly incursions, and dark magic. As faithful devotees of the Sacred Flame, they believe delerium is a dangerous and contaminating blight. Led by the valiant Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal, the knights have been dispatched to eradicate Drakkenheim's corruption at its source.

The Silver Order are a well-known military organization hailing from the nation of Elyria in the southwest of the continent. Loyal to the Church of the Sacred Flame, they operate as a church-sanctioned military whose stated purpose is to protect the world from evil magical intrusions, to keep otherworldly threats at bay, and to protect the people against dark magic and abuses of power from mageborn. Many believe the Silver Order are a strict organization who upholds the letter of the law within the Edicts of Lumen, a legal document that dictates the balance of power between the church, the mages, and the royalty.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: What the Silver Order lacks in subtlety they make up for with sheer force. They are a military organization, and their soldiers are well trained and work together as a team. When they tackle problems, they do so in a uniform fashion, knowing when to rely on one another, complete tasks and make pushes in unison. The Silver Order has simple call signs, hand signals, commands, and strategies that they can rely on in the field.
Silver Order knights and paladins should work as a cohesive unit who know their strengths and how to protect their weaknesses.

Any Silver Order regiment is accompanied by at least one paladin or Flamekeeper, and usually at least one of each. Larger organized military missions will see griffon riders as well as entire units of paladins and several Flamekeepers or Pyre Priests. This means that no Silver Order unit is without moderate healing, protective buffs, and often forms of divination and holy battle magic. When push comes to shove, the order's divine spellcasters tend to have a few {@spell Fireball|XPHB|Fireballs} and {@spell Flame Strike|XPHB|Flamestrikes} amongst their options.

entries.name: Hooded Lanterns
entries: The Hooded Lanterns are an irregular military force drawn from remnants of the old Drakkenheim City Watch and veterans of the Westemr Civil War, led by the grim {@creature Lord Commander Elias Drexel|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. They wish to drive out the monsters and outlaws who infest their nation's capital, find an heir to the throne, and restore the realm of Westemr.

The Hooded Lanterns are divided into three regiments which occupy the city and the areas surrounding it. New recruits joining the Lanterns are often first put into the Support Regiment. They make up the chefs, apothecaries, scribes, and maintenance workers at every Hooded Lantern fortification. Many of those positions are held by folk who will never move beyond the Support Regiment, and their job is valuable to the foundations of the Hooded Lanterns.

The Watch Regiment defend the walls and gates of any Lantern-controlled location. Oftentimes, if the Vanguards manage to gain a new foothold in the city, a group of Hooded Lanterns Watch are sent to hold the new position and ensure it remains in the Hooded Lanterns' hands. They also often operate as scouts in the field. Not specifically aiming for tactical engagement or large-scale battles, but they are the eyes and ears of the Lanterns throughout the city and occasionally clean up wandering monsters from the streets near their bases.

The Vanguard Regiment are the front line of the Hooded Lanterns. They are skilled combatants, who know their way around the ruins of the city and can find vantage points, plan ambushes, secure positions, and dispose of monster dens and other enemies. Vanguards are often soldiers who have proven themselves as reliable and talented Watch or Support Regiment and aim to prove themselves further in the city.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Hooded Lanterns rarely go into a fight without a plan. They set up ambushes, tailoring an encounter to put them at an advantage. They know their territory and can navigate the ruins of the city with relative ease compared to most adventurers who journey into Drakkenheim. They travel in well-equipped groups, and often carry tools to alert other nearby scouting parties if they need help.

The Hooded Lanterns are skilled archers. They often occupy rooftops and ruined towers. If they expect combat to occur, they position soldiers with bows in any nearby vantage points with a clear view of their allies down on the streets. They place scouts in ruined buildings to keep eyes on the streets and run for aid if a combat breaks out. The Lanterns lay traps and ambushes before their enemies have entered the area. Hooded Lanterns are often incredibly prepared and use the ruins as camouflage for their attack.

data.name: Appendix C: Contamination, Delerium, and New Conditions

entries.name: Contamination
entries: Characters in the world of Drakkenheim may be exposed to eldritch pollutants or arcane radiation emitted by delerium. These hazards cause a new condition called Contamination, which causes otherworldly {@area Mutations|8ca|x} that have both detrimental and beneficial effects.

entries.name: What's Changed?
entries: Veterans of the Drakkenheim setting may notice these Contamination rules are slightly different from the original ones presented in {@adventure Dungeons of Drakkenheim|DungeonsDrakkenheim}. Now that we've been using the Contamination rules for a few years, we felt there was an opportunity for refinement. Here's a summary of what's different from the rules originally printed:

items: Contamination Level 4 now causes the {@area Weakened|8f9|x} condition; this is mechanically similar to the original Symptom but uses the new Conditions in this book.

Contamination Level 5 now causes the {@area Dazed|8eb|x} condition instead of the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. Player characters should find this gives them a solid opportunity to survive at this high contamination level, and villainous adversaries can now recklessly force a monstrous transformation upon themselves by casting a contaminated spell!

The {@area Mutations|8ca|x} table has been expanded to a {@dice d100} table with 50 different possibilities. As before, most mutations remain beneficial or cosmetic, but there are a few drawbacks sprinkled among them.

The {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Arcane Anomaly} table has similarly been expanded to a {@dice d100} table with 50 different options. If you've been following the development of this project, you may be wondering where the Greater Arcane Anomalies went: many have been rolled into the new table.
The monsters introduced in this book offer a great selection of choices for Monstrous Transformations!

entries.name: Contamination [Condition]
entries: While you have Contamination, you experience the following effects.

entries.name: Contamination Levels
entries: This condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain one or more levels of Contamination. You undergo a Monstrous Transformation if your Contamination level reaches 6.

entries.name: Contamination Symptoms
entries: A Contaminated creature suffers the symptoms from its current level as well as all lower levels. Conditions gained from Contamination end when those Contamination levels end. There is no other way to remove conditions caused by symptoms of Contamination.

entries.caption: Contamination Symptoms
rows: Halve the Hit Points you regain when you expend Hit Dice during a Short Rest
You do not regain Hit Points when you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: Each time you gain a Contamination level, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the result is equal to or lower than your current Contamination level, you gain a randomly determined mutation by rolling on the {@table Mutations|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} table. The effects of the mutation remain while you have Contamination levels. Unless otherwise specified, a creature can't gain the same mutation more than once. If a duplicate result is rolled, the GM chooses a different one or rolls again.

entries.caption: Mutations
rows: Wave of Mutation. You gain any one mutation of your choice, then gain an additional randomly determined mutation. Then, all creatures within 60 feet of you gain 1 contamination level. Instead of rolling to determine whether or not those creatures gain a mutation, each automatically gains 1 mutation.

Anomaly Locus. When you fail a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can reroll the {@dice d20}. When you do, you trigger an {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. You must finish a Short Rest before you can do so again.

Sanguine Appetite. You develop a taste for blood which intensifies when you're wounded. While you have the {@area Bloodied|8e7|x} or {@area Bleeding|8e6|x} conditions, you gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on melee attack rolls against other creatures with the Bloodied or Bleeding conditions.

Fledgling Wings. Bat-like wings painfully explode from your back. You gain a flying speed of 40 feet during your turn. If you end your turn aloft, you fall. If you have 4 or more contamination levels, your wings expand and your flying speed increases to 60 feet, and you no longer fall when you end your turn aloft.

Wretched Bile. Bubbling contaminated ichor unconformably builds up in your guts, which you can vomit forth periodically. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with an exhalation in a 15-foot Cone. Each creature in that area must make a Constitution saving throw ({@dc 8} plus your Constitution modifier and Proficiency Bonus). On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 1d10} Necrotic damage for each Contamination level you have gained. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage. You can use your Wretched Bile a number of times equal to your Contamination level, and regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

Terrible Stench. Your body emits a pungent odor which reeks of death and sulfur. Creatures who end their turn within 5 feet of you have gain the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of their next turn. Creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks made to locate or track you.

Explosive Demise. You feel volatile growths inside your body radiating intense heat. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Fire damage. If you are reduced to 0 Hit Points while you have the Contaminated condition, you die and explode horribly in a shower of gore. Creatures within a 20-foot-radius must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. Failure: {@dice 4d6} Fire plus {@damage 4d6} Necrotic damage. Success: Half damage.

Hallucinogenic Visions. Your perception of the world around you twists into a miraculous landscape of rainbows, flowers, and vibrant colors, like walking through a pleasant dream. All creatures appear beautiful, friendly, smiling, and whimsical to you.

Cryogenic Shift. Your body rapidly disperses heat as ice begins forming on your flesh. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Cold damage, but if you don't move at least half your speed on your turn, you have the {@area Frozen|8f0|x} condition ({@dc 15}).
Nascent Delusions. You gain a randomly determined form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, which persists so long as you have the Contaminated condition.

Electric Discharge. Strange glands filled with crackling energy appear on your body. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Lightning damage. At the start of each of your turns, you deal Lightning damage to each creature within 5 feet of you. The damage equals a number of d6s equal to your Proficiency Bonus. If you have 4 or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, the dice become d10s, and the range increases to 10 feet.

Hulking. If you are Medium or smaller, your size increases by one step (from Small to Medium, or Medium to Large). While your size is increased, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Strength ability checks. You return to your normal size when you no longer have {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

Shrinking. If you are Small or Larger, your size decreases by one step (from Small to Tiny, from Large to Medium). While your size is decreased, you have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength ability checks. You return to your normal size when you no longer have {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

Vocal Warp. Your voice takes on a strange pitch and resonance determined by rolling {@dice 1d6}. 1: Alien Resonance; 2: Wet Gurgling; 3: Demonic Baritone; 4: Constantly Singing; 5: Distant Echoing; 6: Rasping Whisper.
Wasting. Body parts begin falling out of you. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which: 1–2: fingernails; 3–4: teeth; and 5–6: toenails.

Rotting Extremities. One of your body parts begins to blacken and wither. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which: 1–2: your lips; 3–4: your nose; 5–6: your ears. If you reach four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, they rot and fall off. You can still speak and hear, however.

Transforming Skin. Your skin begins to change. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine the effect: 1: painful blisters which seep strange liquids; 2: cracking and peeling to reveal raw sinew; 3: strange patterns and runes; 4: welts and bruises which throb violently; 5: necrosis and rotting in patches; 6: lesions in otherworldly multi-colored hues.

Lambent Glow. You emit a dim octarine glow to a range of 10 feet. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you instead emit {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} to a range of 30 feet.

Shedding. Each time you gain a Contamination level, some of your hair falls out in patches. Once you reach four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, all hair on your body completely falls out.

Ocular Tumors. An eyeball opens somewhere on your body for each Contamination level you have gained. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you can see in all directions.

Alien Organs. You feel a bloated shift within your abdomen, as if something has been altered in your internal composition. Several of your organs have changed into something unrecognizable yet still functional. They're filled with alien black goo.
Shimmering Veins. Your blood veins glow through your skin, casting a faint octarine light.
Shadowless. You no longer cast a shadow, regardless of the light sources around you.
Flickering Presence. Your form flickers intermittently like a poorly tuned hologram.
Gossamer Hair. Your hair becomes fine and ethereal, floating gently as if underwater.
Sprouting Crystals. Small bits of delerium begin to erupt from your bones and through your skin. They itch painfully.

Burning Blood. FLAME ON! As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can give yourself the {@area Burning|8e8|x} condition. The Fire damage is a number of d6s equal to half your Proficiency Bonus (rounded down). While you have the Burning condition, you gain a Fly speed equal to your Speed. You can end the Burning condition as an action. If the Burning damage reduces you to 0 Hit Points, your flesh burns away and only a skeleton remains.

Screaming Brain. You grow a sentient brain in your body, and it doesn't like you very much. It berates you and constantly questions your judgment, constantly wishing to escape the confines of your body.
Vestigial Limbs. Your body suddenly sprouts additional appendages. The limbs are not usable, however. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine what grows: 1: fingers; 2: toes; 3: leg; 4: Arm; 5: tail; 6: head.

Transmuted Flesh. Your flesh and body transform into an seemingly inorganic material but you remain animate and alive. This doesn't affect your game statistics. Roll {@dice 1d6} to determine which material: 1: iron; 2: wood; 3: glass; 4: stone; 5: water; 6: plastic.

Otherworldly Resistance. The Contamination growing in your body makes you strangely resistant to similar forces. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to a damage type. Roll a {@dice d10} to determine which damage type: 1–2: Necrotic; 3–4: Thunder; 5–6: Radiant; 7–8: Psychic; 9–10: Force. You can gain this mutation multiple times, rolling a different damage type each time.

Chitinous Plates. Shell-like growths appear all over your body, giving you a +1 bonus to AC. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, this bonus increases to +2.
Amorphous Form. Your bones and organs become gelatinous. You can move through a space as narrow as 6 inches wide without squeezing.
Spiked Growths. At the start of each of your turns, you deal 5 ({@dice 1d10}) Piercing damage for each contamination level you have gained to any creature you are {@variantrule grappling|XPHB}.

Aquatic Adaptation. You sprout fish-like fins and gills. You gain a Swim speed equal to your Speed and can breathe underwater. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you can only breathe underwater. You can hold your breath outside water for up to 1 hour.

Cyclopean Vision. Your eyes merge into a single central eye, which you can use to cast the {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} cantrip. You use your choice of Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability.
Spatial Displacement. You can cast {@spell Misty Step|XPHB} once for each Contamination level you have. You regain these uses when you finish a Long Rest.
Tentacled Limb. One of your arms becomes a fleshy tentacle. When you make a melee attack on your turn, increase your {@itemProperty R|XPHB|reach} by 5 feet.
Spider Climb. You gain a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your walking speed. You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Whispering Voices. You gain telepathy to a range of 10 feet, but other people hear it as their own voice. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, the range extends to 60 feet.

Belly Maw. A toothy mouth appears on your stomach. You can use it to make a melee attack as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on your turn against a creature within 5 of you. Its attack bonus is equal to your Proficiency Bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice). If you hit with it, you deal Piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + your Strength or Dexterity modifier, plus an additional {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage for each contamination level you have gained.

Eyeless Sight. Your eyes become milky orbs. You gain {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} to a range of 10 feet. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, your eyes rot out, and dim octarine light burns in the sockets. Your Blindsight increases to 30 feet.

Arcane Blood. You gain an additional spell slot of the highest level you can cast (to a maximum of 5th level). If you don't have spell slots, your Hit Point maximum increases by an amount equal to your level. If you have four or more {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, you gain two spell slots instead of one or increase your Hit Points by twice your level.
Reversed Limbs. Your base Walking speed increases by 10 feet and your long jump distance is doubled.

Chameleon. Your skin turns translucent and changes color to match your surroundings. As an action, you can give yourself the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition, which lasts until the end of your next turn or until you make an attack roll, deal damage, or cast a spell. You can use this ability only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use it, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.
Magic Resistance. You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

Regenerative Flesh. At the start of each of your turns, if you are {@status Bloodied|XPHB} and have at least 1 Hit Point, you regain Hit Points equal to twice your Proficiency Bonus. The healed flesh regrows as knobby, scaled, alien hide.

Multiplied Senses. Your face sprouts additional eyeballs, ears, and noses. You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Initiative checks as well as Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks.

Corrosive Mucus. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can spit acid at a creature within 30 feet. Make a ranged attack against the creature. On a hit, you deal {@damage 2d10} Acid damage and the creature is {@area Burning|8e8|x} ({@dice 1d10} Acid).
Rampant Mutation! Roll twice, ignoring this result on subsequent rolls.

entries.name: Long Rests
entries: Each time you finish a Long Rest while you have 1 or more Contamination levels, roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 1, you gain a Contamination level.

entries.name: Removing Contamination Levels
entries: Only specific magic can remove Contamination levels:

items: The {@spell Purge Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} spell
{@spell Heal|XPHB} removes all Contamination levels and mutations in addition to its other effects.

Contamination is not a curse, poison, or disease. Spells such as {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Protection from Poison|XPHB}, and {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} do not remove Contamination levels.
Being raised from the dead reduces a creature's Contamination level by 1.

entries: When your Contamination level reaches 0, the condition ends, as well as the effects of all mutations.

Skin, hair, fingernails, and toenails lost to mutations regrow normally once Contamination is removed. However, a {@spell Regenerate|XPHB} spell or similar magic is needed to restore any other body parts (such as teeth, limbs, or eyes) lost due to Contamination. Appendages or limbs that develop as a result of mutations wither and fall off when Contamination is removed, and other warped body parts are restored to their original form.

entries.name: Dying with Contamination Levels
entries: If you die while you have one or more Contamination levels, your corpse reanimates as a {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} 24 hours later. A creature with six or more class levels or hit dice rises as a {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} instead.

entries.name: Monstrous Transformation
entries: If you end your turn with six or more Contamination Levels, you permanently transform into a horrific monster controlled by the Game Master.

items: The Game Master chooses the new form, which is most often an Aberration or Monstrosity of some kind such as a {@creature Gibbering Mouther|XMM}, {@creature Delerium Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, or {@creature Pyknic Maunder|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
Your game statistics are entirely replaced by those of the chosen monster, including the new form's Hit Points and Hit Dice.
All Contamination levels are removed, though the GM may grant additional traits to the new form similar to any beneficial mutations gained from Contamination Levels.
The Game Master determines what remains of the original creature's personality and memories, if anything. Regardless, the creature falls under the Game Master's control.

entries.name: Reversing the Transformation
entries: A {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell or similar magic can restore a single transformed creature to its previous form, removing all Contamination and restoring the original creature's personality and memories. This is considered a stressful use of the Wish spell, and thus there is a 33 percent chance that the caster will be unable to cast Wish ever again if they use the spell in this manner.
Note that the means of reversing a monstrous transformation are completely unknown at the outset of the campaign. A Monstrous Transformation is widely regarded as permanent.

entries.name: New Spell
entries: {@spell Purge Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}

entries.name: Delerium
entries: Delerium is a magical mineral left behind by the meteor that landed in Drakkenheim. It appears in geode clusters of translucent, sharp-edged crystals which reflect octarine light. The eldritch stones softly hum in dissonant tones, and glow brightly at night or when exposed to magic. Deposits are found throughout Drakkenheim, often fused into stone streets and buildings like crystalline moss.
A typical delerium fragment is about the size of a finger. Crystals may be fist-sized or slightly larger, and geodes may be as big as a pumpkin. Massive clusters might grow taller than a human.

entries.name: Delerium Properties
entries: All delerium samples have the following traits regardless of size:

items: {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immune} to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage; as well as Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage from non-magical weapons.
{@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistant} to Acid, Cold, Fire, and Lightning damage; as well as Slashing and Piercing damage from magical weapons.
{@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerable} to Bludgeoning damage from magical weapons.

Unless contained within an {@spell Antimagic Field|XPHB}, delerium shatters and crumbles into worthless ash when reduced to 0 Hit Points. However, delerium geodes release a random {@table Arcane Anomalies|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} when destroyed ({@book see below|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|11|Arcane Anomalies}).

entries.name: Delerium Hazards
entries: When a humanoid creature touches delerium without protective gear for the first time on their turn, or ends their turn in bodily contact with delerium, they must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage and gain one level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}, as described earlier in this appendix.

entries.name: Delerium Harvesting
entries: Delerium found in Drakkenheim is usually fused into the ground or stone buildings. It is carefully extracted using handheld mining equipment such as shovels, picks, hammers, and chisels. Consult the {@book table|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|11|Delerium Crystals} to determine how long it takes characters to extract delerium. Lacking proper equipment, extraction takes ten times as long. Massive clusters are impossible to extract without heavy equipment or powerful magic.

entries.name: Uses for Delerium
entries: Delerium has vast arcane potential. Beyond trade, crystals are used for several purposes:

entries.name: Spell Component
entries: Delerium may be used as an arcane focus or material component for any spell on the sorcerer, warlock, or wizard spell list. When casting a spell which requires a costly material component, a spellcaster may instead use delerium of equivalent or greater value to the required cost.

entries.name: Magic Items
entries: Delerium is an exceptional material for creating magical items of all kinds. Any existing magic item described in the Basic Rules could be made with delerium. Fragments, shards, crystals, and geodes may be used to make uncommon, rare, very rare, and legendary items respectively. At the GM's discretion, characters who can cast level 5 spells or higher may learn techniques to craft magic items of their own during their downtime.

entries.name: Stable Delerium
entries: The process for crafting magic items with delerium renders the crystals stable. Unless otherwise specified, characters do not take damage nor risk {@area Contamination|8c6|x} when they touch or handle stable delerium. Stable delerium is damaged and destroyed in the same manner as a normal magic item of its kind.

entries.name: Delerium Dust
entries: Delerium dust is made by grinding the crystals against one another to create a fine powder. This milling process is extraordinarily hazardous unless performed within an {@spell Antimagic Field|XPHB}. Delerium dust can be used in alchemy, as a spell component, a reagent for brewing potions, or mixed into inks used to scribe spell scrolls.

entries.name: Improvised Weapons & Ammunition
entries: Delerium fragments may be used as ammunition for a sling or fashioned into a makeshift club. Such weapons and ammunition deal an extra {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage, and humanoid creatures struck must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or gain one level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}. Delerium used as ammunition in this way is destroyed.

entries.name: The Haze
entries: The Haze is magical radiation emitted by the vast concentration of delerium. It covers the ruins of Drakkenheim, but smaller pockets of Haze are beginning to manifest in other areas.

entries.name: Effects on Characters
entries: Humanoid creatures do not gain any benefits from finishing a Long Rest within the Haze.

In addition, a humanoid creature may only spend up to 12 hours within the Haze, after which it must finish a Long Rest to adequately recover from exposure. Humanoid creatures who remain in the Haze beyond 24 hours before recuperating risk {@area Contamination|8c6|x}. For each additional hour spent within the Haze beyond 24 hours, a humanoid creature must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain one level of Contamination.

entries.name: Environmental Effects
entries: The Haze magically manifests mist throughout the area. Characters can see normally through the mist up to 150 feet. Vision beyond is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}, but vision past 300 feet is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB|Totally Obscured}. Any mists dispersed during the day re-form 10 minutes later.
The Haze dampens sunlight. Creatures with Sunlight Vulnerability or similar traits do not suffer these penalties during the day while within the Haze.
The corpses of beasts and humanoid creatures do not rot within the Haze.

entries.name: Effects on Spells
entries: Any divination or teleportation spell cast outside the Haze targeting a creature or location within the Haze automatically fails. Spell-based telepathic communications or effects such as the {@spell Sending|XPHB} spell transmitted from outside the Haze fail to contact a character within it, and vice-versa. Finally, Divination spells fail to reveal useful information about delerium, the Haze, the origins of the meteor, or any events which occurred within the Haze.

When a character attempts any of the above using a spell or other effect, they must make a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, they take 21 ({@dice 6d6}) Psychic damage and become {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} with madness until they finish a Long Rest. During this time, the spellcaster speaks only in gibberish. A {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spell ends this effect.

{@spell Leomund's Tiny Hut||Tiny Hut} and similar spells or abilities do not provide shelter from the Haze. However, characters may rest within a {@spell Mordenkainen's Magnificent Mansion||Magnificent Mansion} spell cast within the Haze.

entries.name: Deep Haze
entries: Certain areas are so suffused by the Haze that mere exposure is extremely dangerous and potentially fatal. Known as the Deep Haze, these areas have the following additional traits:

items: Deep Haze is instantly recognized by a thick prismatic fog. Characters can see normally through this fog up to 60 feet. Vision beyond is {@variantrule Lightly Obscured|XPHB}, and vision past 120 feet is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB|Totally Obscured}. If dispersed during the day, the fog reforms 1 minute later.

Characters entering the Deep Haze must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, and again for each full hour spent within. On a failed saving throw, they suffer 10 ({@dice 3d6}) Necrotic damage and gain one level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}.

entries.name: Delerium Sludge
entries: Gargantuan {@item geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium geodes} seep an opalescent sludge. Characters submerged in delerium sludge must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the start of their turn. They take 42 ({@dice 12d6}) Necrotic damage on a failed saving throw, and half as much on a successful one. In addition, characters who fail the saving throw gain one level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}.

entries.caption: Arcane Anomalies
rows: A resonant cascade of eldritch phenomena! The resulting energies reflect, refract, and collide with another producing ongoing effects. Roll another Arcane Anomaly, then once more on Initiative count 20 for the next {@dice 1d4} rounds.

Gravity breaks within a 100-foot radius area for 1 hour. Creatures levitate in midair and must push or pull against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling) to move as if climbing. Unattended objects float around randomly.

The nearest creature is affected by a {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB|Hideous Laughter} spell (spell save {@dc 15}) but instead of laughing, they repeat unfathomable syllables and words. Occasionally, a somewhat comprehensible but totally illogical phrase emerges, such as "...oh time thy pyramids!"
Time skips a beat. Creatures within 60 feet experience a palpable feeling of vertigo followed by a powerful sensation of deja vu and are {@area Dazed|8eb|x} for 1 round (no saving throw).

The nearest creature becomes unstuck in time. It is affected by the {@spell Blink|XPHB} spell for 1 minute. Instead of vanishing into the Ethereal Plane, the creature vanishes into a sliver of time in its past or possible future.

A prismatic burst of energy erupts in a 20-foot radius. Creatures in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 28 ({@dice 8d6}) Radiant damage and become {@condition Blinded|XPHB} for 1 round. The smell of ozone fills the area, and nearby wood and inanimate plants are transformed into solid glass.
Echoes of possible realities are briefly visible for 1 minute. When a creature within 60 feet is hit by an attack, a faint vision of the creature being killed by that attack appears.
Discordant music fills the mind of all creatures within 30 feet, who are affected by {@spell Otto's Irresistible Dance|XPHB|Irresistible Dance} (spell save {@dc 15}).
A section of stone, water, air, or energy becomes an appropriate {@area Contaminated Elemental|0eb|x} that is hostile to all nearby creatures.
An extraplanar creature is summoned. The GM either chooses the creature or determines it randomly. It is friendly to the creature who triggered the anomaly.
All humanoid corpses with 120 feet animate as hostile {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Haze Husks}. The shrieking undead beg frantically for forgiveness as they rip apart the living.

The {@creature Shadow|XMM|Shadows} of {@dice 1d6} random creatures in the area animate and try to kill them while softly whispering "Guilty, guilty, guilty..." Once destroyed, the creatures don't cast a shadow for 24 hours.
All creatures within 60 feet gain the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition for 1 minute or until they attack or cast a spell.

Tendrils of life flow from the nearest creature to others. It must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Necrotic damage, or half as much on a success. The three nearest creatures within 60 feet each regain Hit Points equal to the damage taken.

A {@spell Hypnotic Pattern|XPHB} (spell save {@dc 15}) appears. It creates scintillating impossible colors in shapes which are simply wrong. Creatures {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} by the spell weep uncontrollably for the duration.
A {@spell Evard's Black Tentacles|XPHB|Black Tentacles} spell appears in the area for 1 hour (escape {@dc 15}).
Objects within 60 feet come to life for 1 hour, as if affected by the {@spell Animate Objects|XPHB} spell. They mumble awful truths but are not hostile.
Time slows down for up to six random creatures within 120 feet. They are affected by the {@spell Slow|XPHB} spell for 1 minute. (spell save {@dc 15}).
Time speeds up for one randomly determined creature within 60 feet of the anomaly. They are affected by the {@spell Haste|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.
The nearest creature is polymorphed into an {@creature Awakened Shrub|XMM} for 1 hour or until reduced to 0 Hit Points.
A bowl of flowers and a very surprised-looking aquatic mammal appear 100 feet in the air. "Oh no, not again..." thinks the bowl of flowers.

All creatures within a 30-foot-radius are affected by {@spell Mirror Image|XPHB}. Affected creatures do not know if they were the original or simply a reflection, and the feeling gnaws at the back of their minds forevermore.

The skin, flesh, and hair sloughs off all living humanoid creatures within a 30-foot-radius in a horrific display of gore, leaving behind only their skeletons and equipment. This doesn't kill or otherwise harm the affected creatures or change their game statistics. Their flesh, skin, and hair regrow slowly and painfully over the next {@dice 3d6} hours.

The sound of shattering glass is heard as the delicate webs of {@dice 1d4} {@creature Eldritch Crawlers|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} appear. Each spider appears with webbing which acts like the {@spell Web|XPHB} spell. The webs and eldritch crawlers remain until destroyed, or until the crawlers successfully obtain suitable prey.

A powerful magnetic force takes root in the triggering creature. All other creatures within 30 feet of the triggering creature must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, they are pulled up to 20 feet towards the triggering creature.

Each creature within 60 feet of the triggering creature (including the triggering creature) chooses a direction and rolls {@dice 2d6}. Each creature is then teleported to the nearest unoccupied space in that direction equal to the result times five feet. (e.g. 35 feet for a result of 7 on {@dice 2d6}).

Strange glowing fungus sprouts in a 20-foot radius around the triggering creature and hums softly with discordant tunes. Anyone who hears the tune mindlessly whistles the song in moments of idleness for the next {@dice 1d6} days.
A randomly determined mundane item worn or carried by the triggering creature flashes with brilliant energy, becoming an Uncommon magic item of the Game Master's choice.

A blast of raw contaminated energy explodes forth from the triggering creature in a 20-foot radius. All other creatures in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. They suffer 18 ({@dice 4d8}) Necrotic damage and gain one level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x} on a failed save. On a successful save, they take half as much damage and do not gain any {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels.

The triggering creature is momentarily pulled into the Space Between Worlds. They vanish from their space until the start of their next turn. When they reappear, they must make a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, they take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Psychic damage and gain one random form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} (see {@area Conditions|8e3|x} later in this appendix). On a successful save, they take half as much damage and don't suffer from any madness.
The triggering creature's muscles bulge and its skin turns purple-green. It is enlarged as if affected by the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.

Wicked spirits flutter around the triggering creature. It is surrounded by the {@spell Spirit Guardians|XPHB} spell (spell save {@dc 15}), which deals Necrotic damage and harms all creatures except the triggering creature. The spirits taunt and jeer at the triggering creature.

The triggering creature gains {@dice 1d6} levels of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}. Unlike normal {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} levels, these Contamination levels disappear after the character finishes a Long Rest. If the character undergoes a Monstrous Transformation while it has any of these Contamination levels, it reverts to its original form when the new form is reduced to 0 Hit Points or after 24 hours. It then gains a random form of {@condition Drakkenheim Madness|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} from the harrowing ordeal (see {@area Conditions|8e3|x} later in this appendix).
The triggering creature screams uncontrollably in horror for the next minute. Afterwards, it must make a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be unable to speak for the next {@dice 1d4} hours.
All creatures within 30 feet of the triggering creature (but not the triggering creature) gain the benefit of {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.

The triggering creature begins melting. Their skin sags and begins dripping off. Their bones turn to jelly and they become a puddle on the ground which quickly evaporates into a cloud of octarine mist. For 1 hour, the creature is under the effects of the {@spell Gaseous Form|XPHB} spell.

A burst of arcane energy lashes out to strike the triggering creature. While potentially lethal, if the triggering creature is a spellcaster they can attempt to absorb this energy to regain spell slots. If they do, the triggering creature regains {@dice 1d10} levels worth of spell slots. If the triggering creature doesn't have spell slots or can't regain the full amount, it instead suffers 18 ({@dice 4d8}) Force damage. Any spell cast using a spell slot regained from this effect automatically triggers another arcane anomaly.

All creatures within 60 feet of the triggering creature begin to transform into plantlike versions of themselves. Their skin becomes bark, they grow leaves and buds from their flesh, and creak as they move. For the next minute, each affected creature gains the benefit of the {@spell Barkskin|XPHB} spell but becomes vulnerable to Fire damage.

An 100-foot-radius octarine storm cloud emerges 300 feet above as pouring glittering rain falls for 1 minute. The area below the cloud becomes {@variantrule heavily obscured|XPHB}. A creature who starts its turn in the area must roll a {@dice d6}, on the result of a 1 they are struck by octarine lightning. They take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) Lightning damage and must make a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of {@area Contamination|8c6|x}.

An {@spell Bigby's Hand||Arcane Hand} spell (spell save {@dc 18}, +10 to hit) appears in the area and assaults the triggering creature, trying to rip them apart, fling them from high places, or squeeze them to death.

The triggering creature is affected by {@spell Flesh to Stone|XPHB} (spell save {@dc 15}). Instead of transforming into stone, it slowly turns into solid {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystal}. If it is wholly transformed into delerium, its body is equivalent in value to a {@item geode|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium geode}. While {@condition Petrified|XPHB} in this manner, the creature is fully conscious and aware of its surroundings. If the delerium geode is used to create a magic item, the creature's personality invests the resulting item with sentience.

A {@spell Simulacrum|XPHB}, as created by the spell,of the triggering creature appears. It claims to be a traveler from the future and insists the character must slay a randomly determined ally to prevent a terrible fate. If slain, the simulacrum melts into delerium sludge instead of snow.

A glowing crystalline orb appears hovering 10 feet above. Anyone within 30 feet of the orb hears the incoherent whispering of several voices. The first creature who touches the orb can communicate with the voices as if by the {@spell Contact Other Plane|XPHB} spell. The orb then disappears.

Each creature within a 30-foot-radius immediately hallucinates their own inevitable death in such a vivid manner that they are stricken with terror and a wave of lethargic hopelessness. Each creature must make a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition Stunned|XPHB} for the next minute. A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of their turns to end the effect, shaking off the terror and returning to reality.

Reminiscent of the flames which consumed Drakkenheim in the meteor's wake, a roaring wave of eldritch fire erupts in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. Each creature in the Emanation has the {@area Burning|8e8|x} ({@dice 3d6} Fire) condition.
All the heat is suddenly pulled from one random creature within a 30-foot-radius, who becomes {@area Frozen|8f0|x} (save {@dc 15}).

Your arms and legs gain the ability to detach for the next minute and they rejoin at the end of this duration. They gain a Flying speed of 15 feet, you can control them as you normally would, they have an AC of 10 and any damage dealt to them is dealt directly to you.

The area erupts with unnatural, alien flora.
