Strange pulsing trees and octarine flowers emerge, twisting vines with pulsing octarine veins, rich plants that sparkle and hum softly, along with an abundance of various strange glowing fruit. Any creature who eats the strange fruit immediately gains the benefits of the {@spell Heroes' Feast|XPHB} spell. While under the effects of the spell, their eyes glow with octarine light, and their veins bulge and glow as well. They shed {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} in a 10-foot radius around them. The plants wither and crumble to dust after 1 hour.

The triggering creature explodes out of its skin and into a {@creature Delerium Dragon Wyrmling|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} as if under the effects of {@spell True Polymorph|XPHB}. The creature reverts to its true form after 1 hour.

The triggering creature gains the ability to see through all of time and space, gaining unbound knowledge of all that has been, and all that will be. The creature immediately takes 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Psychic damage. If this damage reduces the creature to 0 Hit Points, it is knocked {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} but is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}. For the next hour, the creature gains the benefits of the {@spell Foresight|XPHB} spell as their mind is filled with visions of all possible futures and unbound realities. At the end of the hour, the creature takes an additional 36 ({@dice 8d8}) Psychic damage as they are flung back to a basic understanding of life, the universe, and probability.

entries.name: Conditions
entries: This section details new conditions introduced in this book, augmenting the standard conditions found within the {@book Fifth Edition Core rules|XPHB|1|Conditions}.

entries.name: Addled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma attacks rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

entries.name: Bewildered
entries: You can't cast spells, except for cantrips with a casting time of 1 action.

entries.name: Bleeding [X]
entries: You're losing blood to an open wound.

items: {@b Ongoing Damage}. At the end of each of your turns, you lose Hit Points. The number of Hit Points lost is indicated by the condition, such as "Bleeding {@dice 2d4}."
{@b Regaining Hit Points}. The condition ends if you regain any Hit Points.
{@b Medical Treatment}. You or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action and use a healer's kit to staunch the bleeding (no check required), ending the condition.

entries.name: Bloodied
entries: You're wounded. A creature is Bloodied while it has half its Hit Points or fewer remaining.

entries.name: Burning [X]
entries: You're on fire or covered in acid:

items: {@b Ongoing Damage}. At the end of each of your turns, you take damage. The damage type and amount are indicated by the condition, such as "Burning ({@dice 4d6} Fire)" or "Burning ({@dice 2d4} Acid)."

{@b Ending the Condition}. The condition ends if you or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action to extinguish the flames or scrape off the acid, or if some other effect douses the flames (such as being submerged in water).

entries.name: Clumsy
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

entries.name: Contamination
entries: The Contamination condition is detailed {@area "Contamination"|8ea|x} above.

entries.name: Dazed
entries: You can move or take an action on your turn, not both. You can't take Bonus Actions.

entries.name: Defenseless
entries: Attack rolls against you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

entries.name: Distracted
entries: You can't take Reactions.

entries.name: Drakkenheim Madness
entries: A character with Drakkenheim Madness gains one of the following traits:

items: "I wish I didn't have all these useless organs inside me."
"The contamination is a blessing which will transform me into a wondrous creature."
"The monsters are civilians trying to live a peaceful life! We need to protect them!"
"I must wear a flesh-coat made from my slain enemies to gain their strength!"
"My companions died in the ruins. I'm sorry friends, you are merely ghosts haunting me, you aren't real. Stop trying to talk to other people."
"I need to eat everything I can find. It's probably going to be my last meal."
"Drakkenheim is so beautiful at night. I could spend forever wandering the streets by moonlight. We should go tonight! Let's go every night!"
"Don't you fools get it?! If you die in Drakkenheim, you die IN REAL LIFE!!!!"
"A sinister cabal of disembodied hands is plotting against me."
"I must go into the ruins and kill. Rip and tear, until it is done."

entries.name: Enfeebled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

entries.name: Frozen [DC X]
entries: You're partially encased in ice:

items: You're {@area Immobilized|8f2|x} and {@area Defenseless|8ec|x}.
You're {@area Helpless|8f1|x} against attacks made with a weapon that deals Bludgeoning damage.

You or another creature take an action to break the ice away. To do so, you must succeed on a Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the condition ends. The DC is indicated by the condition, such as Frozen ({@dc 15}).
This condition ends on you if you take 20 Bludgeoning or Fire damage.
Any attack that hits you is a Critical Hit.
Your Speed becomes 0, and you can't benefit from any bonuses to your Speed.
If you're flying when you become Immobilized, you fall.

entries.name: Jinxed [X]
entries: Roll the die indicated by the condition, such as "Jinxed {@dice 1d4}" each time you make an attack roll or saving throw. Subtract the value on the die from the result.

items: You're {@area Dazed|8eb|x} and {@area Defenseless|8ec|x}.
You drop whatever you're holding in your hands.
You must spend an action to draw, stow, or pick up an object.

entries.name: Sickened
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Constitution saving throws.

entries.name: Slowed
entries: Your Speed is halved.

entries.name: Staggered
entries: You can't make more than one weapon attack during your turn, regardless of your class features, spells, or magic items.

entries.name: Valor [X]
entries: Add a die to your attack rolls and saving throws. The die rolled is specified by the condition, such as Valor ({@dice 1d4}).

entries.name: Weakened
entries: You deal half damage with weapon attacks and spells.

data.name: Appendix D: Crafting & Harvesting
entries: This appendix presents rules player characters may use to create magic items using components harvested from defeated monsters. Here you'll find:

items: Rules for {@area Harvesting Components|905|x} from slain foes. The monster descriptions earlier in this book detail the specific monster parts player characters can harvest from each creature.
Rules and recipes for creating new magic items found in the world of Drakkenheim using parts from monsters in this book!
Descriptions for various Workshops where characters can build their items.

entries: These rules are intended to {@i replace} the typical magic item crafting found in the {@book Fifth Edition Core Rules|XDMG|6|Crafting Magic Items}. You should choose which system works best for your campaign rather than combining these rules with other magic item crafting systems.

entries.name: Crafting Overview
entries: In brief, here's how characters craft items using these rules:

items: {@area Learn the Recipe.|8ff|x} The player characters must first find the {@b Recipe} for the magic item they want to create, which identifies its properties and the {@b Components} needed. The Recipe also details the types of monsters from which the Components must be harvested. Permanent items, such as weapons and armor, require between four and ten Components, while consumables, like potions and scrolls, only need two or three.

{@area Harvest the Components.|905|x} After the player characters defeat a monster, they can spend ten minutes to {@b Harvest} and preserve {@b Components} from the corpse. This process must be completed quickly after a monster dies, otherwise the Component's innate magic fades. The Game Master describes what Components are available, and then each player character may choose to harvest one Component (regardless of how many foes were defeated). This abstractly represents how Components can be damaged in battle, ruined by harvesting, or of insufficient quality for crafting.

{@area Locate a Workshop.|913|x} Once the required Components are collected, the characters must bring them to a suitable {@b Workshop} to build the item. Workshops have a rarity that corresponds to the magic items which may be produced there. Uncommon or Rare Workshops may be found in great cities, whereas Very Rare and Legendary Workshops are only found in fantastic locations with powerful magical phenomena present, such as magma forges deep in the heart of the earth and arcane laboratories constructed along extraplanar rifts.
{@area Construct the Item.|921|x} The characters spend one day working at the Workshop to combine the Components, and their new magic item is complete!

entries.name: Component and Workshop Rarity
entries: Components and Workshops have a rarity, which correspond to the rarity of the magic item made with them. For example, an Uncommon magic item typically calls for Uncommon Components and must be created at an Uncommon workshop. This rarity also provides a rough gauge for what level characters should be able to craft the item.
The rarity of harvested Components are based on the monster's Challenge Rating. Unless otherwise specified, a component's rarity is defined by the Component Rarity table.

The rarity of the Components and workshop used in crafting always determine the highest rarity item they can produce. You can use higher rarity Components and Workshops to produce lower rarity items. For example, if a recipe calls for an Uncommon part, such as monster blood, a character may substitute Rare monster blood to fill the requirements of the Recipe.

entries.name: How Often Do Characters Craft an Item?
entries: Assuming that the player characters face about 4 to 8 combat encounters per character level against non-humanoid foes over the course of an entire campaign, each player character can craft the following quantities of permanent magic items:

items: 3–4 Uncommon
2–3 Rare
1–2 Very Rare
1 Legendary

entries: These numbers are approximate but are provided to offer a baseline set of expectations which you can adjust accordingly based on how many magic items you wish your player characters to possess. Characters may craft many more Common magic items, as well as many consumable magic items (potions and scrolls) of all rarities.

We recommend adjusting the amount of treasure found in your campaign when you use these rules. Characters should find about half as many magic items as they normally would, since they'll be crafting their own instead.

entries.name: This is Not an Economic System!
entries: Our objective for these rules was to offer player characters a way to create magic items for their use during adventures. Crafting flows from the adventure's narrative, with every magic item having an evocative tale with its creation. While this system can handle characters occasionally selling items, its not suited for those looking to run a business "farming" monsters for Components, building items, and selling them for profit. Similarly, these rules should {@i not} be extrapolated into a setting's functional economy. This system is about functional gameplay that tells a rewarding story, not creating a realistic simulation.

We recommend discussing these rules during Session Zero before using them at your table. We felt that the fun of this system would be spoiled with restrictions to prevent economic abuse. We didn't want an overly analytical approach to get in the way of fun. Frankly, no rules-based safeguards are as effective as setting the expectations at the start of a campaign for how these rules may be used.

For those looking for narrative justification, the Edicts of Lumen limit magic item creation and sale to the Amethyst Academy, and the mages strictly control this trade. Nevertheless, NPCs may discuss using Components, the need for appropriate facilities, and share recipes with the player characters. Indeed, the Amethyst Academy {@i does} pay adventurers to collect Components for them. However, proficient adventurers, capable craftspeople, and suitable monsters, especially higher-level ones, are relatively scarce. The player characters are amongst the few who are in a position to craft magic items using the rules presented here.

entries.name: Step 1: Learning Recipes
entries: Every magic item has a {@b Recipe} which lists the monster parts required to craft the item and the type of workshop used to construct it.
Most items require between three and ten parts to create. For example, a {@item +1 Weapon|XDMG} must be created at an {@b Uncommon Workshop} and requires the following {@b Uncommon Components}:

items: [Animus] Any Animus.
[Bones] Any Bones.
[Natural Weapon] Any Natural Weapon.
[Hide] Any Hide.

entries: Recipes vary from item to item, but most call for monster parts from at least two or three different creatures or sources.
Characters can learn Recipes in three main ways: {@area Finding Schematics|900|x}, {@area Purchasing Schematics|901|x}, or through {@area Research|902|x}.

entries.name: Finding Schematics
entries: Most often, characters learn how to craft a particular magic item by finding a {@b Schematic}. These documents reveal the rarity, type, and full properties for a crafted magic item, as well as all Components needed to create it. A Schematic may be found as treasure placed by the Game Master or given as a reward for completing a quest.

A Schematic takes the form of written or illustrated plans, such as a diagram on parchment, an instruction manual, or inscriptions upon ancient ruins. A master craftsperson might be able to teach the player characters how to make an Uncommon or Rare magic item, whereas Schematics for Very Rare and Legendary items may be knowledge gleaned from the whispers of an otherworldly entity, ancient archmage, or powerful dragon.

Learning Components from a Schematic is an ideal method to kick off a "scavenger hunt" side-quest for the player characters. Plans in hand, they know what they need to get, but it's up to them to locate the monsters and Components needed. Schematics encourage the characters to keep a careful eye out for rare or interesting creatures, and perhaps search a little more thoroughly through the deep dungeons and dark streets of Drakkenheim for a rare prize.
I like the recipes with pictures and arrows so I can get right down to business.

entries.name: Purchasing Schematics
entries: Occasionally, player characters may have the opportunity to purchase a Schematic. The Schematic Pricing table below details suggested prices based on the rarity of the finished item:

entries.name: Research
entries: During their adventures, player characters may gather all manner of curious Components, but they may not know exactly what magic items can be created from these collected materials. In such cases, the player characters may study the found parts to discover possible Recipes on their own. This method allows the player characters to discover a magic item Recipe piecemeal, and creates the feeling the characters are inventing or discovering something new.

During a Long Rest, a character can examine a number of Components equal to their Intelligence modifier (minimum one Component). Once they finish a Long Rest, the character learns the Recipe for one magic item the studied Component can be used to create. Since some monster Components can be used to create a variety of different items, an individual Component can be studied multiple times.

entries.name: Instant Discovery
entries: If the player characters have collected all the monster parts needed to craft an item, but haven't yet learned the Recipe, they discover the full Recipe once they research any one of the required parts. Seeing all the parts together is enough for a flash of inspiration!

entries.name: Tool Proficiency

entries.name: Step 2: Harvesting Components
entries: Characters may harvest and preserve Components from the corpse of a slain creature using monster harvesting tools.

Harvesting monster components or extracting its animus must begin within ten minutes of its death. After this time, the magical energy within fades and the animus passes to the ether, and any remaining Components are no longer usable for creating magic items.

No ability checks are required to successfully harvest monsters or extract an animus. As long as a character has the time and tools, they always successfully collect one monster Component from a creature's corpse. The toolkit provides everything a character needs to extract and preserve parts from any creature.

items: {@item Monster Harvesting Tools (50 GP).|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} The toolkit provides everything characters need to extract animus and preserve any creature parts. This kit contains skinning knives, a cleaver, syringes, a hammer, scissors, scalpels, a bone saw, hooks, as well as a vials, watertight containers, binding reagents, and wrappings.

entries.name: Monster Components
entries: When the characters decide to harvest a monster's corpse, the Game Master determines which Components can be harvested from a monster, if any. In this book, each monster entry lists the Components available from that creature.

entries.name: Component Rarity
entries: The rarity of all parts are determined by the CR of the monster as presented by the {@area table|907|x} earlier in this chapter.

Most item recipes call for Components with the same rarity as the item itself. However, some recipes may call for a component from a specific named monster, such as a {@creature Frost Giant|XMM}, an {@creature Ancient Red Dragon|XMM}, or a {@creature Banshee|XMM}. In such cases, if no part of the presented rarity is available for a monster of that type, the DM should allow a component of a lower rarity to be used. For example, the {@item Ghost Sight Bow|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} is a Very Rare item that requires the bones of a {@creature Dryad|XMM} and the hair of a {@b Banshee}. In this case, these components require you to find any Dryad or Banshee and do not require the parts to be Very Rare.

entries.name: Component Categories
entries: Each Component belongs to one of the following categories:

items: {@b Animus}. This special Component is described {@area below|909|x}.
{@b Bones}. This includes the skull, spine, or the stem of a plant monster.
{@b Dust}. Detritus left behind by magical creatures or undead.
{@b Fluid}. Usually monster blood, and also ectoplasm, sap, or mucus.
{@b Hair}. Any fur or feathers.
{@b Hide}. Includes the monster's skin, scales, carapace, bark, or plates.
{@b Natural Weapons}. Almost any natural weapon from the monster's game statistics, such as teeth, claws, horns, tentacles, etc.
{@b Organs}. A broad category including both internal body parts and sensory organs, such as the heart, brain, glands, eyes, or guts.

entries.name: Magical Animus
entries: In the world of Drakkenheim, magic items are created by imbuing a physical object with a metaphysical animus. This vital energy must be properly extracted from a magical creature. A creature's animus is formed from the latent magical energy held within its body, but it is distinct from a creature's soul. Aberrations, Celestials, Constructs, Dragons, Elementals, Fey, Fiends, Giants, Monstrosities, Plants, Oozes, and Undead all possess a magical animus. Beasts and Humanoids typically do {@i not} possess an animus.

When a creature is slain, its animus lingers momentarily before fading into the ether. However, a creature's animus can be collected and contained within a vessel of some kind, which is then used to make a magical item. It is impossible to extract the animus of a creature without killing it.

Creating magic items requires the animus of one or more suitably powerful creatures. However, some magic items may call for a specific type of animus, such as the animus of a fey creature or dragon. In rare cases, a magic item may require the animus of a much more specific monster.

entries.name: Animus Vessels
entries: An animus must be collected and stored in a specially prepared magical {@b vessel}. Traditionally, these vessels were minor magic items in their own right: often rune-etched gemstones infused with magic and created in a laborious process. However, the world of Drakkenheim was transformed by the arrival of delerium: the eldritch crystals function as suitable vessels in their raw state. A {@item crystal|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|delerium crystal} filled with magical animus glows with a brilliant octarine light, similar to how the crystals resonate with energy when exposed to magic.

entries.name: Creating Animus Vessels
entries: An animus vessel can be created in 1 hour by combining any three other components of the same rarity. The resulting vessel can then be used as a vessel for an animus of the corresponding rarity. For example, an animus made from three Rare components can hold a Rare animus.

entries.name: Harvest and Extraction Time
entries: Once started, collecting Components or animus takes ten minutes of work. During this time, the character must remain within 5 feet of the corpse. If the process is interrupted, harvesting must resume within ten minutes, or the Components are lost. A player character may only harvest Components from one creature at a time, regardless of its size. Several characters can work together to harvest multiple parts from the same corpse. No matter how many characters harvest a single corpse, they must all spend ten minutes harvesting.

entries.name: Collector's Choice
entries: Each character may harvest one component from a creature's corpse per encounter.

Characters can work together to harvest several different parts from one monster, or they may split up and harvest parts from several creatures at once. A monster's body usually provides only one of each available part, so two characters harvesting parts from the same corpse must choose to collect different parts, unless the Game Master determines that the creature's unique physiology allows the collection of multiples of the same part. For example, a Game Master might allow both horns from a Minotaur to be harvested, but it would take the work of two characters to collect both. Other parts may be more abstract in quantity: it's enough to know that the characters collected a bag of dragon fangs or a vial of troll blood without worrying about a specific measurement.

When the player characters decide to butcher a carcass for Components, the Game Master lists all the possible Components available from the body. Each character may then choose one Component to collect. All other Components are lost and unusable, either because they were damaged in battle, ruined in the harvesting process, or deemed of unsuitable quality for magic item crafting.
Gently slide your knife along the spine,or as close to what could be considered a spine, the primary spine.

entries.name: Example Harvesting
entries: For example, suppose the player characters defeat a {@creature Gorgon|XMM}. They decide to harvest parts from its corpse. The Game Master describes that the Gorgon has the following Rare Components: eyes (organ), a skull (bones), monster blood (fluid), plates (hide), horns (natural weapon), glands (organs), and its animus. There are three player characters, and all work together to harvest parts from the Gorgon. Sebastian decides to collect the Gorgon's Animus, Pluto decides to take the Gorgon's plates, and Veo decides to take the Gorgon's monster blood. All the other parts are lost.

In another case, suppose four player characters defeat a small horde of ten {@creature Ratling Warriors|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}. The party would only be able to collect parts from four of them. The parts from the other monsters are lost.

entries.name: Keeping Records
entries: When recording what monster parts the player characters have collected, it's important to identify the Component's name category, as well as the name, creature type, and rarity of the creature. For example, a character might record the following Components:

items: Minotaur, horns (natural weapon). Uncommon Monstrosity.
Vampire, undead dust (dust). Rare Undead.
Troll, skin (hide). Uncommon Giant.
Adult Red Dragon, monster blood (fluid). Legendary Dragon.

entries: Recording how many bones characters collect from a slain red dragon, or how many vials of blood characters drain from the corpse of a dead troll, isn't necessary. Regardless of a creature's actual size or dimensions, a character harvests enough material from its corpse to fulfill the ingredients required for a single magic item. Simply recording "Red Dragon monster blood" or "Troll hide" is sufficient. If characters collect the blood or hide from multiple dragons or trolls, simply record "3x Red Dragon blood" or "3x Troll's hide."

entries.name: Component Weight
entries: In general, most Components weigh no more than 1 pound each. When tracking the weight of individual Components, consider the final weight of the constructed item it will be used to create. Most weapons, wondrous items, and consumables weigh between 1 and 5 pounds, so most Components should fall within this range. The Game Master may determine that certain Components intended for use in medium or heavy armor (or other bulky items) weigh substantially more. For example, dragon scales or gorgon plates collected for use in scale or plate armor could weigh as much as 50 pounds.

entries.name: Why Only One Item?
entries: These rules intentionally abstract monster harvesting. Instead of rolling to determine whether or not they harvest parts, or how many parts are harvested, it is simply one part per character per harvest. This prevents the player characters from finding more monster parts than expected (and thus being able to craft more magic items than intended). Similarly, this restriction minimizes the amount of required bookkeeping. Even taking one monster part per character will result in the characters holding on to a lot of crafting materials, and we wanted to avoid clogging up their inventories with hundreds of items they won't ever use.

entries.name: Buying and Selling Components
entries: Talented arcanists, artificers, and forgesmiths alike frequently eschew the adventuring life, preferring to commission adventurers to procure rare Components for magic item crafting on their behalf.
Buying and selling Components is an optional downtime activity characters can engage in between their adventures.

Most often, those purchasing Components are looking for a specific Component or two, and seek the services of dedicated monster hunters to retrieve their materials. Even the industrious Amethyst Academy rarely makes an unsolicited purchase, and the mages are seldom willing to purchase anything presented to them.
Typically, finding a seller or buyer for a monster Component takes a number of days equal to the Challenge Rating of the monster.
Additionally, some creature types are more difficult to find than others, resulting in an increase in component prices as follows:

entries.name: Step 3: Find a Workshop
entries: Crafting magical items also requires a suitably equipped Workshop to create the item, such as a blacksmith's forge, arcane laboratory, or artisan's studio. While a typical blacksmith's forge is fine for making steel, it is ill-suited to working with dragonbone, demonic animus, troll's blood, and elemental earth!

In addition to providing all the tools and equipment necessary, a Workshop also supplies all mundane materials needed for crafting magic items. A forge has an ample supply of coal, iron, and steel, for example, whereas an arcane laboratory or artisan studio has paper, inks, chemicals, and other materials characters would logically need to supplement the monster Components.

entries.name: Workshop Rarity
entries: Like monster parts, each Workshop has a rarity from Common to Legendary. The Workshop's rarity corresponds to the maximum rarity of the magic items which may be created working there. Creating a Rare magic item requires a Rare Workshop, but a Legendary Workshop could be used to fashion an Uncommon magic item, for example.

entries.name: Common Workshops
entries: These Workshops are made for fashioning everyday mundane equipment, and usually lack the specialized and magical tools needed for making magic items. However, they're usually sufficient for making Common magic items, or consumables such as potions and scrolls.

entries.name: Uncommon Workshops
entries: Characters can find Uncommon Workshops in towns and larger settlements. Examples include the finest blacksmith's forge in the region, or a typical wizard's tower.

entries.name: Crowe and Sons Smithy
entries: In Emberwood Village, just outside the city of Drakkenheim sits the Crowe and Sons Smithy. Tobias Crowe is a humble family man who has worked the forge his whole life. His forge is well stocked with all the mundane gear someone would need to craft basic items, and Tobias himself has worked magical gear in the forge as long as he has the right supplies. He is always willing to let adventurers who show they know what they are doing handle the forge, and often aids them in the crafting of unique magic items.

The forge sits under a wooden overhang connected to an old shop. The wall is lined with tools and fitted with a table and shelves containing iron, wood, sacks of coal, brass, copper, leather straps and much more. The old stone forge has a large bellow that you can operate by foot and a rustic and worn anvil next to a metal bucket of cool water.

entries.name: Rare Workshops
entries: Rare Workshops are usually only found in large cities. These impressive facilities are equipped with state-of-the art tools and machinery, and able to import the finest raw materials from around the world.

entries.name: Smithy on the Scar
entries: The Smithy on the Scar was an old blacksmith shop taken over by a group of Ironhelm dwarves. They have refitted the forge to work delerium, meteoric iron, and gunpowder. They have all the tools needed for crafting fine magic items, gunpowder weapons, and some of the best dwarven inventions in the area. With a constant supply of delerium arriving, a group looking to use the forge need only do a seemingly simple task: help the Ironhelm dwarves and guard their forge through the night while they mine the delerium in the scar. Do this, and they will happily allow you to access their gear and make any weapons you need.

entries.name: Apothecary Laboratory
entries: Beneath Altbruke University is a labyrinthian series of corridors, tunnels, and workshops. Amongst them is a great Laboratory complete with a forge, alchemical gear, and a well-stocked storage of every rare element the school could get their hands on. It is better equipped for the crafting of unique potions, poisons, and tonics, but can also be used to craft unique magical items of exquisite design. The abundance of iron, leather, and steel the school has at its disposal means that if one can gain access to this forge, they will be well equipped to do any crafting needed. However, getting the apothecaries of Altbruke University to grant permission is another story.

entries.name: Very Rare Workshops
entries: Very Rare Workshops are built with access to a notable power source used to channel the great heat or mighty arcane forces needed to work with rare and valuable materials. Examples could include an adamantine forge located along a magma flow, or an arcane university channeling the energy of a Thin Place.

entries.name: Inscrutable Tower Laboratories
entries: In the lower chambers of the Inscrutable Tower lies the great Arcane Forge. The Tower is a conduit of sorts that draws in raw arcane energies and focuses them within the tower's nexus. Although the nexus powers many arcane devices throughout the tower, and used as a prime focus for magical practices throughout, the Arcane Forge also draws from this well of power when being used to craft exceptionally rare and powerful magical artifacts. Many of the Academy's most renowned artificers worked in the Arcane Forge. Even in the destruction of Drakkenheim, the forge remains well stocked with the gear needed to draw immense arcane power for forging items. The only issue is that the nexus is not fully operational and the tower needs to be brought back online to use the forge again.

entries.name: Dwarven Volcano Forge
entries: High in the Drakeclaw Mountains is the great Dragon's Maw, a sleeping volcano that was once home to the Firebrand dwarves, who built their great city in the heart of the caldera of the volcano, and harnessed the magma flows into a powerful dwarven forge. Fire elementals once worked the forge and crafted some of the finest dwarven weapons in history. The forge still sits amongst the ruins of this great dwarven empire and is completely operational. However, the {@creature ancient red dragon|XMM} Volmongoth claimed the caldera centuries ago as their lair, and access to the forge has been near impossible since then. One would either need to treat with Volmongoth for access or defeat them in battle. Neither seems likely.

entries.name: Legendary Workshops
entries: A Legendary Workshop is a one-of-a-kind place built in special locations due to the magical phenomena present. Indeed, these storied places are seldom found in the Mortal World at all and may require travel to other dimensions or worlds.

entries.name: Space Between Worlds Star Forge
entries: Deep within the Space Between Worlds, on a floating pile of rubble within the Void Sea, sits the Star Forge. There is no record of who built the Star Forge, or what its intention was. Perhaps just a strange random happenstance amongst the chaotic possibilities, or maybe a chunk of rock drawn in from some distant dimension, the Star Forge can harness the very fabric of arcane magic from the roiling cosmos of the Space Between Worlds and channel that into the gear made within it. For those seeking to harness unimaginable power into their creations, journeying into the Space Between Worlds and seeking out this forge is one of the few known paths to creating such potent items. Getting there is nearly impossible, and is only half the problem, for firing up the forge draws the attention of all number of eldritch beings, who feed on the raw arcana that flow into the forge. One must survive the onslaught long enough to finish their gear, and then escape with it.

entries.name: Workshop Quests
entries: Locating a suitable Workshop can be a quest all on its own. However, a Game Master may wish to add an additional complication or problem:

items: The Workshop's power source has been damaged or stolen, and the characters must retrieve a replacement and conduct necessary repairs.

The Workshop has run out of raw materials or fuel. For example, a dwarven forge relied on a nearby iron mine which has been overrun by monsters, or bandits raided the supply caravans supplying alchemical materials for an apothecaries' lab. The characters must recover the Components or deal with the issue before the Workshop can be used.
The Workshop is owned or run by a powerful individual or faction who will not allow the characters to use it until they complete a mission to prove their worthiness or demonstrate their capabilities.

entries.name: Step 4: Craft the Item
entries: Once the characters have collected their items, learned the Recipe, and brought all Components to a suitable Workshop, it's time to make the item!

Creating the item only requires a few hours of diligent work. Set the pace appropriate for the campaign and the part of the narrative: it's fine for the characters to spend an hour making the item, or a day. An extended period of downtime isn't necessary: this system makes the characters take an active role collecting the Components, Schematics, and crafting Workshop rather than downtime and gold.

entries.name: Interlopers!
entries: At your option, characters crafting a Legendary magic item may have to do battle against invaders seeking to stop them in the process! This can make for a fun and climatic end to an adventure arc.
Doing so is a simple skill challenge: completing the magic item requires the characters spend a number of actions to finish the item.
Each round, magical invaders, such as elementals, outsiders, demons, or spirits, appear to try to stop the characters completing the item. They won't relent until the item is finished.

entries.name: Thank You
entries: This book was made possible by the incredible support of a passionate and creative team. We, Monty Martin and Kelly McLaughlin of {@i The Dungeon Dudes}, extend our deepest gratitude to the entire Ghostfire Gaming team—editors, designers, artists, and many others—who brought this project to life.

A special thanks to our fellow Dungeon Dudes, players, and best friends, Jill Danaitis and Joe O'Gorman, whose contributions to our world and lore enrich every game we play. Joe, in particular, was instrumental in this book's creation as the original Pluto Jackson, providing all the quotes and the introductory letter within. We also want to acknowledge Kyle Drier, whose tireless work behind the scenes keeps us organized and on schedule, and our amazing brand manager, Bettie Rage, whose dedication and guidance ensured consistency and focus during crucial moments of this project.

Bringing to life the vast array of monsters in this book and pushing the boundaries of combat design with new conditions and epic bosses was no small task. We couldn't have done it without the invaluable playtesting and feedback from our community and backers. A heartfelt thanks to our incredible Alpha Team—Benjamin Burt, Bill Goldschmidt, Brooke Rader, Corline Hazenoot, and Samuel Cavender—for their dedication to refining and strengthening this project. To every backer who took the time to share thoughtful and honest feedback, and to our amazing viewers and Patreon supporters who have allowed us to come as far as we have as creators, we are truly grateful.

Lastly, to our loving partners, Kierston Drier and Shay Bytheway—your endless love, encouragement, and patience through the many late nights of writing and development did not go unnoticed. We are so thankful for your unwavering support.
Kelly McLaughlin & Monty Martin The Dungeon Dudes
